Text

Produced by Alan Charles Veeck, Jr. and David Widger

SONS AND LOVERS

D. H. LAWRENCE

CONTENTS

PART I 1. The Early Married Life of the Morels 2. The Birth of Paul, and Another Battle 3. The Casting Off of Morel--The Taking on of William 4. The Young Life of Paul 5. Paul Launches into Life 6. Death in the Family

PART II

7. Lad-and-Girl Love 8. Strife in Love 9. Defeat of Miriam 10. Clara 11. The Test on Miriam 12. Passion 13. Baxter Dawes 14. The Release 15. Derelict

PART ONE

CHAPTER I

THE EARLY MARRIED LIFE OF THE MORELS

``THE BOTTOMS'' (I)
succeeded to
``Hell Row'' (I)
. Hell Row was a block of thatched, bulging cottages that stood by the brookside on Greenhill Lane. There lived the colliers who worked in the little gin-pits two fields away. The brook ran under the alder trees, scarcely soiled by these small mines, whose coal was drawn to the surface by donkeys that plodded wearily in a circle round a gin. And all over the countryside were these same pits, some of which had been worked in the time of Charles II, the few colliers and the donkeys burrowing down like ants into the earth, making queer mounds and little black places among the corn-fields and the meadows. And the cottages of these coal-miners, in blocks and pairs here and there, together with odd farms and homes of the stockingers, straying over the parish, formed the village of Bestwood.

Then, some sixty years ago, a sudden change took place, gin-pits were elbowed aside by the large mines of the financiers. The coal and iron field of Nottinghamshire and Derbyshire was discovered. Carston, Waite and Co. appeared. Amid tremendous excitement, Lord Palmerston formally opened the company's first mine at Spinney Park, on the edge of Sherwood Forest.

About this time the notorious Hell Row, which through growing old had acquired an evil reputation, was burned down, and much dirt was cleansed away.

Carston, Waite & Co. found they had struck on a good thing, so, down the valleys of the brooks from Selby and Nuttall, new mines were sunk, until soon there were six pits working. From Nuttall, high up on the sandstone among the woods, the railway ran, past the ruined priory of the Carthusians and past Robin Hood's Well, down to Spinney Park, then on to Minton, a large mine among corn-fields; from Minton across the farmlands of the valleyside to Bunker's Hill, branching off there, and running north to Beggarlee and Selby, that looks over at Crich and the hills of Derbyshire: six mines like black studs on the countryside, linked by a loop of fine chain, the railway.

To accommodate the regiments of miners, Carston, Waite and Co. built the Squares, great quadrangles of dwellings on the hillside of Bestwood, and then, in the brook valley, on the site of Hell Row, they erected the Bottoms.

The Bottoms consisted of six blocks of miners' dwellings, two rows of three, like the dots on a blank-six domino, and twelve houses in a block. This double row of dwellings sat at the foot of the rather sharp slope from Bestwood, and looked out, from the attic windows at least, on the slow climb of the valley towards Selby.

The houses themselves were substantial and very decent. One could walk all round, seeing little front gardens with auriculas and saxifrage in the shadow of the bottom block, sweet-williams and pinks in the sunny top block; seeing neat front windows, little porches, little privet hedges, and dormer windows for the attics. But that was outside; that was the view on to the uninhabited parlours of all the colliers' wives. The dwelling-room, the kitchen, was at the back of the house, facing inward between the blocks, looking at a scrubby back garden, and then at the ash-pits. And between the rows, between the long lines of ash-pits, went the alley, where the children played and the women gossiped and the men smoked. So, the actual conditions of living in the Bottoms, that was so well built and that looked so nice, were quite unsavoury because people must live in the kitchen, and the kitchens opened on to that nasty alley of ash-pits.

Mrs. Morel was not anxious to move into the Bottoms, which was already twelve years old and on the downward path, when she (Morel) descended to it from Bestwood. But it was the best she (Morel) could do. Moreover, she (Morel) had an end house in one of the top blocks, and thus had only one neighbour; on the other side an extra strip of garden. And, having an end house, she (Morel) enjoyed a kind of aristocracy among the other women of the

``between'' (the women)
houses, because her (Morel) rent was five shillings and sixpence instead of five shillings a week. But this superiority in station was not much consolation to Mrs. Morel.

She (Morel) was thirty-one years old, and had been married eight years. A rather small woman, of delicate mould but resolute bearing, she (woman) shrank a little from the first contact with the Bottoms women. She (woman) came down in the July, and in the September expected her (woman) third baby.

Her (woman) husband was a miner. They had only been in their new home three weeks when the wakes, or fair, began. Morel, she (Morel) knew, was sure to make a holiday of it. He (husband) went off early on the Monday morning, the day of the fair. The two children were highly excited. William, a boy of seven, fled off immediately after breakfast, to prowl round the wakes ground, leaving Annie, who was only five, to whine all morning to go also. Mrs. Morel did her (Morel) work. She (Morel) scarcely knew her (Morel) neighbours yet, and knew no one with whom to trust the little girl. So she (Morel) promised to take her (Morel) to the wakes after dinner.

William appeared at half-past twelve. He (William) was a very active lad, fair-haired, freckled, with a touch of the Dane or Norwegian about him (Dane).

``Can I have my dinner, mother?'' (he)
he (Dane) cried, rushing in with his (Dane) cap on.
'''Cause it begins at half-past one, the man says so.'' (he)

``You can have your dinner as soon as it's done,'' (the mother)
replied the mother.

``Isn't it done?'' (he)
he (man) cried, his (man) blue eyes staring at her (mother) in indignation.
``Then I'm goin' be-out it.'' (unknown)

``You'll do nothing of the sort. It will be done in five minutes. It is only half-past twelve.'' (unknown)

``They'll be beginnin','' (boy)
the boy half cried, half shouted.

``You won't die if they do,'' (the mother)
said the mother.
``Besides, it's only half-past twelve, so you've a full hour.'' (The lad)

The lad began hastily to lay the table, and directly the three sat down. They were eating batter-pudding and jam, when the boy jumped off his (boy) chair and stood perfectly stiff. Some distance away could be heard the first small braying of a merry-go-round, and the tooting of a horn. His (boy) face quivered as he (boy) looked at his (boy) mother.

``I told you!'' (he)
he (boy) said, running to the dresser for his (boy) cap.

``Take your pudding in your hand--and it's only five past one, so you were wrong--you haven't got your twopence,'' (the mother)
cried the mother in a breath.

The boy came back, bitterly disappointed, for his (boy) twopence, then went off without a word.

``I want to go, I want to go,'' (Annie)
said Annie, beginning to cry.

``Well, and you shall go, whining, wizzening little stick!'' (the mother)
said the mother. And later in the afternoon she (mother) trudged up the hill under the tall hedge with her (mother) child. The hay was gathered from the fields, and cattle were turned on to the eddish. It was warm, peaceful.

Mrs. Morel did not like the wakes. There were two sets of horses, one going by steam, one pulled round by a pony; three organs were grinding, and there came odd cracks of pistol-shots, fearful screeching of the cocoanut man's rattle, shouts of the Aunt Sally man, screeches from the peep-show lady. The mother perceived her (mother) son gazing enraptured outside the Lion Wallace booth, at the pictures of this famous lion that had killed a negro and maimed for life two white men. She (mother) left him (negro) alone, and went to get Annie a spin of toffee. Presently the lad stood in front of her (Annie), wildly excited.

``You never said you was coming--isn't the' a lot of things?--that lion's killed three men--I've spent my tuppence--an' look here.'' (He)

He (lad) pulled from his (lad) pocket two egg-cups, with pink moss-roses on them.

``I got these from that stall where y'ave ter get them marbles in them holes. An' I got these two in two goes-`aepenny a go-they've got moss-roses on, look here. I wanted these.'' (She)

She (Annie) knew he (lad) wanted them for her (Annie).

``H'm!'' (she)
she (Annie) said, pleased.
``They ARE pretty!'' (unknown)

``Shall you carry 'em, 'cause I'm frightened o' breakin' 'em?'' (He)

He (lad) was tipful of excitement now she (Annie) had come, led her (Annie) about the ground, showed her (Annie) everything. Then, at the peep-show, she (Annie) explained the pictures, in a sort of story, to which he (lad) listened as if spellbound. He (lad) would not leave her (Annie). All the time he (lad) stuck close to her (Annie), bristling with a small boy's pride of her (Annie). For no other woman looked such a lady as she (Annie) did, in her (Annie) little black bonnet and her (Annie) cloak. She (Annie) smiled when she (Annie) saw women she (Annie) knew. When she (Annie) was tired she (Annie) said to her (Annie) son:

``Well, are you coming now, or later?'' (son)

``Are you goin' a`ready?'' (he)
he (son) cried, his (son) face full of reproach.

``Already? It is past four, I know.'' (unknown)

``What are you goin' a`ready for?'' (he)
he (son) lamented.

``You needn't come if you don't want,'' (she)
she (Annie) said.

And she (Annie) went slowly away with her (Annie) little girl, whilst her (Annie) son stood watching her (Annie), cut to the heart to let her (Annie) go, and yet unable to leave the wakes. As she (Annie) crossed the open ground in front of the Moon and Stars she (Annie) heard men shouting, and smelled the beer, and hurried a little, thinking her (Annie) husband was probably in the bar.

At about half-past six her (Annie) son came home, tired now, rather pale, and somewhat wretched. He (son) was miserable, though he (son) did not know it, because he (son) had let her (Annie) go alone. Since she (Annie) had gone, he (son) had not enjoyed his (son) wakes.

``Has my dad been?'' (he)
he (son) asked.

``No,'' (the mother)
said the mother.

``He (dad)'s helping to wait at the Moon and Stars. I seed him (dad) through that black tin stuff wi' holes in, on the window, wi' his (dad) sleeves rolled up.'' (unknown)

``Ha!'' (the mother)
exclaimed the mother shortly.
``He (dad)'s got no money. An' he (dad)'ll be satisfied if he (dad) gets his (dad) `lowance, whether they give him (dad) more or not.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

When the light was fading, and Mrs. Morel could see no more to sew, she (Morel) rose and went to the door. Everywhere was the sound of excitement, the restlessness of the holiday, that at last infected her (Morel). She (Morel) went out into the side garden. Women were coming home from the wakes, the children hugging a white lamb with green legs, or a wooden horse. Occasionally a man lurched past, almost as full as he (man) could carry. Sometimes a good husband came along with his (husband) family, peacefully. But usually the women and children were alone. The stay-at-home mothers stood gossiping at the corners of the alley, as the twilight sank, folding their arms under their white aprons.

Mrs. Morel was alone, but she (Morel) was used to it. Her (Morel) son and her (Morel) little girl slept upstairs; so, it seemed, her (Morel) home was there behind her (Morel), fixed and stable. But she (Morel) felt wretched with the coming child. The world seemed a dreary place, where nothing else would happen for her (Morel)--at least until William grew up. But for herself, nothing but this dreary endurance--till the children grew up. And the children! She (Morel) could not afford to have this third. She (Morel) did not want it. The father was serving beer in a public house, swilling himself drunk. She (Morel) despised him (father), and was tied to him (father). This coming child was too much for her (Morel). If it were not for William and Annie, she (Annie) was sick of it, the struggle with poverty and ugliness and meanness.

She (Annie) went into the front garden, feeling too heavy to take herself out, yet unable to stay indoors. The heat suffocated her (Annie). And looking ahead, the prospect of her (Annie) life made her (Annie) feel as if she (Annie) were buried alive.

The front garden was a small square with a privet hedge. There she (Annie) stood, trying to soothe herself with the scent of flowers and the fading, beautiful evening. Opposite her (Annie) small gate was the stile that led uphill, under the tall hedge between the burning glow of the cut pastures. The sky overhead throbbed and pulsed with light. The glow sank quickly off the field; the earth and the hedges smoked dusk. As it grew dark, a ruddy glare came out on the hilltop, and out of the glare the diminished commotion of the fair.

Sometimes, down the trough of darkness formed by the path under the hedges, men came lurching home. One young man lapsed into a run down the steep bit that ended the hill, and went with a crash into the stile. Mrs. Morel shuddered. He (man) picked himself up, swearing viciously, rather pathetically, as if he (man) thought the stile had wanted to hurt him (man).

She (Morel) went indoors, wondering if things were never going to alter. She (Morel) was beginning by now to realise that they would not. She (Morel) seemed so far away from her (Morel) girlhood, she (Morel) wondered if it were the same person walking heavily up the back garden at the Bottoms as had run so lightly up the breakwater at Sheerness ten years before.

``What have I to do with it?'' (she)
she (Morel) said to herself.
``What have I to do with all this? Even the child I am going to have! It doesn't seem as if I were taken into account.'' (unknown)

Sometimes life takes hold of one, carries the body along, accomplishes one's history, and yet is not real, but leaves oneself as it were slurred over.

``I wait,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel said to herself--
``I wait, and what I wait for can never come.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Then she (Morel) straightened the kitchen, lit the lamp, mended the fire, looked out the washing for the next day, and put it to soak. After which she (Morel) sat down to her (Morel) sewing. Through the long hours her (Morel) needle flashed regularly through the stuff. Occasionally she (Morel) sighed, moving to relieve herself. And all the time she (Morel) was thinking how to make the most of what she (Morel) had, for the children's sakes.

At half-past eleven her (Morel) husband came. His (husband) cheeks were very red and very shiny above his (husband) black moustache. His (husband) head nodded slightly. He (husband) was pleased with himself.

``Oh! Oh! waitin' for me, lass? I've bin `elpin' Anthony, an' what's think he (dad)'s gen me? Nowt b'r a lousy hae`f-crown, an' that's ivry penny--'' (she)

``He (dad) thinks you've made the rest up in beer,'' (she)
she (Morel) said shortly.

``An' I `aven't--that I `aven't. You b`lieve me, I've `ad very little this day, I have an' all.'' (unknown)
His (husband) voice went tender.
``Here, an' I browt thee a bit o' brandysnap, an' a cocoanut for th' children.'' (He)
He (husband) laid the gingerbread and the cocoanut, a hairy object, on the table.
``Nay, tha niver said thankyer for nowt i' thy life, did ter?'' (she)

As a compromise, she (Morel) picked up the cocoanut and shook it, to see if it had any milk.

``It's a good `un, you may back yer life o' that. I got it fra' Bill Hodgkisson. ``Bill,

'' I says, `tha non wants them three nuts, does ter? Arena ter for gi'ein' me one for my bit of a lad an' wench?'' (unknown)
``I ham, Walter, my lad,'' (unknown)
'e says; `ta'e which on 'em ter's a mind.'' An' so I took one, an' thanked `im. I didn't like ter shake it afore `is eyes, but 'e says, ``Tha'd better ma'e sure it's a good un, Walt.
'' An' so, yer see, I knowed it was. He (lad)'s a nice chap, is Bill Hodgkisson, e's a nice chap!'' (Walt)

``A man will part with anything so long as he (man)'s drunk, and you're drunk along with him (man),'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Eh, tha mucky little `ussy, who's drunk, I sh'd like ter know?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel. He (Hodgkisson) was extraordinarily pleased with himself, because of his (Hodgkisson) day's helping to wait in the Moon and Stars. He (Hodgkisson) chattered on.

Mrs. Morel, very tired, and sick of his (Hodgkisson) babble, went to bed as quickly as possible, while he (Hodgkisson) raked the fire.

Mrs. Morel came of a good old burgher family, famous independents who had fought with Colonel Hutchinson, and who remained stout Congregationalists. Her (Morel) grandfather had gone bankrupt in the lace-market at a time when so many lace-manufacturers were ruined in Nottingham. Her (Morel) father, George Coppard, was an engineer--a large, handsome, haughty man, proud of his (man) fair skin and blue eyes, but more proud still of his (man) integrity. Gertrude resembled her (Gertrude) mother in her (Gertrude) small build. But her (Gertrude) temper, proud and unyielding, she (Gertrude) had from the Coppards.

George Coppard was bitterly galled by his (Coppard) own poverty. He (Coppard) became foreman of the engineers in the dockyard at Sheerness. Mrs. Morel--Gertrude--was the second daughter. She (Morel) favoured her (Morel) mother, loved her (Morel) mother best of all; but she (Morel) had the Coppards' clear, defiant blue eyes and their broad brow. She (Morel) remembered to have hated her (Morel) father's overbearing manner towards her (Morel) gentle, humorous, kindly-souled mother. She (Morel) remembered running over the breakwater at Sheerness and finding the boat. She (Morel) remembered to have been petted and flattered by all the men when she (Morel) had gone to the dockyard, for she (Morel) was a delicate, rather proud child. She (Morel) remembered the funny old mistress, whose assistant she (Morel) had become, whom she (Morel) had loved to help in the private school. And she (Morel) still had the Bible that John Field had given her (Morel). She (Morel) used to walk home from chapel with John Field when she (Morel) was nineteen. He (Field) was the son of a well-to-do tradesman, had been to college in London, and was to devote himself to business.

She (Morel) could always recall in detail a September Sunday afternoon, when they had sat under the vine at the back of her (Morel) father's house. The sun came through the chinks of the vine-leaves and made beautiful patterns, like a lace scarf, falling on her (Morel) and on him (father). Some of the leaves were clean yellow, like yellow flat flowers.

``Now sit still,'' (he)
he (father) had cried.
``Now your hair, I don't know what it IS like! It's as bright as copper and gold, as red as burnt copper, and it has gold threads where the sun shines on it. Fancy their saying it's brown. Your mother calls it mouse-colour.'' (She)

She (Morel) had met his (father) brilliant eyes, but her (Morel) clear face scarcely showed the elation which rose within her (Morel).

``But you say you don't like business,'' (she)
she (Morel) pursued.

``I don't. I hate it!'' (he)
he (father) cried hotly.

``And you would like to go into the ministry,'' (she)
she (Morel) half implored.

``I should. I should love it, if I thought I could make a first-rate preacher.'' (unknown)

``Then why don't you--why DON``T you?'' Her (Morel) voice rang with defiance.

``If I were a man, nothing would stop me.'' (She)

She (Morel) held her (Morel) head erect. He (father) was rather timid before her (Morel).

``But my father's so stiff-necked. He (father) means to put me into the business, and I know he (father)'ll do it.'' (unknown)

``But if you're a MAN?'' (she)
she (Morel) had cried.

``Being a man isn't everything,'' (he)
he (father) replied, frowning with puzzled helplessness.

Now, as she (Morel) moved about her (Morel) work at the Bottoms, with some experience of what being a man meant, she (Morel) knew that it was NOT everything.

At twenty, owing to her (Morel) health, she (Morel) had left Sheerness. Her (Morel) father had retired home to Nottingham. John Field's father had been ruined; the son had gone as a teacher in Norwood. She (Morel) did not hear of him (Norwood) until, two years later, she (Morel) made determined inquiry. He (Norwood) had married his (Norwood) landlady, a woman of forty, a widow with property.

And still Mrs. Morel preserved John Field's Bible. She (Morel) did not now believe him (Field) to be--Well, she (Morel) understood pretty well what he (Field) might or might not have been. So she (Morel) preserved his (Field) Bible, and kept his (Field) memory intact in her (Morel) heart, for her (Morel) own sake. To her (Morel) dying day, for thirty-five years, she (Morel) did not speak of him (Field).

When she (Morel) was twenty-three years old, she (Morel) met, at a Christmas party, a young man from the Erewash Valley. Morel was then twenty-seven years old. He (man) was well set-up, erect, and very smart. He (man) had wavy black hair that shone again, and a vigorous black beard that had never been shaved. His (man) cheeks were ruddy, and his (man) red, moist mouth was noticeable because he (man) laughed so often and so heartily. He (man) had that rare thing, a rich, ringing laugh. Gertrude Coppard had watched him (man), fascinated. He (man) was so full of colour and animation, his (man) voice ran so easily into comic grotesque, he (man) was so ready and so pleasant with everybody. Her (Coppard) own father had a rich fund of humour, but it was satiric. This man's was different: soft, non-intellectual, warm, a kind of gambolling.

She (Coppard) herself was opposite. She (Coppard) had a curious, receptive mind which found much pleasure and amusement in listening to other folk. She (Coppard) was clever in leading folk to talk. She (Coppard) loved ideas, and was considered very intellectual. What she (Coppard) liked most of all was an argument on religion or philosophy or politics with some educated man. This she (Coppard) did not often enjoy. So she (Coppard) always had people tell her (Coppard) about themselves, finding her (Coppard) pleasure so.

In her (Coppard) person she (Coppard) was rather small and delicate, with a large brow, and dropping bunches of brown silk curls. Her (Coppard) blue eyes were very straight, honest, and searching. She (Coppard) had the beautiful hands of the Coppards. Her (Coppard) dress was always subdued. She (Coppard) wore dark blue silk, with a peculiar silver chain of silver scallops. This, and a heavy brooch of twisted gold, was her (Coppard) only ornament. She (Coppard) was still perfectly intact, deeply religious, and full of beautiful candour.

Walter Morel seemed melted away before her (Coppard). She (Coppard) was to the miner that thing of mystery and fascination, a lady. When she (lady) spoke to him (Morel), it was with a southern pronunciation and a purity of English which thrilled him (Morel) to hear. She (lady) watched him (Morel). He (Morel) danced well, as if it were natural and joyous in him (Morel) to dance. His (Morel) grandfather was a French refugee who had married an English barmaid--if it had been a marriage. Gertrude Coppard watched the young miner as he (Morel) danced, a certain subtle exultation like glamour in his (Morel) movement, and his (Morel) face the flower of his (Morel) body, ruddy, with tumbled black hair, and laughing alike whatever partner he (Morel) bowed above. She (Coppard) thought him (Morel) rather wonderful, never having met anyone like him (Morel). Her (Coppard) father was to her (Coppard) the type of all men. And George Coppard, proud in his (Coppard) bearing, handsome, and rather bitter; who preferred theology in reading, and who drew near in sympathy only to one man, the Apostle Paul; who was harsh in government, and in familiarity ironic; who ignored all sensuous pleasure:--he (Paul) was very different from the miner. Gertrude herself was rather contemptuous of dancing; she (Gertrude) had not the slightest inclination towards that accomplishment, and had never learned even a Roger de Coverley. She (Gertrude) was puritan, like her (Gertrude) father, high-minded, and really stern. Therefore the dusky, golden softness of this man's sensuous flame of life, that flowed off his (man) flesh like the flame from a candle, not baffled and gripped into incandescence by thought and spirit as her (Gertrude) life was, seemed to her (Gertrude) something wonderful, beyond her (Gertrude).

He (man) came and bowed above her (Gertrude). A warmth radiated through her (Gertrude) as if she (Gertrude) had drunk wine.

``Now do come and have this one wi' me,'' (he)
he (man) said caressively.
``It's easy, you know. I'm pining to see you dance.'' (She)

She (Gertrude) had told him (man) before she (Gertrude) could not dance. She (Gertrude) glanced at his (man) humility and smiled. Her (Gertrude) smile was very beautiful. It moved the man so that he (man) forgot everything.

``No, I won't dance,'' (she)
she (Gertrude) said softly. Her (Gertrude) words came clean and ringing.

Not knowing what he (man) was doing--he (man) often did the right thing by instinct--he (man) sat beside her (Gertrude), inclining reverentially.

``But you mustn't miss your dance,'' (she)
she (Gertrude) reproved.

``Nay, I don't want to dance that--it's not one as I care about.'' (unknown)

``Yet you invited me to it.'' (He)

He (man) laughed very heartily at this.

``I never thought o' that. Tha`rt not long in taking the curl out of me.'' (unknown)

It was her (Gertrude) turn to laugh quickly.

``You don't look as if you'd come much uncurled,'' (she)
she (Gertrude) said.

``I'm like a pig's tail, I curl because I canna help it,'' (he)
he (man) laughed, rather boisterously.

``And you are a miner!'' (she)
she (Gertrude) exclaimed in surprise.

``Yes. I went down when I was ten.'' (She)

She (Gertrude) looked at him (man) in wondering dismay.

``When you were ten! And wasn't it very hard?'' (she)
she (Gertrude) asked.

``You soon get used to it. You live like th' mice, an' you pop out at night to see what's going on.'' (unknown)

``It makes me feel blind,'' (she)
she (Gertrude) frowned.

``Like a moudiwarp!'' (he)
he (man) laughed.
``Yi, an' there's some chaps as does go round like moudiwarps.'' (He)
He (man) thrust his (man) face forward in the blind, snout-like way of a mole, seeming to sniff and peer for direction.
``They dun though!'' (he)
he (man) protested naively.
``Tha niver seed such a way they get in. But tha mun let me ta'e thee down some time, an' tha can see for thysen.'' (She)

She (Gertrude) looked at him (man), startled. This was a new tract of life suddenly opened before her (Gertrude). She (Gertrude) realised the life of the miners, hundreds of them toiling below earth and coming up at evening. He (man) seemed to her (Gertrude) noble. He (man) risked his (man) life daily, and with gaiety. She (Gertrude) looked at him (man), with a touch of appeal in her (Gertrude) pure humility.

``Shouldn't ter like it?'' (he)
he (man) asked tenderly.
''`Appen not, it `ud dirty thee.'' (he)

She (Gertrude) had never been

``thee'd'' (She)
and
``thou'd'' (She)
before.

The next Christmas they were married, and for three months she (Gertrude) was perfectly happy: for six months she (Gertrude) was very happy.

He (man) had signed the pledge, and wore the blue ribbon of a tee-totaller: he (man) was nothing if not showy. They lived, she (Gertrude) thought, in his (man) own house. It was small, but convenient enough, and quite nicely furnished, with solid, worthy stuff that suited her (Gertrude) honest soul. The women, her (Gertrude) neighbours, were rather foreign to her (Gertrude), and Morel's mother and sisters were apt to sneer at her (mother) ladylike ways. But she (mother) could perfectly well live by herself, so long as she (mother) had her (mother) husband close.

Sometimes, when she (mother) herself wearied of love-talk, she (mother) tried to open her (mother) heart seriously to him (husband). She (mother) saw him (husband) listen deferentially, but without understanding. This killed her (mother) efforts at a finer intimacy, and she (mother) had flashes of fear. Sometimes he (husband) was restless of an evening: it was not enough for him (husband) just to be near her (mother), she (mother) realised. She (mother) was glad when he (husband) set himself to little jobs.

He (husband) was a remarkably handy man--could make or mend anything. So she (mother) would say:

``I do like that coal-rake of your mother's--it is small and natty.'' (she)

``Does ter, my wench? Well, I made that, so I can make thee one!'' (unknown)

``What! why, it's a steel one!'' (unknown)

``An' what if it is! Tha s`lt ha'e one very similar, if not exactly same.'' (She)

She (mother) did not mind the mess, nor the hammering and noise. He (husband) was busy and happy.

But in the seventh month, when she (mother) was brushing his (husband) Sunday coat, she (mother) felt papers in the breast pocket, and, seized with a sudden curiosity, took them out to read. He (husband) very rarely wore the frock-coat he (husband) was married in: and it had not occurred to her (mother) before to feel curious concerning the papers. They were the bills of the household furniture, still unpaid.

``Look here,'' (she)
she (mother) said at night, after he (husband) was washed and had had his (husband) dinner.
``I found these in the pocket of your wedding-coat. Haven't you settled the bills yet?'' (unknown)

``No. I haven't had a chance.'' (unknown)

``But you told me all was paid. I had better go into Nottingham on Saturday and settle them. I don't like sitting on another man's chairs and eating from an unpaid table.'' (He)

He (husband) did not answer.

``I can have your bank-book, can't I?'' (unknown)

``Tha can ha'e it, for what good it'll be to thee.'' (unknown)

``I thought--'' (she)
she (mother) began. He (husband) had told her (mother) he (husband) had a good bit of money left over. But she (mother) realised it was no use asking questions. She (mother) sat rigid with bitterness and indignation.

The next day she (mother) went down to see his (husband) mother.

``Didn't you buy the furniture for Walter?'' (she)
she (mother) asked.

``Yes, I did,'' (the woman)
tartly retorted the elder woman.

``And how much did he (Walter) give you to pay for it?'' (The woman)

The elder woman was stung with fine indignation.

``Eighty pound, if you're so keen on knowin','' (she)
she (woman) replied.

``Eighty pounds! But there are forty-two pounds still owing!'' (unknown)

``I can't help that.'' (unknown)

``But where has it all gone?'' (unknown)

``You'll find all the papers, I think, if you look--beside ten pound as he (Walter) owed me, an' six pound as the wedding cost down here.'' (unknown)

``Six pounds!'' (Gertrude/Gertrude Morel)
echoed Gertrude Morel. It seemed to her (woman) monstrous that, after her (woman) own father had paid so heavily for her (woman) wedding, six pounds more should have been squandered in eating and drinking at Walter's parents' house, at his (Walter) expense.

``And how much has he (Walter) sunk in his (Walter) houses?'' (she)
she (woman) asked.

``His (Walter) houses--which houses?'' (Gertrude/Gertrude Morel)

Gertrude Morel went white to the lips. He (Walter) had told her (Morel) the house he (Walter) lived in, and the next one, was his (Walter) own.

``I thought the house we live in--'' (she)
she (Morel) began.

``They're my houses, those two,'' (the mother-in-law)
said the mother-in-law.
``And not clear either. It's as much as I can do to keep the mortgage interest paid.'' (Gertrude/Gertrude Morel)

Gertrude sat white and silent. She (Gertrude) was her (Gertrude) father now.

``Then we ought to be paying you rent,'' (she)
she (Gertrude) said coldly.

``Walter is paying me rent,'' (the mother)
replied the mother.

``And what rent?'' (Gertrude/Gertrude Morel)
asked Gertrude.

``Six and six a week,'' (the mother)
retorted the mother.

It was more than the house was worth. Gertrude held her (Gertrude) head erect, looked straight before her (Gertrude).

``It is lucky to be you,'' (the woman)
said the elder woman, bitingly,
``to have a husband as takes all the worry of the money, and leaves you a free hand.'' (the woman)

The young wife was silent.

She (wife) said very little to her (wife) husband, but her (wife) manner had changed towards him (husband). Something in her (wife) proud, honourable soul had crystallised out hard as rock.

When October came in, she (wife) thought only of Christmas. Two years ago, at Christmas, she (wife) had met him (husband). Last Christmas she (wife) had married him (husband). This Christmas she (wife) would bear him (husband) a child.

``You don't dance yourself, do you, missis?'' (neighbour)
asked her (wife) nearest neighbour, in October, when there was great talk of opening a dancing-class over the Brick and Tile Inn at Bestwood.

``No--I never had the least inclination to,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel replied.

``Fancy! An' how funny as you should ha' married your Mester. You know he (husband)'s quite a famous one for dancing.'' (unknown)

``I didn't know he (husband) was famous,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
laughed Mrs. Morel.

``Yea, he (husband) is though! Why, he (husband) ran that dancing-class in the Miners' Arms club-room for over five year.'' (unknown)

``Did he (husband)?'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (husband) did.'' (The woman)
The other woman was defiant.
``An' it was thronged every Tuesday, and Thursday, an' Sat`day--an' there WAS carryin's-on, accordin' to all accounts.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

This kind of thing was gall and bitterness to Mrs. Morel, and she (Morel) had a fair share of it. The women did not spare her (Morel), at first; for she (Morel) was superior, though she (Morel) could not help it.

He (husband) began to be rather late in coming home.

``They're working very late now, aren't they?'' (she)
she (Morel) said to her (Morel) washer-woman.

``No later than they allers do, I don't think. But they stop to have their pint at Ellen's, an' they get talkin', an' there you are! Dinner stone cold--an' it serves 'em right.'' (unknown)

``But Mr. Morel does not take any drink.'' (The woman)

The woman dropped the clothes, looked at Mrs. Morel, then went on with her (Morel) work, saying nothing.

Gertrude Morel was very ill when the boy was born. Morel was good to her (Morel), as good as gold. But she (Morel) felt very lonely, miles away from her (Morel) own people. She (Morel) felt lonely with him (boy) now, and his (boy) presence only made it more intense.

The boy was small and frail at first, but he (boy) came on quickly. He (boy) was a beautiful child, with dark gold ringlets, and dark-blue eyes which changed gradually to a clear grey. His (boy) mother loved him (boy) passionately. He (boy) came just when her (mother) own bitterness of disillusion was hardest to bear; when her (mother) faith in life was shaken, and her (mother) soul felt dreary and lonely. She (mother) made much of the child, and the father was jealous.

At last Mrs. Morel despised her (Morel) husband. She (Morel) turned to the child; she (Morel) turned from the father. He (father) had begun to neglect her (Morel); the novelty of his (father) own home was gone. He (father) had no grit, she (Morel) said bitterly to herself. What he (father) felt just at the minute, that was all to him (father). He (father) could not abide by anything. There was nothing at the back of all his (father) show.

There began a battle between the husband and wife--a fearful, bloody battle that ended only with the death of one. She (wife) fought to make him (father) undertake his (father) own responsibilities, to make him (father) fulfill his (father) obligations. But he (father) was too different from her (wife). His (father) nature was purely sensuous, and she (wife) strove to make him (father) moral, religious. She (wife) tried to force him (father) to face things. He (father) could not endure it--it drove him (father) out of his (father) mind.

While the baby was still tiny, the father's temper had become so irritable that it was not to be trusted. The child had only to give a little trouble when the man began to bully. A little more, and the hard hands of the collier hit the baby. Then Mrs. Morel loathed her (Morel) husband, loathed him (husband) for days; and he (husband) went out and drank; and she (Morel) cared very little what he (husband) did. Only, on his (husband) return, she (Morel) scathed him (husband) with her (Morel) satire.

The estrangement between them caused him (husband), knowingly or unknowingly, grossly to offend her (Morel) where he (husband) would not have done.

William was only one year old, and his (William) mother was proud of him (William), he (William) was so pretty. She (mother) was not well off now, but her (mother) sisters kept the boy in clothes. Then, with his (boy) little white hat curled with an ostrich feather, and his (boy) white coat, he (boy) was a joy to her (mother), the twining wisps of hair clustering round his (boy) head. Mrs. Morel lay listening, one Sunday morning, to the chatter of the father and child downstairs. Then she (Morel) dozed off. When she (Morel) came downstairs, a great fire glowed in the grate, the room was hot, the breakfast was roughly laid, and seated in his (father) armchair, against the chimney-piece, sat Morel, rather timid; and standing between his (father) legs, the child--cropped like a sheep, with such an odd round poll--looking wondering at her (Morel); and on a newspaper spread out upon the hearthrug, a myriad of crescent-shaped curls, like the petals of a marigold scattered in the reddening firelight.

Mrs. Morel stood still. It was her (Morel) first baby. She (Morel) went very white, and was unable to speak.

``What dost think o' `im?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Morel laughed uneasily.

She (Morel) gripped her (Morel) two fists, lifted them, and came forward. Morel shrank back.

``I could kill you, I could!'' (she)
she (Morel) said. She (Morel) choked with rage, her (Morel) two fists uplifted.

``Yer non want ter make a wench on `im,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Morel said, in a frightened tone, bending his (Morel) head to shield his (Morel) eyes from hers. His (Morel) attempt at laughter had vanished.

The mother looked down at the jagged, close-clipped head of her (mother) child. She (mother) put her (mother) hands on his (Morel) hair, and stroked and fondled his (Morel) head.

``Oh--my boy!'' (she)
she (mother) faltered. Her (mother) lip trembled, her (mother) face broke, and, snatching up the child, she (mother) buried her (mother) face in his (Morel) shoulder and cried painfully. She (mother) was one of those women who cannot cry; whom it hurts as it hurts a man. It was like ripping something out of her (mother), her (mother) sobbing.

Morel sat with his (man) elbows on his (man) knees, his (man) hands gripped together till the knuckles were white. He (man) gazed in the fire, feeling almost stunned, as if he (man) could not breathe.

Presently she (Morel) came to an end, soothed the child and cleared away the breakfast-table. She (Morel) left the newspaper, littered with curls, spread upon the hearthrug. At last her (Morel) husband gathered it up and put it at the back of the fire. She (Morel) went about her (Morel) work with closed mouth and very quiet. Morel was subdued. He (husband) crept about wretchedly, and his (husband) meals were a misery that day. She (Morel) spoke to him (husband) civilly, and never alluded to what he (husband) had done. But he (husband) felt something final had happened.

Afterwards she (Morel) said she (Morel) had been silly, that the boy's hair would have had to be cut, sooner or later. In the end, she (Morel) even brought herself to say to her (Morel) husband it was just as well he (husband) had played barber when he (husband) did. But she (Morel) knew, and Morel knew, that that act had caused something momentous to take place in her (Morel) soul. She (Morel) remembered the scene all her (Morel) life, as one in which she (Morel) had suffered the most intensely.

This act of masculine clumsiness was the spear through the side of her (Morel) love for Morel. Before, while she (Morel) had striven against him (husband) bitterly, she (Morel) had fretted after him (husband), as if he (husband) had gone astray from her (Morel). Now she (Morel) ceased to fret for his (husband) love: he (husband) was an outsider to her (Morel). This made life much more bearable.

Nevertheless, she (Morel) still continued to strive with him (husband). She (Morel) still had her (Morel) high moral sense, inherited from generations of Puritans. It was now a religious instinct, and she (Morel) was almost a fanatic with him (husband), because she (Morel) loved him (husband), or had loved him (husband). If he (husband) sinned, she (Morel) tortured him (husband). If he (husband) drank, and lied, was often a poltroon, sometimes a knave, she (Morel) wielded the lash unmercifully.

The pity was, she (Morel) was too much his (husband) opposite. She (Morel) could not be content with the little he (husband) might be; she (Morel) would have him (husband) the much that he (husband) ought to be. So, in seeking to make him (husband) nobler than he (husband) could be, she (Morel) destroyed him (husband). She (Morel) injured and hurt and scarred herself, but she (Morel) lost none of her (Morel) worth. She (Morel) also had the children.

He (husband) drank rather heavily, though not more than many miners, and always beer, so that whilst his (husband) health was affected, it was never injured. The week-end was his (husband) chief carouse. He (husband) sat in the Miners' Arms until turning-out time every Friday, every Saturday, and every Sunday evening. On Monday and Tuesday he (husband) had to get up and reluctantly leave towards ten o'clock. Sometimes he (husband) stayed at home on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, or was only out for an hour. He (husband) practically never had to miss work owing to his (husband) drinking.

But although he (husband) was very steady at work, his (husband) wages fell off. He (husband) was blab-mouthed, a tongue-wagger. Authority was hateful to him (husband), therefore he (husband) could only abuse the pit-managers. He (husband) would say, in the Palmerston:

``Th' gaffer come down to our stall this morning, an' 'e says, ``You know, Walter, this `ere'll not do. What about these props?'' An' I says to him (husband), ``Why, what art talkin' about? What d'st mean about th' props?'' ``It'll never do, this

``ere,'' (unknown)
'e says.
``You'll be havin' th' roof in, one o' these days.'' (I)
An' I says, ``Tha'd better stan' on a bit o' clunch, then, an' hold it up wi' thy ``ead.
'' So 'e wor that mad, 'e cossed an' 'e swore, an' t`other chaps they did laugh.'' (I)
Morel was a good mimic. He (husband) imitated the manager's fat, squeaky voice, with its attempt at good English.

'''I shan't have it, Walter. Who knows more about it, me or you?'' (the manager)
So I says,
``I've niver fun out how much tha' knows, Alfred. It'll `appen carry thee ter bed an' back.'' (I)
'

So Morel would go on to the amusement of his (Walter) boon companions. And some of this would be true. The pit-manager was not an educated man. He (man) had been a boy along with Morel, so that, while the two disliked each other, they more or less took each other for granted. But Alfred Charlesworth did not forgive the butty these public-house sayings. Consequently, although Morel was a good miner, sometimes earning as much as five pounds a week when he (Alfred) married, he (Alfred) came gradually to have worse and worse stalls, where the coal was thin, and hard to get, and unprofitable.

Also, in summer, the pits are slack. Often, on bright sunny mornings, the men are seen trooping home again at ten, eleven, or twelve o'clock. No empty trucks stand at the pit-mouth. The women on the hillside look across as they shake the hearthrug against the fence, and count the wagons the engine is taking along the line up the valley. And the children, as they come from school at dinner-time, looking down the fields and seeing the wheels on the headstocks standing, say:

``Minton's knocked off. My dad'll be at home.'' (the children)

And there is a sort of shadow over all, women and children and men, because money will be short at the end of the week.

Morel was supposed to give his (women) wife thirty shillings a week, to provide everything--rent, food, clothes, clubs, insurance, doctors. Occasionally, if he (women) were flush, he (women) gave her (Morel) thirty-five. But these occasions by no means balanced those when he (women) gave her (Morel) twenty-five. In winter, with a decent stall, the miner might earn fifty or fifty-five shillings a week. Then he (women) was happy. On Friday night, Saturday, and Sunday, he (women) spent royally, getting rid of his (women) sovereign or thereabouts. And out of so much, he (women) scarcely spared the children an extra penny or bought them a pound of apples. It all went in drink. In the bad times, matters were more worrying, but he (women) was not so often drunk, so that Mrs. Morel used to say:

``I'm not sure I wouldn't rather be short, for when he (Minton)'s flush, there isn't a minute of peace.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

If he (women) earned forty shillings he (women) kept ten; from thirty-five he (women) kept five; from thirty-two he (women) kept four; from twenty-eight he (women) kept three; from twenty-four he (women) kept two; from twenty he (women) kept one-and-six; from eighteen he (women) kept a shilling; from sixteen he (women) kept sixpence. He (women) never saved a penny, and he (women) gave his (women) wife no opportunity of saving; instead, she (wife) had occasionally to pay his (women) debts; not public-house debts, for those never were passed on to the women, but debts when he (women) had bought a canary, or a fancy walking-stick.

At the wakes time Morel was working badly, and Mrs. Morel was trying to save against her (Morel) confinement. So it galled her (Morel) bitterly to think he (women) should be out taking his (women) pleasure and spending money, whilst she (Morel) remained at home, harassed. There were two days' holiday. On the Tuesday morning Morel rose early. He (Morel) was in good spirits. Quite early, before six o'clock, she (Morel) heard him (Morel) whistling away to himself downstairs. He (Morel) had a pleasant way of whistling, lively and musical. He (Morel) nearly always whistled hymns. He (Morel) had been a choir-boy with a beautiful voice, and had taken solos in Southwell cathedral. His (Morel) morning whistling alone betrayed it.

His (Morel) wife lay listening to him (Morel) tinkering away in the garden, his (Morel) whistling ringing out as he (Morel) sawed and hammered away. It always gave her (wife) a sense of warmth and peace to hear him (Morel) thus as she (wife) lay in bed, the children not yet awake, in the bright early morning, happy in his (Morel) man's fashion.

At nine o'clock, while the children with bare legs and feet were sitting playing on the sofa, and the mother was washing up, he (Morel) came in from his (Morel) carpentry, his (Morel) sleeves rolled up, his (Morel) waistcoat hanging open. He (Morel) was still a good-looking man, with black, wavy hair, and a large black moustache. His (Morel) face was perhaps too much inflamed, and there was about him (Morel) a look almost of peevishness. But now he (Morel) was jolly. He (Morel) went straight to the sink where his (Morel) wife was washing up.

``What, are thee there!'' (he)
he (Morel) said boisterously.
``Sluthe off an' let me wesh mysen.'' (unknown)

``You may wait till I've finished,'' (wife)
said his (Morel) wife.

``Oh, mun I? An' what if I shonna?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

This good-humoured threat amused Mrs. Morel.

``Then you can go and wash yourself in the soft-water tub.'' (unknown)

``Ha! I can' an' a', tha mucky little `ussy.'' (he)

With which he (Morel) stood watching her (Morel) a moment, then went away to wait for her (Morel).

When he (Morel) chose he (Morel) could still make himself again a real gallant. Usually he (Morel) preferred to go out with a scarf round his (Morel) neck. Now, however, he (Morel) made a toilet. There seemed so much gusto in the way he (Morel) puffed and swilled as he (Morel) washed himself, so much alacrity with which he (Morel) hurried to the mirror in the kitchen, and, bending because it was too low for him (Morel), scrupulously parted his (Morel) wet black hair, that it irritated Mrs. Morel. He (Morel) put on a turn-down collar, a black bow, and wore his (Morel) Sunday tail-coat. As such, he (Morel) looked spruce, and what his (Morel) clothes would not do, his (Morel) instinct for making the most of his (Morel) good looks would.

At half-past nine Jerry Purdy came to call for his (Purdy) pal. Jerry was Morel's bosom friend, and Mrs. Morel disliked him (Jerry). He (Jerry) was a tall, thin man, with a rather foxy face, the kind of face that seems to lack eyelashes. He (Jerry) walked with a stiff, brittle dignity, as if his (Jerry) head were on a wooden spring. His (Jerry) nature was cold and shrewd. Generous where he (Jerry) intended to be generous, he (Jerry) seemed to be very fond of Morel, and more or less to take charge of him (Morel).

Mrs. Morel hated him (Morel). She (Morel) had known his (Morel) wife, who had died of consumption, and who had, at the end, conceived such a violent dislike of her (Morel) husband, that if he (husband) came into her (Morel) room it caused her (Morel) haemorrhage. None of which Jerry had seemed to mind. And now his (Jerry) eldest daughter, a girl of fifteen, kept a poor house for him (Jerry), and looked after the two younger children.

``A mean, wizzen-hearted stick!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel said of him (Jerry).

``I've never known Jerry mean in MY life,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
protested Morel.
``A opener-handed and more freer chap you couldn't find anywhere, accordin' to my knowledge.'' (unknown)

``Open-handed to you,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
retorted Mrs. Morel.
``But his (Jerry) fist is shut tight enough to his (Jerry) children, poor things.'' (unknown)

``Poor things! And what for are they poor things, I should like to know.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

But Mrs. Morel would not be appeased on Jerry's score.

The subject of argument was seen, craning his (Jerry) thin neck over the scullery curtain. He (Jerry) caught Mrs. Morel's eye.

``Mornin', missis! Mester in?'' (unknown)

``Yes--he (Jerry) is.'' (Jerry)

Jerry entered unasked, and stood by the kitchen doorway. He (Jerry) was not invited to sit down, but stood there, coolly asserting the rights of men and husbands.

``A nice day,'' (he)
he (Jerry) said to Mrs. Morel.

``Yes.

``Grand out this morning--grand for a walk.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean YOU

``RE going for a walk?'' (unknown)
she (Morel) asked.

``Yes. We mean walkin' to Nottingham,'' (he)
he (Jerry) replied.

``H'm!'' (The men)

The two men greeted each other, both glad: Jerry, however, full of assurance, Morel rather subdued, afraid to seem too jubilant in presence of his (Jerry) wife. But he (Jerry) laced his (Jerry) boots quickly, with spirit. They were going for a ten-mile walk across the fields to Nottingham. Climbing the hillside from the Bottoms, they mounted gaily into the morning. At the Moon and Stars they had their first drink, then on to the Old Spot. Then a long five miles of drought to carry them into Bulwell to a glorious pint of bitter. But they stayed in a field with some haymakers whose gallon bottle was full, so that, when they came in sight of the city, Morel was sleepy. The town spread upwards before them, smoking vaguely in the midday glare, fridging the crest away to the south with spires and factory bulks and chimneys. In the last field Morel lay down under an oak tree and slept soundly for over an hour. When he (Morel) rose to go forward he (Morel) felt queer.

The two had dinner in the Meadows, with Jerry's sister, then repaired to the Punch Bowl, where they mixed in the excitement of pigeon-racing. Morel never in his (Jerry) life played cards, considering them as having some occult, malevolent power--

``the devil's pictures,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
he (Jerry) called them! But he (Jerry) was a master of skittles and of dominoes. He (Jerry) took a challenge from a Newark man, on skittles. All the men in the old, long bar took sides, betting either one way or the other. Morel took off his (Jerry) coat. Jerry held the hat containing the money. The men at the tables watched. Some stood with their mugs in their hands. Morel felt his (Jerry) big wooden ball carefully, then launched it. He (Jerry) played havoc among the nine-pins, and won half a crown, which restored him (Jerry) to solvency.

By seven o'clock the two were in good condition. They caught the 7.30 train home.

In the afternoon the Bottoms was intolerable. Every inhabitant remaining was out of doors. The women, in twos and threes, bareheaded and in white aprons, gossiped in the alley between the blocks. Men, having a rest between drinks, sat on their heels and talked. The place smelled stale; the slate roofs glistered in the arid heat.

Mrs. Morel took the little girl down to the brook in the meadows, which were not more than two hundred yards away. The water ran quickly over stones and broken pots. Mother and child leaned on the rail of the old sheep-bridge, watching. Up at the dipping-hole, at the other end of the meadow, Mrs. Morel could see the naked forms of boys flashing round the deep yellow water, or an occasional bright figure dart glittering over the blackish stagnant meadow. She (Morel) knew William was at the dipping-hole, and it was the dread of her (Morel) life lest he (William) should get drowned. Annie played under the tall old hedge, picking up alder cones, that she (Annie) called currants. The child required much attention, and the flies were teasing.

The children were put to bed at seven o'clock. Then she (Annie) worked awhile.

When Walter Morel and Jerry arrived at Bestwood they felt a load off their minds; a railway journey no longer impended, so they could put the finishing touches to a glorious day. They entered the Nelson with the satisfaction of returned travellers.

The next day was a work-day, and the thought of it put a damper on the men's spirits. Most of them, moreover, had spent their money. Some were already rolling dismally home, to sleep in preparation for the morrow. Mrs. Morel, listening to their mournful singing, went indoors. Nine o'clock passed, and ten, and still

``the pair'' (unknown)
had not returned. On a doorstep somewhere a man was singing loudly, in a drawl:
``Lead, kindly Light.'' (a man)
Mrs. Morel was always indignant with the drunken men that they must sing that hymn when they got maudlin.

``As if

``Genevieve' weren't good enough,'' (unknown)
she (Morel) said.

The kitchen was full of the scent of boiled herbs and hops. On the hob a large black saucepan steamed slowly. Mrs. Morel took a panchion, a great bowl of thick red earth, streamed a heap of white sugar into the bottom, and then, straining herself to the weight, was pouring in the liquor.

Just then Morel came in. He (man) had been very jolly in the Nelson, but coming home had grown irritable. He (Nelson) had not quite got over the feeling of irritability and pain, after having slept on the ground when he (Nelson) was so hot; and a bad conscience afflicted him (Nelson) as he (Nelson) neared the house. He (Nelson) did not know he (Nelson) was angry. But when the garden gate resisted his (Nelson) attempts to open it, he (Nelson) kicked it and broke the latch. He (Nelson) entered just as Mrs. Morel was pouring the infusion of herbs out of the saucepan. Swaying slightly, he (Nelson) lurched against the table. The boiling liquor pitched. Mrs. Morel started back.

``Good gracious,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried,
``coming home in his (devil) drunkenness!'' (she)

``Comin' home in his (devil) what?'' (he)
he (Nelson) snarled, his (Nelson) hat over his (Nelson) eye.

Suddenly her (Morel) blood rose in a jet.

``Say you're NOT drunk!'' (she)
she (Morel) flashed.

She (Morel) had put down her (Morel) saucepan, and was stirring the sugar into the beer. He (Nelson) dropped his (Nelson) two hands heavily on the table, and thrust his (Nelson) face forwards at her (Morel).

''`Say you're not drunk,''' (her)
he (Nelson) repeated.
``Why, nobody but a nasty little bitch like you `ud `ave such a thought.'' (He)

He (Nelson) thrust his (Nelson) face forward at her (Morel).

``There's money to bezzle with, if there's money for nothing else.'' (unknown)

``I've not spent a two-shillin' bit this day,'' (he)
he (Nelson) said.

``You don't get as drunk as a lord on nothing,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.
``And,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried, flashing into sudden fury,
``if you've been sponging on your beloved Jerry, why, let him (Jerry) look after his (Jerry) children, for they need it.'' (she)

``It's a lie, it's a lie. Shut your face, woman.'' (unknown)

They were now at battle-pitch. Each forgot everything save the hatred of the other and the battle between them. She (Morel) was fiery and furious as he (Nelson). They went on till he (Nelson) called her (Morel) a liar.

``No,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried, starting up, scarce able to breathe.
``Don't call me that--you, the most despicable liar that ever walked in shoe-leather.'' (She)
She (Morel) forced the last words out of suffocated lungs.

``You're a liar!'' (he)
he (Nelson) yelled, banging the table with his (Nelson) fist.
``You're a liar, you're a liar.'' (She)

She (Morel) stiffened herself, with clenched fists.

``The house is filthy with you,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried.

``Then get out on it--it's mine. Get out on it!'' (he)
he (Nelson) shouted.
``It's me as brings th' money whoam, not thee. It's my house, not thine. Then ger out on't--ger out on't!'' (unknown)

``And I would,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried, suddenly shaken into tears of impotence.
``Ah, wouldn't I, wouldn't I have gone long ago, but for those children. Ay, haven't I repented not going years ago, when I'd only the one'' (unknown)
--suddenly drying into rage.
``Do you think it's for YOU I stop--do you think I'd stop one minute for YOU?'' (unknown)

``Go, then,'' (he)
he (Nelson) shouted, beside himself.
``Go!'' (unknown)

``No!'' (She)
She (Morel) faced round.
``No,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried loudly,
``you shan't have it ALL your own way; you shan't do ALL you like. I've got those children to see to. My word,'' (she)
she (Morel) laughed,
``I should look well to leave them to you.'' (she)

``Go,'' (he)
he (Nelson) cried thickly, lifting his (Nelson) fist. He (Nelson) was afraid of her (Morel).
``Go!'' (unknown)

``I should be only too glad. I should laugh, laugh, my lord, if I could get away from you,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.

He (Nelson) came up to her (Morel), his (Nelson) red face, with its bloodshot eyes, thrust forward, and gripped her (Morel) arms. She (Morel) cried in fear of him (Nelson), struggled to be free. Coming slightly to himself, panting, he (Nelson) pushed her (Morel) roughly to the outer door, and thrust her (Morel) forth, slotting the bolt behind her (Morel) with a bang. Then he (Nelson) went back into the kitchen, dropped into his (Nelson) armchair, his (Nelson) head, bursting full of blood, sinking between his (Nelson) knees. Thus he (Nelson) dipped gradually into a stupor, from exhaustion and intoxication.

The moon was high and magnificent in the August night. Mrs. Morel, seared with passion, shivered to find herself out there in a great white light, that fell cold on her (Morel), and gave a shock to her (Morel) inflamed soul. She (Morel) stood for a few moments helplessly staring at the glistening great rhubarb leaves near the door. Then she (Morel) got the air into her (Morel) breast. She (Morel) walked down the garden path, trembling in every limb, while the child boiled within her (Morel). For a while she (Morel) could not control her (Morel) consciousness; mechanically she (Morel) went over the last scene, then over it again, certain phrases, certain moments coming each time like a brand red-hot down on her (Morel) soul; and each time she (Morel) enacted again the past hour, each time the brand came down at the same points, till the mark was burnt in, and the pain burnt out, and at last she (Morel) came to herself. She (Morel) must have been half an hour in this delirious condition. Then the presence of the night came again to her (Morel). She (Morel) glanced round in fear. She (Morel) had wandered to the side garden, where she (Morel) was walking up and down the path beside the currant bushes under the long wall. The garden was a narrow strip, bounded from the road, that cut transversely between the blocks, by a thick thorn hedge.

She (Morel) hurried out of the side garden to the front, where she (Morel) could stand as if in an immense gulf of white light, the moon streaming high in face of her (Morel), the moonlight standing up from the hills in front, and filling the valley where the Bottoms crouched, almost blindingly. There, panting and half weeping in reaction from the stress, she (Morel) murmured to herself over and over again:

``The nuisance! the nuisance!'' (she)

She (Morel) became aware of something about her (Morel). With an effort she (Morel) roused herself to see what it was that penetrated her (Morel) consciousness. The tall white lilies were reeling in the moonlight, and the air was charged with their perfume, as with a presence. Mrs. Morel gasped slightly in fear. She (Morel) touched the big, pallid flowers on their petals, then shivered. They seemed to be stretching in the moonlight. She (Morel) put her (Morel) hand into one white bin: the gold scarcely showed on her (Morel) fingers by moonlight. She (Morel) bent down to look at the binful of yellow pollen; but it only appeared dusky. Then she (Morel) drank a deep draught of the scent. It almost made her (Morel) dizzy.

Mrs. Morel leaned on the garden gate, looking out, and she (Morel) lost herself awhile. She (Morel) did not know what she (Morel) thought. Except for a slight feeling of sickness, and her (Morel) consciousness in the child, herself melted out like scent into the shiny, pale air. After a time the child, too, melted with her (Morel) in the mixing-pot of moonlight, and she (Morel) rested with the hills and lilies and houses, all swum together in a kind of swoon.

When she (Morel) came to herself she (Morel) was tired for sleep. Languidly she (Morel) looked about her (Morel); the clumps of white phlox seemed like bushes spread with linen; a moth ricochetted over them, and right across the garden. Following it with her (Morel) eye roused her (Morel). A few whiffs of the raw, strong scent of phlox invigorated her (Morel). She (Morel) passed along the path, hesitating at the white rose-bush. It smelled sweet and simple. She (Morel) touched the white ruffles of the roses. Their fresh scent and cool, soft leaves reminded her (Morel) of the morning-time and sunshine. She (Morel) was very fond of them. But she (Morel) was tired, and wanted to sleep. In the mysterious out-of-doors she (Morel) felt forlorn.

There was no noise anywhere. Evidently the children had not been wakened, or had gone to sleep again. A train, three miles away, roared across the valley. The night was very large, and very strange, stretching its hoary distances infinitely. And out of the silver-grey fog of darkness came sounds vague and hoarse: a corncrake not far off, sound of a train like a sigh, and distant shouts of men.

Her (Morel) quietened heart beginning to beat quickly again, she (Morel) hurried down the side garden to the back of the house. Softly she (Morel) lifted the latch; the door was still bolted, and hard against her (Morel). She (Morel) rapped gently, waited, then rapped again. She (Morel) must not rouse the children, nor the neighbours. He (Morel) must be asleep, and he (Morel) would not wake easily. Her (Morel) heart began to burn to be indoors. She (Morel) clung to the door-handle. Now it was cold; she (Morel) would take a chill, and in her (Morel) present condition!

Putting her (Morel) apron over her (Morel) head and her (Morel) arms, she (Morel) hurried again to the side garden, to the window of the kitchen. Leaning on the sill, she (Morel) could just see, under the blind, her (Morel) husband's arms spread out on the table, and his (husband) black head on the board. He (husband) was sleeping with his (husband) face lying on the table. Something in his (husband) attitude made her (Morel) feel tired of things. The lamp was burning smokily; she (Morel) could tell by the copper colour of the light. She (Morel) tapped at the window more and more noisily. Almost it seemed as if the glass would break. Still he (husband) did not wake up.

After vain efforts, she (Morel) began to shiver, partly from contact with the stone, and from exhaustion. Fearful always for the unborn child, she (Morel) wondered what she (Morel) could do for warmth. She (Morel) went down to the coal-house, where there was an old hearthrug she (Morel) had carried out for the rag-man the day before. This she (Morel) wrapped over her (Morel) shoulders. It was warm, if grimy. Then she (Morel) walked up and down the garden path, peeping every now and then under the blind, knocking, and telling herself that in the end the very strain of his (Morel) position must wake him (Morel).

At last, after about an hour, she (Morel) rapped long and low at the window. Gradually the sound penetrated to him (Morel). When, in despair, she (Morel) had ceased to tap, she (Morel) saw him (Morel) stir, then lift his (Morel) face blindly. The labouring of his (Morel) heart hurt him (Morel) into consciousness. She (Morel) rapped imperatively at the window. He (Morel) started awake. Instantly she (Morel) saw his (Morel) fists set and his (Morel) eyes glare. He (Morel) had not a grain of physical fear. If it had been twenty burglars, he (Morel) would have gone blindly for them. He (Morel) glared round, bewildered, but prepared to fight.

``Open the door, Walter,'' (she)
she (Morel) said coldly.

His (Morel) hands relaxed. It dawned on him (Morel) what he (Morel) had done. His (Morel) head dropped, sullen and dogged. She (Morel) saw him (Morel) hurry to the door, heard the bolt chock. He (Morel) tried the latch. It opened--and there stood the silver-grey night, fearful to him (Morel), after the tawny light of the lamp. He (Morel) hurried back.

When Mrs. Morel entered, she (Morel) saw him (Morel) almost running through the door to the stairs. He (Morel) had ripped his (Morel) collar off his (Morel) neck in his (Morel) haste to be gone ere she (Morel) came in, and there it lay with bursten button-holes. It made her (Morel) angry.

She (Morel) warmed and soothed herself. In her (Morel) weariness forgetting everything, she (Morel) moved about at the little tasks that remained to be done, set his (Morel) breakfast, rinsed his (Morel) pit-bottle, put his (Morel) pit-clothes on the hearth to warm, set his (Morel) pit-boots beside them, put him (Morel) out a clean scarf and snap-bag and two apples, raked the fire, and went to bed. He (Morel) was already dead asleep. His (Morel) narrow black eyebrows were drawn up in a sort of peevish misery into his (Morel) forehead while his (Morel) cheeks' down-strokes, and his (Morel) sulky mouth, seemed to be saying:

``I don't care who you are nor what you are, I SHALL have my own way.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel knew him (Morel) too well to look at him (Morel). As she (Morel) unfastened her (Morel) brooch at the mirror, she (Morel) smiled faintly to see her (Morel) face all smeared with the yellow dust of lilies. She (Morel) brushed it off, and at last lay down. For some time her (Morel) mind continued snapping and jetting sparks, but she (Morel) was asleep before her (Morel) husband awoke from the first sleep of his (husband) drunkenness.

CHAPTER II

THE BIRTH OF PAUL, AND ANOTHER BATTLE

AFTER such a scene as the last, Walter Morel was for some days abashed and ashamed, but he (Morel) soon regained his (Morel) old bullying indifference. Yet there was a slight shrinking, a diminishing in his (Morel) assurance. Physically even, he (Morel) shrank, and his (Morel) fine full presence waned. He (Morel) never grew in the least stout, so that, as he (Morel) sank from his (Morel) erect, assertive bearing, his (Morel) physique seemed to contract along with his (Morel) pride and moral strength.

But now he (Morel) realised how hard it was for his (Morel) wife to drag about at her (wife) work, and, his (Morel) sympathy quickened by penitence, hastened forward with his (Morel) help. He (Morel) came straight home from the pit, and stayed in at evening till Friday, and then he (Morel) could not remain at home. But he (Morel) was back again by ten o'clock, almost quite sober.

He (Morel) always made his (Morel) own breakfast. Being a man who rose early and had plenty of time he (Morel) did not, as some miners do, drag his (Morel) wife out of bed at six o'clock. At five, sometimes earlier, he (Morel) woke, got straight out of bed, and went downstairs. When she (wife) could not sleep, his (Morel) wife lay waiting for this time, as for a period of peace. The only real rest seemed to be when he (Morel) was out of the house.

He (Morel) went downstairs in his (Morel) shirt and then struggled into his (Morel) pit-trousers, which were left on the hearth to warm all night. There was always a fire, because Mrs. Morel raked. And the first sound in the house was the bang, bang of the poker against the raker, as Morel smashed the remainder of the coal to make the kettle, which was filled and left on the hob, finally boil. His (Morel) cup and knife and fork, all he (Morel) wanted except just the food, was laid ready on the table on a newspaper. Then he (Morel) got his (Morel) breakfast, made the tea, packed the bottom of the doors with rugs to shut out the draught, piled a big fire, and sat down to an hour of joy. He (Morel) toasted his (Morel) bacon on a fork and caught the drops of fat on his (Morel) bread; then he (Morel) put the rasher on his (Morel) thick slice of bread, and cut off chunks with a clasp-knife, poured his (Morel) tea into his (Morel) saucer, and was happy. With his (Morel) family about, meals were never so pleasant. He (Morel) loathed a fork: it is a modern introduction which has still scarcely reached common people. What Morel preferred was a clasp-knife. Then, in solitude, he (Morel) ate and drank, often sitting, in cold weather, on a little stool with his (Morel) back to the warm chimney-piece, his (Morel) food on the fender, his (Morel) cup on the hearth. And then he (Morel) read the last night's newspaper--what of it he (Morel) could--spelling it over laboriously. He (Morel) preferred to keep the blinds down and the candle lit even when it was daylight; it was the habit of the mine.

At a quarter to six he (Morel) rose, cut two thick slices of bread and butter, and put them in the white calico snap-bag. He (calico) filled his (calico) tin bottle with tea. Cold tea without milk or sugar was the drink he (calico) preferred for the pit. Then he (calico) pulled off his (calico) shirt, and put on his (calico) pit-singlet, a vest of thick flannel cut low round the neck, and with short sleeves like a chemise.

Then he (calico) went upstairs to his (calico) wife with a cup of tea because she (wife) was ill, and because it occurred to him (calico).

``I've brought thee a cup o' tea, lass,'' (he)
he (calico) said.

``Well, you needn't, for you know I don't like it,'' (she)
she (wife) replied.

``Drink it up; it'll pop thee off to sleep again.'' (She)

She (wife) accepted the tea. It pleased him (calico) to see her (wife) take it and sip it.

``I'll back my life there's no sugar in,'' (she)
she (wife) said.

``Yi--there's one big `un,'' (he)
he (calico) replied, injured.

``It's a wonder,'' (she)
she (wife) said, sipping again.

She (wife) had a winsome face when her (wife) hair was loose. He (calico) loved her (wife) to grumble at him (calico) in this manner. He (calico) looked at her (wife) again, and went, without any sort of leave-taking. He (calico) never took more than two slices of bread and butter to eat in the pit, so an apple or an orange was a treat to him (calico). He (calico) always liked it when she (wife) put one out for him (calico). He (calico) tied a scarf round his (calico) neck, put on his (calico) great, heavy boots, his (calico) coat, with the big pocket, that carried his (calico) snap-bag and his (calico) bottle of tea, and went forth into the fresh morning air, closing, without locking, the door behind him (calico). He (calico) loved the early morning, and the walk across the fields. So he (calico) appeared at the pit-top, often with a stalk from the hedge between his (calico) teeth, which he (calico) chewed all day to keep his (calico) mouth moist, down the mine, feeling quite as happy as when he (calico) was in the field.

Later, when the time for the baby grew nearer, he (calico) would bustle round in his (calico) slovenly fashion, poking out the ashes, rubbing the fireplace, sweeping the house before he (calico) went to work. Then, feeling very self-righteous, he (calico) went upstairs.

``Now I'm cleaned up for thee: tha's no `casions ter stir a peg all day, but sit and read thy books.'' (her)

Which made her (calico) laugh, in spite of her (calico) indignation.

``And the dinner cooks itself?'' (she)
she (calico) answered.

``Eh, I know nowt about th' dinner.'' (unknown)

``You'd know if there weren't any.'' (unknown)

``Ay, `appen so,'' (he)
he (calico) answered, departing.

When she (calico) got downstairs, she (calico) would find the house tidy, but dirty. She (calico) could not rest until she (calico) had thoroughly cleaned; so she (calico) went down to the ash-pit with her (calico) dustpan. Mrs. Kirk, spying her (Kirk), would contrive to have to go to her (Kirk) own coal-place at that minute. Then, across the wooden fence, she (Kirk) would call:

``So you keep wagging on, then?'' (she)

``Ay,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
answered Mrs. Morel deprecatingly.
``There's nothing else for it.'' (unknown)

``Have you seen Hose?'' (a woman)
called a very small woman from across the road. It was Mrs. Anthony, a black-haired, strange little body, who always wore a brown velvet dress, tight fitting.

``I haven't,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Eh, I wish he (thy)'d come. I've got a copperful of clothes, an' I'm sure I heered his (thy) bell.'' (unknown)

``Hark! He (thy)'s at the end.'' (The women)

The two women looked down the alley. At the end of the Bottoms a man stood in a sort of old-fashioned trap, bending over bundles of cream-coloured stuff; while a cluster of women held up their arms to him (man), some with bundles. Mrs. Anthony herself had a heap of creamy, undyed stockings hanging over her (Anthony) arm.

``I've done ten dozen this week,'' (she)
she (Anthony) said proudly to Mrs. Morel.

``T-t-t!'' (unknown)
went the other.
``I don't know how you can find time.'' (unknown)

``Eh!'' (Mrs. Anthony/Anthony)
said Mrs. Anthony.
``You can find time if you make time.'' (unknown)

``I don't know how you do it,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``And how much shall you get for those many?'' (unknown)

``Tuppence-ha`penny a dozen,'' (unknown)
replied the other.

``Well,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``I'd starve before I'd sit down and seam twenty-four stockings for twopence ha`penny.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't know,'' (Mrs. Anthony/Anthony)
said Mrs. Anthony.
``You can rip along with 'em.'' (unknown)

Hose was coming along, ringing his (man) bell. Women were waiting at the yard-ends with their seamed stockings hanging over their arms. The man, a common fellow, made jokes with them, tried to swindle them, and bullied them. Mrs. Morel went up her (Morel) yard disdainfully.

It was an understood thing that if one woman wanted her (woman) neighbour, she (woman) should put the poker in the fire and bang at the back of the fireplace, which, as the fires were back to back, would make a great noise in the adjoining house. One morning Mrs. Kirk, mixing a pudding, nearly started out of her (Kirk) skin as she (Kirk) heard the thud, thud, in her (Kirk) grate. With her (Kirk) hands all floury, she (Kirk) rushed to the fence.

``Did you knock, Mrs. Morel?'' (unknown)

``If you wouldn't mind, Mrs. Kirk.'' (Mrs. Kirk)

Mrs. Kirk climbed on to her (Kirk) copper, got over the wall on to Mrs. Morel's copper, and ran in to her (Morel) neighbour.

``Eh, dear, how are you feeling?'' (she)
she (Morel) cried in concern.

``You might fetch Mrs. Bower,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

Mrs. Kirk went into the yard, lifted up her (Morel) strong, shrill voice, and called:

``Ag-gie--Ag-gie!'' (Mrs. Kirk)

The sound was heard from one end of the Bottoms to the other. At last Aggie came running up, and was sent for Mrs. Bower, whilst Mrs. Kirk left her (Kirk) pudding and stayed with her (Kirk) neighbour.

Mrs. Morel went to bed. Mrs. Kirk had Annie and William for dinner. Mrs. Bower, fat and waddling, bossed the house.

``Hash some cold meat up for the master's dinner, and make him (master) an apple-charlotte pudding,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``He (master) may go without pudding this day,'' (Mrs. Bower)
said Mrs. Bower.

Morel was not as a rule one of the first to appear at the bottom of the pit, ready to come up. Some men were there before four o'clock, when the whistle blew loose-all; but Morel, whose stall, a poor one, was at this time about a mile and a half away from the bottom, worked usually till the first mate stopped, then he (mate) finished also. This day, however, the miner was sick of the work. At two o'clock he (mate) looked at his (mate) watch, by the light of the green candle--he (mate) was in a safe working--and again at half-past two. He (mate) was hewing at a piece of rock that was in the way for the next day's work. As he (mate) sat on his (mate) heels, or kneeled, giving hard blows with his (mate) pick,

``Uszza--uszza!'' (he)
he (mate) went.

``Shall ter finish, Sorry?'' (Barker)
cried Barker, his (mate) fellow butty.

``Finish? Niver while the world stands!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
growled Morel.

And he (mate) went on striking. He (mate) was tired.

``It's a heart-breaking job,'' (Barker)
said Barker.

But Morel was too exasperated, at the end of his (Barker) tether, to answer. Still he (Barker) struck and hacked with all his (Barker) might.

``Tha might as well leave it, Walter,'' (Barker)
said Barker.
``It'll do to-morrow, without thee hackin' thy guts out.'' (unknown)

``I'll lay no b-- finger on this to-morrow, Isr`el!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Morel.

``Oh, well, if tha wunna, somebody else'll ha'e to,'' (unknown)
said Israel.

Then Morel continued to strike.

``Hey-up there--LOOSE-A'!'' (the men)
cried the men, leaving the next stall.

Morel continued to strike.

``Tha'll happen catch me up,'' (Barker)
said Barker, departing.
