When he (Barker) had gone, Morel, left alone, felt savage. He (Barker) had not finished his (Barker) job. He (Barker) had overworked himself into a frenzy. Rising, wet with sweat, he (Barker) threw his (Barker) tool down, pulled on his (Barker) coat, blew out his (Barker) candle, took his (Barker) lamp, and went. Down the main road the lights of the other men went swinging. There was a hollow sound of many voices. It was a long, heavy tramp underground.

He (tramp) sat at the bottom of the pit, where the great drops of water fell plash. Many colliers were waiting their turns to go up, talking noisily. Morel gave his (tramp) answers short and disagreeable.

``It's rainin', Sorry,'' (Giles)
said old Giles, who had had the news from the top.

Morel found one comfort. He (Giles) had his (Giles) old umbrella, which he (Giles) loved, in the lamp cabin. At last he (Giles) took his (Giles) stand on the chair, and was at the top in a moment. Then he (Giles) handed in his (Giles) lamp and got his (Giles) umbrella, which he (Giles) had bought at an auction for one-and-six. He (Giles) stood on the edge of the pit-bank for a moment, looking out over the fields; grey rain was falling. The trucks stood full of wet, bright coal. Water ran down the sides of the waggons, over the white

``C.W. and Co.'' (unknown)
. Colliers, walking indifferent to the rain, were streaming down the line and up the field, a grey, dismal host. Morel put up his (Giles) umbrella, and took pleasure from the peppering of the drops thereon.

All along the road to Bestwood the miners tramped, wet and grey and dirty, but their red mouths talking with animation. Morel also walked with a gang, but he (Giles) said nothing. He (Giles) frowned peevishly as he (Giles) went. Many men passed into the Prince of Wales or into Ellen's. Morel, feeling sufficiently disagreeable to resist temptation, trudged along under the dripping trees that overhung the park wall, and down the mud of Greenhill Lane.

Mrs. Morel lay in bed, listening to the rain, and the feet of the colliers from Minton, their voices, and the bang, bang of the gates as they went through the stile up the field.

``There's some herb beer behind the pantry door,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``Th' master'll want a drink, if he (master) doesn't stop.'' (he)

But he (Minton) was late, so she (Morel) concluded he (Minton) had called for a drink, since it was raining. What did he (Minton) care about the child or her (Morel)?

She (Morel) was very ill when her (Morel) children were born.

``What is it?'' (she)
she (Morel) asked, feeling sick to death.

``A boy.'' (she)

And she (Morel) took consolation in that. The thought of being the mother of men was warming to her (Morel) heart. She (Morel) looked at the child. It had blue eyes, and a lot of fair hair, and was bonny. Her (Morel) love came up hot, in spite of everything. She (Morel) had it in bed with her (Morel).

Morel, thinking nothing, dragged his (Minton) way up the garden path, wearily and angrily. He (Minton) closed his (Minton) umbrella, and stood it in the sink; then he (Minton) sluthered his (Minton) heavy boots into the kitchen. Mrs. Bower appeared in the inner doorway.

``Well,'' (she)
she (Bower) said,
``she (boy)'s about as bad as she (boy) can be. It's a boy childt.'' (she)

The miner grunted, put his (Minton) empty snap-bag and his (Minton) tin bottle on the dresser, went back into the scullery and hung up his (Minton) coat, then came and dropped into his (Minton) chair.

``Han yer got a drink?'' (he)
he (Minton) asked.

The woman went into the pantry. There was heard the pop of a cork. She (woman) set the mug, with a little, disgusted rap, on the table before Morel. He (Minton) drank, gasped, wiped his (Minton) big moustache on the end of his (Minton) scarf, drank, gasped, and lay back in his (Minton) chair. The woman would not speak to him (Minton) again. She (woman) set his (Minton) dinner before him (Minton), and went upstairs.

``Was that the master?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
asked Mrs. Morel.

``I've gave him (master) his (master) dinner,'' (Mrs. Bower)
replied Mrs. Bower.

After he (Minton) had sat with his (Minton) arms on the table--he (Minton) resented the fact that Mrs. Bower put no cloth on for him (Minton), and gave him (Minton) a little plate, instead of a full-sized dinner-plate--he (Minton) began to eat. The fact that his (Minton) wife was ill, that he (Minton) had another boy, was nothing to him (Minton) at that moment. He (Minton) was too tired; he (Minton) wanted his (Minton) dinner; he (Minton) wanted to sit with his (Minton) arms lying on the board; he (Minton) did not like having Mrs. Bower about. The fire was too small to please him (Minton).

After he (Minton) had finished his (Minton) meal, he (Minton) sat for twenty minutes; then he (Minton) stoked up a big fire. Then, in his (Minton) stockinged feet, he (Minton) went reluctantly upstairs. It was a struggle to face his (Minton) wife at this moment, and he (Minton) was tired. His (Minton) face was black, and smeared with sweat. His (Minton) singlet had dried again, soaking the dirt in. He (Minton) had a dirty woollen scarf round his (Minton) throat. So he (Minton) stood at the foot of the bed.

``Well, how are ter, then?'' (he)
he (Minton) asked.

``I s'll be all right,'' (she)
she (wife) answered.

``H'm!'' (He)

He (Minton) stood at a loss what to say next. He (Minton) was tired, and this bother was rather a nuisance to him (Minton), and he (Minton) didn't quite know where he (Minton) was.

``A lad, tha says,'' (he)
he (Minton) stammered.

She (wife) turned down the sheet and showed the child.

``Bless him (lad)!'' (he)
he (Minton) murmured. Which made her (wife) laugh, because he (Minton) blessed by rote--pretending paternal emotion, which he (Minton) did not feel just then.

``Go now,'' (she)
she (wife) said.

``I will, my lass,'' (he)
he (Minton) answered, turning away.

Dismissed, he (Minton) wanted to kiss her (wife), but he (Minton) dared not. She (wife) half wanted him (Minton) to kiss her (wife), but could not bring herself to give any sign. She (wife) only breathed freely when he (Minton) was gone out of the room again, leaving behind him (Minton) a faint smell of pit-dirt.

Mrs. Morel had a visit every day from the Congregational clergyman. Mr. Heaton was young, and very poor. His (Heaton) wife had died at the birth of his (Heaton) first baby, so he (Heaton) remained alone in the manse. He (Heaton) was a Bachelor of Arts of Cambridge, very shy, and no preacher. Mrs. Morel was fond of him (preacher), and he (preacher) depended on her (Morel). For hours he (preacher) talked to her (Morel), when she (Morel) was well. He (preacher) became the god-parent of the child.

Occasionally the minister stayed to tea with Mrs. Morel. Then she (Morel) laid the cloth early, got out her (Morel) best cups, with a little green rim, and hoped Morel would not come too soon; indeed, if he (minister) stayed for a pint, she (Morel) would not mind this day. She (Morel) had always two dinners to cook, because she (Morel) believed children should have their chief meal at midday, whereas Morel needed his (minister) at five o'clock. So Mr. Heaton would hold the baby, whilst Mrs. Morel beat up a batter-pudding or peeled the potatoes, and he (Heaton), watching her (Morel) all the time, would discuss his (Heaton) next sermon. His (Heaton) ideas were quaint and fantastic. She (Morel) brought him (Heaton) judiciously to earth. It was a discussion of the wedding at Cana.

``When He (lad) changed the water into wine at Cana,'' (he)
he (Heaton) said,
``that is a symbol that the ordinary life, even the blood, of the married husband and wife, which had before been uninspired, like water, became filled with the Spirit, and was as wine, because, when love enters, the whole spiritual constitution of a man changes, is filled with the Holy Ghost, and almost his (man) form is altered.'' (he)

Mrs. Morel thought to herself:

``Yes, poor fellow, his (man) young wife is dead; that is why he (man) makes his (man) love into the Holy Ghost.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

They were halfway down their first cup of tea when they heard the sluther of pit-boots.

``Good gracious!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
exclaimed Mrs. Morel, in spite of herself.

The minister looked rather scared. Morel entered. He (minister) was feeling rather savage. He (minister) nodded a

``How d'yer do'' (He)
to the clergyman, who rose to shake hands with him (minister).

``Nay,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel, showing his (minister) hand,
``look thee at it! Tha niver wants ter shake hands wi' a hand like that, does ter? There's too much pick-haft and shovel-dirt on it.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

The minister flushed with confusion, and sat down again. Mrs. Morel rose, carried out the steaming saucepan. Morel took off his (minister) coat, dragged his (minister) armchair to table, and sat down heavily.

``Are you tired?'' (the clergyman)
asked the clergyman.

``Tired? I ham that,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Morel. ``YOU don't know what it is to be tired, as I
``M tired.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (the clergyman)
replied the clergyman.

``Why, look yer `ere,'' (the miner)
said the miner, showing the shoulders of his (clergyman) singlet.
``It's a bit dry now, but it's wet as a clout with sweat even yet. Feel it.'' (unknown)

``Goodness!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Mrs. Morel.
``Mr. Heaton doesn't want to feel your nasty singlet.'' (The clergyman)

The clergyman put out his (clergyman) hand gingerly.

``No, perhaps he (Heaton) doesn't,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel; ``but it's all come out of me, whether or not. An' iv`ry day alike my singlet's wringin' wet.
``Aven't you got a drink, Missis, for a man when he (man) comes home barkled up from the pit?'' (unknown)

``You know you drank all the beer,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, pouring out his (clergyman) tea.

``An' was there no more to be got?'' (the clergyman)
Turning to the clergyman--
``A man gets that caked up wi' th' dust, you know,--that clogged up down a coal-mine, he (man) NEEDS a drink when he (man) comes home.'' (the clergyman)

``I am sure he (man) does,'' (the clergyman)
said the clergyman.

``But it's ten to one if there's owt for him (man).'' (unknown)

``There's water--and there's tea,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Water! It's not water as'll clear his (man) throat.'' (He)

He (clergyman) poured out a saucerful of tea, blew it, and sucked it up through his (clergyman) great black moustache, sighing afterwards. Then he (clergyman) poured out another saucerful, and stood his (clergyman) cup on the table.

``My cloth!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, putting it on a plate.

``A man as comes home as I do 's too tired to care about cloths,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.

``Pity!'' (wife)
exclaimed his (clergyman) wife, sarcastically.

The room was full of the smell of meat and vegetables and pit-clothes.

He (clergyman) leaned over to the minister, his (clergyman) great moustache thrust forward, his (clergyman) mouth very red in his (clergyman) black face.

``Mr. Heaton,'' (he)
he (clergyman) said,
``a man as has been down the black hole all day, dingin' away at a coal-face, yi, a sight harder than that wall--'' (he)

``Needn't make a moan of it,'' (he)
put in Mrs. Morel.

She (Morel) hated her (Morel) husband because, whenever he (clergyman) had an audience, he (clergyman) whined and played for sympathy. William, sitting nursing the baby, hated him (William), with a boy's hatred for false sentiment, and for the stupid treatment of his (William) mother. Annie had never liked him (William); she (Annie) merely avoided him (William).

When the minister had gone, Mrs. Morel looked at her (Morel) cloth.

``A fine mess!'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

``Dos't think I'm goin' to sit wi' my arms danglin', cos tha's got a parson for tea wi' thee?'' (he)
he (minister) bawled.

They were both angry, but she (Morel) said nothing. The baby began to cry, and Mrs. Morel, picking up a saucepan from the hearth, accidentally knocked Annie on the head, whereupon the girl began to whine, and Morel to shout at her (Morel). In the midst of this pandemonium, William looked up at the big glazed text over the mantelpiece and read distinctly:

``God Bless Our Home!'' (William)

Whereupon Mrs. Morel, trying to soothe the baby, jumped up, rushed at him (William), boxed his (William) ears, saying:

``What are YOU putting in for?'' (him)

And then she (Morel) sat down and laughed, till tears ran over her (Morel) cheeks, while William kicked the stool he (William) had been sitting on, and Morel growled:

``I canna see what there is so much to laugh at.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

One evening, directly after the parson's visit, feeling unable to bear herself after another display from her (Morel) husband, she (Morel) took Annie and the baby and went out. Morel had kicked William, and the mother would never forgive him (William).

She (Morel) went over the sheep-bridge and across a corner of the meadow to the cricket-ground. The meadows seemed one space of ripe, evening light, whispering with the distant mill-race. She (Morel) sat on a seat under the alders in the cricket-ground, and fronted the evening. Before her (Morel), level and solid, spread the big green cricket-field, like the bed of a sea of light. Children played in the bluish shadow of the pavilion. Many rooks, high up, came cawing home across the softly-woven sky. They stooped in a long curve down into the golden glow, concentrating, cawing, wheeling, like black flakes on a slow vortex, over a tree clump that made a dark boss among the pasture.

A few gentlemen were practising, and Mrs. Morel could hear the chock of the ball, and the voices of men suddenly roused; could see the white forms of men shifting silently over the green, upon which already the under shadows were smouldering. Away at the grange, one side of the haystacks was lit up, the other sides blue-grey. A waggon of sheaves rocked small across the melting yellow light.

The sun was going down. Every open evening, the hills of Derbyshire were blazed over with red sunset. Mrs. Morel watched the sun sink from the glistening sky, leaving a soft flower-blue overhead, while the western space went red, as if all the fire had swum down there, leaving the bell cast flawless blue. The mountain-ash berries across the field stood fierily out from the dark leaves, for a moment. A few shocks of corn in a corner of the fallow stood up as if alive; she (Morel) imagined them bowing; perhaps her (Morel) son would be a Joseph. In the east, a mirrored sunset floated pink opposite the west's scarlet. The big haystacks on the hillside, that butted into the glare, went cold.

With Mrs. Morel it was one of those still moments when the small frets vanish, and the beauty of things stands out, and she (Morel) had the peace and the strength to see herself. Now and again, a swallow cut close to her (Morel). Now and again, Annie came up with a handful of alder-currants. The baby was restless on his (Joseph) mother's knee, clambering with his (Joseph) hands at the light.

Mrs. Morel looked down at him (Joseph). She (Morel) had dreaded this baby like a catastrophe, because of her (Morel) feeling for her (Morel) husband. And now she (Morel) felt strangely towards the infant. Her (Morel) heart was heavy because of the child, almost as if it were unhealthy, or malformed. Yet it seemed quite well. But she (Morel) noticed the peculiar knitting of the baby's brows, and the peculiar heaviness of its eyes, as if it were trying to understand something that was pain. She (Morel) felt, when she (Morel) looked at her (Morel) child's dark, brooding pupils, as if a burden were on her (Morel) heart.

``He (God) looks as if he (God) was thinking about something--quite sorrowful,'' (Mrs. Kirk)
said Mrs. Kirk.

Suddenly, looking at him (husband), the heavy feeling at the mother's heart melted into passionate grief. She (Kirk) bowed over him (husband), and a few tears shook swiftly out of her (Kirk) very heart. The baby lifted his (husband) fingers.

``My lamb!'' (she)
she (Kirk) cried softly.

And at that moment she (Kirk) felt, in some far inner place of her (Kirk) soul, that she (Kirk) and her (Kirk) husband were guilty.

The baby was looking up at her (Kirk). It had blue eyes like her (Kirk) own, but its look was heavy, steady, as if it had realised something that had stunned some point of its soul.

In her (Kirk) arms lay the delicate baby. Its deep blue eyes, always looking up at her (Kirk) unblinking, seemed to draw her (Kirk) innermost thoughts out of her (Kirk). She (Kirk) no longer loved her (Kirk) husband; she (Kirk) had not wanted this child to come, and there it lay in her (Kirk) arms and pulled at her (Kirk) heart. She (Kirk) felt as if the navel string that had connected its frail little body with hers had not been broken. A wave of hot love went over her (Kirk) to the infant. She (Kirk) held it close to her (Kirk) face and breast. With all her (Kirk) force, with all her (Kirk) soul she (Kirk) would make up to it for having brought it into the world unloved. She (Kirk) would love it all the more now it was here; carry it in her (Kirk) love. Its clear, knowing eyes gave her (Kirk) pain and fear. Did it know all about her (Kirk)? When it lay under her (Kirk) heart, had it been listening then? Was there a reproach in the look? She (Kirk) felt the marrow melt in her (Kirk) bones, with fear and pain.

Once more she (Kirk) was aware of the sun lying red on the rim of the hill opposite. She (Kirk) suddenly held up the child in her (Kirk) hands.

``Look!'' (she)
she (Kirk) said.
``Look, my pretty!'' (She)

She (Kirk) thrust the infant forward to the crimson, throbbing sun, almost with relief. She (Kirk) saw him (Kirk) lift his (Kirk) little fist. Then she (Kirk) put him (Kirk) to her (Kirk) bosom again, ashamed almost of her (Kirk) impulse to give him (Kirk) back again whence he (Kirk) came.

``If he (God) lives,'' (she)
she (Kirk) thought to herself,
``what will become of him (God)--what will he (God) be?'' (she)

Her (Kirk) heart was anxious.

``I will call him (God) Paul,'' (she)
she (Kirk) said suddenly; she (Kirk) knew not why.

After a while she (Kirk) went home. A fine shadow was flung over the deep green meadow, darkening all.

As she (Kirk) expected, she (Kirk) found the house empty. But Morel was home by ten o'clock, and that day, at least, ended peacefully.

Walter Morel was, at this time, exceedingly irritable. His (Morel) work seemed to exhaust him (Morel). When he (Morel) came home he (Morel) did not speak civilly to anybody. If the fire were rather low he (Morel) bullied about that; he (Morel) grumbled about his (Morel) dinner; if the children made a chatter he (Morel) shouted at them in a way that made their mother's blood boil, and made them hate him (Morel).

On the Friday, he (Morel) was not home by eleven o'clock. The baby was unwell, and was restless, crying if he (Morel) were put down. Mrs. Morel, tired to death, and still weak, was scarcely under control.

``I wish the nuisance would come,'' (she)
she (Morel) said wearily to herself.

The child at last sank down to sleep in her (Morel) arms. She (Morel) was too tired to carry him (Morel) to the cradle.

``But I'll say nothing, whatever time he (God) comes,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``It only works me up; I won't say anything. But I know if he (God) does anything it'll make my blood boil,'' (she)
she (Morel) added to herself.

She (Morel) sighed, hearing him (Morel) coming, as if it were something she (Morel) could not bear. He (Morel), taking his (Morel) revenge, was nearly drunk. She (Morel) kept her (Morel) head bent over the child as he (Morel) entered, not wishing to see him (Morel). But it went through her (Morel) like a flash of hot fire when, in passing, he (Morel) lurched against the dresser, setting the tins rattling, and clutched at the white pot knobs for support. He (Morel) hung up his (Morel) hat and coat, then returned, stood glowering from a distance at her (Morel), as she (Morel) sat bowed over the child.

``Is there nothing to eat in the house?'' (he)
he (Morel) asked, insolently, as if to a servant. In certain stages of his (Morel) intoxication he (Morel) affected the clipped, mincing speech of the towns. Mrs. Morel hated him (Morel) most in this condition.

``You know what there is in the house,'' (she)
she (Morel) said, so coldly, it sounded impersonal.

He (Morel) stood and glared at her (Morel) without moving a muscle.

``I asked a civil question, and I expect a civil answer,'' (he)
he (Morel) said affectedly.

``And you got it,'' (she)
she (Morel) said, still ignoring him (Morel).

He (Morel) glowered again. Then he (Morel) came unsteadily forward. He (Morel) leaned on the table with one hand, and with the other jerked at the table drawer to get a knife to cut bread. The drawer stuck because he (Morel) pulled sideways. In a temper he (Morel) dragged it, so that it flew out bodily, and spoons, forks, knives, a hundred metallic things, splashed with a clatter and a clang upon the brick floor. The baby gave a little convulsed start.

``What are you doing, clumsy, drunken fool?'' (the mother)
the mother cried.

``Then tha should get the flamin' thing thysen. Tha should get up, like other women have to, an' wait on a man.'' (unknown)

``Wait on you--wait on you?'' (she)
she (mother) cried.
``Yes, I see myself.'' (unknown)

``Yis, an' I'll learn thee tha's got to. Wait on ME, yes tha sh`lt wait on me--'' (unknown)

``Never, milord. I'd wait on a dog at the door first.'' (unknown)

``What--what?'' (He)

He (Morel) was trying to fit in the drawer. At her (mother) last speech he (Morel) turned round. His (Morel) face was crimson, his (Morel) eyes bloodshot. He (Morel) stared at her (mother) one silent second in threat.

``P-h!'' (she)
she (mother) went quickly, in contempt.

He (Morel) jerked at the drawer in his (Morel) excitement. It fell, cut sharply on his (Morel) shin, and on the reflex he (Morel) flung it at her (mother).

One of the corners caught her (mother) brow as the shallow drawer crashed into the fireplace. She (mother) swayed, almost fell stunned from her (mother) chair. To her (mother) very soul she (mother) was sick; she (mother) clasped the child tightly to her (mother) bosom. A few moments elapsed; then, with an effort, she (mother) brought herself to. The baby was crying plaintively. Her (mother) left brow was bleeding rather profusely. As she (mother) glanced down at the child, her (mother) brain reeling, some drops of blood soaked into its white shawl; but the baby was at least not hurt. She (mother) balanced her (mother) head to keep equilibrium, so that the blood ran into her (mother) eye.

Walter Morel remained as he (Morel) had stood, leaning on the table with one hand, looking blank. When he (Morel) was sufficiently sure of his (Morel) balance, he (Morel) went across to her (mother), swayed, caught hold of the back of her (mother) rocking-chair, almost tipping her (mother) out; then leaning forward over her (mother), and swaying as he (Morel) spoke, he (Morel) said, in a tone of wondering concern:

``Did it catch thee?'' (he)

He (Morel) swayed again, as if he (Morel) would pitch on to the child. With the catastrophe he (Morel) had lost all balance.

``Go away,'' (she)
she (mother) said, struggling to keep her (mother) presence of mind.

He (Morel) hiccoughed.

``Let's--let's look at it,'' (he)
he (Morel) said, hiccoughing again.

``Go away!'' (she)
she (mother) cried.

``Lemme--lemme look at it, lass.'' (She)

She (mother) smelled him (Morel) of drink, felt the unequal pull of his (Morel) swaying grasp on the back of her (mother) rocking-chair.

``Go away,'' (she)
she (mother) said, and weakly she (mother) pushed him (Morel) off.

He (Morel) stood, uncertain in balance, gazing upon her (mother). Summoning all her (mother) strength she (mother) rose, the baby on one arm. By a cruel effort of will, moving as if in sleep, she (mother) went across to the scullery, where she (mother) bathed her (mother) eye for a minute in cold water; but she (mother) was too dizzy. Afraid lest she (mother) should swoon, she (mother) returned to her (mother) rocking-chair, trembling in every fibre. By instinct, she (mother) kept the baby clasped.

Morel, bothered, had succeeded in pushing the drawer back into its cavity, and was on his (mother) knees, groping, with numb paws, for the scattered spoons.

Her (Morel) brow was still bleeding. Presently Morel got up and came craning his (mother) neck towards her (Morel).

``What has it done to thee, lass?'' (he)
he (mother) asked, in a very wretched, humble tone.

``You can see what it's done,'' (she)
she (Morel) answered.

He (mother) stood, bending forward, supported on his (mother) hands, which grasped his (mother) legs just above the knee. He (mother) peered to look at the wound. She (Morel) drew away from the thrust of his (mother) face with its great moustache, averting her (Morel) own face as much as possible. As he (mother) looked at her (Morel), who was cold and impassive as stone, with mouth shut tight, he (mother) sickened with feebleness and hopelessness of spirit. He (mother) was turning drearily away, when he (mother) saw a drop of blood fall from the averted wound into the baby's fragile, glistening hair. Fascinated, he (mother) watched the heavy dark drop hang in the glistening cloud, and pull down the gossamer. Another drop fell. It would soak through to the baby's scalp. He (mother) watched, fascinated, feeling it soak in; then, finally, his (mother) manhood broke.

``What of this child?'' (all wife)
was all his (mother) wife said to him (mother). But her (wife) low, intense tones brought his (mother) head lower. She (wife) softened:
``Get me some wadding out of the middle drawer,'' (She)
she (wife) said.

He (mother) stumbled away very obediently, presently returning with a pad, which she (wife) singed before the fire, then put on her (wife) forehead, as she (wife) sat with the baby on her (wife) lap.

``Now that clean pit-scarf.'' (he)

Again he (mother) rummaged and fumbled in the drawer, returning presently with a red, narrow scarf. She (wife) took it, and with trembling fingers proceeded to bind it round her (wife) head.

``Let me tie it for thee,'' (he)
he (mother) said humbly.

``I can do it myself,'' (she)
she (wife) replied. When it was done she (wife) went upstairs, telling him (mother) to rake the fire and lock the door.

In the morning Mrs. Morel said:

``I knocked against the latch of the coal-place, when I was getting a raker in the dark, because the candle blew out.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Her (Morel) two small children looked up at her (Morel) with wide, dismayed eyes. They said nothing, but their parted lips seemed to express the unconscious tragedy they felt.

Walter Morel lay in bed next day until nearly dinner-time. He (Morel) did not think of the previous evening's work. He (Morel) scarcely thought of anything, but he (Morel) would not think of that. He (Morel) lay and suffered like a sulking dog. He (Morel) had hurt himself most; and he (Morel) was the more damaged because he (Morel) would never say a word to her (Morel), or express his (Morel) sorrow. He (Morel) tried to wriggle out of it.

``It was her (lass) own fault,'' (he)
he (Morel) said to himself. Nothing, however, could prevent his (Morel) inner consciousness inflicting on him (Morel) the punishment which ate into his (Morel) spirit like rust, and which he (Morel) could only alleviate by drinking.

He (Morel) felt as if he (Morel) had not the initiative to get up, or to say a word, or to move, but could only lie like a log. Moreover, he (Morel) had himself violent pains in the head. It was Saturday. Towards noon he (Morel) rose, cut himself food in the pantry, ate it with his (Morel) head dropped, then pulled on his (Morel) boots, and went out, to return at three o'clock slightly tipsy and relieved; then once more straight to bed. He (Morel) rose again at six in the evening, had tea and went straight out.

Sunday was the same: bed till noon, the Palmerston Arms till 2.30, dinner, and bed; scarcely a word spoken. When Mrs. Morel went upstairs, towards four o'clock, to put on her (Morel) Sunday dress, he (Morel) was fast asleep. She (Morel) would have felt sorry for him (Morel), if he (Morel) had once said,

``Wife, I'm sorry.'' (he)
But no; he (Morel) insisted to himself it was her (Morel) fault. And so he (Morel) broke himself. So she (Morel) merely left him (Morel) alone. There was this deadlock of passion between them, and she (Morel) was stronger.

The family began tea. Sunday was the only day when all sat down to meals together.

``Isn't my father going to get up?'' (William)
asked William.

``Let him (father) lie,'' (the mother)
the mother replied.

There was a feeling of misery over all the house. The children breathed the air that was poisoned, and they felt dreary. They were rather disconsolate, did not know what to do, what to play at.

Immediately Morel woke he (William) got straight out of bed. That was characteristic of him (William) all his (William) life. He (William) was all for activity. The prostrated inactivity of two mornings was stifling him (William).

It was near six o'clock when he (William) got down. This time he (William) entered without hesitation, his (William) wincing sensitiveness having hardened again. He (William) did not care any longer what the family thought or felt.

The tea-things were on the table. William was reading aloud from

``The Child's Own'' (William)
, Annie listening and asking eternally
``why?'' (Annie)
Both children hushed into silence as they heard the approaching thud of their father's stockinged feet, and shrank as he (father) entered. Yet he (father) was usually indulgent to them.

Morel made the meal alone, brutally. He (father) ate and drank more noisily than he (father) had need. No one spoke to him (father). The family life withdrew, shrank away, and became hushed as he (father) entered. But he (father) cared no longer about his (father) alienation.

Immediately he (father) had finished tea he (father) rose with alacrity to go out. It was this alacrity, this haste to be gone, which so sickened Mrs. Morel. As she (Morel) heard him (father) sousing heartily in cold water, heard the eager scratch of the steel comb on the side of the bowl, as he (father) wetted his (father) hair, she (Morel) closed her (Morel) eyes in disgust. As he (father) bent over, lacing his (father) boots, there was a certain vulgar gusto in his (father) movement that divided him (father) from the reserved, watchful rest of the family. He (father) always ran away from the battle with himself. Even in his (father) own heart's privacy, he (father) excused himself, saying,

``If she (lass) hadn't said so-and-so, it would never have happened. She (lass) asked for what she (lass)'s got.'' (he)
The children waited in restraint during his (father) preparations. When he (father) had gone, they sighed with relief.

He (father) closed the door behind him (father), and was glad. It was a rainy evening. The Palmerston would be the cosier. He (father) hastened forward in anticipation. All the slate roofs of the Bottoms shone black with wet. The roads, always dark with coal-dust, were full of blackish mud. He (father) hastened along. The Palmerston windows were steamed over. The passage was paddled with wet feet. But the air was warm, if foul, and full of the sound of voices and the smell of beer and smoke.

``What shollt ha'e, Walter?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried a voice, as soon as Morel appeared in the doorway.

``Oh, Jim, my lad, wheriver has thee sprung frae?'' (The men)

The men made a seat for him (father), and took him (father) in warmly. He (father) was glad. In a minute or two they had thawed all responsibility out of him (father), all shame, all trouble, and he (father) was clear as a bell for a jolly night.

On the Wednesday following, Morel was penniless. He (father) dreaded his (father) wife. Having hurt her (Morel), he (father) hated her (Morel). He (father) did not know what to do with himself that evening, having not even twopence with which to go to the Palmerston, and being already rather deeply in debt. So, while his (father) wife was down the garden with the child, he (father) hunted in the top drawer of the dresser where she (wife) kept her (wife) purse, found it, and looked inside. It contained a half-crown, two halfpennies, and a sixpence. So he (father) took the sixpence, put the purse carefully back, and went out.

The next day, when she (wife) wanted to pay the greengrocer, she (wife) looked in the purse for her (wife) sixpence, and her (wife) heart sank to her (wife) shoes. Then she (wife) sat down and thought:

``WAS there a sixpence? I hadn't spent it, had I? And I hadn't left it anywhere else?'' (she)

She (wife) was much put about. She (wife) hunted round everywhere for it. And, as she (wife) sought, the conviction came into her (wife) heart that her (wife) husband had taken it. What she (wife) had in her (wife) purse was all the money she (wife) possessed. But that he (husband) should sneak it from her (wife) thus was unbearable. He (husband) had done so twice before. The first time she (wife) had not accused him (husband), and at the week-end he (husband) had put the shilling again into her (wife) purse. So that was how she (wife) had known he (husband) had taken it. The second time he (husband) had not paid back.

This time she (wife) felt it was too much. When he (husband) had had his (husband) dinner--he (husband) came home early that day--she (wife) said to him (husband) coldly:

``Did you take sixpence out of my purse last night?'' (him)

``Me!'' (he)
he (husband) said, looking up in an offended way.
``No, I didna! I niver clapped eyes on your purse.'' (she)

But she (wife) could detect the lie.

``Why, you know you did,'' (she)
she (wife) said quietly.

``I tell you I didna,'' (he)
he (husband) shouted.
``Yer at me again, are yer? I've had about enough on't.'' (unknown)

``So you filch sixpence out of my purse while I'm taking the clothes in.'' (unknown)

``I'll may yer pay for this,'' (he)
he (husband) said, pushing back his (husband) chair in desperation. He (husband) bustled and got washed, then went determinedly upstairs. Presently he (husband) came down dressed, and with a big bundle in a blue-checked, enormous handkerchief.

``And now,'' (he)
he (husband) said,
``you'll see me again when you do.'' (he)

``It'll be before I want to,'' (she)
she (wife) replied; and at that he (husband) marched out of the house with his (husband) bundle. She (wife) sat trembling slightly, but her (wife) heart brimming with contempt. What would she (wife) do if he (husband) went to some other pit, obtained work, and got in with another woman? But she (woman) knew him (husband) too well--he (husband) couldn't. She (woman) was dead sure of him (husband). Nevertheless her (woman) heart was gnawed inside her (woman).

``Where's my dad?'' (William)
said William, coming in from school.

``He (dad) says he (dad)'s run away,'' (the mother)
replied the mother.

``Where to?'' (unknown)

``Eh, I don't know. He (dad)'s taken a bundle in the blue handkerchief, and says he (dad)'s not coming back.'' (unknown)

``What shall we do?'' (the boy)
cried the boy.

``Eh, never trouble, he (dad) won't go far.'' (unknown)

``But if he (dad) doesn't come back,'' (Annie)
wailed Annie.

And she (Annie) and William retired to the sofa and wept. Mrs. Morel sat and laughed.

``You pair of gabeys!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed.
``You'll see him (dad) before the night's out.'' (the children)

But the children were not to be consoled. Twilight came on. Mrs. Morel grew anxious from very weariness. One part of her (Morel) said it would be a relief to see the last of him (William); another part fretted because of keeping the children; and inside her (Morel), as yet, she (Morel) could not quite let him (William) go. At the bottom, she (Morel) knew very well he (William) could NOT go.

When she (Morel) went down to the coal-place at the end of the garden, however, she (Morel) felt something behind the door. So she (Morel) looked. And there in the dark lay the big blue bundle. She (Morel) sat on a piece of coal and laughed. Every time she (Morel) saw it, so fat and yet so ignominious, slunk into its corner in the dark, with its ends flopping like dejected ears from the knots, she (Morel) laughed again. She (Morel) was relieved.

Mrs. Morel sat waiting. He (William) had not any money, she (Morel) knew, so if he (William) stopped he (William) was running up a bill. She (Morel) was very tired of him (William)--tired to death. He (William) had not even the courage to carry his (William) bundle beyond the yard-end.

As she (Morel) meditated, at about nine o'clock, he (William) opened the door and came in, slinking, and yet sulky. She (Morel) said not a word. He (William) took off his (William) coat, and slunk to his (William) armchair, where he (William) began to take off his (William) boots.

``You'd better fetch your bundle before you take your boots off,'' (she)
she (Morel) said quietly.

``You may thank your stars I've come back to-night,'' (he)
he (William) said, looking up from under his (William) dropped head, sulkily, trying to be impressive.

``Why, where should you have gone? You daren't even get your parcel through the yard-end,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

He (William) looked such a fool she (Morel) was not even angry with him (William). He (William) continued to take his (William) boots off and prepare for bed.

``I don't know what's in your blue handkerchief,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``But if you leave it the children shall fetch it in the morning.'' (he)

Whereupon he (William) got up and went out of the house, returning presently and crossing the kitchen with averted face, hurrying upstairs. As Mrs. Morel saw him (William) slink quickly through the inner doorway, holding his (William) bundle, she (Morel) laughed to herself: but her (Morel) heart was bitter, because she (Morel) had loved him (William).

CHAPTER III

THE CASTING OFF OF MOREL--THE TAKING ON OF WILLIAM

DURING the next week Morel's temper was almost unbearable. Like all miners, he (WILLIAM) was a great lover of medicines, which, strangely enough, he (WILLIAM) would often pay for himself.

``You mun get me a drop o' laxy vitral,'' (he)
he (WILLIAM) said.
``It's a winder as we canna ha'e a sup i' th' `ouse.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

So Mrs. Morel bought him (WILLIAM) elixir of vitriol, his (WILLIAM) favourite first medicine. And he (WILLIAM) made himself a jug of wormwood tea. He (WILLIAM) had hanging in the attic great bunches of dried herbs: wormwood, rue, horehound, elder flowers, parsley-purt, marshmallow, hyssop, dandelion, and centaury. Usually there was a jug of one or other decoction standing on the hob, from which he (WILLIAM) drank largely.

``Grand!'' (he)
he (WILLIAM) said, smacking his (WILLIAM) lips after wormwood.
``Grand!'' (he)
And he (WILLIAM) exhorted the children to try.

``It's better than any of your tea or your cocoa stews,'' (he)
he (WILLIAM) vowed. But they were not to be tempted.

This time, however, neither pills nor vitriol nor all his (WILLIAM) herbs would shift the

``nasty peens in his (You) head'' (He)
. He (WILLIAM) was sickening for an attack of an inflammation of the brain. He (WILLIAM) had never been well since his (WILLIAM) sleeping on the ground when he (WILLIAM) went with Jerry to Nottingham. Since then he (WILLIAM) had drunk and stormed. Now he (WILLIAM) fell seriously ill, and Mrs. Morel had him (WILLIAM) to nurse. He (WILLIAM) was one of the worst patients imaginable. But, in spite of all, and putting aside the fact that he (WILLIAM) was breadwinner, she (Morel) never quite wanted him (WILLIAM) to die. Still there was one part of her (Morel) wanted him (WILLIAM) for herself.

The neighbours were very good to her (Morel): occasionally some had the children in to meals, occasionally some would do the downstairs work for her (Morel), one would mind the baby for a day. But it was a great drag, nevertheless. It was not every day the neighbours helped. Then she (Morel) had nursing of baby and husband, cleaning and cooking, everything to do. She (Morel) was quite worn out, but she (Morel) did what was wanted of her (Morel).

And the money was just sufficient. She (Morel) had seventeen shillings a week from clubs, and every Friday Barker and the other butty put by a portion of the stall's profits for Morel's wife. And the neighbours made broths, and gave eggs, and such invalids' trifles. If they had not helped her (Morel) so generously in those times, Mrs. Morel would never have pulled through, without incurring debts that would have dragged her (Morel) down.

The weeks passed. Morel, almost against hope, grew better. He (Barker) had a fine constitution, so that, once on the mend, he (Barker) went straight forward to recovery. Soon he (Barker) was pottering about downstairs. During his (Barker) illness his (Barker) wife had spoilt him (Barker) a little. Now he (Barker) wanted her (wife) to continue. He (Barker) often put his (Barker) band to his (Barker) head, pulled down the corners of his (Barker) mouth, and shammed pains he (Barker) did not feel. But there was no deceiving her (wife). At first she (wife) merely smiled to herself. Then she (wife) scolded him (Barker) sharply.

``Goodness, man, don't be so lachrymose.'' (him)

That wounded him (Barker) slightly, but still he (Barker) continued to feign sickness.

``I wouldn't be such a mardy baby,'' (the wife)
said the wife shortly.

Then he (Barker) was indignant, and cursed under his (Barker) breath, like a boy. He (Barker) was forced to resume a normal tone, and to cease to whine.

Nevertheless, there was a state of peace in the house for some time. Mrs. Morel was more tolerant of him (Barker), and he (Barker), depending on her (Morel) almost like a child, was rather happy. Neither knew that she (Morel) was more tolerant because she (Morel) loved him (Barker) less. Up till this time, in spite of all, he (Barker) had been her (Morel) husband and her (Morel) man. She (Morel) had felt that, more or less, what he (Barker) did to himself he (Barker) did to her (Morel). Her (Morel) living depended on him (Barker). There were many, many stages in the ebbing of her (Morel) love for him (Barker), but it was always ebbing.

Now, with the birth of this third baby, her (Morel) self no longer set towards him (Barker), helplessly, but was like a tide that scarcely rose, standing off from him (Barker). After this she (Morel) scarcely desired him (Barker). And, standing more aloof from him (Barker), not feeling him (Barker) so much part of herself, but merely part of her (Morel) circumstances, she (Morel) did not mind so much what he (Barker) did, could leave him (Barker) alone.

There was the halt, the wistfulness about the ensuing year, which is like autumn in a man's life. His (man) wife was casting him (man) off, half regretfully, but relentlessly; casting him (man) off and turning now for love and life to the children. Henceforward he (man) was more or less a husk. And he (man) himself acquiesced, as so many men do, yielding their place to their children.

During his (man) recuperation, when it was really over between them, both made an effort to come back somewhat to the old relationship of the first months of their marriage. He (man) sat at home and, when the children were in bed, and she (wife) was sewing--she (wife) did all her (wife) sewing by hand, made all shirts and children's clothing--he (man) would read to her (wife) from the newspaper, slowly pronouncing and delivering the words like a man pitching quoits. Often she (wife) hurried him (man) on, giving him (man) a phrase in anticipation. And then he (man) took her (wife) words humbly.

The silences between them were peculiar. There would be the swift, slight

``cluck'' (he)
of her (wife) needle, the sharp
``pop'' (he)
of his (man) lips as he (man) let out the smoke, the warmth, the sizzle on the bars as he (man) spat in the fire. Then her (wife) thoughts turned to William. Already he (William) was getting a big boy. Already he (William) was top of the class, and the master said he (master) was the smartest lad in the school. She (wife) saw him (master) a man, young, full of vigour, making the world glow again for her (wife).

And Morel sitting there, quite alone, and having nothing to think about, would be feeling vaguely uncomfortable. His (Morel) soul would reach out in its blind way to her (wife) and find her (wife) gone. He (Morel) felt a sort of emptiness, almost like a vacuum in his (Morel) soul. He (Morel) was unsettled and restless. Soon he (Morel) could not live in that atmosphere, and he (Morel) affected his (Morel) wife. Both felt an oppression on their breathing when they were left together for some time. Then he (Morel) went to bed and she (wife) settled down to enjoy herself alone, working, thinking, living.

Meanwhile another infant was coming, fruit of this little peace and tenderness between the separating parents. Paul was seventeen months old when the new baby was born. He (Paul) was then a plump, pale child, quiet, with heavy blue eyes, and still the peculiar slight knitting of the brows. The last child was also a boy, fair and bonny. Mrs. Morel was sorry when she (Morel) knew she (Morel) was with child, both for economic reasons and because she (Morel) did not love her (Morel) husband; but not for the sake of the infant.

They called the baby Arthur. He (Arthur) was very pretty, with a mop of gold curls, and he (Arthur) loved his (Arthur) father from the first. Mrs. Morel was glad this child loved the father. Hearing the miner's footsteps, the baby would put up his (Arthur) arms and crow. And if Morel were in a good temper, he (Arthur) called back immediately, in his (Arthur) hearty, mellow voice:

``What then, my beauty? I sh'll come to thee in a minute.'' (he)

And as soon as he (Arthur) had taken off his (Arthur) pit-coat, Mrs. Morel would put an apron round the child, and give him (Arthur) to his (Arthur) father.

``What a sight the lad looks!'' (she)
she (Morel) would exclaim sometimes, taking back the baby, that was smutted on the face from his (Arthur) father's kisses and play. Then Morel laughed joyfully.

``He (lad)'s a little collier, bless his (lad) bit o' mutton!'' (he)
he (Arthur) exclaimed.

And these were the happy moments of her (Morel) life now, when the children included the father in her (Morel) heart.

Meanwhile William grew bigger and stronger and more active, while Paul, always rather delicate and quiet, got slimmer, and trotted after his (Paul) mother like her (mother) shadow. He (Paul) was usually active and interested, but sometimes he (Paul) would have fits of depression. Then the mother would find the boy of three or four crying on the sofa.

``What's the matter?'' (she)
she (mother) asked, and got no answer.

``What's the matter?'' (she)
she (mother) insisted, getting cross.

``I don't know,'' (the child)
sobbed the child.

So she (mother) tried to reason him (boy) out of it, or to amuse him (boy), but without effect. It made her (mother) feel beside herself. Then the father, always impatient, would jump from his (father) chair and shout:

``If he (lad) doesn't stop, I'll smack him (lad) till he (lad) does.'' (the father)

``You'll do nothing of the sort,'' (the mother)
said the mother coldly. And then she (mother) carried the child into the yard, plumped him (father) into his (father) little chair, and said:
``Now cry there, Misery!'' (him)

And then a butterfly on the rhubarb-leaves perhaps caught his (father) eye, or at last he (father) cried himself to sleep. These fits were not often, but they caused a shadow in Mrs. Morel's heart, and her (Morel) treatment of Paul was different from that of the other children.

Suddenly one morning as she (Morel) was looking down the alley of the Bottoms for the barm-man, she (Morel) heard a voice calling her (Morel). It was the thin little Mrs. Anthony in brown velvet.

``Here, Mrs. Morel, I want to tell you about your Willie.'' (unknown)

``Oh, do you?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel.
``Why, what's the matter?'' (unknown)

``A lad as gets `old of another an' rips his (lad) clothes off'n `is back,'' (Mrs. Anthony/Anthony)
Mrs. Anthony said,
``wants showing something.'' (Mrs. Anthony/Anthony)

``Your Alfred's as old as my William,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

''`Appen 'e is, but that doesn't give him (Paul) a right to get hold of the boy's collar, an' fair rip it clean off his (boy) back.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Well,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``I don't thrash my children, and even if I did, I should want to hear their side of the tale.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``They'd happen be a bit better if they did get a good hiding,'' (Mrs. Anthony/Anthony)
retorted Mrs. Anthony.
``When it comes ter rippin' a lad's clean collar off'n `is back a-purpose--'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``I'm sure he (lad) didn't do it on purpose,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Make me a liar!'' (Mrs. Anthony/Anthony)
shouted Mrs. Anthony.

Mrs. Morel moved away and closed her (Morel) gate. Her (Morel) hand trembled as she (Morel) held her (Morel) mug of barm.

``But I s'll let your mester know,'' (Mrs. Anthony/Anthony)
Mrs. Anthony cried after her (Anthony).

At dinner-time, when William had finished his (William) meal and wanted to be off again--he (William) was then eleven years old--his (William) mother said to him (William):

``What did you tear Alfred Anthony's collar for?'' (him)

``When did I tear his (Anthony) collar?'' (unknown)

``I don't know when, but his (Anthony) mother says you did.'' (unknown)

``Why--it was yesterday--an' it was torn a`ready.'' (unknown)

``But you tore it more.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'd got a cobbler as `ad licked seventeen--an' Alfy Ant`ny 'e says:

``Adam an' Eve an' pinch-me, Went down to a river to bade. Adam an' Eve got drownded, Who do yer think got saved?'' (I)

An' so I says:

``Oh, Pinch-YOU,'' (I)
an' so I pinched `im, an' 'e was mad, an' so he (William) snatched my cobbler an' run off with it. An' so I run after `im, an' when I was gettin' hold of `im, 'e dodged, an' it ripped `is collar. But I got my cobbler--''

He (cobbler) pulled from his (cobbler) pocket a black old horse-chestnut hanging on a string. This old cobbler had

``cobbled'' (This cobbler)
--hit and smashed--seventeen other cobblers on similar strings. So the boy was proud of his (boy) veteran.

``Well,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``you know you've got no right to rip his (Adam) collar.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Well, our mother!'' (he)
he (boy) answered.
``I never meant tr'a done it--an' it was on'y an old indirrubber collar as was torn a`ready.'' (unknown)

``Next time,'' (mother)
said his (boy) mother,
``YOU be more careful. I shouldn't like it if you came home with your collar torn off.'' (mother)

``I don't care, our mother; I never did it a-purpose.'' (The boy)

The boy was rather miserable at being reprimanded.

``No--well, you be more careful.'' (William)

William fled away, glad to be exonerated. And Mrs. Morel, who hated any bother with the neighbours, thought she (Morel) would explain to Mrs. Anthony, and the business would be over.

But that evening Morel came in from the pit looking very sour. He (William) stood in the kitchen and glared round, but did not speak for some minutes. Then:

``Wheer's that Willy?'' (he)
he (William) asked.

``What do you want HIM for?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
asked Mrs. Morel, who had guessed.

``I'll let `im know when I get him (Willy),'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel, banging his (William) pit-bottle on to the dresser.

``I suppose Mrs. Anthony's got hold of you and been yarning to you about Alfy's collar,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, rather sneering.

``Niver mind who's got hold of me,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel. ``When I get hold of
``IM I'll make his (Willy) bones rattle.'' (unknown)

``It's a poor tale,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``that you're so ready to side with any snipey vixen who likes to come telling tales against your own children.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``I'll learn `im!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.
``It none matters to me whose lad 'e is; `e's none goin' rippin' an' tearin' about just as he (lad)'s a mind.'' (unknown)

''`Ripping and tearing about!''' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
repeated Mrs. Morel.
``He (lad) was running after that Alfy, who'd taken his (lad) cobbler, and he (lad) accidentally got hold of his (lad) collar, because the other dodged--as an Anthony would.'' (unknown)

``I know!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
shouted Morel threateningly.

``You would, before you're told,'' (wife)
replied his (William) wife bitingly.

``Niver you mind,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
stormed Morel.
``I know my business.'' (unknown)

``That's more than doubtful,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``supposing some loud-mouthed creature had been getting you to thrash your own children.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``I know,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
repeated Morel.

And he (William) said no more, but sat and nursed his (William) bad temper. Suddenly William ran in, saying:

``Can I have my tea, mother?'' (William)

``Tha can ha'e more than that!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
shouted Morel.

``Hold your noise, man,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel;
``and don't look so ridiculous.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``He (man)'ll look ridiculous before I've done wi' him (man)!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
shouted Morel, rising from his (William) chair and glaring at his (William) son.

William, who was a tall lad for his (William) years, but very sensitive, had gone pale, and was looking in a sort of horror at his (William) father.

``Go out!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel commanded her (Morel) son.

William had not the wit to move. Suddenly Morel clenched his (William) fist, and crouched.

``I'll GI

``E him (man) `go out'!'' (unknown)
he (William) shouted like an insane thing.

``What!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Mrs. Morel, panting with rage.
``You shall not touch him (man) for HER telling, you shall not!'' (unknown)

``Shonna I?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
shouted Morel.
``Shonna I?'' (the boy)

And, glaring at the boy, he (boy) ran forward. Mrs. Morel sprang in between them, with her (Morel) fist lifted.

``Don't you DARE!'' (she)
she (Morel) cried.

``What!'' (he)
he (boy) shouted, baffled for the moment.
``What!'' (She)

She (Morel) spun round to her (Morel) son.

``GO out of the house!'' (she)
she (Morel) commanded him (son) in fury.

The boy, as if hypnotised by her (Morel), turned suddenly and was gone. Morel rushed to the door, but was too late. He (boy) returned, pale under his (boy) pit-dirt with fury. But now his (boy) wife was fully roused.

``Only dare!'' (she)
she (Morel) said in a loud, ringing voice.
``Only dare, milord, to lay a finger on that child! You'll regret it for ever.'' (He)

He (boy) was afraid of her (Morel). In a towering rage, he (boy) sat down.

When the children were old enough to be left, Mrs. Morel joined the Women's Guild. It was a little club of women attached to the Co-operative Wholesale Society, which met on Monday night in the long room over the grocery shop of the Bestwood

``Co-op'' (Bestwood)
. The women were supposed to discuss the benefits to be derived from co-operation, and other social questions. Sometimes Mrs. Morel read a paper. It seemed queer to the children to see their mother, who was always busy about the house, sitting writing in her (Morel) rapid fashion, thinking, referring to books, and writing again. They felt for her (Morel) on such occasions the deepest respect.

But they loved the Guild. It was the only thing to which they did not grudge their mother--and that partly because she (mother) enjoyed it, partly because of the treats they derived from it. The Guild was called by some hostile husbands, who found their wives getting too independent, the

``clat-fart'' (wives)
shop--that is, the gossip-shop. It is true, from off the basis of the Guild, the women could look at their homes, at the conditions of their own lives, and find fault. So the colliers found their women had a new standard of their own, rather disconcerting. And also, Mrs. Morel always had a lot of news on Monday nights, so that the children liked William to be in when their mother came home, because she (mother) told him (William) things.

Then, when the lad was thirteen, she (mother) got him (lad) a job in the

``Co-op.'' (him)
office. He (lad) was a very clever boy, frank, with rather rough features and real viking blue eyes.

``What dost want ter ma'e a stool-harsed Jack on `im for?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.
``All he (Jack)'ll do is to wear his (Jack) britches behind out an' earn nowt. What's 'e startin' wi'?'' (unknown)

``It doesn't matter what he (Jack)'s starting with,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``It wouldna! Put `im i' th' pit we me, an' `ell earn a easy ten shillin' a wik from th' start. But six shillin' wearin' his (Jack) truck-end out on a stool's better than ten shillin' i' th' pit wi`me, I know.'' (unknown)

``He (Jack) is NOT going in the pit,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``and there's an end of it.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``It wor good enough for me, but it's non good enough for `im.'' (unknown)

``If your mother put you in the pit at twelve, it's no reason why I should do the same with my lad.'' (unknown)

``Twelve! It wor a sight afore that!'' (unknown)

``Whenever it was,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

She (Morel) was very proud of her (Morel) son. He (son) went to the night school, and learned shorthand, so that by the time he (son) was sixteen he (son) was the best shorthand clerk and book-keeper on the place, except one. Then he (son) taught in the night schools. But he (son) was so fiery that only his (son) good-nature and his (son) size protected him (son).

All the things that men do--the decent things--William did. He (William) could run like the wind. When he (William) was twelve he (William) won a first prize in a race; an inkstand of glass, shaped like an anvil. It stood proudly on the dresser, and gave Mrs. Morel a keen pleasure. The boy only ran for her (Morel). He (boy) flew home with his (boy) anvil, breathless, with a

``Look, mother!'' (He)
That was the first real tribute to herself. She (Morel) took it like a queen.

``How pretty!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed.

Then he (boy) began to get ambitious. He (boy) gave all his (boy) money to his (boy) mother. When he (boy) earned fourteen shillings a week, she (mother) gave him (boy) back two for himself, and, as he (boy) never drank, he (boy) felt himself rich. He (boy) went about with the bourgeois of Bestwood. The townlet contained nothing higher than the clergyman. Then came the bank manager, then the doctors, then the tradespeople, and after that the hosts of colliers. Willam began to consort with the sons of the chemist, the schoolmaster, and the tradesmen. He (chemist) played billiards in the Mechanics' Hall. Also he (chemist) danced--this in spite of his (chemist) mother. All the life that Bestwood offered he (chemist) enjoyed, from the sixpenny-hops down Church Street, to sports and billiards.

Paul was treated to dazzling descriptions of all kinds of flower-like ladies, most of whom lived like cut blooms in William's heart for a brief fortnight.

Occasionally some flame would come in pursuit of her (mother) errant swain. Mrs. Morel would find a strange girl at the door, and immediately she (Morel) sniffed the air.

``Is Mr. Morel in?'' (the damsel)
the damsel would ask appealingly.

``My husband is at home,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel replied.

``I--I mean YOUNG Mr. Morel,'' (unknown)
repeated the maiden painfully.

``Which one? There are several.'' (unknown)

Whereupon much blushing and stammering from the fair one.

``I--I met Mr. Morel--at Ripley,'' (she)
she (Morel) explained.

``Oh--at a dance!'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``I don't approve of the girls my son meets at dances. And he (son) is NOT at home.'' (he)

Then he (swain) came home angry with his (swain) mother for having turned the girl away so rudely. He (swain) was a careless, yet eager-looking fellow, who walked with long strides, sometimes frowning, often with his (swain) cap pushed jollily to the back of his (swain) head. Now he (swain) came in frowning. He (swain) threw his (swain) cap on to the sofa, and took his (swain) strong jaw in his (swain) hand, and glared down at his (swain) mother. She (mother) was small, with her (mother) hair taken straight back from her (mother) forehead. She (mother) had a quiet air of authority, and yet of rare warmth. Knowing her (mother) son was angry, she (mother) trembled inwardly.

``Did a lady call for me yesterday, mother?'' (he)
he (son) asked.

``I don't know about a lady. There was a girl came.'' (unknown)

``And why didn't you tell me?'' (unknown)

``Because I forgot, simply.'' (He)

He (son) fumed a little.

``A good-looking girl--seemed a lady?'' (unknown)

``I didn't look at her (girl).'' (unknown)

``Big brown eyes?'' (unknown)

``I did NOT look. And tell your girls, my son, that when they're running after you, they're not to come and ask your mother for you. Tell them that--brazen baggages you meet at dancing-classes.'' (unknown)

``I'm sure she (mother) was a nice girl.'' (unknown)

``And I'm sure she (mother) wasn't.'' (unknown)

There ended the altercation. Over the dancing there was a great strife between the mother and the son. The grievance reached its height when William said he (William) was going to Hucknall Torkard--considered a low town--to a fancy-dress ball. He (William) was to be a Highlander. There was a dress he (William) could hire, which one of his (William) friends had had, and which fitted him (William) perfectly. The Highland suit came home. Mrs. Morel received it coldly and would not unpack it.

``My suit come?'' (William)
cried William.

``There's a parcel in the front room.'' (He)

He (William) rushed in and cut the string.

``How do you fancy your son in this!'' (he)
he (William) said, enraptured, showing her (Morel) the suit.

``You know I don't want to fancy you in it.'' (he)

On the evening of the dance, when he (William) had come home to dress, Mrs. Morel put on her (Morel) coat and bonnet.

``Aren't you going to stop and see me, mother?'' (he)
he (William) asked.

``No; I don't want to see you,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.

She (Morel) was rather pale, and her (Morel) face was closed and hard. She (Morel) was afraid of her (Morel) son's going the same way as his (son) father. He (son) hesitated a moment, and his (son) heart stood still with anxiety. Then he (son) caught sight of the Highland bonnet with its ribbons. He (son) picked it up gleefully, forgetting her (Morel). She (Morel) went out.

When he (son) was nineteen he (son) suddenly left the Co-op. office and got a situation in Nottingham. In his (son) new place he (son) had thirty shillings a week instead of eighteen. This was indeed a rise. His (son) mother and his (son) father were brimmed up with pride. Everybody praised William. It seemed he (William) was going to get on rapidly. Mrs. Morel hoped, with his (William) aid, to help her (Morel) younger sons. Annie was now studying to be a teacher. Paul, also very clever, was getting on well, having lessons in French and German from his (Paul) godfather, the clergyman who was still a friend to Mrs. Morel. Arthur, a spoilt and very good-looking boy, was at the Board school, but there was talk of his (Arthur) trying to get a scholarship for the High School in Nottingham.

William remained a year at his (William) new post in Nottingham. He (William) was studying hard, and growing serious. Something seemed to be fretting him (William). Still he (William) went out to the dances and the river parties. He (William) did not drink. The children were all rabid teetotallers. He (William) came home very late at night, and sat yet longer studying. His (William) mother implored him (William) to take more care, to do one thing or another.

``Dance, if you want to dance, my son; but don't think you can work in the office, and then amuse yourself, and THEN study on top of all. You can't; the human frame won't stand it. Do one thing or the other--amuse yourself or learn Latin; but don't try to do both.'' (he)

Then he (William) got a place in London, at a hundred and twenty a year. This seemed a fabulous sum. His (William) mother doubted almost whether to rejoice or to grieve.

``They want me in Lime Street on Monday week, mother,'' (he)
he (William) cried, his (William) eyes blazing as he (William) read the letter. Mrs. Morel felt everything go silent inside her (Morel). He (William) read the letter:
''`And will you reply by Thursday whether you accept. Yours faithfully--' They want me, mother, at a hundred and twenty a year, and don't even ask to see me. Didn't I tell you I could do it! Think of me in London! And I can give you twenty pounds a year, mater. We s'll all be rolling in money.'' (He)

``We shall, my son,'' (she)
she (mother) answered sadly.

It never occurred to him (William) that she (mother) might be more hurt at his (William) going away than glad of his (William) success. Indeed, as the days drew near for his (William) departure, her (mother) heart began to close and grow dreary with despair. She (mother) loved him (William) so much! More than that, she (mother) hoped in him (William) so much. Almost she (mother) lived by him (William). She (mother) liked to do things for him (William): she (mother) liked to put a cup for his (William) tea and to iron his (William) collars, of which he (William) was so proud. It was a joy to her (mother) to have him (William) proud of his (William) collars. There was no laundry. So she (mother) used to rub away at them with her (mother) little convex iron, to polish them, till they shone from the sheer pressure of her (mother) arm. Now she (mother) would not do it for him (William). Now he (William) was going away. She (mother) felt almost as if he (William) were going as well out of her (mother) heart. He (William) did not seem to leave her (mother) inhabited with himself. That was the grief and the pain to her (mother). He (William) took nearly all himself away.

A few days before his (William) departure--he (William) was just twenty--he (William) burned his (William) love-letters. They had hung on a file at the top of the kitchen cupboard. From some of them he (William) had read extracts to his (William) mother. Some of them she (mother) had taken the trouble to read herself. But most were too trivial.

Now, on the Saturday morning he (William) said:

``Come on, Postle, let's go through my letters, and you can have the birds and flowers.'' (he)

Mrs. Morel had done her (Morel) Saturday's work on the Friday, because he (William) was having a last day's holiday. She (Morel) was making him (William) a rice cake, which he (William) loved, to take with him (William). He (William) was scarcely conscious that she (Morel) was so miserable.

He (William) took the first letter off the file. It was mauve-tinted, and had purple and green thistles. William sniffed the page.

``Nice scent! Smell.'' (he)

And he (William) thrust the sheet under Paul's nose.

``Um!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, breathing in.
``What d'you call it? Smell, mother.'' (mother)

His (Paul) mother ducked her (mother) small, fine nose down to the paper.

``I don't want to smell their rubbish,'' (she)
she (mother) said, sniffing.

``This girl's father,'' (William)
said William, ``is as rich as Croesus. He (father) owns property without end. She (girl) calls me Lafayette, because I know French. ``You will see, I've forgiven you'--I like HER forgiving me.
``I told mother about you this morning, and she (mother) will have much pleasure if you come to tea on Sunday, but she (mother) will have to get father's consent also. I sincerely hope he (father) will agree. I will let you know how it transpires. If, however, you--''' (unknown)

''`Let you know how it' what?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
interrupted Mrs. Morel.

''`Transpires'--oh yes!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

''`Transpires!''' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
repeated Mrs. Morel mockingly.
``I thought she (mother) was so well educated!'' (William)

William felt slightly uncomfortable, and abandoned this maiden, giving Paul the corner with the thistles. He (Paul) continued to read extracts from his (Paul) letters, some of which amused his (Paul) mother, some of which saddened her (mother) and made her (mother) anxious for him (Paul).

``My lad,'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``they're very wise. They know they've only got to flatter your vanity, and you press up to them like a dog that has its head scratched.'' (she)

``Well, they can't go on scratching for ever,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.
``And when they've done, I trot away.'' (unknown)

``But one day you'll find a string round your neck that you can't pull off,'' (she)
she (mother) answered.

``Not me! I'm equal to any of 'em, mater, they needn't flatter themselves.'' (unknown)

``You flatter YOURSELF,'' (she)
she (mother) said quietly.

Soon there was a heap of twisted black pages, all that remained of the file of scented letters, except that Paul had thirty or forty pretty tickets from the corners of the notepaper--swallows and forget-me-nots and ivy sprays. And William went to London, to start a new life.

CHAPTER IV

THE YOUNG LIFE OF PAUL

PAUL would be built like his (William) mother, slightly and rather small. His (William) fair hair went reddish, and then dark brown; his (William) eyes were grey. He (William) was a pale, quiet child, with eyes that seemed to listen, and with a full, dropping underlip.

As a rule he (William) seemed old for his (William) years. He (William) was so conscious of what other people felt, particularly his (William) mother. When she (mother) fretted he (William) understood, and could have no peace. His (William) soul seemed always attentive to her (mother).

As he (William) grew older he (William) became stronger. William was too far removed from him (William) to accept him (William) as a companion. So the smaller boy belonged at first almost entirely to Annie. She (Annie) was a tomboy and a

``flybie-skybie'' (a tomboy flybie-skybie)
, as her (Annie) mother called her (Annie). But she (Annie) was intensely fond of her (Annie) second brother. So Paul was towed round at the heels of Annie, sharing her (Annie) game. She (Annie) raced wildly at lerky with the other young wild-cats of the Bottoms. And always Paul flew beside her (Annie), living her (Annie) share of the game, having as yet no part of his (Paul) own. He (Paul) was quiet and not noticeable. But his (Paul) sister adored him (Paul). He (Paul) always seemed to care for things if she (sister) wanted him (Paul) to.

She (sister) had a big doll of which she (sister) was fearfully proud, though not so fond. So she (sister) laid the doll on the sofa, and covered it with an antimacassar, to sleep. Then she (sister) forgot it. Meantime Paul must practise jumping off the sofa arm. So he (Paul) jumped crash into the face of the hidden doll. Annie rushed up, uttered a loud wail, and sat down to weep a dirge. Paul remained quite still.

``You couldn't tell it was there, mother; you couldn't tell it was there,'' (he)
he (Paul) repeated over and over. So long as Annie wept for the doll he (Paul) sat helpless with misery. Her (Annie) grief wore itself out. She (Annie) forgave her (Annie) brother--he (brother) was so much upset. But a day or two afterwards she (Annie) was shocked.

``Let's make a sacrifice of Arabella,'' (he)
he (brother) said.
``Let's burn her (mother).'' (She)

She (Annie) was horrified, yet rather fascinated. She (Annie) wanted to see what the boy would do. He (boy) made an altar of bricks, pulled some of the shavings out of Arabella's body, put the waxen fragments into the hollow face, poured on a little paraffin, and set the whole thing alight. He (boy) watched with wicked satisfaction the drops of wax melt off the broken forehead of Arabella, and drop like sweat into the flame. So long as the stupid big doll burned he (boy) rejoiced in silence. At the end be poked among the embers with a stick, fished out the arms and legs, all blackened, and smashed them under stones.

``That's the sacrifice of Missis Arabella,'' (he)
he (boy) said.
``An' I'm glad there's nothing left of her (mother).'' (Annie)

Which disturbed Annie inwardly, although she (Annie) could say nothing. He (boy) seemed to hate the doll so intensely, because he (boy) had broken it.

All the children, but particularly Paul, were peculiarly against their father, along with their mother. Morel continued to bully and to drink. He (Paul) had periods, months at a time, when he (Paul) made the whole life of the family a misery. Paul never forgot coming home from the Band of Hope one Monday evening and finding his (Paul) mother with her (mother) eye swollen and discoloured, his (Paul) father standing on the hearthrug, feet astride, his (Paul) head down, and William, just home from work, glaring at his (Paul) father. There was a silence as the young children entered, but none of the elders looked round.

William was white to the lips, and his (William) fists were clenched. He (William) waited until the children were silent, watching with children's rage and hate; then he (William) said:

``You coward, you daren't do it when I was in.'' (he)

But Morel's blood was up. He (William) swung round on his (William) son. William was bigger, but Morel was hard-muscled, and mad with fury.

``Dossn't I?'' (he)
he (William) shouted.
``Dossn't I? Ha'e much more o' thy chelp, my young jockey, an' I'll rattle my fist about thee. Ay, an' I sholl that, dost see?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel crouched at the knees and showed his (William) fist in an ugly, almost beast-like fashion. William was white with rage.

``Will yer?'' (he)
he (William) said, quiet and intense.
``It `ud be the last time, though.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel danced a little nearer, crouching, drawing back his (William) fist to strike. William put his (William) fists ready. A light came into his (William) blue eyes, almost like a laugh. He (William) watched his (William) father. Another word, and the men would have begun to fight. Paul hoped they would. The three children sat pale on the sofa.

``Stop it, both of you,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Mrs. Morel in a hard voice.
``We've had enough for ONE night. And YOU,'' (she)
she (Morel) said, turning on to her (Morel) husband,
``look at your children!'' (husband)

Morel glanced at the sofa.

``Look at the children, you nasty little bitch!'' (he)
he (husband) sneered.
``Why, what have I done to the children, I should like to know? But they're like yourself; you've put 'em up to your own tricks and nasty ways--you've learned 'em in it, you `ave.'' (She)

She (Morel) refused to answer him (husband). No one spoke. After a while he (husband) threw his (husband) boots under the table and went to bed.

``Why didn't you let me have a go at him (bitch)?'' (William)
said William, when his (William) father was upstairs.
``I could easily have beaten him (bitch).'' (unknown)

``A nice thing--your own father,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.

''`FATHER!''' (she)
repeated William.
``Call HIM MY father!'' (unknown)

``Well, he (father) is--and so--'' (unknown)

``But why don't you let me settle him (father)? I could do, easily.'' (unknown)

``The idea!'' (she)
she (Morel) cried.
``It hasn't come to THAT yet.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (he)
he (William) said,
``it's come to worse. Look at yourself. WHY didn't you let me give it him (father)?'' (he)

``Because I couldn't bear it, so never think of it,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried quickly.

And the children went to bed, miserably.

When William was growing up, the family moved from the Bottoms to a house on the brow of the hill, commanding a view of the valley, which spread out like a convex cockle-shell, or a clamp-shell, before it. In front of the house was a huge old ash-tree. The west wind, sweeping from Derbyshire, caught the houses with full force, and the tree shrieked again. Morel liked it.

``It's music,'' (he)
he (William) said.
``It sends me to sleep.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

But Paul and Arthur and Annie hated it. To Paul it became almost a demoniacal noise. The winter of their first year in the new house their father was very bad. The children played in the street, on the brim of the wide, dark valley, until eight o'clock. Then they went to bed. Their mother sat sewing below. Having such a great space in front of the house gave the children a feeling of night, of vastness, and of terror. This terror came in from the shrieking of the tree and the anguish of the home discord. Often Paul would wake up, after he (Paul) had been asleep a long time, aware of thuds downstairs. Instantly he (Paul) was wide awake. Then he (Paul) heard the booming shouts of his (Paul) father, come home nearly drunk, then the sharp replies of his (Paul) mother, then the bang, bang of his (Paul) father's fist on the table, and the nasty snarling shout as the man's voice got higher. And then the whole was drowned in a piercing medley of shrieks and cries from the great, wind-swept ash-tree. The children lay silent in suspense, waiting for a lull in the wind to hear what their father was doing. He (father) might hit their mother again. There was a feeling of horror, a kind of bristling in the darkness, and a sense of blood. They lay with their hearts in the grip of an intense anguish. The wind came through the tree fiercer and fiercer. All the chords of the great harp hummed, whistled, and shrieked. And then came the horror of the sudden silence, silence everywhere, outside and downstairs. What was it? Was it a silence of blood? What had he (father) done?

The children lay and breathed the darkness. And then, at last, they heard their father throw down his (father) boots and tramp upstairs in his (father) stockinged feet. Still they listened. Then at last, if the wind allowed, they heard the water of the tap drumming into the kettle, which their mother was filling for morning, and they could go to sleep in peace.

So they were happy in the morning--happy, very happy playing, dancing at night round the lonely lamp-post in the midst of the darkness. But they had one tight place of anxiety in their hearts, one darkness in their eyes, which showed all their lives.

Paul hated his (Paul) father. As a boy he (Paul) had a fervent private religion.

``Make him (father) stop drinking,'' (he)
he (Paul) prayed every night.
``Lord, let my father die,'' (he)
he (Paul) prayed very often.
``Let him (father) not be killed at pit,'' (he)
he (Paul) prayed when, after tea, the father did not come home from work.

That was another time when the family suffered intensely. The children came from school and had their teas. On the hob the big black saucepan was simmering, the stew-jar was in the oven, ready for Morel's dinner. He (father) was expected at five o'clock. But for months he (father) would stop and drink every night on his (father) way from work.
