In the winter nights, when it was cold, and grew dark early, Mrs. Morel would put a brass candlestick on the table, light a tallow candle to save the gas. The children finished their bread-and-butter, or dripping, and were ready to go out to play. But if Morel had not come they faltered. The sense of his (father) sitting in all his (father) pit-dirt, drinking, after a long day's work, not coming home and eating and washing, but sitting, getting drunk, on an empty stomach, made Mrs. Morel unable to bear herself. From her (Morel) the feeling was transmitted to the other children. She (Morel) never suffered alone any more: the children suffered with her (Morel).

Paul went out to play with the rest. Down in the great trough of twilight, tiny clusters of lights burned where the pits were. A few last colliers straggled up the dim field path. The lamplighter came along. No more colliers came. Darkness shut down over the valley; work was done. It was night.

Then Paul ran anxiously into the kitchen. The one candle still burned on the table, the big fire glowed red. Mrs. Morel sat alone. On the hob the saucepan steamed; the dinner-plate lay waiting on the table. All the room was full of the sense of waiting, waiting for the man who was sitting in his (man) pit-dirt, dinnerless, some mile away from home, across the darkness, drinking himself drunk. Paul stood in the doorway.

``Has my dad come?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``You can see he (dad) hasn't,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, cross with the futility of the question.

Then the boy dawdled about near his (boy) mother. They shared the same anxiety. Presently Mrs. Morel went out and strained the potatoes.

``They're ruined and black,'' (she)
she (Morel) said;
``but what do I care?'' (she)

Not many words were spoken. Paul almost hated his (Paul) mother for suffering because his (Paul) father did not come home from work.

``What do you bother yourself for?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``If he (dad) wants to stop and get drunk, why don't you let him (dad)?'' (unknown)

``Let him (dad)!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
flashed Mrs. Morel.
``You may well say `let him (dad)'.'' (She)

She (Morel) knew that the man who stops on the way home from work is on a quick way to ruining himself and his (man) home. The children were yet young, and depended on the breadwinner. William gave her (Morel) the sense of relief, providing her (Morel) at last with someone to turn to if Morel failed. But the tense atmosphere of the room on these waiting evenings was the same.

The minutes ticked away. At six o'clock still the cloth lay on the table, still the dinner stood waiting, still the same sense of anxiety and expectation in the room. The boy could not stand it any longer. He (boy) could not go out and play. So he (boy) ran in to Mrs. Inger, next door but one, for her (Inger) to talk to him (boy). She (Inger) had no children. Her (Inger) husband was good to her (Inger) but was in a shop, and came home late. So, when she (Inger) saw the lad at the door, she (Inger) called:

``Come in, Paul.'' (she)

The two sat talking for some time, when suddenly the boy rose, saying:

``Well, I'll be going and seeing if my mother wants an errand doing.'' (the boy)

He (boy) pretended to be perfectly cheerful, and did not tell his (boy) friend what ailed him (boy). Then he (boy) ran indoors.

Morel at these times came in churlish and hateful.

``This is a nice time to come home,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Wha's it matter to yo' what time I come whoam?'' (he)
he (boy) shouted.

And everybody in the house was still, because he (boy) was dangerous. He (boy) ate his (boy) food in the most brutal manner possible, and, when he (boy) had done, pushed all the pots in a heap away from him (boy), to lay his (boy) arms on the table. Then he (boy) went to sleep.

Paul hated his (Paul) father so. The collier's small, mean head, with its black hair slightly soiled with grey, lay on the bare arms, and the face, dirty and inflamed, with a fleshy nose and thin, paltry brows, was turned sideways, asleep with beer and weariness and nasty temper. If anyone entered suddenly, or a noise were made, the man looked up and shouted:

``I'll lay my fist about thy y'ead, I'm tellin' thee, if tha doesna stop that clatter! Dost hear?'' (the man)

And the two last words, shouted in a bullying fashion, usually at Annie, made the family writhe with hate of the man.

He (man) was shut out from all family affairs. No one told him (man) anything. The children, alone with their mother, told her (mother) all about the day's happenings, everything. Nothing had really taken place in them until it was told to their mother. But as soon as the father came in, everything stopped. He (father) was like the scotch in the smooth, happy machinery of the home. And he (father) was always aware of this fall of silence on his (father) entry, the shutting off of life, the unwelcome. But now it was gone too far to alter.

He (father) would dearly have liked the children to talk to him (father), but they could not. Sometimes Mrs. Morel would say:

``You ought to tell your father.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Paul won a prize in a competition in a child's paper. Everybody was highly jubilant.

``Now you'd better tell your father when he (father) comes in,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``You know how be carries on and says he (father)'s never told anything.'' (unknown)

``All right,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul. But he (Paul) would almost rather have forfeited the prize than have to tell his (Paul) father.

``I've won a prize in a competition, dad,'' (he)
he (Paul) said. Morel turned round to him (Paul).

``Have you, my boy? What sort of a competition?'' (unknown)

``Oh, nothing--about famous women.'' (unknown)

``And how much is the prize, then, as you've got?'' (unknown)

``It's a book.'' (unknown)

``Oh, indeed!'' (unknown)

``About birds.'' (unknown)

``Hm--hm!'' (unknown)

And that was all. Conversation was impossible between the father and any other member of the family. He (father) was an outsider. He (father) had denied the God in him (father).

The only times when he (father) entered again into the life of his (father) own people was when he (father) worked, and was happy at work. Sometimes, in the evening, he (father) cobbled the boots or mended the kettle or his (father) pit-bottle. Then he (father) always wanted several attendants, and the children enjoyed it. They united with him (father) in the work, in the actual doing of something, when he (father) was his (father) real self again.

He (father) was a good workman, dexterous, and one who, when he (father) was in a good humour, always sang. He (father) had whole periods, months, almost years, of friction and nasty temper. Then sometimes he (father) was jolly again. It was nice to see him (father) run with a piece of red-hot iron into the scullery, crying:

``Out of my road--out of my road!'' (him)

Then he (father) hammered the soft, red-glowing stuff on his (father) iron goose, and made the shape he (father) wanted. Or he (father) sat absorbed for a moment, soldering. Then the children watched with joy as the metal sank suddenly molten, and was shoved about against the nose of the soldering-iron, while the room was full of a scent of burnt resin and hot tin, and Morel was silent and intent for a minute. He (father) always sang when he (father) mended boots because of the jolly sound of hammering. And he (father) was rather happy when he (father) sat putting great patches on his (father) moleskin pit trousers, which he (father) would often do, considering them too dirty, and the stuff too hard, for his (father) wife to mend.

But the best time for the young children was when he (father) made fuses. Morel fetched a sheaf of long sound wheat-straws from the attic. These he (father) cleaned with his (father) hand, till each one gleamed like a stalk of gold, after which he (father) cut the straws into lengths of about six inches, leaving, if he (father) could, a notch at the bottom of each piece. He (father) always had a beautifully sharp knife that could cut a straw clean without hurting it. Then he (father) set in the middle of the table a heap of gunpowder, a little pile of black grains upon the white-scrubbed board. He (father) made and trimmed the straws while Paul and Annie rifled and plugged them. Paul loved to see the black grains trickle down a crack in his (Paul) palm into the mouth of the straw, peppering jollily downwards till the straw was full. Then he (Paul) bunged up the mouth with a bit of soap--which he (Paul) got on his (Paul) thumb-nail from a pat in a saucer--and the straw was finished.

``Look, dad!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``That's right, my beauty,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Morel, who was peculiarly lavish of endearments to his (Paul) second son. Paul popped the fuse into the powder-tin, ready for the morning, when Morel would take it to the pit, and use it to fire a shot that would blast the coal down.

Meantime Arthur, still fond of his (Arthur) father, would lean on the arm of Morel's chair and say:

``Tell us about down pit, daddy.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

This Morel loved to do.

``Well, there's one little `oss--we call `im Taffy,'' (he)
he (Arthur) would begin.
``An' he (daddy)'s a fawce `un!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel had a warm way of telling a story. He (Arthur) made one feel Taffy's cunning.

``He (daddy)'s a brown `un,'' (he)
he (Arthur) would answer, ``an' not very high. Well, he (daddy) comes i' th' stall wi' a rattle, an' then yo' `ear `im sneeze.

''`Ello, Taff,'' (unknown)
you say, `what art sneezin' for? Bin ta'ein' some snuff?''

``An' 'e sneezes again. Then he (daddy) slives up an' shoves `is `ead on yer, that cadin'.

''`What's want, Taff?'' (yo)
yo' say.''

``And what does he (daddy)?'' (Arthur/ARTHUR)
Arthur always asked.

``He (daddy) wants a bit o' bacca, my duckie.'' (everybody)

This story of Taffy would go on interminably, and everybody loved it.

Or sometimes it was a new tale.

``An' what dost think, my darlin'? When I went to put my coat on at snap-time, what should go runnin' up my arm but a mouse.

''`Hey up, theer!'' (I)
I shouts.

``An' I wor just in time ter get `im by th' tail.'' (unknown)

``And did you kill it?'' (unknown)

``I did, for they're a nuisance. The place is fair snied wi' 'em.'' (unknown)

``An' what do they live on?'' (unknown)

``The corn as the `osses drops--an' they'll get in your pocket an' eat your snap, if you'll let 'em--no matter where yo' hing your coat--the slivin', nibblin' little nuisances, for they are.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

These happy evenings could not take place unless Morel had some job to do. And then he (Arthur) always went to bed very early, often before the children. There was nothing remaining for him (Arthur) to stay up for, when he (Arthur) had finished tinkering, and had skimmed the headlines of the newspaper.

And the children felt secure when their father was in bed. They lay and talked softly a while. Then they started as the lights went suddenly sprawling over the ceiling from the lamps that swung in the hands of the colliers tramping by outside, going to take the nine o'clock shift. They listened to the voices of the men, imagined them dipping down into the dark valley. Sometimes they went to the window and watched the three or four lamps growing tinier and tinier, swaying down the fields in the darkness. Then it was a joy to rush back to bed and cuddle closely in the warmth.

Paul was rather a delicate boy, subject to bronchitis. The others were all quite strong; so this was another reason for his (Paul) mother's difference in feeling for him (Paul). One day he (Paul) came home at dinner-time feeling ill. But it was not a family to make any fuss.

``What's the matter with YOU?'' (mother)
his (Paul) mother asked sharply.

``Nothing,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.

But he (Paul) ate no dinner.

``If you eat no dinner, you're not going to school,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

``Why?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``That's why.'' (he)

So after dinner he (Paul) lay down on the sofa, on the warm chintz cushions the children loved. Then he (Paul) fell into a kind of doze. That afternoon Mrs. Morel was ironing. She (Morel) listened to the small, restless noise the boy made in his (boy) throat as she (Morel) worked. Again rose in her (Morel) heart the old, almost weary feeling towards him (boy). She (Morel) had never expected him (boy) to live. And yet he (boy) had a great vitality in his (boy) young body. Perhaps it would have been a little relief to her (Morel) if he (boy) had died. She (Morel) always felt a mixture of anguish in her (Morel) love for him (boy).

He (boy), in his (boy) semi-conscious sleep, was vaguely aware of the clatter of the iron on the iron-stand, of the faint thud, thud on the ironing-board. Once roused, he (boy) opened his (boy) eyes to see his (boy) mother standing on the hearthrug with the hot iron near her (mother) cheek, listening, as it were, to the heat. Her (mother) still face, with the mouth closed tight from suffering and disillusion and self-denial, and her (mother) nose the smallest bit on one side, and her (mother) blue eyes so young, quick, and warm, made his (boy) heart contract with love. When she (mother) was quiet, so, she (mother) looked brave and rich with life, but as if she (mother) had been done out of her (mother) rights. It hurt the boy keenly, this feeling about her (mother) that she (mother) had never had her (mother) life's fulfilment: and his (boy) own incapability to make up to her (mother) hurt him (boy) with a sense of impotence, yet made him (boy) patiently dogged inside. It was his (boy) childish aim.

She (mother) spat on the iron, and a little ball of spit bounded, raced off the dark, glossy surface. Then, kneeling, she (mother) rubbed the iron on the sack lining of the hearthrug vigorously. She (mother) was warm in the ruddy firelight. Paul loved the way she (mother) crouched and put her (mother) head on one side. Her (mother) movements were light and quick. It was always a pleasure to watch her (mother). Nothing she (mother) ever did, no movement she (mother) ever made, could have been found fault with by her (mother) children. The room was warm and full of the scent of hot linen. Later on the clergyman came and talked softly with her (mother).

Paul was laid up with an attack of bronchitis. He (Paul) did not mind much. What happened happened, and it was no good kicking against the pricks. He (Paul) loved the evenings, after eight o'clock, when the light was put out, and he (Paul) could watch the fire-flames spring over the darkness of the walls and ceiling; could watch huge shadows waving and tossing, till the room seemed full of men who battled silently.

On retiring to bed, the father would come into the sickroom. He (father) was always very gentle if anyone were ill. But he (father) disturbed the atmosphere for the boy.

``Are ter asleep, my darlin'?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Morel asked softly.

``No; is my mother comin'?'' (unknown)

``She (mother)'s just finishin' foldin' the clothes. Do you want anything?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Morel rarely
``thee'd'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
his (father) son.

``I don't want nothing. But how long will she (mother) be?'' (unknown)

``Not long, my duckie.'' (The father)

The father waited undecidedly on the hearthrug for a moment or two. He (father) felt his (father) son did not want him (father). Then he (father) went to the top of the stairs and said to his (father) wife:

``This childt's axin' for thee; how long art goin' to be?'' (wife)

``Until I've finished, good gracious! Tell him (thee) to go to sleep.'' (unknown)

``She (mother) says you're to go to sleep,'' (the father)
the father repeated gently to Paul.

``Well, I want HER to come,'' (the boy)
insisted the boy.

``He (thee) says he (thee) can't go off till you come,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Morel called downstairs.

``Eh, dear! I shan't be long. And do stop shouting downstairs. There's the other children--'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Then Morel came again and crouched before the bedroom fire. He (Paul) loved a fire dearly.

``She (mother) says she (mother) won't be long,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

He (Paul) loitered about indefinitely. The boy began to get feverish with irritation. His (boy) father's presence seemed to aggravate all his (boy) sick impatience. At last Morel, after having stood looking at his (boy) son awhile, said softly:

``Good-night, my darling.'' (son)

``Good-night,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul replied, turning round in relief to be alone.

Paul loved to sleep with his (Paul) mother. Sleep is still most perfect, in spite of hygienists, when it is shared with a beloved. The warmth, the security and peace of soul, the utter comfort from the touch of the other, knits the sleep, so that it takes the body and soul completely in its healing. Paul lay against her (mother) and slept, and got better; whilst she (mother), always a bad sleeper, fell later on into a profound sleep that seemed to give her (mother) faith.

In convalescence he (Paul) would sit up in bed, see the fluffy horses feeding at the troughs in the field, scattering their hay on the trodden yellow snow; watch the miners troop home--small, black figures trailing slowly in gangs across the white field. Then the night came up in dark blue vapour from the snow.

In convalescence everything was wonderful. The snowflakes, suddenly arriving on the window-pane, clung there a moment like swallows, then were gone, and a drop of water was crawling down the glass. The snowflakes whirled round the corner of the house, like pigeons dashing by. Away across the valley the little black train crawled doubtfully over the great whiteness.

While they were so poor, the children were delighted if they could do anything to help economically. Annie and Paul and Arthur went out early in the morning, in summer, looking for mushrooms, hunting through the wet grass, from which the larks were rising, for the white-skinned, wonderful naked bodies crouched secretly in the green. And if they got half a pound they felt exceedingly happy: there was the joy of finding something, the joy of accepting something straight from the hand of Nature, and the joy of contributing to the family exchequer.

But the most important harvest, after gleaning for frumenty, was the blackberries. Mrs. Morel must buy fruit for puddings on the Saturdays; also she (Morel) liked blackberries. So Paul and Arthur scoured the coppices and woods and old quarries, so long as a blackberry was to be found, every week-end going on their search. In that region of mining villages blackberries became a comparative rarity. But Paul hunted far and wide. He (Paul) loved being out in the country, among the bushes. But he (Paul) also could not bear to go home to his (Paul) mother empty. That, he (Paul) felt, would disappoint her (mother), and he (Paul) would have died rather.

``Good gracious!'' (she)
she (mother) would exclaim as the lads came in, late, and tired to death, and hungry,
``wherever have you been?'' (the lads)

``Well,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
replied Paul,
``there wasn't any, so we went over Misk Hills. And look here, our mother!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

She (mother) peeped into the basket.

``Now, those are fine ones!'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed.

``And there's over two pounds--isn't there over two pounds'' (She)
?

She (mother) tried the basket.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (mother) answered doubtfully.

Then Paul fished out a little spray. He (Paul) always brought her (mother) one spray, the best he (Paul) could find.

``Pretty!'' (she)
she (mother) said, in a curious tone, of a woman accepting a love-token.

The boy walked all day, went miles and miles, rather than own himself beaten and come home to her (mother) empty-handed. She (mother) never realised this, whilst he (boy) was young. She (mother) was a woman who waited for her (mother) children to grow up. And William occupied her (mother) chiefly.

But when William went to Nottingham, and was not so much at home, the mother made a companion of Paul. The latter was unconsciously jealous of his (Paul) brother, and William was jealous of him (William). At the same time, they were good friends.

Mrs. Morel's intimacy with her (Morel) second son was more subtle and fine, perhaps not so passionate as with her (Morel) eldest. It was the rule that Paul should fetch the money on Friday afternoons. The colliers of the five pits were paid on Fridays, but not individually. All the earnings of each stall were put down to the chief butty, as contractor, and he (contractor) divided the wages again, either in the public-house or in his (contractor) own home. So that the children could fetch the money, school closed early on Friday afternoons. Each of the Morel children--William, then Annie, then Paul--had fetched the money on Friday afternoons, until they went themselves to work. Paul used to set off at half-past three, with a little calico bag in his (Paul) pocket. Down all the paths, women, girls, children, and men were seen trooping to the offices.

These offices were quite handsome: a new, red-brick building, almost like a mansion, standing in its own grounds at the end of Greenhill Lane. The waiting-room was the hall, a long, bare room paved with blue brick, and having a seat all round, against the wall. Here sat the colliers in their pit-dirt. They had come up early. The women and children usually loitered about on the red gravel paths. Paul always examined the grass border, and the big grass bank, because in it grew tiny pansies and tiny forget-me-nots. There was a sound of many voices. The women had on their Sunday hats. The girls chattered loudly. Little dogs ran here and there. The green shrubs were silent all around.

Then from inside came the cry

``Spinney Park--Spinney Park.'' (the folk)
All the folk for Spinney Park trooped inside. When it was time for Bretty to be paid, Paul went in among the crowd. The pay-room was quite small. A counter went across, dividing it into half. Behind the counter stood two men--Mr. Braithwaite and his (Braithwaite) clerk, Mr. Winterbottom. Mr. Braithwaite was large, somewhat of the stern patriarch in appearance, having a rather thin white beard. He (Braithwaite) was usually muffled in an enormous silk neckerchief, and right up to the hot summer a huge fire burned in the open grate. No window was open. Sometimes in winter the air scorched the throats of the people, coming in from the freshness. Mr. Winterbottom was rather small and fat, and very bald. He (Winterbottom) made remarks that were not witty, whilst his (Winterbottom) chief launched forth patriarchal admonitions against the colliers.

The room was crowded with miners in their pit-dirt, men who had been home and changed, and women, and one or two children, and usually a dog. Paul was quite small, so it was often his (Paul) fate to be jammed behind the legs of the men, near the fire which scorched him (Paul). He (Paul) knew the order of the names--they went according to stall number.

``Holliday,'' (Mr. Braithwaite)
came the ringing voice of Mr. Braithwaite. Then Mrs. Holliday stepped silently forward, was paid, drew aside.

``Bower--John Bower.'' (A boy)

A boy stepped to the counter. Mr. Braithwaite, large and irascible, glowered at him (Braithwaite) over his (Braithwaite) spectacles.

``John Bower!'' (he)
he (Braithwaite) repeated.

``It's me,'' (the boy)
said the boy.

``Why, you used to `ave a different nose than that,'' (Mr. Winterbottom)
said glossy Mr. Winterbottom, peering over the counter. The people tittered, thinking of John Bower senior.

``How is it your father's not come!'' (Mr. Braithwaite)
said Mr. Braithwaite, in a large and magisterial voice.

``He (father)'s badly,'' (the boy)
piped the boy.

``You should tell him (father) to keep off the drink,'' (the cashier)
pronounced the great cashier.

``An' niver mind if he (father) puts his (father) foot through yer,'' (unknown)
said a mocking voice from behind.

All the men laughed. The large and important cashier looked down at his (Braithwaite) next sheet.

``Fred Pilkington!'' (he)
he (Braithwaite) called, quite indifferent.

Mr. Braithwaite was an important shareholder in the firm.

Paul knew his (Paul) turn was next but one, and his (Paul) heart began to beat. He (Paul) was pushed against the chimney-piece. His (Paul) calves were burning. But he (Paul) did not hope to get through the wall of men.

``Walter Morel!'' (unknown)
came the ringing voice.

``Here!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
piped Paul, small and inadequate.

``Morel--Walter Morel!'' (the cashier finger thumb)
the cashier repeated, his (Paul) finger and thumb on the invoice, ready to pass on.

Paul was suffering convulsions of self-consciousness, and could not or would not shout. The backs of the men obliterated him (Paul). Then Mr. Winterbottom came to the rescue.

``He (Morel)'s here. Where is he (Morel)? Morel's lad?'' (The man round)

The fat, red, bald little man peered round with keen eyes. He (Winterbottom) pointed at the fireplace. The colliers looked round, moved aside, and disclosed the boy.

``Here he (Morel) is!'' (Mr. Winterbottom)
said Mr. Winterbottom.

Paul went to the counter.

``Seventeen pounds eleven and fivepence. Why don't you shout up when you're called?'' (Mr. Braithwaite)
said Mr. Braithwaite. He (Braithwaite) banged on to the invoice a five-pound bag of silver, then in a delicate and pretty movement, picked up a little ten-pound column of gold, and plumped it beside the silver. The gold slid in a bright stream over the paper. The cashier finished counting off the money; the boy dragged the whole down the counter to Mr. Winterbottom, to whom the stoppages for rent and tools must be paid. Here he (Winterbottom) suffered again.

``Sixteen an' six,'' (Mr. Winterbottom)
said Mr. Winterbottom.

The lad was too much upset to count. He (Winterbottom) pushed forward some loose silver and half a sovereign.

``How much do you think you've given me?'' (Mr. Winterbottom)
asked Mr. Winterbottom.

The boy looked at him (boy), but said nothing. He (boy) had not the faintest notion.

``Haven't you got a tongue in your head?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul bit his (Paul) lip, and pushed forward some more silver.

``Don't they teach you to count at the Board-school?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``Nowt but algibbra an' French,'' (a collier)
said a collier.

``An' cheek an' impidence,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said another.

Paul was keeping someone waiting. With trembling fingers he (Paul) got his (Paul) money into the bag and slid out. He (Paul) suffered the tortures of the damned on these occasions.

His (Paul) relief, when he (Paul) got outside, and was walking along the Mansfield Road, was infinite. On the park wall the mosses were green. There were some gold and some white fowls pecking under the apple trees of an orchard. The colliers were walking home in a stream. The boy went near the wall, self-consciously. He (boy) knew many of the men, but could not recognise them in their dirt. And this was a new torture to him (boy).

When he (boy) got down to the New Inn, at Bretty, his (boy) father was not yet come. Mrs. Wharmby, the landlady, knew him (boy). His (boy) grandmother, Morel's mother, had been Mrs. Wharmby's friend.

``Your father's not come yet,'' (the landlady)
said the landlady, in the peculiar half-scornful, half-patronising voice of a woman who talks chiefly to grown men.
``Sit you down.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul sat down on the edge of the bench in the bar. Some colliers were

``reckoning'' (Some colliers)
--sharing out their money--in a corner; others came in. They all glanced at the boy without speaking. At last Morel came; brisk, and with something of an air, even in his (boy) blackness.

``Hello!'' (he)
he (boy) said rather tenderly to his (boy) son.
``Have you bested me? Shall you have a drink of something?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul and all the children were bred up fierce anti-alcoholists, and he (Paul) would have suffered more in drinking a lemonade before all the men than in having a tooth drawn.

The landlady looked at him (Paul) _de haut en bas_, rather pitying, and at the same time, resenting his (Paul) clear, fierce morality. Paul went home, glowering. He (Paul) entered the house silently. Friday was baking day, and there was usually a hot bun. His (Paul) mother put it before him (Paul).

Suddenly he (Paul) turned on her (mother) in a fury, his (Paul) eyes flashing:

``I'm NOT going to the office any more,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Why, what's the matter?'' (mother)
his (Paul) mother asked in surprise. His (Paul) sudden rages rather amused her (mother).

``I'm NOT going any more,'' (he)
he (Paul) declared.

``Oh, very well, tell your father so.'' (He)

He (Paul) chewed his (Paul) bun as if he (Paul) hated it.

``I'm not--I'm not going to fetch the money.'' (unknown)

``Then one of Carlin's children can go; they'd be glad enough of the sixpence,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

This sixpence was Paul's only income. It mostly went in buying birthday presents; but it WAS an income, and he (Paul) treasured it. But--

``They can have it, then!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``I don't want it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, very well,'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother.
``But you needn't bully ME about it.'' (unknown)

``They're hateful, and common, and hateful, they are, and I'm not going any more. Mr. Braithwaite drops his (Braithwaite) `h's', an' Mr. Winterbottom says

``You was'.'' (unknown)

``And is that why you won't go any more?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
smiled Mrs. Morel.

The boy was silent for some time. His (boy) face was pale, his (boy) eyes dark and furious. His (boy) mother moved about at her (mother) work, taking no notice of him (boy).

``They always stan' in front of me, so's I can't get out,'' (he)
he (boy) said.

``Well, my lad, you've only to ASK them,'' (she)
she (mother) replied.

``An' then Alfred Winterbottom says,

``What do they teach you at the Board-school?''' (unknown)

``They never taught HIM much,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``that is a fact--neither manners nor wit--and his (Alfred) cunning he (Alfred) was born with.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

So, in her (Morel) own way, she (Morel) soothed him (boy). His (boy) ridiculous hypersensitiveness made her (Morel) heart ache. And sometimes the fury in his (boy) eyes roused her (Morel), made her (Morel) sleeping soul lift up its head a moment, surprised.

``What was the cheque?'' (she)
she (Morel) asked.

``Seventeen pounds eleven and fivepence, and sixteen and six stoppages,'' (the boy)
replied the boy.
``It's a good week; and only five shillings stoppages for my father.'' (she)

So she (Morel) was able to calculate how much her (Morel) husband had earned, and could call him (husband) to account if he (husband) gave her (Morel) short money. Morel always kept to himself the secret of the week's amount.

Friday was the baking night and market night. It was the rule that Paul should stay at home and bake. He (Paul) loved to stop in and draw or read; he (Paul) was very fond of drawing. Annie always

``gallivanted'' (Annie)
on Friday nights; Arthur was enjoying himself as usual. So the boy remained alone.

Mrs. Morel loved her (Morel) marketing. In the tiny market-place on the top of the hill, where four roads, from Nottingham and Derby, Ilkeston and Mansfield, meet, many stalls were erected. Brakes ran in from surrounding villages. The market-place was full of women, the streets packed with men. It was amazing to see so many men everywhere in the streets. Mrs. Morel usually quarrelled with her (Morel) lace woman, sympathised with her (Morel) fruit man--who was a gabey, but his (man) wife was a bad `un--laughed with the fish man--who was a scamp but so droll--put the linoleum man in his (man) place, was cold with the odd-wares man, and only went to the crockery man when she (wife) was driven--or drawn by the cornflowers on a little dish; then she (wife) was coldly polite.

``I wondered how much that little dish was,'' (she)
she (wife) said.

``Sevenpence to you.'' (unknown)

``Thank you.'' (She)

She (wife) put the dish down and walked away; but she (wife) could not leave the market-place without it. Again she (wife) went by where the pots lay coldly on the floor, and she (wife) glanced at the dish furtively, pretending not to.

She (wife) was a little woman, in a bonnet and a black costume. Her (wife) bonnet was in its third year; it was a great grievance to Annie.

``Mother!'' (the girl)
the girl implored,
``don't wear that nubbly little bonnet.'' (the girl)

``Then what else shall I wear,'' (the mother)
replied the mother tartly.
``And I'm sure it's right enough.'' (unknown)

It had started with a tip; then had had flowers; now was reduced to black lace and a bit of jet.

``It looks rather come down,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``Couldn't you give it a pick-me-up?'' (unknown)

``I'll jowl your head for impudence,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, and she (Morel) tied the strings of the black bonnet valiantly under her (Morel) chin.

She (Morel) glanced at the dish again. Both she (Morel) and her (Morel) enemy, the pot man, had an uncomfortable feeling, as if there were something between them. Suddenly he (man) shouted:

``Do you want it for fivepence?'' (he)

She (Morel) started. Her (Morel) heart hardened; but then she (Morel) stooped and took up her (Morel) dish.

``I'll have it,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

``Yer'll do me the favour, like?'' (he)
he (man) said.
``Yer'd better spit in it, like yer do when y'ave something give yer.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel paid him (man) the fivepence in a cold manner.

``I don't see you give it me,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``You wouldn't let me have it for fivepence if you didn't want to.'' (unknown)

``In this flamin', scrattlin' place you may count yerself lucky if you can give your things away,'' (he)
he (man) growled.

``Yes; there are bad times, and good,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

But she (Morel) had forgiven the pot man. They were friends. She (Morel) dare now finger his (man) pots. So she (Morel) was happy.

Paul was waiting for her (Morel). He (Paul) loved her (Morel) home-coming. She (Morel) was always her (Morel) best so--triumphant, tired, laden with parcels, feeling rich in spirit. He (Paul) heard her (Morel) quick, light step in the entry and looked up from his (Paul) drawing.

``Oh!'' (she)
she (Morel) sighed, smiling at him (Paul) from the doorway.

``My word, you ARE loaded!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed, putting down his (Paul) brush.

``I am!'' (she)
she (Morel) gasped.
``That brazen Annie said she (Annie)'d meet me. SUCH a weight!'' (She)

She (Morel) dropped her (Morel) string bag and her (Morel) packages on the table.

``Is the bread done?'' (she)
she (Morel) asked, going to the oven.

``The last one is soaking,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.
``You needn't look, I've not forgotten it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, that pot man!'' (she)
she (Morel) said, closing the oven door.
``You know what a wretch I've said he (man) was? Well, I don't think he (man)'s quite so bad.'' (unknown)

``Don't you?'' (The boy)

The boy was attentive to her (Morel). She (Morel) took off her (Morel) little black bonnet.

``No. I think he (man) can't make any money--well, it's everybody's cry alike nowadays--and it makes him (man) disagreeable.'' (unknown)

``It would ME,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Well, one can't wonder at it. And he (man) let me have--how much do you think he (man) let me have THIS for?'' (She)

She (Morel) took the dish out of its rag of newspaper, and stood looking on it with joy.

``Show me!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

The two stood together gloating over the dish.

``I LOVE cornflowers on things,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Yes, and I thought of the teapot you bought me--'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``One and three,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Fivepence!'' (unknown)

``It's not enough, mother.'' (unknown)

``No. Do you know, I fairly sneaked off with it. But I'd been extravagant, I couldn't afford any more. And he (man) needn't have let me have it if he (man) hadn't wanted to.'' (unknown)

``No, he (man) needn't, need he (man),'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, and the two comforted each other from the fear of having robbed the pot man.

``We c'n have stewed fruit in it,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Or custard, or a jelly,'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother.

``Or radishes and lettuce,'' (he)
said he (Paul).

``Don't forget that bread,'' (she)
she (mother) said, her (mother) voice bright with glee.

Paul looked in the oven; tapped the loaf on the base.

``It's done,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, giving it to her (mother).

She (mother) tapped it also.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (mother) replied, going to unpack her (mother) bag.
``Oh, and I'm a wicked, extravagant woman. I know I s'll come to want.'' (He)

He (Paul) hopped to her (mother) side eagerly, to see her (mother) latest extravagance. She (mother) unfolded another lump of newspaper and disclosed some roots of pansies and of crimson daisies.

``Four penn`orth!'' (she)
she (mother) moaned.

``How CHEAP!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried.

``Yes, but I couldn't afford it THIS week of all weeks.'' (unknown)

``But lovely!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried.

``Aren't they!'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed, giving way to pure joy.
``Paul, look at this yellow one, isn't it--and a face just like an old man!'' (unknown)

``Just!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
cried Paul, stooping to sniff.
``And smells that nice! But he (man)'s a bit splashed.'' (He)

He (Paul) ran in the scullery, came back with the flannel, and carefully washed the pansy.

``NOW look at him (man) now he (man)'s wet!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Yes!'' (she)
she (pansy) exclaimed, brimful of satisfaction.

The children of Scargill Street felt quite select. At the end where the Morels lived there were not many young things. So the few were more united. Boys and girls played together, the girls joining in the fights and the rough games, the boys taking part in the dancing games and rings and make-belief of the girls.

Annie and Paul and Arthur loved the winter evenings, when it was not wet. They stayed indoors till the colliers were all gone home, till it was thick dark, and the street would be deserted. Then they tied their scarves round their necks, for they scorned overcoats, as all the colliers' children did, and went out. The entry was very dark, and at the end the whole great night opened out, in a hollow, with a little tangle of lights below where Minton pit lay, and another far away opposite for Selby. The farthest tiny lights seemed to stretch out the darkness for ever. The children looked anxiously down the road at the one lamp-post, which stood at the end of the field path. If the little, luminous space were deserted, the two boys felt genuine desolation. They stood with their hands in their pockets under the lamp, turning their backs on the night, quite miserable, watching the dark houses. Suddenly a pinafore under a short coat was seen, and a long-legged girl came flying up.

``Where's Billy Pillins an' your Annie an' Eddie Dakin?'' (unknown)

``I don't know.'' (unknown)

But it did not matter so much--there were three now. They set up a game round the lamp-post, till the others rushed up, yelling. Then the play went fast and furious.

There was only this one lamp-post. Behind was the great scoop of darkness, as if all the night were there. In front, another wide, dark way opened over the hill brow. Occasionally somebody came out of this way and went into the field down the path. In a dozen yards the night had swallowed them. The children played on.

They were brought exceedingly close together owing to their isolation. If a quarrel took place, the whole play was spoilt. Arthur was very touchy, and Billy Pillins--really Philips--was worse. Then Paul had to side with Arthur, and on Paul's side went Alice, while Billy Pillins always had Emmie Limb and Eddie Dakin to back him (Pillins) up. Then the six would fight, hate with a fury of hatred, and flee home in terror. Paul never forgot, after one of these fierce internecine fights, seeing a big red moon lift itself up, slowly, between the waste road over the hilltop, steadily, like a great bird. And he (Paul) thought of the Bible, that the moon should be turned to blood. And the next day he (Paul) made haste to be friends with Billy Pillins. And then the wild, intense games went on again under the lamp-post, surrounded by so much darkness. Mrs. Morel, going into her (Morel) parlour, would hear the children singing away:

``My shoes are made of Spanish leather, My socks are made of silk; I wear a ring on every finger, I wash myself in milk.'' (children)

They sounded so perfectly absorbed in the game as their voices came out of the night, that they had the feel of wild creatures singing. It stirred the mother; and she (mother) understood when they came in at eight o'clock, ruddy, with brilliant eyes, and quick, passionate speech.

They all loved the Scargill Street house for its openness, for the great scallop of the world it had in view. On summer evenings the women would stand against the field fence, gossiping, facing the west, watching the sunsets flare quickly out, till the Derbyshire hills ridged across the crimson far away, like the black crest of a newt.

In this summer season the pits never turned full time, particularly the soft coal. Mrs. Dakin, who lived next door to Mrs. Morel, going to the field fence to shake her (Morel) hearthrug, would spy men coming slowly up the hill. She (Morel) saw at once they were colliers. Then she (Morel) waited, a tall, thin, shrew-faced woman, standing on the hill brow, almost like a menace to the poor colliers who were toiling up. It was only eleven o'clock. From the far-off wooded hills the haze that hangs like fine black crape at the back of a summer morning had not yet dissipated. The first man came to the stile.

``Chock-chock!'' (unknown)
went the gate under his (man) thrust.

``What, han' yer knocked off?'' (Mrs. Dakin)
cried Mrs. Dakin.

``We han, missis.'' (unknown)

``It's a pity as they letn yer goo,'' (she)
she (Dakin) said sarcastically.

``It is that,'' (the man)
replied the man.

``Nay, you know you're flig to come up again,'' (she)
she (Dakin) said.

And the man went on. Mrs. Dakin, going up her (Dakin) yard, spied Mrs. Morel taking the ashes to the ash-pit.

``I reckon Minton's knocked off, missis,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried.

``Isn't it sickenin!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
exclaimed Mrs. Morel in wrath.

``Ha! But I'n just seed Jont Hutchby.'' (unknown)

``They might as well have saved their shoe-leather,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel. And both women went indoors disgusted.

The colliers, their faces scarcely blackened, were trooping home again. Morel hated to go back. He (man) loved the sunny morning. But he (man) had gone to pit to work, and to be sent home again spoilt his (man) temper.

``Good gracious, at this time!'' (wife)
exclaimed his (man) wife, as he (man) entered.

``Can I help it, woman?'' (he)
he (man) shouted.

``And I've not done half enough dinner.'' (unknown)

``Then I'll eat my bit o' snap as I took with me,'' (he)
he (man) bawled pathetically. He (man) felt ignominious and sore.

And the children, coming home from school, would wonder to see their father eating with his (father) dinner the two thick slices of rather dry and dirty bread-and-butter that had been to pit and back.

``What's my dad eating his (dad) snap for now?'' (Arthur/ARTHUR)
asked Arthur.

``I should ha'e it holled at me if I didna,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
snorted Morel.

``What a story!'' (wife)
exclaimed his (Arthur) wife.

``An' is it goin' to be wasted?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.
``I'm not such a extravagant mortal as you lot, with your waste. If I drop a bit of bread at pit, in all the dust an' dirt, I pick it up an' eat it.'' (unknown)

``The mice would eat it,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``It wouldn't be wasted.'' (unknown)

``Good bread-an'-butter's not for mice, either,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.
``Dirty or not dirty, I'd eat it rather than it should be wasted.'' (unknown)

``You might leave it for the mice and pay for it out of your next pint,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Oh, might I?'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed.

They were very poor that autumn. William had just gone away to London, and his (William) mother missed his (William) money. He (William) sent ten shillings once or twice, but he (William) had many things to pay for at first. His (William) letters came regularly once a week. He (William) wrote a good deal to his (William) mother, telling her (mother) all his (William) life, how he (William) made friends, and was exchanging lessons with a Frenchman, how he (William) enjoyed London. His (William) mother felt again he (William) was remaining to her (mother) just as when he (William) was at home. She (mother) wrote to him (William) every week her (mother) direct, rather witty letters. All day long, as she (mother) cleaned the house, she (mother) thought of him (William). He (William) was in London: he (William) would do well. Almost, he (William) was like her (mother) knight who wore HER favour in the battle.

He (William) was coming at Christmas for five days. There had never been such preparations. Paul and Arthur scoured the land for holly and evergreens. Annie made the pretty paper hoops in the old-fashioned way. And there was unheard-of extravagance in the larder. Mrs. Morel made a big and magnificent cake. Then, feeling queenly, she (Morel) showed Paul how to blanch almonds. He (Paul) skinned the long nuts reverently, counting them all, to see not one was lost. It was said that eggs whisked better in a cold place. So the boy stood in the scullery, where the temperature was nearly at freezing-point, and whisked and whisked, and flew in excitement to his (boy) mother as the white of egg grew stiffer and more snowy.

``Just look, mother! Isn't it lovely?'' (he)

And he (boy) balanced a bit on his (boy) nose, then blew it in the air.

``Now, don't waste it,'' (the mother)
said the mother.

Everybody was mad with excitement. William was coming on Christmas Eve. Mrs. Morel surveyed her (Morel) pantry. There was a big plum cake, and a rice cake, jam tarts, lemon tarts, and mince-pies--two enormous dishes. She (Morel) was finishing cooking--Spanish tarts and cheese-cakes. Everywhere was decorated. The kissing bunch of berried holly hung with bright and glittering things, spun slowly over Mrs. Morel's head as she (Morel) trimmed her (Morel) little tarts in the kitchen. A great fire roared. There was a scent of cooked pastry. He (William) was due at seven o'clock, but he (William) would be late. The three children had gone to meet him (William). She (Morel) was alone. But at a quarter to seven Morel came in again. Neither wife nor husband spoke. He (husband) sat in his (husband) armchair, quite awkward with excitement, and she (Morel) quietly went on with her (Morel) baking. Only by the careful way in which she (Morel) did things could it be told how much moved she (Morel) was. The clock ticked on.

``What time dost say he (your)'s coming?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Morel asked for the fifth time.

``The train gets in at half-past six,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied emphatically.

``Then he (your)'ll be here at ten past seven.'' (unknown)

``Eh, bless you, it'll be hours late on the Midland,'' (she)
she (Morel) said indifferently. But she (Morel) hoped, by expecting him (husband) late, to bring him (husband) early. Morel went down the entry to look for him (husband). Then he (husband) came back.

``Goodness, man!'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``You're like an ill-sitting hen.'' (unknown)

``Hadna you better be gettin' him (man) summat t' eat ready?'' (the father)
asked the father.

``There's plenty of time,'' (she)
she (Morel) answered.

``There's not so much as I can see on,'' (he)
he (husband) answered, turning crossly in his (husband) chair. She (Morel) began to clear her (Morel) table. The kettle was singing. They waited and waited.

Meantime the three children were on the platform at Sethley Bridge, on the Midland main line, two miles from home. They waited one hour. A train came--he (husband) was not there. Down the line the red and green lights shone. It was very dark and very cold.

``Ask him (man) if the London train's come,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul to Annie, when they saw a man in a tip cap.

``I'm not,'' (Annie)
said Annie.
``You be quiet--he (man) might send us off.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

But Paul was dying for the man to know they were expecting someone by the London train: it sounded so grand. Yet he (Paul) was much too much scared of broaching any man, let alone one in a peaked cap, to dare to ask. The three children could scarcely go into the waiting-room for fear of being sent away, and for fear something should happen whilst they were off the platform. Still they waited in the dark and cold.

``It's an hour an' a half late,'' (Arthur/ARTHUR)
said Arthur pathetically.

``Well,'' (Annie)
said Annie,
``it's Christmas Eve.'' (Annie)

They all grew silent. He (Arthur) wasn't coming. They looked down the darkness of the railway. There was London! It seemed the utter-most of distance. They thought anything might happen if one came from London. They were all too troubled to talk. Cold, and unhappy, and silent, they huddled together on the platform.

At last, after more than two hours, they saw the lights of an engine peering round, away down the darkness. A porter ran out. The children drew back with beating hearts. A great train, bound for Manchester, drew up. Two doors opened, and from one of them, William. They flew to him (William). He (William) handed parcels to them cheerily, and immediately began to explain that this great train had stopped for HIS (William) sake at such a small station as Sethley Bridge: it was not booked to stop.

Meanwhile the parents were getting anxious. The table was set, the chop was cooked, everything was ready. Mrs. Morel put on her (Morel) black apron. She (Morel) was wearing her (Morel) best dress. Then she (Morel) sat, pretending to read. The minutes were a torture to her (Morel).

``H'm!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.
``It's an hour an' a ha'ef.'' (unknown)

``And those children waiting!'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

``Th' train canna ha' come in yet,'' (he)
he (William) said.

``I tell you, on Christmas Eve they're HOURS wrong.'' (unknown)

They were both a bit cross with each other, so gnawed with anxiety. The ash tree moaned outside in a cold, raw wind. And all that space of night from London home! Mrs. Morel suffered. The slight click of the works inside the clock irritated her (Morel). It was getting so late; it was getting unbearable.

At last there was a sound of voices, and a footstep in the entry.

``Ha's here!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Morel, jumping up.

Then he (William) stood back. The mother ran a few steps towards the door and waited. There was a rush and a patter of feet, the door burst open. William was there. He (William) dropped his (William) Gladstone bag and took his (William) mother in his (William) arms.

``Mater!'' (he)
he (William) said.

``My boy!'' (she)
she (mother) cried.

And for two seconds, no longer, she (mother) clasped him (William) and kissed him (William). Then she (mother) withdrew and said, trying to be quite normal:

``But how late you are!'' (she)

``Aren't I!'' (he)
he (William) cried, turning to his (William) father.
``Well, dad!'' (The men)

The two men shook hands.

``Well, my lad!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel's eyes were wet.

``We thought tha'd niver be commin','' (he)
he (William) said.

``Oh, I'd come!'' (William)
exclaimed William.

Then the son turned round to his (son) mother.

``But you look well,'' (she)
she (mother) said proudly, laughing.

``Well!'' (he)
he (son) exclaimed.
``I should think so--coming home!'' (He)

He (son) was a fine fellow, big, straight, and fearless-looking. He (son) looked round at the evergreens and the kissing bunch, and the little tarts that lay in their tins on the hearth.

``By jove! mother, it's not different!'' (he)
he (son) said, as if in relief.

Everybody was still for a second. Then he (son) suddenly sprang forward, picked a tart from the hearth, and pushed it whole into his (son) mouth.

``Well, did iver you see such a parish oven!'' (the father)
the father exclaimed.

He (son) had brought them endless presents. Every penny he (son) had he (son) had spent on them. There was a sense of luxury overflowing in the house. For his (son) mother there was an umbrella with gold on the pale handle. She (mother) kept it to her (mother) dying day, and would have lost anything rather than that. Everybody had something gorgeous, and besides, there were pounds of unknown sweets: Turkish delight, crystallised pineapple, and such-like things which, the children thought, only the splendour of London could provide. And Paul boasted of these sweets among his (Paul) friends.

``Real pineapple, cut off in slices, and then turned into crystal--fair grand!'' (Everybody)

Everybody was mad with happiness in the family. Home was home, and they loved it with a passion of love, whatever the suffering had been. There were parties, there were rejoicings. People came in to see William, to see what difference London had made to him (William). And they all found him (William)

``such a gentleman, and SUCH a fine fellow, my word'' (him)
!

When he (William) went away again the children retired to various places to weep alone. Morel went to bed in misery, and Mrs. Morel felt as if she (Morel) were numbed by some drug, as if her (Morel) feelings were paralysed. She (Morel) loved him (William) passionately.

He (William) was in the office of a lawyer connected with a large shipping firm, and at the midsummer his (William) chief offered him (William) a trip in the Mediterranean on one of the boats, for quite a small cost. Mrs. Morel wrote:

``Go, go, my boy. You may never have a chance again, and I should love to think of you cruising there in the Mediterranean almost better than to have you at home.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
But William came home for his (William) fortnight's holiday. Not even the Mediterranean, which pulled at all his (William) young man's desire to travel, and at his (William) poor man's wonder at the glamorous south, could take him (William) away when he (William) might come home. That compensated his (William) mother for much.

CHAPTER V

PAUL LAUNCHES INTO LIFE

MOREL was rather a heedless man, careless of danger. So he (man) had endless accidents. Now, when Mrs. Morel heard the rattle of an empty coal-cart cease at her (Morel) entry-end, she (Morel) ran into the parlour to look, expecting almost to see her (Morel) husband seated in the waggon, his (husband) face grey under his (husband) dirt, his (husband) body limp and sick with some hurt or other. If it were he (husband), she (Morel) would run out to help.

About a year after William went to London, and just after Paul had left school, before he (Paul) got work, Mrs. Morel was upstairs and her (Morel) son was painting in the kitchen--he (son) was very clever with his (son) brush--when there came a knock at the door. Crossly he (son) put down his (son) brush to go. At the same moment his (son) mother opened a window upstairs and looked down.

A pit-lad in his (son) dirt stood on the threshold.

``Is this Walter Morel's?'' (he)
he (son) asked.

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``What is it?'' (she)

But she (Morel) had guessed already.

``Your mester's got hurt,'' (he)
he (son) said.

``Eh, dear me!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed.
``It's a wonder if he (Morel) hadn't, lad. And what's he (Morel) done this time?'' (unknown)

``I don't know for sure, but it's `is leg somewhere. They ta'ein' `im ter th' `ospital.'' (unknown)

``Good gracious me!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed.
``Eh, dear, what a one he (Morel) is! There's not five minutes of peace, I'll be hanged if there is! His (Morel) thumb's nearly better, and now--Did you see him (Morel)?'' (unknown)

``I seed him (Morel) at th' bottom. An' I seed 'em bring `im up in a tub, an' 'e wor in a dead faint. But he (Morel) shouted like anythink when Doctor Fraser examined him (Fraser) i' th' lamp cabin--an' cossed an' swore, an' said as 'e wor goin' to be ta'en whoam--'e worn't goin' ter th' `ospital.'' (The boy)

The boy faltered to an end.

``He (Fraser) WOULD want to come home, so that I can have all the bother. Thank you, my lad. Eh, dear, if I'm not sick--sick and surfeited, I am!'' (She)

She (Morel) came downstairs. Paul had mechanically resumed his (Paul) painting.

``And it must be pretty bad if they've taken him (lad) to the hospital,'' (she)
she (Morel) went on.
``But what a CARELESS creature he (lad) is! OTHER men don't have all these accidents. Yes, he (lad) WOULD want to put all the burden on me. Eh, dear, just as we WERE getting easy a bit at last. Put those things away, there's no time to be painting now. What time is there a train? I know I s'll have to go trailing to Keston. I s'll have to leave that bedroom.'' (unknown)

``I can finish it,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``You needn't. I shall catch the seven o'clock back, I should think. Oh, my blessed heart, the fuss and commotion he (me)'ll make! And those granite setts at Tinder Hill--he (me) might well call them kidney pebbles--they'll jolt him (me) almost to bits. I wonder why they can't mend them, the state they're in, an' all the men as go across in that ambulance. You'd think they'd have a hospital here. The men bought the ground, and, my sirs, there'd be accidents enough to keep it going. But no, they must trail them ten miles in a slow ambulance to Nottingham. It's a crying shame! Oh, and the fuss he (me)'ll make! I know he (me) will! I wonder who's with him (me). Barker, I s'd think. Poor beggar, he (beggar)'ll wish himself anywhere rather. But he (beggar)'ll look after him (beggar), I know. Now there's no telling how long he (beggar)'ll be stuck in that hospital--and WON

``T he (beggar) hate it! But if it's only his (beggar) leg it's not so bad.'' (she)

All the time she (Morel) was getting ready. Hurriedly taking off her (Morel) bodice, she (Morel) crouched at the boiler while the water ran slowly into her (Morel) lading-can.

``I wish this boiler was at the bottom of the sea!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed, wriggling the handle impatiently. She (Morel) had very handsome, strong arms, rather surprising on a smallish woman.

Paul cleared away, put on the kettle, and set the table.

``There isn't a train till four-twenty,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``You've time enough.'' (unknown)

``Oh no, I haven't!'' (she)
she (woman) cried, blinking at him (Paul) over the towel as she (woman) wiped her (woman) face.

``Yes, you have. You must drink a cup of tea at any rate. Should I come with you to Keston?'' (unknown)

``Come with me? What for, I should like to know? Now, what have I to take him (beggar)? Eh, dear! His (beggar) clean shirt--and it's a blessing it IS clean. But it had better be aired. And stockings--he (beggar) won't want them--and a towel, I suppose; and handkerchiefs. Now what else?'' (unknown)

``A comb, a knife and fork and spoon,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul. His (Paul) father had been in the hospital before.

``Goodness knows what sort of state his (beggar) feet were in,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
continued Mrs. Morel, as she (Morel) combed her (Morel) long brown hair, that was fine as silk, and was touched now with grey.
``He (beggar)'s very particular to wash himself to the waist, but below he (beggar) thinks doesn't matter. But there, I suppose they see plenty like it.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul had laid the table. He (Paul) cut his (Paul) mother one or two pieces of very thin bread and butter.

``Here you are,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, putting her (mother) cup of tea in her (mother) place.

``I can't be bothered!'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed crossly.

``Well, you've got to, so there, now it's put out ready,'' (he)
he (Paul) insisted.

So she (mother) sat down and sipped her (mother) tea, and ate a little, in silence. She (mother) was thinking.

In a few minutes she (mother) was gone, to walk the two and a half miles to Keston Station. All the things she (mother) was taking him (Paul) she (mother) had in her (mother) bulging string bag. Paul watched her (mother) go up the road between the hedges--a little, quick-stepping figure, and his (Paul) heart ached for her (mother), that she (mother) was thrust forward again into pain and trouble. And she (mother), tripping so quickly in her (mother) anxiety, felt at the back of her (mother) her (mother) son's heart waiting on her (mother), felt him (son) bearing what part of the burden he (son) could, even supporting her (mother). And when she (mother) was at the hospital, she (mother) thought:

``It WILL upset that lad when I tell him (lad) how bad it is. I'd better be careful.'' (she)
And when she (mother) was trudging home again, she (mother) felt he (son) was coming to share her (mother) burden.

``Is it bad?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul, as soon as she (mother) entered the house.

``It's bad enough,'' (she)
she (mother) replied.

``What?'' (She)

She (mother) sighed and sat down, undoing her (mother) bonnet-strings. Her (mother) son watched her (mother) face as it was lifted, and her (mother) small, work-hardened hands fingering at the bow under her (mother) chin.

``Well,'' (she)
she (mother) answered,
``it's not really dangerous, but the nurse says it's a dreadful smash. You see, a great piece of rock fell on his (lad) leg--here--and it's a compound fracture. There are pieces of bone sticking through--'' (she)

``Ugh--how horrid!'' (the children)
exclaimed the children.

``And,'' (she)
she (mother) continued, ``of course he (lad) says he (lad)'s going to die--it wouldn't be him (lad) if he (lad) didn't. ``I'm done for, my lass!'' he (son) said, looking at me. ``Don't be so silly,'' I said to him (son). ``You're not going to die of a broken leg, however badly it's smashed.'' ``I s'll niver come out of `ere but in a wooden box,'' he (son) groaned. ``Well,
'' I said, `if you want them to carry you into the garden in a wooden box, when you're better, I've no doubt they will.'' (unknown)
``If we think it's good for him (lad),'' (the Sister)
said the Sister. She (Sister)'s an awfully nice Sister, but rather strict.''

Mrs. Morel took off her (Morel) bonnet. The children waited in silence.

``Of course, he (lad) IS bad,'' (she)
she (Morel) continued,
``and he (lad) will be. It's a great shock, and he (lad)'s lost a lot of blood; and, of course, it IS a very dangerous smash. It's not at all sure that it will mend so easily. And then there's the fever and the mortification--if it took bad ways he (lad)'d quickly be gone. But there, he (lad)'s a clean-blooded man, with wonderful healing flesh, and so I see no reason why it SHOULD take bad ways. Of course there's a wound--'' (she)

She (Morel) was pale now with emotion and anxiety. The three children realised that it was very bad for their father, and the house was silent, anxious.

``But he (lad) always gets better,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul after a while.

``That's what I tell him (lad),'' (the mother)
said the mother.

Everybody moved about in silence.

``And he (lad) really looked nearly done for,'' (she)
she (mother) said.
``But the Sister says that is the pain.'' (Annie)

Annie took away her (Annie) mother's coat and bonnet.

``And he (lad) looked at me when I came away! I said: ``I s'll have to go now, Walter, because of the train--and the children.

'' And he (Paul) looked at me. It seems hard.'' (the children)

Paul took up his (Paul) brush again and went on painting. Arthur went outside for some coal. Annie sat looking dismal. And Mrs. Morel, in her (Annie) little rocking-chair that her (Annie) husband had made for her (Annie) when the first baby was coming, remained motionless, brooding. She (Annie) was grieved, and bitterly sorry for the man who was hurt so much. But still, in her (Annie) heart of hearts, where the love should have burned, there was a blank. Now, when all her (Annie) woman's pity was roused to its full extent, when she (Annie) would have slaved herself to death to nurse him (man) and to save him (man), when she (Annie) would have taken the pain herself, if she (Annie) could, somewhere far away inside her (Annie), she (Annie) felt indifferent to him (man) and to his (man) suffering. It hurt her (Annie) most of all, this failure to love him (man), even when he (man) roused her (Annie) strong emotions. She (Annie) brooded a while.

``And there,'' (she)
she (Annie) said suddenly,
``when I'd got halfway to Keston, I found I'd come out in my working boots--and LOOK at them.'' (she)
They were an old pair of Paul's, brown and rubbed through at the toes.
``I didn't know what to do with myself, for shame,'' (she)
she (Annie) added.

In the morning, when Annie and Arthur were at school, Mrs. Morel talked again to her (Morel) son, who was helping her (Morel) with her (Morel) housework.

``I found Barker at the hospital. He (Barker) did look bad, poor little fellow! ``Well,

'' I said to him (son), `what sort of a journey did you have with him (son)?'' (unknown)
``Dunna ax me, missis!'' (he)
he (son) said.
``Ay,'' (I)
I said,
``I know what he (Barker)'d be.'' (I)
``But it WOR bad for him (Barker), Mrs. Morel, it WOR that!'' (he)
he (son) said.
``I know,'' (I)
I said.
``At ivry jolt I thought my `eart would ha' flown clean out o' my mouth,'' (he)
he (son) said.
``An' the scream 'e gives sometimes! Missis, not for a fortune would I go through wi' it again.'' (unknown)
``I can quite understand it,'' (I)
I said.
``It's a nasty job, though,'' (he)
he (son) said, `an' one as'll be a long while afore it's right again.'' ``I'm afraid it will,
'' I said. I like Mr. Barker--I DO like him (Barker). There's something so manly about him (Barker).'' (I)

Paul resumed his (Paul) task silently.

``And of course,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel continued, ``for a man like your father, the hospital IS hard. He (man) CAN
``T understand rules and regulations. And he (man) won't let anybody else touch him (man), not if he (man) can help it. When he (man) smashed the muscles of his (man) thigh, and it had to be dressed four times a day, WOULD he (man) let anybody but me or his (man) mother do it? He (man) wouldn't. So, of course, he (man)'ll suffer in there with the nurses. And I didn't like leaving him (man). I'm sure, when I kissed him (man) an' came away, it seemed a shame.'' (she)

So she (Morel) talked to her (Morel) son, almost as if she (Morel) were thinking aloud to him (son), and he (son) took it in as best he (son) could, by sharing her (Morel) trouble to lighten it. And in the end she (Morel) shared almost everything with him (son) without knowing.

Morel had a very bad time. For a week he (son) was in a critical condition. Then he (son) began to mend. And then, knowing he (son) was going to get better, the whole family sighed with relief, and proceeded to live happily.

They were not badly off whilst Morel was in the hospital. There were fourteen shillings a week from the pit, ten shillings from the sick club, and five shillings from the Disability Fund; and then every week the butties had something for Mrs. Morel--five or seven shillings--so that she (Morel) was quite well to do. And whilst Morel was progressing favourably in the hospital, the family was extraordinarily happy and peaceful. On Saturdays and Wednesdays Mrs. Morel went to Nottingham to see her (Morel) husband. Then she (Morel) always brought back some little thing: a small tube of paints for Paul, or some thick paper; a couple of postcards for Annie, that the whole family rejoiced over for days before the girl was allowed to send them away; or a fret-saw for Arthur, or a bit of pretty wood. She (girl) described her (girl) adventures into the big shops with joy. Soon the folk in the picture-shop knew her (girl), and knew about Paul. The girl in the book-shop took a keen interest in her (girl). Mrs. Morel was full of information when she (Morel) got home from Nottingham. The three sat round till bed-time, listening, putting in, arguing. Then Paul often raked the fire.

``I'm the man in the house now,'' (he)
he (Paul) used to say to his (Paul) mother with joy. They learned how perfectly peaceful the home could be. And they almost regretted--though none of them would have owned to such callousness--that their father was soon coming back.

Paul was now fourteen, and was looking for work. He (Paul) was a rather small and rather finely-made boy, with dark brown hair and light blue eyes. His (Paul) face had already lost its youthful chubbiness, and was becoming somewhat like William's--rough-featured, almost rugged--and it was extraordinarily mobile. Usually he (William) looked as if he (William) saw things, was full of life, and warm; then his (William) smile, like his (William) mother's, came suddenly and was very lovable; and then, when there was any clog in his (William) soul's quick running, his (William) face went stupid and ugly. He (William) was the sort of boy that becomes a clown and a lout as soon as he (William) is not understood, or feels himself held cheap; and, again, is adorable at the first touch of warmth.

He (William) suffered very much from the first contact with anything. When he (William) was seven, the starting school had been a nightmare and a torture to him (William). But afterwards he (William) liked it. And now that he (William) felt he (William) had to go out into life, he (William) went through agonies of shrinking self-consciousness. He (William) was quite a clever painter for a boy of his (William) years, and he (William) knew some French and German and mathematics that Mr. Heaton had taught him (Heaton). But nothing he (Heaton) had was of any commercial value. He (Heaton) was not strong enough for heavy manual work, his (Heaton) mother said. He (Heaton) did not care for making things with his (Heaton) hands, preferred racing about, or making excursions into the country, or reading, or painting.

``What do you want to be?'' (mother)
his (Heaton) mother asked.

``Anything.'' (unknown)

``That is no answer,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

But it was quite truthfully the only answer he (Heaton) could give. His (Heaton) ambition, as far as this world's gear went, was quietly to earn his (Heaton) thirty or thirty-five shillings a week somewhere near home, and then, when his (Heaton) father died, have a cottage with his (Heaton) mother, paint and go out as he (Heaton) liked, and live happy ever after. That was his (Heaton) programme as far as doing things went. But he (Heaton) was proud within himself, measuring people against himself, and placing them, inexorably. And he (Heaton) thought that PERHAPS he (Heaton) might also make a painter, the real thing. But that he (Heaton) left alone.

``Then,'' (mother)
said his (Heaton) mother,
``you must look in the paper for the advertisements.'' (mother)

He (Heaton) looked at her (mother). It seemed to him (Heaton) a bitter humiliation and an anguish to go through. But he (Heaton) said nothing. When he (Heaton) got up in the morning, his (Heaton) whole being was knotted up over this one thought:

``I've got to go and look for advertisements for a job.'' (he)

It stood in front of the morning, that thought, killing all joy and even life, for him (Heaton). His (Heaton) heart felt like a tight knot.

And then, at ten o'clock, he (Heaton) set off. He (Heaton) was supposed to be a queer, quiet child. Going up the sunny street of the little town, he (Heaton) felt as if all the folk he (Heaton) met said to themselves:

``He (man)'s going to the Co-op. reading-room to look in the papers for a place. He (man) can't get a job. I suppose he (man)'s living on his (man) mother.'' (he)
Then he (Heaton) crept up the stone stairs behind the drapery shop at the Co-op., and peeped in the reading-room. Usually one or two men were there, either old, useless fellows, or colliers
``on the club'' (colliers)
. So he (Heaton) entered, full of shrinking and suffering when they looked up, seated himself at the table, and pretended to scan the news. He (Heaton) knew they would think:
``What does a lad of thirteen want in a reading-room with a newspaper?'' (He)
and he (Heaton) suffered.

Then he (Heaton) looked wistfully out of the window. Already he (Heaton) was a prisoner of industrialism. Large sunflowers stared over the old red wall of the garden opposite, looking in their jolly way down on the women who were hurrying with something for dinner. The valley was full of corn, brightening in the sun. Two collieries, among the fields, waved their small white plumes of steam. Far off on the hills were the woods of Annesley, dark and fascinating. Already his (Heaton) heart went down. He (Heaton) was being taken into bondage. His (Heaton) freedom in the beloved home valley was going now.

The brewers' waggons came rolling up from Keston with enormous barrels, four a side, like beans in a burst bean-pod. The waggoner, throned aloft, rolling massively in his (waggoner) seat, was not so much below Paul's eye. The man's hair, on his (waggoner) small, bullet head, was bleached almost white by the sun, and on his (waggoner) thick red arms, rocking idly on his (waggoner) sack apron, the white hairs glistened. His (waggoner) red face shone and was almost asleep with sunshine. The horses, handsome and brown, went on by themselves, looking by far the masters of the show.

Paul wished he (Paul) were stupid.

``I wish,'' (he)
he (Paul) thought to himself,
``I was fat like him (lad), and like a dog in the sun. I wish I was a pig and a brewer's waggoner.'' (he)

Then, the room being at last empty, he (Paul) would hastily copy an advertisement on a scrap of paper, then another, and slip out in immense relief. His (Paul) mother would scan over his (Paul) copies.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``you may try.'' (she)

William had written out a letter of application, couched in admirable business language, which Paul copied, with variations. The boy's handwriting was execrable, so that William, who did all things well, got into a fever of impatience.

The elder brother was becoming quite swanky. In London he (brother) found that he (brother) could associate with men far above his (brother) Bestwood friends in station. Some of the clerks in the office had studied for the law, and were more or less going through a kind of apprenticeship. William always made friends among men wherever he (William) went, he (William) was so jolly. Therefore he (William) was soon visiting and staying in houses of men who, in Bestwood, would have looked down on the unapproachable bank manager, and would merely have called indifferently on the Rector. So he (Rector) began to fancy himself as a great gun. He (Rector) was, indeed, rather surprised at the ease with which he (Rector) became a gentleman.

His (Rector) mother was glad, he (Rector) seemed so pleased. And his (Rector) lodging in Walthamstow was so dreary. But now there seemed to come a kind of fever into the young man's letters. He (man) was unsettled by all the change, he (man) did not stand firm on his (man) own feet, but seemed to spin rather giddily on the quick current of the new life. His (man) mother was anxious for him (man). She (mother) could feel him (man) losing himself. He (man) had danced and gone to the theatre, boated on the river, been out with friends; and she (mother) knew he (man) sat up afterwards in his (man) cold bedroom grinding away at Latin, because he (man) intended to get on in his (man) office, and in the law as much as he (man) could. He (man) never sent his (man) mother any money now. It was all taken, the little he (man) had, for his (man) own life. And she (mother) did not want any, except sometimes, when she (mother) was in a tight corner, and when ten shillings would have saved her (mother) much worry. She (mother) still dreamed of William, and of what he (William) would do, with herself behind him (William). Never for a minute would she (mother) admit to herself how heavy and anxious her (mother) heart was because of him (William).

Also he (William) talked a good deal now of a girl he (William) had met at a dance, a handsome brunette, quite young, and a lady, after whom the men were running thick and fast.

``I wonder if you would run, my boy,'' (mother)
his (William) mother wrote to him (William),
``unless you saw all the other men chasing her (mother) too. You feel safe enough and vain enough in a crowd. But take care, and see how you feel when you find yourself alone, and in triumph.'' (him)
William resented these things, and continued the chase. He (William) had taken the girl on the river.
``If you saw her (mother), mother, you would know how I feel. Tall and elegant, with the clearest of clear, transparent olive complexions, hair as black as jet, and such grey eyes--bright, mocking, like lights on water at night. It is all very well to be a bit satirical till you see her (mother). And she (mother) dresses as well as any woman in London. I tell you, your son doesn't half put his (son) head up when she (mother) goes walking down Piccadilly with him (son).'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel wondered, in her (Morel) heart, if her (Morel) son did not go walking down Piccadilly with an elegant figure and fine clothes, rather than with a woman who was near to him (son). But she (woman) congratulated him (son) in her (woman) doubtful fashion. And, as she (woman) stood over the washing-tub, the mother brooded over her (mother) son. She (mother) saw him (son) saddled with an elegant and expensive wife, earning little money, dragging along and getting draggled in some small, ugly house in a suburb.

``But there,'' (she)
she (mother) told herself,
``I am very likely a silly--meeting trouble halfway.'' (she)
Nevertheless, the load of anxiety scarcely ever left her (mother) heart, lest William should do the wrong thing by himself.

Presently, Paul was bidden call upon Thomas Jordan, Manufacturer of Surgical Appliances, at 21, Spaniel Row, Nottingham. Mrs. Morel was all joy.

``There, you see!'' (she)
she (Morel) cried, her (Morel) eyes shining.
``You've only written four letters, and the third is answered. You're lucky, my boy, as I always said you were.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul looked at the picture of a wooden leg, adorned with elastic stockings and other appliances, that figured on Mr. Jordan's notepaper, and he (Jordan) felt alarmed. He (Jordan) had not known that elastic stockings existed. And he (Jordan) seemed to feel the business world, with its regulated system of values, and its impersonality, and he (Jordan) dreaded it. It seemed monstrous also that a business could be run on wooden legs.

Mother and son set off together one Tuesday morning. It was August and blazing hot. Paul walked with something screwed up tight inside him (Paul). He (Paul) would have suffered much physical pain rather than this unreasonable suffering at being exposed to strangers, to be accepted or rejected.
