Yet he (Paul) chattered away with his (Paul) mother. He (Paul) would never have confessed to her (mother) how he (Paul) suffered over these things, and she (mother) only partly guessed. She (mother) was gay, like a sweetheart. She (mother) stood in front of the ticket-office at Bestwood, and Paul watched her (mother) take from her (mother) purse the money for the tickets. As he (Paul) saw her (mother) hands in their old black kid gloves getting the silver out of the worn purse, his (Paul) heart contracted with pain of love of her (mother).

She (mother) was quite excited, and quite gay. He (Paul) suffered because she (mother) WOULD talk aloud in presence of the other travellers.

``Now look at that silly cow!'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``careering round as if it thought it was a circus.'' (she)

``It's most likely a bottfly,'' (he)
he (Paul) said very low.

``A what?'' (she)
she (mother) asked brightly and unashamed.

They thought a while. He (Paul) was sensible all the time of having her (mother) opposite him (Paul). Suddenly their eyes met, and she (mother) smiled to him (Paul)--a rare, intimate smile, beautiful with brightness and love. Then each looked out of the window.

The sixteen slow miles of railway journey passed. The mother and son walked down Station Street, feeling the excitement of lovers having an adventure together. In Carrington Street they stopped to hang over the parapet and look at the barges on the canal below.

``It's just like Venice,'' (he)
he (Carrington) said, seeing the sunshine on the water that lay between high factory walls.

``Perhaps,'' (she)
she (mother) answered, smiling.

They enjoyed the shops immensely.

``Now you see that blouse,'' (she)
she (mother) would say,
``wouldn't that just suit our Annie? And for one-and-eleven-three. Isn't that cheap?'' (she)

``And made of needlework as well,'' (he)
he (Carrington) said.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

They had plenty of time, so they did not hurry. The town was strange and delightful to them. But the boy was tied up inside in a knot of apprehension. He (boy) dreaded the interview with Thomas Jordan.

It was nearly eleven o'clock by St. Peter's Church. They turned up a narrow street that led to the Castle. It was gloomy and old-fashioned, having low dark shops and dark green house doors with brass knockers, and yellow-ochred doorsteps projecting on to the pavement; then another old shop whose small window looked like a cunning, half-shut eye. Mother and son went cautiously, looking everywhere for

``Thomas Jordan and Son'' (son)
. It was like hunting in some wild place. They were on tiptoe of excitement.

Suddenly they spied a big, dark archway, in which were names of various firms, Thomas Jordan among them.

``Here it is!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``But now WHERE is it?'' (unknown)

They looked round. On one side was a queer, dark, cardboard factory, on the other a Commercial Hotel.

``It's up the entry,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

And they ventured under the archway, as into the jaws of the dragon. They emerged into a wide yard, like a well, with buildings all round. It was littered with straw and boxes, and cardboard. The sunshine actually caught one crate whose straw was streaming on to the yard like gold. But elsewhere the place was like a pit. There were several doors, and two flights of steps. Straight in front, on a dirty glass door at the top of a staircase, loomed the ominous words

``Thomas Jordan and Son--Surgical Appliances.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel went first, her (Morel) son followed her (Morel). Charles I mounted his (son) scaffold with a lighter heart than had Paul Morel as he (Morel) followed his (Morel) mother up the dirty steps to the dirty door.

She (mother) pushed open the door, and stood in pleased surprise. In front of her (mother) was a big warehouse, with creamy paper parcels everywhere, and clerks, with their shirt-sleeves rolled back, were going about in an at-home sort of way. The light was subdued, the glossy cream parcels seemed luminous, the counters were of dark brown wood. All was quiet and very homely. Mrs. Morel took two steps forward, then waited. Paul stood behind her (Morel). She (Morel) had on her (Morel) Sunday bonnet and a black veil; he (Paul) wore a boy's broad white collar and a Norfolk suit.

One of the clerks looked up. He (Paul) was thin and tall, with a small face. His (Paul) way of looking was alert. Then he (Paul) glanced round to the other end of the room, where was a glass office. And then he (Paul) came forward. He (Paul) did not say anything, but leaned in a gentle, inquiring fashion towards Mrs. Morel.

``Can I see Mr. Jordan?'' (she)
she (Morel) asked.

``I'll fetch him (Jordan),'' (the man)
answered the young man.

He (man) went down to the glass office. A red-faced, white-whiskered old man looked up. He (man) reminded Paul of a pomeranian dog. Then the same little man came up the room. He (man) had short legs, was rather stout, and wore an alpaca jacket. So, with one ear up, as it were, he (man) came stoutly and inquiringly down the room.

``Good-morning!'' (he)
he (man) said, hesitating before Mrs. Morel, in doubt as to whether she (Morel) were a customer or not.

``Good-morning. I came with my son, Paul Morel. You asked him (Morel) to call this morning.'' (unknown)

``Come this way,'' (Mr. Jordan)
said Mr. Jordan, in a rather snappy little manner intended to be businesslike.

They followed the manufacturer into a grubby little room, upholstered in black American leather, glossy with the rubbing of many customers. On the table was a pile of trusses, yellow wash-leather hoops tangled together. They looked new and living. Paul sniffed the odour of new wash-leather. He (Paul) wondered what the things were. By this time he (Paul) was so much stunned that he (Paul) only noticed the outside things.

``Sit down!'' (Mr. Jordan)
said Mr. Jordan, irritably pointing Mrs. Morel to a horse-hair chair. She (Morel) sat on the edge in an uncertain fashion. Then the little old man fidgeted and found a paper.

``Did you write this letter?'' (he)
he (man) snapped, thrusting what Paul recognised as his (Paul) own notepaper in front of him (Paul).

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.

At that moment he (Paul) was occupied in two ways: first, in feeling guilty for telling a lie, since William had composed the letter; second, in wondering why his (William) letter seemed so strange and different, in the fat, red hand of the man, from what it had been when it lay on the kitchen table. It was like part of himself, gone astray. He (man) resented the way the man held it.

``Where did you learn to write?'' (the man)
said the old man crossly.

Paul merely looked at him (Paul) shamedly, and did not answer.

``He (Morel) IS a bad writer,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
put in Mrs. Morel apologetically. Then she (Morel) pushed up her (Morel) veil. Paul hated her (Morel) for not being prouder with this common little man, and he (man) loved her (Morel) face clear of the veil.

``And you say you know French?'' (the man)
inquired the little man, still sharply.

``Yes,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``What school did you go to?'' (unknown)

``The Board-school.'' (unknown)

``And did you learn it there?'' (unknown)

``No--I--'' (The boy)
The boy went crimson and got no farther.

``His (Morel) godfather gave him (Morel) lessons,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, half pleading and rather distant.

Mr. Jordan hesitated. Then, in his (Jordan) irritable manner--he (Jordan) always seemed to keep his (Jordan) hands ready for action--he (Jordan) pulled another sheet of paper from his (Jordan) pocket, unfolded it. The paper made a crackling noise. He (Jordan) handed it to Paul.

``Read that,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

It was a note in French, in thin, flimsy foreign handwriting that the boy could not decipher. He (boy) stared blankly at the paper.

''`Monsieur,''' (He)
he (boy) began; then he (boy) looked in great confusion at Mr. Jordan.
``It's the--it's the--'' (He)

He (Jordan) wanted to say

``handwriting'' (He)
, but his (Jordan) wits would no longer work even sufficiently to supply him (Jordan) with the word. Feeling an utter fool, and hating Mr. Jordan, he (Jordan) turned desperately to the paper again.

''`Sir,--Please send me'--er--er--I can't tell the--er--`two pairs--gris fil bas--grey thread stockings'--er--er--`sans--without'--er--I can't tell the words--er--`doigts--fingers'--er--I can't tell the--'' (he)

He (Jordan) wanted to say

``handwriting'' (He)
, but the word still refused to come. Seeing him (Jordan) stuck, Mr. Jordan snatched the paper from him (Jordan).

''`Please send by return two pairs grey thread stockings without TOES.''' (him)

``Well,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
flashed Paul,
''`doigts' means `fingers'--as well--as a rule--'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

The little man looked at him (man). He (man) did not know whether

``doigts'' (He)
meant
``fingers'' (He)
; he (man) knew that for all HIS (man) purposes it meant
``toes'' (he)
.

``Fingers to stockings!'' (he)
he (man) snapped.

``Well, it DOES mean fingers,'' (the boy)
the boy persisted.

He (boy) hated the little man, who made such a clod of him (boy). Mr. Jordan looked at the pale, stupid, defiant boy, then at the mother, who sat quiet and with that peculiar shut-off look of the poor who have to depend on the favour of others.

``And when could he (Morel) come?'' (he)
he (Jordan) asked.

``Well,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``as soon as you wish. He (Morel) has finished school now.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``He (Morel) would live in Bestwood?'' (unknown)

``Yes; but he (Morel) could be in--at the station--at quarter to eight.'' (unknown)

``H'm!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

It ended by Paul's being engaged as junior spiral clerk at eight shillings a week. The boy did not open his (boy) mouth to say another word, after having insisted that

``doigts'' (The boy)
meant
``fingers'' (The boy)
. He (boy) followed his (boy) mother down the stairs. She (mother) looked at him (boy) with her (mother) bright blue eyes full of love and joy.

``I think you'll like it,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

''`Doigts' does mean `fingers', mother, and it was the writing. I couldn't read the writing.'' (she)

``Never mind, my boy. I'm sure he (boy)'ll be all right, and you won't see much of him (boy). Wasn't that first young fellow nice? I'm sure you'll like them.'' (unknown)

``But wasn't Mr. Jordan common, mother? Does he (Jordan) own it all?'' (unknown)

``I suppose he (Jordan) was a workman who has got on,'' (she)
she (mother) said.
``You mustn't mind people so much. They're not being disagreeable to YOU--it's their way. You always think people are meaning things for you. But they don't.'' (unknown)

It was very sunny. Over the big desolate space of the market-place the blue sky shimmered, and the granite cobbles of the paving glistened. Shops down the Long Row were deep in obscurity, and the shadow was full of colour. Just where the horse trams trundled across the market was a row of fruit stalls, with fruit blazing in the sun--apples and piles of reddish oranges, small green-gage plums and bananas. There was a warm scent of fruit as mother and son passed. Gradually his (son) feeling of ignominy and of rage sank.

``Where should we go for dinner?'' (the mother)
asked the mother.

It was felt to be a reckless extravagance. Paul had only been in an eating-house once or twice in his (Paul) life, and then only to have a cup of tea and a bun. Most of the people of Bestwood considered that tea and bread-and-butter, and perhaps potted beef, was all they could afford to eat in Nottingham. Real cooked dinner was considered great extravagance. Paul felt rather guilty.

They found a place that looked quite cheap. But when Mrs. Morel scanned the bill of fare, her (Morel) heart was heavy, things were so dear. So she (Morel) ordered kidney-pies and potatoes as the cheapest available dish.

``We oughtn't to have come here, mother,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Never mind,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``We won't come again.'' (She)

She (Morel) insisted on his (Paul) having a small currant tart, because he (Paul) liked sweets.

``I don't want it, mother,'' (he)
he (Paul) pleaded.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Morel) insisted;
``you'll have it.'' (she)

And she (Morel) looked round for the waitress. But the waitress was busy, and Mrs. Morel did not like to bother her (Morel) then. So the mother and son waited for the girl's pleasure, whilst she (mother) flirted among the men.

``Brazen hussy!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel to Paul.
``Look now, she (mother)'s taking that man HIS (man) pudding, and he (man) came long after us.'' (unknown)

``It doesn't matter, mother,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

Mrs. Morel was angry. But she (Morel) was too poor, and her (Morel) orders were too meagre, so that she (Morel) had not the courage to insist on her (Morel) rights just then. They waited and waited.

``Should we go, mother?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Then Mrs. Morel stood up. The girl was passing near.

``Will you bring one currant tart?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel clearly.

The girl looked round insolently.

``Directly,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

``We have waited quite long enough,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

In a moment the girl came back with the tart. Mrs. Morel asked coldly for the bill. Paul wanted to sink through the floor. He (Paul) marvelled at his (Paul) mother's hardness. He (Paul) knew that only years of battling had taught her (mother) to insist even so little on her (mother) rights. She (mother) shrank as much as he (Paul).

``It's the last time I go THERE for anything!'' (she)
she (mother) declared, when they were outside the place, thankful to be clear.

``We'll go,'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``and look at Keep's and Boot's, and one or two places, shall we?'' (she)

They had discussions over the pictures, and Mrs. Morel wanted to buy him (Paul) a little sable brush that he (Paul) hankered after. But this indulgence he (Paul) refused. He (Paul) stood in front of milliners' shops and drapers' shops almost bored, but content for her (Morel) to be interested. They wandered on.

``Now, just look at those black grapes!'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``They make your mouth water. I've wanted some of those for years, but I s'll have to wait a bit before I get them.'' (she)

Then she (Morel) rejoiced in the florists, standing in the doorway sniffing.

``Oh! oh! Isn't it simply lovely!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul saw, in the darkness of the shop, an elegant young lady in black peering over the counter curiously.

``They're looking at you,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, trying to draw his (Paul) mother away.

``But what is it?'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed, refusing to be moved.

``Stocks!'' (he)
he (Paul) answered, sniffing hastily.
``Look, there's a tubful.'' (unknown)

``So there is--red and white. But really, I never knew stocks to smell like it!'' (she)
And, to his (Paul) great relief, she (mother) moved out of the doorway, but only to stand in front of the window.

``Paul!'' (she)
she (mother) cried to him (Paul), who was trying to get out of sight of the elegant young lady in black--the shop-girl.
``Paul! Just look here!'' (He)

He (Paul) came reluctantly back.

``Now, just look at that fuchsia!'' (she)
she (lady) exclaimed, pointing.

``H'm!'' (He)
He (Paul) made a curious, interested sound.
``You'd think every second as the flowers was going to fall off, they hang so big an' heavy.'' (unknown)

``And such an abundance!'' (she)
she (lady) cried.

``And the way they drop downwards with their threads and knots!'' (unknown)

``Yes!'' (she)
she (lady) exclaimed.
``Lovely!'' (unknown)

``I wonder who'll buy it!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I wonder!'' (she)
she (lady) answered.
``Not us.'' (unknown)

``It would die in our parlour.'' (unknown)

``Yes, beastly cold, sunless hole; it kills every bit of a plant you put in, and the kitchen chokes them to death.'' (unknown)

They bought a few things, and set off towards the station. Looking up the canal, through the dark pass of the buildings, they saw the Castle on its bluff of brown, green-bushed rock, in a positive miracle of delicate sunshine.

``Won't it be nice for me to come out at dinner-times?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``I can go all round here and see everything. I s'll love it.'' (unknown)

``You will,'' (mother)
assented his (Paul) mother.

He (Paul) had spent a perfect afternoon with his (Paul) mother. They arrived home in the mellow evening, happy, and glowing, and tired.

In the morning he (Paul) filled in the form for his (Paul) season-ticket and took it to the station. When he (Paul) got back, his (Paul) mother was just beginning to wash the floor. He (Paul) sat crouched up on the sofa.

``He (our) says it'll be here on Saturday,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``And how much will it be?'' (unknown)

``About one pound eleven,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (mother) went on washing her (mother) floor in silence.

``Is it a lot?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``It's no more than I thought,'' (she)
she (mother) answered.

``An' I s'll earn eight shillings a week,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (mother) did not answer, but went on with her (mother) work. At last she (mother) said:

``That William promised me, when he (William) went to London, as he (William)'d give me a pound a month. He (William) has given me ten shillings--twice; and now I know he (William) hasn't a farthing if I asked him (William). Not that I want it. Only just now you'd think he (William) might be able to help with this ticket, which I'd never expected.'' (she)

``He (William) earns a lot,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``He (William) earns a hundred and thirty pounds. But they're all alike. They're large in promises, but it's precious little fulfilment you get.'' (unknown)

``He (William) spends over fifty shillings a week on himself,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``And I keep this house on less than thirty,'' (she)
she (mother) replied;
``and am supposed to find money for extras. But they don't care about helping you, once they've gone. He (William)'d rather spend it on that dressed-up creature.'' (she)

``She (William) should have her (William) own money if she (William)'s so grand,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``She (William) should, but she (William) hasn't. I asked him (William). And I know he (William) doesn't buy her (William) a gold bangle for nothing. I wonder whoever bought ME a gold bangle.'' (William)

William was succeeding with his (William)

``Gipsy'' (William)
, as he (William) called her (mother). He (William) asked the girl--her (mother) name was Louisa Lily Denys Western--for a photograph to send to his (William) mother. The photo came--a handsome brunette, taken in profile, smirking slightly--and, it might be, quite naked, for on the photograph not a scrap of clothing was to be seen, only a naked bust.

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
wrote Mrs. Morel to her (Morel) son,
``the photograph of Louie is very striking, and I can see she (William) must be attractive. But do you think, my boy, it was very good taste of a girl to give her (girl) young man that photo to send to his (man) mother--the first? Certainly the shoulders are beautiful, as you say. But I hardly expected to see so much of them at the first view.'' (son)

Morel found the photograph standing on the chiffonier in the parlour. He (son) came out with it between his (son) thick thumb and finger.

``Who dost reckon this is?'' (he)
he (son) asked of his (son) wife.

``It's the girl our William is going with,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel.

``H'm!

``Er's a bright spark, from th' look on `er, an' one as wunna do him (William) owermuch good neither. Who is she (girl)?'' (unknown)

``Her (girl) name is Louisa Lily Denys Western.'' (unknown)

``An' come again to-morrer!'' (the miner)
exclaimed the miner.
``An' is `er an actress?'' (unknown)

``She (actress) is not. She (actress)'s supposed to be a lady.'' (unknown)

``I'll bet!'' (he)
he (son) exclaimed, still staring at the photo.
``A lady, is she (lady)? An' how much does she (lady) reckon ter keep up this sort o' game on?'' (unknown)

``On nothing. She (lady) lives with an old aunt, whom she (lady) hates, and takes what bit of money's given her (lady).'' (unknown)

``H'm!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel, laying down the photograph.
``Then he (lady)'s a fool to ha' ta'en up wi' such a one as that.'' (unknown)

``Dear Mater,'' (William)
William replied.
``I'm sorry you didn't like the photograph. It never occurred to me when I sent it, that you mightn't think it decent. However, I told Gyp that it didn't quite suit your prim and proper notions, so she (lady)'s going to send you another, that I hope will please you better. She (lady)'s always being photographed; in fact, the photographers ask her (lady) if they may take her (lady) for nothing.'' (the girl)

Presently the new photograph came, with a little silly note from the girl. This time the young lady was seen in a black satin evening bodice, cut square, with little puff sleeves, and black lace hanging down her (lady) beautiful arms.

``I wonder if she (lady) ever wears anything except evening clothes,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel sarcastically.
``I'm sure I ought to be impressed.'' (unknown)

``You are disagreeable, mother,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``I think the first one with bare shoulders is lovely.'' (unknown)

``Do you?'' (mother)
answered his (Paul) mother.
``Well, I don't.'' (the boy)

On the Monday morning the boy got up at six to start work. He (boy) had the season-ticket, which had cost such bitterness, in his (boy) waistcoat pocket. He (boy) loved it with its bars of yellow across. His (boy) mother packed his (boy) dinner in a small, shut-up basket, and he (boy) set off at a quarter to seven to catch the 7.15 train. Mrs. Morel came to the entry-end to see him (boy) off.

It was a perfect morning. From the ash tree the slender green fruits that the children call

``pigeons'' (the children)
were twinkling gaily down on a little breeze, into the front gardens of the houses. The valley was full of a lustrous dark haze, through which the ripe corn shimmered, and in which the steam from Minton pit melted swiftly. Puffs of wind came. Paul looked over the high woods of Aldersley, where the country gleamed, and home had never pulled at him (Paul) so powerfully.

``Good-morning, mother,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, smiling, but feeling very unhappy.

``Good-morning,'' (she)
she (It) replied cheerfully and tenderly.

She (It) stood in her (It) white apron on the open road, watching him (Paul) as he (Paul) crossed the field. He (Paul) had a small, compact body that looked full of life. She (It) felt, as she (It) saw him (Paul) trudging over the field, that where he (Paul) determined to go he (Paul) would get. She (It) thought of William. He (William) would have leaped the fence instead of going round the stile. He (William) was away in London, doing well. Paul would be working in Nottingham. Now she (It) had two sons in the world. She (It) could think of two places, great centres of industry, and feel that she (It) had put a man into each of them, that these men would work out what SHE wanted; they were derived from her (It), they were of her (It), and their works also would be hers. All the morning long she (It) thought of Paul.

At eight o'clock he (Paul) climbed the dismal stairs of Jordan's Surgical Appliance Factory, and stood helplessly against the first great parcel-rack, waiting for somebody to pick him (Paul) up. The place was still not awake. Over the counters were great dust sheets. Two men only had arrived, and were heard talking in a corner, as they took off their coats and rolled up their shirt-sleeves. It was ten past eight. Evidently there was no rush of punctuality. Paul listened to the voices of the two clerks. Then he (Paul) heard someone cough, and saw in the office at the end of the room an old, decaying clerk, in a round smoking-cap of black velvet embroidered with red and green, opening letters. He (Paul) waited and waited. One of the junior clerks went to the old man, greeted him (man) cheerily and loudly. Evidently the old

``chief'' (unknown)
was deaf. Then the young fellow came striding importantly down to his (fellow) counter. He (fellow) spied Paul.

``Hello!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``You the new lad?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``H'm! What's your name?'' (unknown)

``Paul Morel.'' (unknown)

``Paul Morel? All right, you come on round here.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul followed him (Paul) round the rectangle of counters. The room was second storey. It had a great hole in the middle of the floor, fenced as with a wall of counters, and down this wide shaft the lifts went, and the light for the bottom storey. Also there was a corresponding big, oblong hole in the ceiling, and one could see above, over the fence of the top floor, some machinery; and right away overhead was the glass roof, and all light for the three storeys came downwards, getting dimmer, so that it was always night on the ground floor and rather gloomy on the second floor. The factory was the top floor, the warehouse the second, the storehouse the ground floor. It was an insanitary, ancient place.

Paul was led round to a very dark corner.

``This is the ``Spiral' corner,'' said the clerk.

``You're Spiral, with Pappleworth. He (Pappleworth)'s your boss, but he (Pappleworth)'s not come yet. He (Pappleworth) doesn't get here till half-past eight. So you can fetch the letters, if you like, from Mr. Melling down there.'' (The man)

The young man pointed to the old clerk in the office.

``All right,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Here's a peg to hang your cap on. Here are your entry ledgers. Mr. Pappleworth won't be long.'' (the man strides)

And the thin young man stalked away with long, busy strides over the hollow wooden floor.

After a minute or two Paul went down and stood in the door of the glass office. The old clerk in the smoking-cap looked down over the rim of his (Paul) spectacles.

``Good-morning,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, kindly and impressively.
``You want the letters for the Spiral department, Thomas?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul resented being called

``Thomas'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
. But he (Paul) took the letters and returned to his (Paul) dark place, where the counter made an angle, where the great parcel-rack came to an end, and where there were three doors in the corner. He (Paul) sat on a high stool and read the letters--those whose handwriting was not too difficult. They ran as follows:

``Will you please send me at once a pair of lady's silk spiral thigh-hose, without feet, such as I had from you last year; length, thigh to knee, etc.'' (unknown)
Or,
``Major Chamberlain wishes to repeat his (Chamberlain) previous order for a silk non-elastic suspensory bandage.'' (the boy)

Many of these letters, some of them in French or Norwegian, were a great puzzle to the boy. He (boy) sat on his (boy) stool nervously awaiting the arrival of his (boy)

``boss'' (He)
. He (boy) suffered tortures of shyness when, at half-past eight, the factory girls for upstairs trooped past him (boy).

Mr. Pappleworth arrived, chewing a chlorodyne gum, at about twenty to nine, when all the other men were at work. He (Pappleworth) was a thin, sallow man with a red nose, quick, staccato, and smartly but stiffly dressed. He (Pappleworth) was about thirty-six years old. There was something rather

``doggy'' (him)
, rather smart, rather `cute and shrewd, and something warm, and something slightly contemptible about him (Pappleworth).

``You my new lad?'' (he)
he (Pappleworth) said.

Paul stood up and said he (Paul) was.

``Fetched the letters?'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)

Mr. Pappleworth gave a chew to his (Pappleworth) gum.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Copied 'em?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``Well, come on then, let's look slippy. Changed your coat?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``You want to bring an old coat and leave it here.'' (He)
He (Pappleworth) pronounced the last words with the chlorodyne gum between his (Pappleworth) side teeth. He (Pappleworth) vanished into the darkness behind the great parcel-rack, reappeared coatless, turning up a smart striped shirt-cuff over a thin and hairy arm. Then he (Pappleworth) slipped into his (Pappleworth) coat. Paul noticed how thin he (Paul) was, and that his (Paul) trousers were in folds behind. He (Paul) seized a stool, dragged it beside the boy's, and sat down.

``Sit down,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Paul took a seat.

Mr. Pappleworth was very close to him (Pappleworth). The man seized the letters, snatched a long entry-book out of a rack in front of him (Pappleworth), flung it open, seized a pen, and said:

``Now look here. You want to copy these letters in here.'' (him)
He (Pappleworth) sniffed twice, gave a quick chew at his (Pappleworth) gum, stared fixedly at a letter, then went very still and absorbed, and wrote the entry rapidly, in a beautiful flourishing hand. He (Pappleworth) glanced quickly at Paul.

``See that?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Think you can do it all right?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``All right then, let's see you.'' (He)

He (Paul) sprang off his (Paul) stool. Paul took a pen. Mr. Pappleworth disappeared. Paul rather liked copying the letters, but he (Paul) wrote slowly, laboriously, and exceedingly badly. He (Paul) was doing the fourth letter, and feeling quite busy and happy, when Mr. Pappleworth reappeared.

``Now then, how`r' yer getting on? Done 'em?'' (He)

He (Pappleworth) leaned over the boy's shoulder, chewing, and smelling of chlorodyne.

``Strike my bob, lad, but you're a beautiful writer!'' (he)
he (Pappleworth) exclaimed satirically.
``Ne'er mind, how many h`yer done? Only three! I'd 'a eaten 'em. Get on, my lad, an' put numbers on 'em. Here, look! Get on!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul ground away at the letters, whilst Mr. Pappleworth fussed over various jobs. Suddenly the boy started as a shrill whistle sounded near his (Pappleworth) ear. Mr. Pappleworth came, took a plug out of a pipe, and said, in an amazingly cross and bossy voice:

``Yes?'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)

Paul heard a faint voice, like a woman's, out of the mouth of the tube. He (Paul) gazed in wonder, never having seen a speaking-tube before.

``Well,'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth disagreeably into the tube,
``you'd better get some of your back work done, then.'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)

Again the woman's tiny voice was heard, sounding pretty and cross.

``I've not time to stand here while you talk,'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth, and he (Pappleworth) pushed the plug into the tube.

``Come, my lad,'' (he)
he (Pappleworth) said imploringly to Paul,
``there's Polly crying out for them orders. Can't you buck up a bit? Here, come out!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

He (Paul) took the book, to Paul's immense chagrin, and began the copying himself. He (Paul) worked quickly and well. This done, he (Paul) seized some strips of long yellow paper, about three inches wide, and made out the day's orders for the work-girls.

``You'd better watch me,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to Paul, working all the while rapidly. Paul watched the weird little drawings of legs, and thighs, and ankles, with the strokes across and the numbers, and the few brief directions which his (Paul) chief made upon the yellow paper. Then Mr. Pappleworth finished and jumped up.

``Come on with me,'' (he)
he (Pappleworth) said, and the yellow papers flying in his (Pappleworth) hands, he (Pappleworth) dashed through a door and down some stairs, into the basement where the gas was burning. They crossed the cold, damp storeroom, then a long, dreary room with a long table on trestles, into a smaller, cosy apartment, not very high, which had been built on to the main building. In this room a small woman with a red serge blouse, and her (woman) black hair done on top of her (woman) head, was waiting like a proud little bantam.

``Here y'are!'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Pappleworth.

``I think it is `here you are'!'' (Polly)
exclaimed Polly.
``The girls have been here nearly half an hour waiting. Just think of the time wasted!'' (unknown)

``YOU think of getting your work done and not talking so much,'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth.
``You could ha' been finishing off.'' (unknown)

``You know quite well we finished everything off on Saturday!'' (him)
cried Pony, flying at him (Pappleworth), her (Polly) dark eyes flashing.

``Tu-tu-tu-tu-terterter!'' (he)
he (Pappleworth) mocked.
``Here's your new lad. Don't ruin him (lad) as you did the last.'' (unknown)

``As we did the last!'' (Polly)
repeated Polly.
``Yes, WE do a lot of ruining, we do. My word, a lad would TAKE some ruining after he (lad)'d been with you.'' (unknown)

``It's time for work now, not for talk,'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth severely and coldly.

``It was time for work some time back,'' (Polly)
said Polly, marching away with her (Polly) head in the air. She (Polly) was an erect little body of forty.

In that room were two round spiral machines on the bench under the window. Through the inner doorway was another longer room, with six more machines. A little group of girls, nicely dressed in white aprons, stood talking together.

``Have you nothing else to do but talk?'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth.

``Only wait for you,'' (girl)
said one handsome girl, laughing.

``Well, get on, get on,'' (he)
he (Pappleworth) said.
``Come on, my lad. You'll know your road down here again.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

And Paul ran upstairs after his (Paul) chief. He (Paul) was given some checking and invoicing to do. He (Paul) stood at the desk, labouring in his (Paul) execrable handwriting. Presently Mr. Jordan came strutting down from the glass office and stood behind him (Jordan), to the boy's great discomfort. Suddenly a red and fat finger was thrust on the form he (Jordan) was filling in.

``MR. J. A. Bates, Esquire!'' (unknown)
exclaimed the cross voice just behind his (Jordan) ear.

Paul looked at

``Mr. J. A. Bates, Esquire'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
in his (Paul) own vile writing, and wondered what was the matter now.

``Didn't they teach you any better THAN that while they were at it? If you put ``Mr.

'' you don't put Esquire'-a man can't be both at once.'' (Mr.)

The boy regretted his (boy) too-much generosity in disposing of honours, hesitated, and with trembling fingers, scratched out the

``Mr.'' (The boy)
Then all at once Mr. Jordan snatched away the invoice.

``Make another! Are you going to send that to a gentleman?'' (he)
And he (Jordan) tore up the blue form irritably.

Paul, his (Paul) ears red with shame, began again. Still Mr. Jordan watched.

``I don't know what they DO teach in schools. You'll have to write better than that. Lads learn nothing nowadays, but how to recite poetry and play the fiddle. Have you seen his (Mr.) writing?'' (he)
he (Jordan) asked of Mr. Pappleworth.

``Yes; prime, isn't it?'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
replied Mr. Pappleworth indifferently.

Mr. Jordan gave a little grunt, not unamiable. Paul divined that his (Paul) master's bark was worse than his (Paul) bite. Indeed, the little manufacturer, although he (Paul) spoke bad English, was quite gentleman enough to leave his (Paul) men alone and to take no notice of trifles. But he (Paul) knew he (Paul) did not look like the boss and owner of the show, so he (Paul) had to play his (Paul) role of proprietor at first, to put things on a right footing.

``Let's see, WHAT

``S your name?'' (unknown)
asked Mr. Pappleworth of the boy.

``Paul Morel.'' (children)

It is curious that children suffer so much at having to pronounce their own names.

``Paul Morel, is it? All right, you Paul-Morel through them things there, and then--'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)

Mr. Pappleworth subsided on to a stool, and began writing. A girl came up from out of a door just behind, put some newly-pressed elastic web appliances on the counter, and returned. Mr. Pappleworth picked up the whitey-blue knee-band, examined it, and its yellow order-paper quickly, and put it on one side. Next was a flesh-pink

``leg'' (He)
. He (Pappleworth) went through the few things, wrote out a couple of orders, and called to Paul to accompany him (Paul). This time they went through the door whence the girl had emerged. There Paul found himself at the top of a little wooden flight of steps, and below him (Paul) saw a room with windows round two sides, and at the farther end half a dozen girls sitting bending over the benches in the light from the window, sewing. They were singing together
``Two Little Girls in Blue'' (unknown)
. Hearing the door opened, they all turned round, to see Mr. Pappleworth and Paul looking down on them from the far end of the room. They stopped singing.

``Can't you make a bit less row?'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth.
``Folk'll think we keep cats.'' (A woman)

A hunchback woman on a high stool turned her (woman) long, rather heavy face towards Mr. Pappleworth, and said, in a contralto voice:

``They're all tom-cats then.'' (contralto)

In vain Mr. Pappleworth tried to be impressive for Paul's benefit. He (Paul) descended the steps into the finishing-off room, and went to the hunchback Fanny. She (Fanny) had such a short body on her (Fanny) high stool that her (Fanny) head, with its great bands of bright brown hair, seemed over large, as did her (Fanny) pale, heavy face. She (Fanny) wore a dress of green-black cashmere, and her (Fanny) wrists, coming out of the narrow cuffs, were thin and flat, as she (Fanny) put down her (Fanny) work nervously. He (Paul) showed her (Fanny) something that was wrong with a knee-cap.

``Well,'' (she)
she (Fanny) said,
``you needn't come blaming it on to me. It's not my fault.'' (she)
Her (Fanny) colour mounted to her (Fanny) cheek.

``I never said it WAS your fault. Will you do as I tell you?'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
replied Mr. Pappleworth shortly.

``You don't say it's my fault, but you'd like to make out as it was,'' (hunchback)
the hunchback woman cried, almost in tears. Then she (woman) snatched the knee-cap from her (woman)
``boss'' (she)
, saying:
``Yes, I'll do it for you, but you needn't be snappy.'' (she)

``Here's your new lad,'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth.

Fanny turned, smiling very gently on Paul.

``Oh!'' (she)
she (Fanny) said.

``Yes; don't make a softy of him (lad) between you.'' (unknown)

``It's not us as `ud make a softy of him (lad),'' (she)
she (Fanny) said indignantly.

``Come on then, Paul,'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth.

``Au revoy, Paul,'' (the girls)
said one of the girls.

There was a titter of laughter. Paul went out, blushing deeply, not having spoken a word.

The day was very long. All morning the work-people were coming to speak to Mr. Pappleworth. Paul was writing or learning to make up parcels, ready for the midday post. At one o'clock, or, rather, at a quarter to one, Mr. Pappleworth disappeared to catch his (Pappleworth) train: he (Pappleworth) lived in the suburbs. At one o'clock, Paul, feeling very lost, took his (Paul) dinner-basket down into the stockroom in the basement, that had the long table on trestles, and ate his (Paul) meal hurriedly, alone in that cellar of gloom and desolation. Then he (Paul) went out of doors. The brightness and the freedom of the streets made him (Paul) feel adventurous and happy. But at two o'clock he (Paul) was back in the corner of the big room. Soon the work-girls went trooping past, making remarks. It was the commoner girls who worked upstairs at the heavy tasks of truss-making and the finishing of artificial limbs. He (Paul) waited for Mr. Pappleworth, not knowing what to do, sitting scribbling on the yellow order-paper. Mr. Pappleworth came at twenty minutes to three. Then he (Pappleworth) sat and gossiped with Paul, treating the boy entirely as an equal, even in age.

In the afternoon there was never very much to do, unless it were near the week-end, and the accounts had to be made up. At five o'clock all the men went down into the dungeon with the table on trestles, and there they had tea, eating bread-and-butter on the bare, dirty boards, talking with the same kind of ugly haste and slovenliness with which they ate their meal. And yet upstairs the atmosphere among them was always jolly and clear. The cellar and the trestles affected them.

After tea, when all the gases were lighted, WORK went more briskly. There was the big evening post to get off. The hose came up warm and newly pressed from the workrooms. Paul had made out the invoices. Now he (Paul) had the packing up and addressing to do, then he (Paul) had to weigh his (Paul) stock of parcels on the scales. Everywhere voices were calling weights, there was the chink of metal, the rapid snapping of string, the hurrying to old Mr. Melling for stamps. And at last the postman came with his (postman) sack, laughing and jolly. Then everything slacked off, and Paul took his (Paul) dinner-basket and ran to the station to catch the eight-twenty train. The day in the factory was just twelve hours long.

His (Paul) mother sat waiting for him (Paul) rather anxiously. He (Paul) had to walk from Keston, so was not home until about twenty past nine. And he (Paul) left the house before seven in the morning. Mrs. Morel was rather anxious about his (Paul) health. But she (Morel) herself had had to put up with so much that she (Morel) expected her (Morel) children to take the same odds. They must go through with what came. And Paul stayed at Jordan's, although all the time he (Paul) was there his (Paul) health suffered from the darkness and lack of air and the long hours.

He (Paul) came in pale and tired. His (Paul) mother looked at him (Paul). She (mother) saw he (Paul) was rather pleased, and her (mother) anxiety all went.

``Well, and how was it?'' (she)
she (mother) asked.

``Ever so funny, mother,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.
``You don't have to work a bit hard, and they're nice with you.'' (unknown)

``And did you get on all right?'' (unknown)

``Yes: they only say my writing's bad. But Mr. Pappleworth--he (Pappleworth)'s my man--said to Mr. Jordan I should be all right. I'm Spiral, mother; you must come and see. It's ever so nice.'' (he)

Soon he (Paul) liked Jordan's. Mr. Pappleworth, who had a certain

``saloon bar'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
flavour about him (Pappleworth), was always natural, and treated him (Pappleworth) as if he (Pappleworth) had been a comrade. Sometimes the
``Spiral boss'' (unknown)
was irritable, and chewed more lozenges than ever. Even then, however, he (Pappleworth) was not offensive, but one of those people who hurt themselves by their own irritability more than they hurt other people.

``Haven't you done that YET?'' (he)
he (Pappleworth) would cry.
``Go on, be a month of Sundays.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Again, and Paul could understand him (Paul) least then, he (Paul) was jocular and in high spirits.

``I'm going to bring my little Yorkshire terrier bitch tomorrow,'' (he)
he (Paul) said jubilantly to Paul.

``What's a Yorkshire terrier?'' (unknown)

``DON'T know what a Yorkshire terrier is? DON

``T KNOW A YORKSHIRE--'' (unknown)
Mr. Pappleworth was aghast.

``Is it a little silky one--colours of iron and rusty silver?'' (unknown)

``THAT'S it, my lad. She (bitch)'s a gem. She (bitch)'s had five pounds' worth of pups already, and she (bitch)'s worth over seven pounds herself; and she (bitch) doesn't weigh twenty ounces.'' (the bitch)

The next day the bitch came. She (bitch) was a shivering, miserable morsel. Paul did not care for her (bitch); she (bitch) seemed so like a wet rag that would never dry. Then a man called for her (bitch), and began to make coarse jokes. But Mr. Pappleworth nodded his (Pappleworth) head in the direction of the boy, and the talk went on _sotto voce_.

Mr. Jordan only made one more excursion to watch Paul, and then the only fault he (Paul) found was seeing the boy lay his (Paul) pen on the counter.

``Put your pen in your ear, if you're going to be a clerk. Pen in your ear!'' (he)
And one day he (Paul) said to the lad:
``Why don't you hold your shoulders straighter? Come down here,'' (the lad)
when he (Paul) took him (Paul) into the glass office and fitted him (Paul) with special braces for keeping the shoulders square.

But Paul liked the girls best. The men seemed common and rather dull. He (Paul) liked them all, but they were uninteresting. Polly, the little brisk overseer downstairs, finding Paul eating in the cellar, asked him (Paul) if she (Polly) could cook him (Paul) anything on her (Polly) little stove. Next day his (Paul) mother gave him (Paul) a dish that could be heated up. He (Paul) took it into the pleasant, clean room to Polly. And very soon it grew to be an established custom that he (Paul) should have dinner with her (Polly). When he (Paul) came in at eight in the morning he (Paul) took his (Paul) basket to her (Polly), and when he (Paul) came down at one o'clock she (Polly) had his (Paul) dinner ready.

He (Paul) was not very tall, and pale, with thick chestnut hair, irregular features, and a wide, full mouth. She (Polly) was like a small bird. He (Paul) often called her (Polly) a

``robinet'' (her)
. Though naturally rather quiet, he (Paul) would sit and chatter with her (Polly) for hours telling her (Polly) about his (Paul) home. The girls all liked to hear him (Paul) talk. They often gathered in a little circle while he (Paul) sat on a bench, and held forth to them, laughing. Some of them regarded him (Paul) as a curious little creature, so serious, yet so bright and jolly, and always so delicate in his (Paul) way with them. They all liked him (Paul), and he (Paul) adored them. Polly he (Paul) felt he (Paul) belonged to. Then Connie, with her (Connie) mane of red hair, her (Connie) face of apple-blossom, her (Connie) murmuring voice, such a lady in her (Connie) shabby black frock, appealed to his (Paul) romantic side.

``When you sit winding,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, ``it looks as if you were spinning at a spinning-wheel--it looks ever so nice. You remind me of Elaine in the
``Idylls of the King'. I'd draw you if I could.'' (she)

And she (Connie) glanced at him (Paul) blushing shyly. And later on he (Paul) had a sketch he (Paul) prized very much: Connie sitting on the stool before the wheel, her (Connie) flowing mane of red hair on her (Connie) rusty black frock, her (Connie) red mouth shut and serious, running the scarlet thread off the hank on to the reel.

With Louie, handsome and brazen, who always seemed to thrust her (Connie) hip at him (Louie), he (Louie) usually joked.

Emma was rather plain, rather old, and condescending. But to condescend to him (Louie) made her (Emma) happy, and he (Louie) did not mind.

``How do you put needles in?'' (he)
he (Louie) asked.

``Go away and don't bother.'' (unknown)

``But I ought to know how to put needles in.'' (She)

She (Emma) ground at her (Emma) machine all the while steadily.

``There are many things you ought to know,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied.

``Tell me, then, how to stick needles in the machine.'' (unknown)

``Oh, the boy, what a nuisance he (boy) is! Why, THIS is how you do it.'' (He)

He (Louie) watched her (Emma) attentively. Suddenly a whistle piped. Then Polly appeared, and said in a clear voice:

``Mr. Pappleworth wants to know how much longer you're going to be down here playing with the girls, Paul.'' (Polly)

Paul flew upstairs, calling

``Good-bye!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
and Emma drew herself up.

``It wasn't ME who wanted him (Paul) to play with the machine,'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

As a rule, when all the girls came back at two o'clock, he (Paul) ran upstairs to Fanny, the hunchback, in the finishing-off room. Mr. Pappleworth did not appear till twenty to three, and he (Pappleworth) often found his (Pappleworth) boy sitting beside Fanny, talking, or drawing, or singing with the girls.

Often, after a minute's hesitation, Fanny would begin to sing. She (Fanny) had a fine contralto voice. Everybody joined in the chorus, and it went well. Paul was not at all embarrassed, after a while, sitting in the room with the half a dozen work-girls.

At the end of the song Fanny would say:

``I know you've been laughing at me.'' (Fanny)

``Don't be so soft, Fanny!'' (the girls)
cried one of the girls.

Once there was mention of Connie's red hair.

``Fanny's is better, to my fancy,'' (Emma)
said Emma.

``You needn't try to make a fool of me,'' (Fanny)
said Fanny, flushing deeply.

``No, but she (Fanny) has, Paul; she (Fanny)'s got beautiful hair.'' (unknown)

``It's a treat of a colour,'' (he)
said he (Paul).
``That coldish colour like earth, and yet shiny. It's like bog-water.'' (unknown)

``Goodness me!'' (girl)
exclaimed one girl, laughing.

``How I do but get criticised,'' (Fanny)
said Fanny.

``But you should see it down, Paul,'' (Emma)
cried Emma earnestly.
``It's simply beautiful. Put it down for him (Paul), Fanny, if he (Paul) wants something to paint.'' (Fanny)

Fanny would not, and yet she (Fanny) wanted to.

``Then I'll take it down myself,'' (the lad)
said the lad.

``Well, you can if you like,'' (Fanny)
said Fanny.

And he (lad) carefully took the pins out of the knot, and the rush of hair, of uniform dark brown, slid over the humped back.

``What a lovely lot!'' (he)
he (lad) exclaimed.

The girls watched. There was silence. The youth shook the hair loose from the coil.

``It's splendid!'' (he)
he (lad) said, smelling its perfume.
``I'll bet it's worth pounds.'' (unknown)

``I'll leave it you when I die, Paul,'' (Fanny)
said Fanny, half joking.

``You look just like anybody else, sitting drying their hair,'' (the girls)
said one of the girls to the long-legged hunchback.

Poor Fanny was morbidly sensitive, always imagining insults. Polly was curt and businesslike. The two departments were for ever at war, and Paul was always finding Fanny in tears. Then he (Paul) was made the recipient of all her (Fanny) woes, and he (Paul) had to plead her (Fanny) case with Polly.

So the time went along happily enough. The factory had a homely feel. No one was rushed or driven. Paul always enjoyed it when the work got faster, towards post-time, and all the men united in labour. He (Paul) liked to watch his (Paul) fellow-clerks at work. The man was the work and the work was the man, one thing, for the time being. It was different with the girls. The real woman never seemed to be there at the task, but as if left out, waiting.

From the train going home at night he (man) used to watch the lights of the town, sprinkled thick on the hills, fusing together in a blaze in the valleys. He (man) felt rich in life and happy. Drawing farther off, there was a patch of lights at Bulwell like myriad petals shaken to the ground from the shed stars; and beyond was the red glare of the furnaces, playing like hot breath on the clouds.

He (man) had to walk two and more miles from Keston home, up two long hills, down two short hills. He (man) was often tired, and he (man) counted the lamps climbing the hill above him (man), how many more to pass. And from the hilltop, on pitch-dark nights, he (man) looked round on the villages five or six miles away, that shone like swarms of glittering living things, almost a heaven against his (man) feet. Marlpool and Heanor scattered the far-off darkness with brilliance. And occasionally the black valley space between was traced, violated by a great train rushing south to London or north to Scotland. The trains roared by like projectiles level on the darkness, fuming and burning, making the valley clang with their passage. They were gone, and the lights of the towns and villages glittered in silence.

And then he (man) came to the corner at home, which faced the other side of the night. The ash-tree seemed a friend now. His (friend) mother rose with gladness as he (friend) entered. He (friend) put his (friend) eight shillings proudly on the table.

``It'll help, mother?'' (he)
he (friend) asked wistfully.

``There's precious little left,'' (she)
she (mother) answered,
``after your ticket and dinners and such are taken off.'' (she)

Then he (friend) told her (mother) the budget of the day. His (friend) life-story, like an Arabian Nights, was told night after night to his (friend) mother. It was almost as if it were her (mother) own life.

CHAPTER VI

DEATH IN THE FAMILY

ARTHUR MOREL was growing up. He (friend) was a quick, careless, impulsive boy, a good deal like his (friend) father. He (friend) hated study, made a great moan if he (friend) had to work, and escaped as soon as possible to his (friend) sport again.

In appearance he (friend) remained the flower of the family, being well made, graceful, and full of life. His (friend) dark brown hair and fresh colouring, and his (friend) exquisite dark blue eyes shaded with long lashes, together with his (friend) generous manner and fiery temper, made him (friend) a favourite. But as he (friend) grew older his (friend) temper became uncertain. He (friend) flew into rages over nothing, seemed unbearably raw and irritable.

His (friend) mother, whom he (friend) loved, wearied of him (friend) sometimes. He (friend) thought only of himself. When he (friend) wanted amusement, all that stood in his (friend) way he (friend) hated, even if it were she (mother). When he (friend) was in trouble he (friend) moaned to her (mother) ceaselessly.

``Goodness, boy!'' (she)
she (mother) said, when he (friend) groaned about a master who, he (friend) said, hated him (friend),
``if you don't like it, alter it, and if you can't alter it, put up with it.'' (him)

And his (friend) father, whom he (friend) had loved and who had worshipped him (friend), he (friend) came to detest. As he (friend) grew older Morel fell into a slow ruin. His (friend) body, which had been beautiful in movement and in being, shrank, did not seem to ripen with the years, but to get mean and rather despicable. There came over him (friend) a look of meanness and of paltriness. And when the mean-looking elderly man bullied or ordered the boy about, Arthur was furious. Moreover, Morel's manners got worse and worse, his (Arthur) habits somewhat disgusting. When the children were growing up and in the crucial stage of adolescence, the father was like some ugly irritant to their souls. His (father) manners in the house were the same as he (father) used among the colliers down pit.

``Dirty nuisance!'' (Arthur/ARTHUR)
Arthur would cry, jumping up and going straight out of the house when his (Arthur) father disgusted him (Arthur). And Morel persisted the more because his (Arthur) children hated it. He (Arthur) seemed to take a kind of satisfaction in disgusting them, and driving them nearly mad, while they were so irritably sensitive at the age of fourteen or fifteen. So that Arthur, who was growing up when his (Arthur) father was degenerate and elderly, hated him (Arthur) worst of all.

Then, sometimes, the father would seem to feel the contemptuous hatred of his (father) children.

``There's not a man tries harder for his (man) family!'' (he)
he (father) would shout.
``He (man) does his (man) best for them, and then gets treated like a dog. But I'm not going to stand it, I tell you!'' (he)

But for the threat and the fact that he (father) did not try so hard as he (father) imagined, they would have felt sorry. As it was, the battle now went on nearly all between father and children, he (father) persisting in his (father) dirty and disgusting ways, just to assert his (father) independence. They loathed him (father).

Arthur was so inflamed and irritable at last, that when he (Arthur) won a scholarship for the Grammar School in Nottingham, his (Arthur) mother decided to let him (Arthur) live in town, with one of her (mother) sisters, and only come home at week-ends.

Annie was still a junior teacher in the Board-school, earning about four shillings a week. But soon she (Annie) would have fifteen shillings, since she (Annie) had passed her (Annie) examination, and there would be financial peace in the house.

Mrs. Morel clung now to Paul. He (Paul) was quiet and not brilliant. But still he (Paul) stuck to his (Paul) painting, and still he (Paul) stuck to his (Paul) mother. Everything he (Paul) did was for her (mother). She (mother) waited for his (Paul) coming home in the evening, and then she (mother) unburdened herself of all she (mother) had pondered, or of all that had occurred to her (mother) during the day. He (Paul) sat and listened with his (Paul) earnestness. The two shared lives.

William was engaged now to his (William) brunette, and had bought her (mother) an engagement ring that cost eight guineas. The children gasped at such a fabulous price.

``Eight guineas!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.
``More fool him (fool)! If he (fool)'d gen me some on't, it `ud ha' looked better on `im.'' (unknown)

``Given YOU some of it!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Mrs. Morel.
``Why give YOU some of it!'' (She)

She (Morel) remembered HE (William) had bought no engagement ring at all, and she (Morel) preferred William, who was not mean, if he (William) were foolish. But now the young man talked only of the dances to which he (man) went with his (man) betrothed, and the different resplendent clothes she (Morel) wore; or he (man) told his (man) mother with glee how they went to the theatre like great swells.

He (man) wanted to bring the girl home. Mrs. Morel said she (Morel) should come at the Christmas. This time William arrived with a lady, but with no presents. Mrs. Morel had prepared supper. Hearing footsteps, she (Morel) rose and went to the door. William entered.

``Hello, mother!'' (He)
He (William) kissed her (Morel) hastily, then stood aside to present a tall, handsome girl, who was wearing a costume of fine black-and-white check, and furs.

``Here's Gyp!'' (unknown)

Miss Western held out her (Morel) hand and showed her (Morel) teeth in a small smile.

``Oh, how do you do, Mrs. Morel!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed.

``I am afraid you will be hungry,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Oh no, we had dinner in the train. Have you got my gloves, Chubby?'' (William)

William Morel, big and raw-boned, looked at her (Morel) quickly.

``How should I?'' (he)
he (Morel) said.

``Then I've lost them. Don't be cross with me.'' (he)

A frown went over his (Morel) face, but he (Morel) said nothing. She (Morel) glanced round the kitchen. It was small and curious to her (Morel), with its glittering kissing-bunch, its evergreens behind the pictures, its wooden chairs and little deal table. At that moment Morel came in.

``Hello, dad!'' (unknown)

``Hello, my son! Tha's let on me!'' (William)

The two shook hands, and William presented the lady. She (Morel) gave the same smile that showed her (Morel) teeth.

``How do you do, Mr. Morel?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel bowed obsequiously.

``I'm very well, and I hope so are you. You must make yourself very welcome.'' (unknown)

``Oh, thank you,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied, rather amused.

``You will like to go upstairs,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``If you don't mind; but not if it is any trouble to you.'' (unknown)

``It is no trouble. Annie will take you. Walter, carry up this box.'' (unknown)

``And don't be an hour dressing yourself up,'' (William)
said William to his (William) betrothed.

Annie took a brass candlestick, and, too shy almost to speak, preceded the young lady to the front bedroom, which Mr. and Mrs. Morel had vacated for her (Morel). It, too, was small and cold by candlelight. The colliers' wives only lit fires in bedrooms in case of extreme illness.

``Shall I unstrap the box?'' (Annie)
asked Annie.

``Oh, thank you very much!'' (Annie)

Annie played the part of maid, then went downstairs for hot water.

``I think she (Annie)'s rather tired, mother,'' (William)
said William.
``It's a beastly journey, and we had such a rush.'' (unknown)

``Is there anything I can give her (Annie)?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
asked Mrs. Morel.

``Oh no, she (Annie)'ll be all right.'' (unknown)

But there was a chill in the atmosphere. After half an hour Miss Western came down, having put on a purplish-coloured dress, very fine for the collier's kitchen.

``I told you you'd no need to change,'' (William)
said William to her (Morel).

``Oh, Chubby!'' (she)
Then she (Morel) turned with that sweetish smile to Mrs. Morel.
``Don't you think he (Annie)'s always grumbling, Mrs. Morel?'' (unknown)

``Is he (Annie)?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``That's not very nice of him (Annie).'' (unknown)

``It isn't, really!'' (unknown)

``You are cold,'' (the mother)
said the mother.
``Won't you come near the fire?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel jumped out of his (William) armchair.

``Come and sit you here!'' (he)
he (William) cried.
``Come and sit you here!'' (unknown)

``No, dad, keep your own chair. Sit on the sofa, Gyp,'' (William)
said William.

``No, no!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Morel.
``This cheer's warmest. Come and sit here, Miss Wesson.'' (unknown)

``Thank you so much,'' (the girl place)
said the girl, seating herself in the collier's armchair, the place of honour. She (Morel) shivered, feeling the warmth of the kitchen penetrate her (Morel).

``Fetch me a hanky, Chubby dear!'' (she)
she (Morel) said, putting up her (Morel) mouth to him (William), and using the same intimate tone as if they were alone; which made the rest of the family feel as if they ought not to be present. The young lady evidently did not realise them as people: they were creatures to her (lady) for the present. William winced.

In such a household, in Streatham, Miss Western would have been a lady condescending to her (lady) inferiors. These people were to her (lady), certainly clownish--in short, the working classes. How was she (lady) to adjust herself?

``I'll go,'' (Annie)
said Annie.

Miss Western took no notice, as if a servant had spoken. But when the girl came downstairs again with the handkerchief, she (girl) said:

``Oh, thank you!'' (she)
in a gracious way.

She (girl) sat and talked about the dinner on the train, which had been so poor; about London, about dances. She (girl) was really very nervous, and chattered from fear. Morel sat all the time smoking his (servant) thick twist tobacco, watching her (Morel), and listening to her (Morel) glib London speech, as he (servant) puffed. Mrs. Morel, dressed up in her (Morel) best black silk blouse, answered quietly and rather briefly. The three children sat round in silence and admiration. Miss Western was the princess. Everything of the best was got out for her (princess): the best cups, the best spoons, the best table cloth, the best coffee-jug. The children thought she (princess) must find it quite grand. She (princess) felt strange, not able to realise the people, not knowing how to treat them. William joked, and was slightly uncomfortable.

At about ten o'clock he (William) said to her (princess):

``Aren't you tired, Gyp?'' (he)

``Rather, Chubby,'' (she)
she (princess) answered, at once in the intimate tones and putting her (princess) head slightly on one side.

``I'll light her (you) the candle, mother,'' (he)
he (William) said.

``Very well,'' (the mother)
replied the mother.

Miss Western stood up, held out her (princess) hand to Mrs. Morel.

``Good-night, Mrs. Morel,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

Paul sat at the boiler, letting the water run from the tap into a stone beer-bottle. Annie swathed the bottle in an old flannel pit-singlet, and kissed her (Annie) mother good-night. She (Annie) was to share the room with the lady, because the house was full.

``You wait a minute,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel to Annie. And Annie sat nursing the hot-water bottle. Miss Western shook hands all round, to everybody's discomfort, and took her (Annie) departure, preceded by William. In five minutes he (William) was downstairs again. His (William) heart was rather sore; he (William) did not know why. He (William) talked very little till everybody had gone to bed, but himself and his (William) mother. Then he (William) stood with his (William) legs apart, in his (William) old attitude on the hearthrug, and said hesitatingly:

``Well, mother?'' (he)

``Well, my son?'' (She)

She (mother) sat in the rocking-chair, feeling somehow hurt and humiliated, for his (William) sake.

``Do you like her (Morel)?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (unknown)
came the slow answer.

``She (Morel)'s shy yet, mother. She (Morel)'s not used to it. It's different from her (Morel) aunt's house, you know.'' (unknown)

``Of course it is, my boy; and she (Morel) must find it difficult.'' (unknown)

``She (Morel) does.'' (he)
Then he (William) frowned swiftly.
``If only she (Morel) wouldn't put on her (Morel) BLESSED airs!'' (unknown)

``It's only her (Morel) first awkwardness, my boy. She (Morel)'ll be all right.'' (unknown)

``That's it, mother,'' (he)
he (William) replied gratefully. But his (William) brow was gloomy.
``You know, she (mother)'s not like you, mother. She (mother)'s not serious, and she (mother) can't think.'' (unknown)

``She (mother)'s young, my boy.'' (unknown)

``Yes; and she (mother)'s had no sort of show. Her (mother) mother died when she (mother) was a child. Since then she (mother)'s lived with her (mother) aunt, whom she (mother) can't bear. And her (mother) father was a rake. She (mother)'s had no love.'' (unknown)

``No! Well, you must make up to her (mother).'' (unknown)

``And so--you have to forgive her (mother) a lot of things.'' (unknown)

``WHAT do you have to forgive her (mother), my boy?'' (unknown)

``I dunno. When she (mother) seems shallow, you have to remember she (mother)'s never had anybody to bring her (mother) deeper side out. And she (mother)'s FEARFULLY fond of me.'' (unknown)

``Anybody can see that.'' (unknown)

``But you know, mother--she (mother)'s--she (mother)'s different from us. Those sort of people, like those she (mother) lives amongst, they don't seem to have the same principles.'' (unknown)

``You mustn't judge too hastily,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

But he (William) seemed uneasy within himself.

In the morning, however, he (William) was up singing and larking round the house.

``Hello!'' (he)
he (William) called, sitting on the stairs.
``Are you getting up?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (unknown)
her (Morel) voice called faintly.

``Merry Christmas!'' (he)
he (William) shouted to her (Morel).

Her (Morel) laugh, pretty and tinkling, was heard in the bedroom. She (Morel) did not come down in half an hour.

``Was she (mother) REALLY getting up when she (mother) said she (mother) was?'' (he)
he (William) asked of Annie.

``Yes, she (mother) was,'' (Annie)
replied Annie.

He (William) waited a while, then went to the stairs again.

``Happy New Year,'' (he)
he (William) called.

``Thank you, Chubby dear!'' (unknown)
came the laughing voice, far away.

``Buck up!'' (he)
he (William) implored.

It was nearly an hour, and still he (William) was waiting for her (Annie). Morel, who always rose before six, looked at the clock.

``Well, it's a winder!'' (he)
he (William) exclaimed.

The family had breakfasted, all but William. He (William) went to the foot of the stairs.

``Shall I have to send you an Easter egg up there?'' (he)
he (William) called, rather crossly. She (Morel) only laughed. The family expected, after that time of preparation, something like magic. At last she (Morel) came, looking very nice in a blouse and skirt.

``Have you REALLY been all this time getting ready?'' (he)
he (William) asked.

``Chubby dear! That question is not permitted, is it, Mrs. Morel?'' (She)

She (Morel) played the grand lady at first. When she (Morel) went with William to chapel, he (William) in his (William) frock-coat and silk hat, she (Morel) in her (Morel) furs and London-made costume, Paul and Arthur and Annie expected everybody to bow to the ground in admiration. And Morel, standing in his (Paul) Sunday suit at the end of the road, watching the gallant pair go, felt he (Paul) was the father of princes and princesses.

And yet she (Morel) was not so grand. For a year now she (Morel) had been a sort of secretary or clerk in a London office. But while she (Morel) was with the Morels she (Morel) queened it. She (Morel) sat and let Annie or Paul wait on her (Annie) as if they were her (Annie) servants. She (Annie) treated Mrs. Morel with a certain glibness and Morel with patronage. But after a day or so she (Morel) began to change her (Morel) tune.

William always wanted Paul or Annie to go along with them on their walks. It was so much more interesting. And Paul really DID admire

``Gipsy'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
wholeheartedly; in fact, his (Paul) mother scarcely forgave the boy for the adulation with which he (Paul) treated the girl.

On the second day, when Lily said:

``Oh, Annie, do you know where I left my muff?'' (Lily/Louisa Lily Denys Western)
William replied:

``You know it is in your bedroom. Why do you ask Annie?'' (William)

And Lily went upstairs with a cross, shut mouth. But it angered the young man that she (Lily) made a servant of his (servant) sister.

On the third evening William and Lily were sitting together in the parlour by the fire in the dark. At a quarter to eleven Mrs. Morel was heard raking the fire. William came out to the kitchen, followed by his (William) beloved.

``Is it as late as that, mother?'' (he)
he (William) said. She (Morel) had been sitting alone.

``It is not LATE, my boy, but it is as late as I usually sit up.'' (unknown)

``Won't you go to bed, then?'' (he)
he (William) asked.

``And leave you two? No, my boy, I don't believe in it.'' (unknown)

``Can't you trust us, mother?'' (unknown)

``Whether I can or not, I won't do it. You can stay till eleven if you like, and I can read.'' (unknown)

``Go to bed, Gyp,'' (he)
he (William) said to his (William) girl.
``We won't keep mater waiting.'' (unknown)

``Annie has left the candle burning, Lily,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel;
``I think you will see.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Yes, thank you. Good-night, Mrs. Morel.'' (William)

William kissed his (William) sweetheart at the foot of the stairs, and she (Morel) went. He (William) returned to the kitchen.

``Can't you trust us, mother?'' (he)
he (William) repeated, rather offended.

``My boy, I tell you I don't BELIEVE in leaving two young things like you alone downstairs when everyone else is in bed.'' (he)

And he (William) was forced to take this answer. He (William) kissed his (William) mother good-night.

At Easter he (William) came over alone. And then he (William) discussed his (William) sweetheart endlessly with his (William) mother.

``You know, mother, when I'm away from her (mother) I don't care for her (mother) a bit. I shouldn't care if I never saw her (mother) again. But, then, when I'm with her (mother) in the evenings I am awfully fond of her (mother).'' (unknown)

``It's a queer sort of love to marry on,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``if she (mother) holds you no more than that!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``It IS funny!'' (he)
he (William) exclaimed. It worried and perplexed him (William).
``But yet--there's so much between us now I couldn't give her (mother) up.'' (unknown)

``You know best,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``But if it is as you say, I wouldn't call it LOVE--at any rate, it doesn't look much like it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't know, mother. She (mother)'s an orphan, and--'' (He)

They never came to any sort of conclusion. He (William) seemed puzzled and rather fretted. She (Morel) was rather reserved. All his (William) strength and money went in keeping this girl. He (William) could scarcely afford to take his (William) mother to Nottingham when he (William) came over.

Paul's wages had been raised at Christmas to ten shillings, to his (William) great joy. He (William) was quite happy at Jordan's, but his (William) health suffered from the long hours and the confinement. His (William) mother, to whom he (William) became more and more significant, thought how to help.

His (William) half-day holiday was on Monday afternoon. On a Monday morning in May, as the two sat alone at breakfast, she (mother) said:

``I think it will be a fine day.'' (she)

He (William) looked up in surprise. This meant something.

``You know Mr. Leivers has gone to live on a new farm. Well, he (Leivers) asked me last week if I wouldn't go and see Mrs. Leivers, and I promised to bring you on Monday if it's fine. Shall we go?'' (unknown)

``I say, little woman, how lovely!'' (he)
he (William) cried.
``And we'll go this afternoon?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul hurried off to the station jubilant. Down Derby Road was a cherry-tree that glistened. The old brick wall by the Statutes ground burned scarlet, spring was a very flame of green. And the steep swoop of highroad lay, in its cool morning dust, splendid with patterns of sunshine and shadow, perfectly still. The trees sloped their great green shoulders proudly; and inside the warehouse all the morning, the boy had a vision of spring outside.

When he (boy) came home at dinner-time his (boy) mother was rather excited.

``Are we going?'' (he)
he (boy) asked.

``When I'm ready,'' (she)
she (mother) replied.

Presently he (boy) got up.

``Go and get dressed while I wash up,'' (he)
he (boy) said.

She (mother) did so. He (boy) washed the pots, straightened, and then took her (mother) boots. They were quite clean. Mrs. Morel was one of those naturally exquisite people who can walk in mud without dirtying their shoes. But Paul had to clean them for her (Morel). They were kid boots at eight shillings a pair. He (Paul), however, thought them the most dainty boots in the world, and he (Paul) cleaned them with as much reverence as if they had been flowers.

Suddenly she (Morel) appeared in the inner doorway rather shyly. She (Morel) had got a new cotton blouse on. Paul jumped up and went forward.

``Oh, my stars!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed.
``What a bobby-dazzler!'' (She)

She (Morel) sniffed in a little haughty way, and put her (Morel) head up.

``It's not a bobby-dazzler at all!'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.
``It's very quiet.'' (She)

She (Morel) walked forward, whilst he (Paul) hovered round her (Morel).

``Well,'' (she)
she (Morel) asked, quite shy, but pretending to be high and mighty,
``do you like it?'' (she)

``Awfully! You ARE a fine little woman to go jaunting out with!'' (He)

He (Paul) went and surveyed her (Morel) from the back.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, ``if I was walking down the street behind you, I should say:
``Doesn't THAT little person fancy herself!'' (he)
'

``Well, she (woman) doesn't,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel.
``She (woman)'s not sure it suits her (woman).'' (unknown)

``Oh no! she (woman) wants to be in dirty black, looking as if she (woman) was wrapped in burnt paper. It DOES suit you, and I say you look nice.'' (She)

She (Morel) sniffed in her (Morel) little way, pleased, but pretending to know better.

``Well,'' (she)
she (Morel) said,
``it's cost me just three shillings. You couldn't have got it ready-made for that price, could you?'' (she)

``I should think you couldn't,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.

``And, you know, it's good stuff.'' (unknown)

``Awfully pretty,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

The blouse was white, with a little sprig of heliotrope and black.

``Too young for me, though, I'm afraid,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

``Too young for you!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed in disgust.
``Why don't you buy some false white hair and stick it on your head.'' (unknown)

``I s'll soon have no need,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.
``I'm going white fast enough.'' (unknown)

``Well, you've no business to,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``What do I want with a white-haired mother?'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid you'll have to put up with one, my lad,'' (she)
she (Morel) said rather strangely.

They set off in great style, she (Morel) carrying the umbrella William had given her (Morel), because of the sun. Paul was considerably taller than she (Morel), though he (Paul) was not big. He (Paul) fancied himself.

On the fallow land the young wheat shone silkily. Minton pit waved its plumes of white steam, coughed, and rattled hoarsely.

``Now look at that!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel. Mother and son stood on the road to watch. Along the ridge of the great pit-hill crawled a little group in silhouette against the sky, a horse, a small truck, and a man. They climbed the incline against the heavens. At the end the man tipped the wagon. There was an undue rattle as the waste fell down the sheer slope of the enormous bank.

``You sit a minute, mother,'' (he)
he (man) said, and she (Morel) took a seat on a bank, whilst he (man) sketched rapidly. She (Morel) was silent whilst he (man) worked, looking round at the afternoon, the red cottages shining among their greenness.

``The world is a wonderful place,'' (she)
she (Morel) said,
``and wonderfully beautiful.'' (she)

``And so's the pit,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``Look how it heaps together, like something alive almost--a big creature that you don't know.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``Perhaps!'' (unknown)

``And all the trucks standing waiting, like a string of beasts to be fed,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``And very thankful I am they ARE standing,'' (she)
she (Morel) said,
``for that means they'll turn middling time this week.'' (she)

``But I like the feel of MEN on things, while they're alive. There's a feel of men about trucks, because they've been handled with men's hands, all of them.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

They went along under the trees of the highroad. He (man) was constantly informing her (Morel), but she (Morel) was interested. They passed the end of Nethermere, that was tossing its sunshine like petals lightly in its lap. Then they turned on a private road, and in some trepidation approached a big farm. A dog barked furiously. A woman came out to see.

``Is this the way to Willey Farm?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel asked.

Paul hung behind in terror of being sent back. But the woman was amiable, and directed them. The mother and son went through the wheat and oats, over a little bridge into a wild meadow. Peewits, with their white breasts glistening, wheeled and screamed about them. The lake was still and blue. High overhead a heron floated. Opposite, the wood heaped on the hill, green and still.

``It's a wild road, mother,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``Just like Canada.'' (unknown)

``Isn't it beautiful!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, looking round.

``See that heron--see--see her (mother) legs?'' (He)

He (Paul) directed his (Paul) mother, what she (Morel) must see and what not. And she (Morel) was quite content.

``But now,'' (she)
she (Morel) said,
``which way? He (Willey) told me through the wood.'' (she)

The wood, fenced and dark, lay on their left.

``I can feel a bit of a path this road,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``You've got town feet, somehow or other, you have.'' (unknown)
