They found a little gate, and soon were in a broad green alley of the wood, with a new thicket of fir and pine on one hand, an old oak glade dipping down on the other. And among the oaks the bluebells stood in pools of azure, under the new green hazels, upon a pale fawn floor of oak-leaves. He (Paul) found flowers for her (Morel).

``Here's a bit of new-mown hay,'' (he)
he (Paul) said; then, again, he (Paul) brought her (Morel) forget-me-nots. And, again, his (Paul) heart hurt with love, seeing her (Morel) hand, used with work, holding the little bunch of flowers he (Paul) gave her (Morel). She (Morel) was perfectly happy.

But at the end of the riding was a fence to climb. Paul was over in a second.

``Come,'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``let me help you.'' (he)

``No, go away. I will do it in my own way.'' (He)

He (Paul) stood below with his (Paul) hands up ready to help her (Morel). She (Morel) climbed cautiously.

``What a way to climb!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed scornfully, when she (Morel) was safely to earth again.

``Hateful stiles!'' (she)
she (Morel) cried.

``Duffer of a little woman,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied,
``who can't get over 'em.'' (he)

In front, along the edge of the wood, was a cluster of low red farm buildings. The two hastened forward. Flush with the wood was the apple orchard, where blossom was falling on the grindstone. The pond was deep under a hedge and overhanging oak trees. Some cows stood in the shade. The farm and buildings, three sides of a quadrangle, embraced the sunshine towards the wood. It was very still.

Mother and son went into the small railed garden, where was a scent of red gillivers. By the open door were some floury loaves, put out to cool. A hen was just coming to peck them. Then, in the doorway suddenly appeared a girl in a dirty apron. She (girl) was about fourteen years old, had a rosy dark face, a bunch of short black curls, very fine and free, and dark eyes; shy, questioning, a little resentful of the strangers, she (girl) disappeared. In a minute another figure appeared, a small, frail woman, rosy, with great dark brown eyes.

``Oh!'' (she)
she (woman) exclaimed, smiling with a little glow,
``you've come, then. I AM glad to see you.'' (she)
Her (woman) voice was intimate and rather sad.

The two women shook hands.

``Now are you sure we're not a bother to you?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``I know what a farming life is.'' (unknown)

``Oh no! We're only too thankful to see a new face, it's so lost up here.'' (unknown)

``I suppose so,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

They were taken through into the parlour--a long, low room, with a great bunch of guelder-roses in the fireplace. There the women talked, whilst Paul went out to survey the land. He (Paul) was in the garden smelling the gillivers and looking at the plants, when the girl came out quickly to the heap of coal which stood by the fence.

``I suppose these are cabbage-roses?'' (he)
he (Paul) said to her (girl), pointing to the bushes along the fence.

She (girl) looked at him (Paul) with startled, big brown eyes.

``I suppose they are cabbage-roses when they come out?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I don't know,'' (she)
she (girl) faltered.
``They're white with pink middles.'' (unknown)

``Then they're maiden-blush.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam flushed. She (Miriam) had a beautiful warm colouring.

``I don't know,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``You don't have MUCH in your garden,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``This is our first year here,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered, in a distant, rather superior way, drawing back and going indoors. He (Paul) did not notice, but went his (Paul) round of exploration. Presently his (Paul) mother came out, and they went through the buildings. Paul was hugely delighted.

``And I suppose you have the fowls and calves and pigs to look after?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel to Mrs. Leivers.

``No,'' (the woman)
replied the little woman.
``I can't find time to look after cattle, and I'm not used to it. It's as much as I can do to keep going in the house.'' (unknown)

``Well, I suppose it is,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

Presently the girl came out.

``Tea is ready, mother,'' (she)
she (Morel) said in a musical, quiet voice.

``Oh, thank you, Miriam, then we'll come,'' (mother)
replied her (Morel) mother, almost ingratiatingly.
``Would you CARE to have tea now, Mrs. Morel?'' (unknown)

``Of course,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``Whenever it's ready.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul and his (Paul) mother and Mrs. Leivers had tea together. Then they went out into the wood that was flooded with bluebells, while fumy forget-me-nots were in the paths. The mother and son were in ecstasy together.

When they got back to the house, Mr. Leivers and Edgar, the eldest son, were in the kitchen. Edgar was about eighteen. Then Geoffrey and Maurice, big lads of twelve and thirteen, were in from school. Mr. Leivers was a good-looking man in the prime of life, with a golden-brown moustache, and blue eyes screwed up against the weather.

The boys were condescending, but Paul scarcely observed it. They went round for eggs, scrambling into all sorts of places. As they were feeding the fowls Miriam came out. The boys took no notice of her (Miriam). One hen, with her (Miriam) yellow chickens, was in a coop. Maurice took his (Maurice) hand full of corn and let the hen peck from it.

``Durst you do it?'' (he)
he (Maurice) asked of Paul.

``Let's see,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

He (Paul) had a small hand, warm, and rather capable-looking. Miriam watched. He (Paul) held the corn to the hen. The bird eyed it with her (Miriam) hard, bright eye, and suddenly made a peck into his (Paul) hand. He (Paul) started, and laughed.

``Rap, rap, rap!'' (unknown)
went the bird's beak in his (Paul) palm. He (Paul) laughed again, and the other boys joined.

``She (Morel) knocks you, and nips you, but she (Morel) never hurts,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, when the last corn had gone.
``Now, Miriam,'' (Maurice)
said Maurice,
``you come an `ave a go.'' (Maurice)

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried, shrinking back.

``Ha! baby. The mardy-kid!'' (brothers)
said her (Miriam) brothers.

``It doesn't hurt a bit,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``It only just nips rather nicely.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) still cried, shaking her (Miriam) black curls and shrinking.

``She (Miriam) dursn't,'' (Geoffrey)
said Geoffrey.
``She (Miriam) niver durst do anything except recite poitry.'' (unknown)

``Dursn't jump off a gate, dursn't tweedle, dursn't go on a slide, dursn't stop a girl hittin' her (girl). She (girl) can do nowt but go about thinkin' herself somebody. ``The Lady of the Lake.

'' Yah!'' (The Lady)
cried Maurice.

Miriam was crimson with shame and misery.

``I dare do more than you,'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried.
``You're never anything but cowards and bullies.'' (unknown)

``Oh, cowards and bullies!'' (unknown)
they repeated mincingly, mocking her (Miriam) speech.

``Not such a clown shall anger me, A boor is answered silently,'' (he)

he (Maurice) quoted against her (Miriam), shouting with laughter.

She (Miriam) went indoors. Paul went with the boys into the orchard, where they had rigged up a parallel bar. They did feats of strength. He (Paul) was more agile than strong, but it served. He (Paul) fingered a piece of apple-blossom that hung low on a swinging bough.

``I wouldn't get the apple-blossom,'' (Edgar)
said Edgar, the eldest brother.
``There'll be no apples next year.'' (unknown)

``I wasn't going to get it,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
replied Paul, going away.

The boys felt hostile to him (Paul); they were more interested in their own pursuits. He (Paul) wandered back to the house to look for his (Paul) mother. As he (Paul) went round the back, he (Paul) saw Miriam kneeling in front of the hen-coop, some maize in her (Miriam) hand, biting her (Miriam) lip, and crouching in an intense attitude. The hen was eyeing her (Miriam) wickedly. Very gingerly she (Miriam) put forward her (Miriam) hand. The hen bobbed for her (Miriam). She (Miriam) drew back quickly with a cry, half of fear, half of chagrin.

``It won't hurt you,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

She (Miriam) flushed crimson and started up.

``I only wanted to try,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said in a low voice.

``See, it doesn't hurt,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, and, putting only two corns in his (Paul) palm, he (Paul) let the hen peck, peck, peck at his (Paul) bare hand.
``It only makes you laugh,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (Miriam) put her (Miriam) hand forward and dragged it away, tried again, and started back with a cry. He (Paul) frowned.

``Why, I'd let her (I) take corn from my face,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``only she (I) bumps a bit. She (I)'s ever so neat. If she (I) wasn't, look how much ground she (I)'d peck up every day.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

He (Paul) waited grimly, and watched. At last Miriam let the bird peck from her (Miriam) hand. She (Miriam) gave a little cry--fear, and pain because of fear--rather pathetic. But she (Miriam) had done it, and she (Miriam) did it again.

``There, you see,'' (the boy)
said the boy.
``It doesn't hurt, does it?'' (She)

She (Miriam) looked at him (boy) with dilated dark eyes.

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) laughed, trembling.

Then she (Miriam) rose and went indoors. She (Miriam) seemed to be in some way resentful of the boy.

``He (I) thinks I'm only a common girl,'' (she)
she (Miriam) thought, and she (Miriam) wanted to prove she (Miriam) was a grand person like the
``Lady of the Lake'' (a person)
.

Paul found his (Paul) mother ready to go home. She (mother) smiled on her (mother) son. He (Paul) took the great bunch of flowers. Mr. and Mrs. Leivers walked down the fields with them. The hills were golden with evening; deep in the woods showed the darkening purple of bluebells. It was everywhere perfectly stiff, save for the rustling of leaves and birds.

``But it is a beautiful place,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Yes,'' (Mr. Leivers)
answered Mr. Leivers;
``it's a nice little place, if only it weren't for the rabbits. The pasture's bitten down to nothing. I dunno if ever I s'll get the rent off it.'' (Mr. Leivers)

He (Leivers) clapped his (Leivers) hands, and the field broke into motion near the woods, brown rabbits hopping everywhere.

``Would you believe it!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
exclaimed Mrs. Morel.

She (Morel) and Paul went on alone together.

``Wasn't it lovely, mother?'' (he)
he (Paul) said quietly.

A thin moon was coming out. His (Paul) heart was full of happiness till it hurt. His (Paul) mother had to chatter, because she (mother), too, wanted to cry with happiness.

``Now WOULDN``T I help that man!'' she (mother) said. ``WOULDN'T I see to the fowls and the young stock! And I``D learn to milk, and I``D talk with him (man), and I``D plan with him (man). My word, if I were his (man) wife, the farm would be run, I know! But there, she (wife) hasn't the strength--she (wife) simply hasn't the strength. She (wife) ought never to have been burdened like it, you know. I'm sorry for her (wife), and I'm sorry for him (man) too. My word, if I

``D had him (man), I shouldn't have thought him (man) a bad husband! Not that she (wife) does either; and she (wife)'s very lovable.'' (William)

William came home again with his (William) sweetheart at the Whitsuntide. He (William) had one week of his (William) holidays then. It was beautiful weather. As a rule, William and Lily and Paul went out in the morning together for a walk. William did not talk to his (William) beloved much, except to tell her (Lily) things from his (William) boyhood. Paul talked endlessly to both of them. They lay down, all three, in a meadow by Minton Church. On one side, by the Castle Farm, was a beautiful quivering screen of poplars. Hawthorn was dropping from the hedges; penny daisies and ragged robin were in the field, like laughter. William, a big fellow of twenty-three, thinner now and even a bit gaunt, lay back in the sunshine and dreamed, while she (Lily) fingered with his (William) hair. Paul went gathering the big daisies. She (Lily) had taken off her (Lily) hat; her (Lily) hair was black as a horse's mane. Paul came back and threaded daisies in her (Lily) jet-black hair--big spangles of white and yellow, and just a pink touch of ragged robin.

``Now you look like a young witch-woman,'' (the boy)
the boy said to her (Lily).
``Doesn't she (wife), William?'' (Lily/Louisa Lily Denys Western)

Lily laughed. William opened his (William) eyes and looked at her (Lily). In his (William) gaze was a certain baffled look of misery and fierce appreciation.

``Has he (William) made a sight of me?'' (she)
she (Lily) asked, laughing down on her (Lily) lover.

``That he (William) has!'' (William)
said William, smiling.

He (William) looked at her (Lily). Her (Lily) beauty seemed to hurt him (William). He (William) glanced at her (Lily) flower-decked head and frowned.

``You look nice enough, if that's what you want to know,'' (he)
he (William) said.

And she (Lily) walked without her (Lily) hat. In a little while William recovered, and was rather tender to her (Lily). Coming to a bridge, he (William) carved her (Lily) initials and his (William) in a heart.

L. L. W.

W. M.

She (Lily) watched his (William) strong, nervous hand, with its glistening hairs and freckles, as he (William) carved, and she (Lily) seemed fascinated by it.

All the time there was a feeling of sadness and warmth, and a certain tenderness in the house, whilst William and Lily were at home. But often he (William) got irritable. She (Lily) had brought, for an eight-days' stay, five dresses and six blouses.

``Oh, would you mind,'' (she)
she (Lily) said to Annie,
``washing me these two blouses, and these things?'' (Annie)

And Annie stood washing when William and Lily went out the next morning. Mrs. Morel was furious. And sometimes the young man, catching a glimpse of his (William) sweetheart's attitude towards his (William) sister, hated her (sister).

On Sunday morning she (sister) looked very beautiful in a dress of foulard, silky and sweeping, and blue as a jay-bird's feather, and in a large cream hat covered with many roses, mostly crimson. Nobody could admire her (sister) enough. But in the evening, when she (sister) was going out, she (sister) asked again:

``Chubby, have you got my gloves?'' (she)

``Which?'' (William)
asked William.

``My new black SUEDE.'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

There was a hunt. She (sister) had lost them.

``Look here, mother,'' (William)
said William,
``that's the fourth pair she (mother)'s lost since Christmas--at five shillings a pair!'' (William)

``You only gave me TWO of them,'' (she)
she (sister) remonstrated.

And in the evening, after supper, he (William) stood on the hearthrug whilst she (sister) sat on the sofa, and he (William) seemed to hate her (sister). In the afternoon he (William) had left her (sister) whilst he (William) went to see some old friend. She (sister) had sat looking at a book. After supper William wanted to write a letter.

``Here is your book, Lily,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``Would you care to go on with it for a few minutes?'' (unknown)

``No, thank you,'' (the girl)
said the girl.
``I will sit still.'' (unknown)

``But it is so dull.'' (William)

William scribbled irritably at a great rate. As he (William) sealed the envelope he (William) said:

``Read a book! Why, she (Lily)'s never read a book in her (Lily) life.'' (he)

``Oh, go along!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, cross with the exaggeration,

``It's true, mother--she (mother) hasn't,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
he (William) cried, jumping up and taking his (William) old position on the hearthrug.
``She (mother)'s never read a book in her (mother) life.'' (unknown)

''`Er's like me,'' (Morel)
chimed in Morel.
''`Er canna see what there is i' books, ter sit borin' your nose in 'em for, nor more can I.'' (Morel)

``But you shouldn't say these things,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel to her (Morel) son.

``But it's true, mother--she (mother) CAN

``T read. What did you give her (mother)?'' (unknown)

``Well, I gave her (mother) a little thing of Annie Swan's. Nobody wants to read dry stuff on Sunday afternoon.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'll bet she (Annie) didn't read ten lines of it.'' (unknown)

``You are mistaken,'' (mother)
said his (son) mother.

All the time Lily sat miserably on the sofa. He (son) turned to her (Lily) swiftly.

``DID you read any?'' (he)
he (son) asked.

``Yes, I did,'' (she)
she (Lily) replied.

``How much?'' (unknown)

``I don't know how many pages.'' (unknown)

``Tell me ONE THING you read.'' (She)

She (Lily) could not.

She (Lily) never got beyond the second page. He (son) read a great deal, and had a quick, active intelligence. She (Lily) could understand nothing but love-making and chatter. He (son) was accustomed to having all his (son) thoughts sifted through his (son) mother's mind; so, when he (son) wanted companionship, and was asked in reply to be the billing and twittering lover, he (lover) hated his (lover) betrothed.

``You know, mother,'' (he)
he (lover) said, when he (lover) was alone with her (mother) at night,
``she (mother)'s no idea of money, she (mother)'s so wessel-brained. When she (mother)'s paid, she (mother)'ll suddenly buy such rot as marrons glaces, and then I have to buy her (mother) season ticket, and her (mother) extras, even her (mother) underclothing. And she (mother) wants to get married, and I think myself we might as well get married next year. But at this rate--'' (he)

``A fine mess of a marriage it would be,'' (mother)
replied his (lover) mother.
``I should consider it again, my boy.'' (unknown)

``Oh, well, I've gone too far to break off now,'' (he)
he (lover) said,
``and so I shall get married as soon as I can.'' (he)

``Very well, my boy. If you will, you will, and there's no stopping you; but I tell you, I can't sleep when I think about it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, she (you)'ll be all right, mother. We shall manage.'' (unknown)

``And she (mother) lets you buy her (mother) underclothing?'' (the mother)
asked the mother.

``Well,'' (he)
he (lover) began apologetically, ``she (mother) didn't ask me; but one morning--and it WAS cold--I found her (mother) on the station shivering, not able to keep still; so I asked her (mother) if she (mother) was well wrapped up. She (mother) said: ``I think so.'' So I said: ``Have you got warm underthings on?'' And she (mother) said: ``No, they were cotton.
'' I asked her (mother) why on earth she (mother) hadn't got something thicker on in weather like that, and she (mother) said because she (mother) HAD nothing. And there she (mother) is--a bronchial subject! I HAD to take her (mother) and get some warm things. Well, mother, I shouldn't mind the money if we had any. And, you know, she (mother) OUGHT to keep enough to pay for her (mother) season-ticket; but no, she (mother) comes to me about that, and I have to find the money.'' (unknown)

``It's a poor lookout,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel bitterly.

He (mother) was pale, and his (mother) rugged face, that used to be so perfectly careless and laughing, was stamped with conflict and despair.

``But I can't give her (mother) up now; it's gone too far,'' (he)
he (mother) said.
``And, besides, for SOME things I couldn't do without her (mother).'' (unknown)

``My boy, remember you're taking your life in your hands,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``NOTHING is as bad as a marriage that's a hopeless failure. Mine was bad enough, God knows, and ought to teach you something; but it might have been worse by a long chalk.'' (He)

He (mother) leaned with his (mother) back against the side of the chimney-piece, his (mother) hands in his (mother) pockets. He (mother) was a big, raw-boned man, who looked as if he (mother) would go to the world's end if he (mother) wanted to. But she (Morel) saw the despair on his (mother) face.

``I couldn't give her (mother) up now,'' (he)
he (mother) said.

``Well,'' (she)
she (Morel) said,
``remember there are worse wrongs than breaking off an engagement.'' (she)

``I can't give her (mother) up NOW,'' (he)
he (mother) said.

The clock ticked on; mother and son remained in silence, a conflict between them; but he (mother) would say no more. At last she (mother) said:

``Well, go to bed, my son. You'll feel better in the morning, and perhaps you'll know better.'' (she)

He (mother) kissed her (mother), and went. She (mother) raked the fire. Her (mother) heart was heavy now as it had never been. Before, with her (mother) husband, things had seemed to be breaking down in her (mother), but they did not destroy her (mother) power to live. Now her (mother) soul felt lamed in itself. It was her (mother) hope that was struck.

And so often William manifested the same hatred towards his (William) betrothed. On the last evening at home he (William) was railing against her (mother).

``Well,'' (he)
he (William) said,
``if you don't believe me, what she (mother)'s like, would you believe she (mother) has been confirmed three times?'' (he)

``Nonsense!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
laughed Mrs. Morel.

``Nonsense or not, she (mother) HAS! That's what confirmation means for her (mother)--a bit of a theatrical show where she (mother) can cut a figure.'' (unknown)

``I haven't, Mrs. Morel!'' (the girl)
cried the girl--
``I haven't! it is not true!'' (the girl)

``What!'' (he)
he (William) cried, flashing round on her (Morel).
``Once in Bromley, once in Beckenham, and once somewhere else.'' (unknown)

``Nowhere else!'' (she)
she (Morel) said, in tears--
``nowhere else!'' (she)

``It WAS! And if it wasn't why were you confirmed TWICE?'' (unknown)

``Once I was only fourteen, Mrs. Morel,'' (she)
she (Morel) pleaded, tears in her (Morel) eyes.

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel;
``I can quite understand it, child. Take no notice of him (It). You ought to be ashamed, William, saying such things.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``But it's true. She (Morel)'s religious--she (Morel) had blue velvet Prayer-Books--and she (Morel)'s not as much religion, or anything else, in her (Morel) than that table-leg. Gets confirmed three times for show, to show herself off, and that's how she (Morel) is in EVERYTHING--EVERYTHING!'' (The girl)

The girl sat on the sofa, crying. She (Morel) was not strong.

``As for LOVE!'' (he)
he (William) cried,
``you might as well ask a fly to love you! It'll love settling on you--'' (he)

``Now, say no more,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
commanded Mrs. Morel.
``If you want to say these things, you must find another place than this. I am ashamed of you, William! Why don't you be more manly. To do nothing but find fault with a girl, and then pretend you're engaged to her (girl)!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel subsided in wrath and indignation.

William was silent, and later he (William) repented, kissed and comforted the girl. Yet it was true, what he (William) had said. He (William) hated her (girl).

When they were going away, Mrs. Morel accompanied them as far as Nottingham. It was a long way to Keston station.

``You know, mother,'' (he)
he (William) said to her (Morel),
``Gyp's shallow. Nothing goes deep with her (girl).'' (her)

``William, I WISH you wouldn't say these things,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, very uncomfortable for the girl who walked beside her (Morel).

``But it doesn't, mother. She (mother)'s very much in love with me now, but if I died she (mother)'d have forgotten me in three months.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel was afraid. Her (Morel) heart beat furiously, hearing the quiet bitterness of her (Morel) son's last speech.

``How do you know?'' (she)
she (Morel) replied. ``You DON
``T know, and therefore you've no right to say such a thing.'' (unknown)

``He (William)'s always saying these things!'' (the girl)
cried the girl.

``In three months after I was buried you'd have somebody else, and I should be forgotten,'' (he)
he (son) said.
``And that's your love!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel saw them into the train in Nottingham, then she (Morel) returned home.

``There's one comfort,'' (she)
she (Morel) said to Paul--
``he (William)'ll never have any money to marry on, that I AM sure of. And so she (mother)'ll save him (William) that way.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

So she (Morel) took cheer. Matters were not yet very desperate. She (Morel) firmly believed William would never marry his (William) Gipsy. She (Morel) waited, and she (Morel) kept Paul near to her (Morel).

All summer long William's letters had a feverish tone; he (William) seemed unnatural and intense. Sometimes he (William) was exaggeratedly jolly, usually he (William) was flat and bitter in his (William) letter.

``Ah,'' (mother)
his (William) mother said,
``I'm afraid he (William)'s ruining himself against that creature, who isn't worthy of his (William) love--no, no more than a rag doll.'' (mother)

He (William) wanted to come home. The midsummer holiday was gone; it was a long while to Christmas. He (William) wrote in wild excitement, saying he (William) could come for Saturday and Sunday at Goose Fair, the first week in October.

``You are not well, my boy,'' (mother)
said his (William) mother, when she (mother) saw him (William). She (mother) was almost in tears at having him (William) to herself again.

``No, I've not been well,'' (he)
he (William) said.
``I've seemed to have a dragging cold all the last month, but it's going, I think.'' (unknown)

It was sunny October weather. He (William) seemed wild with joy, like a schoolboy escaped; then again he (schoolboy) was silent and reserved. He (schoolboy) was more gaunt than ever, and there was a haggard look in his (schoolboy) eyes.

``You are doing too much,'' (mother)
said his (schoolboy) mother to him (schoolboy).

He (schoolboy) was doing extra work, trying to make some money to marry on, he (schoolboy) said. He (schoolboy) only talked to his (schoolboy) mother once on the Saturday night; then he (schoolboy) was sad and tender about his (schoolboy) beloved.

``And yet, you know, mother, for all that, if I died she (mother)'d be broken-hearted for two months, and then she (mother)'d start to forget me. You'd see, she (mother)'d never come home here to look at my grave, not even once.'' (unknown)

``Why, William,'' (mother)
said his (schoolboy) mother,
``you're not going to die, so why talk about it?'' (mother)

``But whether or not--'' (he)
he (schoolboy) replied.

``And she (mother) can't help it. She (mother) is like that, and if you choose her (mother)--well, you can't grumble,'' (mother)
said his (schoolboy) mother.

On the Sunday morning, as he (schoolboy) was putting his (schoolboy) collar on:

``Look,'' (he)
he (schoolboy) said to his (schoolboy) mother, holding up his (schoolboy) chin,
``what a rash my collar's made under my chin!'' (mother)

Just at the junction of chin and throat was a big red inflammation.

``It ought not to do that,'' (mother)
said his (schoolboy) mother.
``Here, put a bit of this soothing ointment on. You should wear different collars.'' (He)

He (schoolboy) went away on Sunday midnight, seeming better and more solid for his (schoolboy) two days at home.

On Tuesday morning came a telegram from London that he (schoolboy) was ill. Mrs. Morel got off her (Morel) knees from washing the floor, read the telegram, called a neighbour, went to her (Morel) landlady and borrowed a sovereign, put on her (Morel) things, and set off. She (Morel) hurried to Keston, caught an express for London in Nottingham. She (Morel) had to wait in Nottingham nearly an hour. A small figure in her (Morel) black bonnet, she (Morel) was anxiously asking the porters if they knew how to get to Elmers End. The journey was three hours. She (Morel) sat in her (Morel) corner in a kind of stupor, never moving. At King's Cross still no one could tell her (Morel) how to get to Elmers End. Carrying her (Morel) string bag, that contained her (Morel) nightdress, a comb and brush, she (Morel) went from person to person. At last they sent her (Morel) underground to Cannon Street.

It was six o'clock when she (Morel) arrived at William's lodging. The blinds were not down.

``How is he (William)?'' (she)
she (Morel) asked.

``No better,'' (the landlady)
said the landlady.

She (Morel) followed the woman upstairs. William lay on the bed, with bloodshot eyes, his (William) face rather discoloured. The clothes were tossed about, there was no fire in the room, a glass of milk stood on the stand at his (William) bedside. No one had been with him (William).

``Why, my son!'' (the mother)
said the mother bravely.

He (William) did not answer. He (William) looked at her (mother), but did not see her (mother). Then he (William) began to say, in a dull voice, as if repeating a letter from dictation:

``Owing to a leakage in the hold of this vessel, the sugar had set, and become converted into rock. It needed hacking--'' (he)

He (William) was quite unconscious. It had been his (William) business to examine some such cargo of sugar in the Port of London.

``How long has he (son) been like this?'' (the mother)
the mother asked the landlady.

``He (son) got home at six o'clock on Monday morning, and he (son) seemed to sleep all day; then in the night we heard him (son) talking, and this morning he (son) asked for you. So I wired, and we fetched the doctor.'' (unknown)

``Will you have a fire made?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel tried to soothe her (Morel) son, to keep him (son) still.

The doctor came. It was pneumonia, and, he (doctor) said, a peculiar erysipelas, which had started under the chin where the collar chafed, and was spreading over the face. He (doctor) hoped it would not get to the brain.

Mrs. Morel settled down to nurse. She (Morel) prayed for William, prayed that he (William) would recognise her (Morel). But the young man's face grew more discoloured. In the night she (Morel) struggled with him (William). He (William) raved, and raved, and would not come to consciousness. At two o'clock, in a dreadful paroxysm, he (William) died.

Mrs. Morel sat perfectly still for an hour in the lodging bedroom; then she (Morel) roused the household.

At six o'clock, with the aid of the charwoman, she (Morel) laid him (William) out; then she (Morel) went round the dreary London village to the registrar and the doctor.

At nine o'clock to the cottage on Scargill Street came another wire:

``William died last night. Let father come, bring money.'' (Scargill Street)

Annie, Paul, and Arthur were at home; Mr. Morel was gone to work. The three children said not a word. Annie began to whimper with fear; Paul set off for his (Paul) father.

It was a beautiful day. At Brinsley pit the white steam melted slowly in the sunshine of a soft blue sky; the wheels of the headstocks twinkled high up; the screen, shuffling its coal into the trucks, made a busy noise.

``I want my father; he (father)'s got to go to London,'' (the boy)
said the boy to the first man he (boy) met on the bank.

``Tha wants Walter Morel? Go in theer an' tell Joe Ward.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul went into the little top office.

``I want my father; he (father)'s got to go to London.'' (unknown)

``Thy feyther? Is he (father) down? What's his (father) name?'' (unknown)

``Mr. Morel.'' (unknown)

``What, Walter? Is owt amiss?'' (unknown)

``He (Walter)'s got to go to London.'' (The man)

The man went to the telephone and rang up the bottom office.

``Walter Morel's wanted, number 42, Hard. Summat's amiss; there's his (Morel) lad here.'' (he)

Then he (man) turned round to Paul.

``He (Morel)'ll be up in a few minutes,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Paul wandered out to the pit-top. He (Paul) watched the chair come up, with its wagon of coal. The great iron cage sank back on its rest, a full carfle was hauled off, an empty tram run on to the chair, a bell ting`ed somewhere, the chair heaved, then dropped like a stone.

Paul did not realise William was dead; it was impossible, with such a bustle going on. The puller-off swung the small truck on to the turn-table, another man ran with it along the bank down the curving lines.

``And William is dead, and my mother's in London, and what will she (mother) be doing?'' (the boy)
the boy asked himself, as if it were a conundrum.

He (boy) watched chair after chair come up, and still no father. At last, standing beside a wagon, a man's form! the chair sank on its rests, Morel stepped off. He (man) was slightly lame from an accident.

``Is it thee, Paul? Is 'e worse?'' (unknown)

``You've got to go to London.'' (men)

The two walked off the pit-bank, where men were watching curiously. As they came out and went along the railway, with the sunny autumn field on one side and a wall of trucks on the other, Morel said in a frightened voice:

''`E's niver gone, child?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``When wor`t?'' (unknown)

``Last night. We had a telegram from my mother.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel walked on a few strides, then leaned up against a truck-side, his (man) hand over his (man) eyes. He (man) was not crying. Paul stood looking round, waiting. On the weighing machine a truck trundled slowly. Paul saw everything, except his (Paul) father leaning against the truck as if he (Paul) were tired.

Morel had only once before been to London. He (Paul) set off, scared and peaked, to help his (Paul) wife. That was on Tuesday. The children were left alone in the house. Paul went to work, Arthur went to school, and Annie had in a friend to be with her (Annie).

On Saturday night, as Paul was turning the corner, coming home from Keston, he (Paul) saw his (Paul) mother and father, who had come to Sethley Bridge Station. They were walking in silence in the dark, tired, straggling apart. The boy waited.

``Mother!'' (he)
he (boy) said, in the darkness.

Mrs. Morel's small figure seemed not to observe. He (boy) spoke again.

``Paul!'' (she)
she (Morel) said, uninterestedly.

She (Morel) let him (boy) kiss her (Morel), but she (Morel) seemed unaware of him (boy).

In the house she (Morel) was the same--small, white, and mute. She (Morel) noticed nothing, she (Morel) said nothing, only:

``The coffin will be here to-night, Walter. You'd better see about some help.'' (she)
Then, turning to the children:
``We're bringing him (Walter) home.'' (the children)

Then she (Morel) relapsed into the same mute looking into space, her (Morel) hands folded on her (Morel) lap. Paul, looking at her (Morel), felt he (Paul) could not breathe. The house was dead silent.

``I went to work, mother,'' (he)
he (Paul) said plaintively.

``Did you?'' (she)
she (Morel) answered, dully.

After half an hour Morel, troubled and bewildered, came in again.

``Wheer s'll we ha'e him (Walter) when he (Walter) DOES come?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked his (Paul) wife.

``In the front-room.'' (unknown)

``Then I'd better shift th' table?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``An' ha'e him (Walter) across th' chairs?'' (unknown)

``You know there--Yes, I suppose so.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel and Paul went, with a candle, into the parlour. There was no gas there. The father unscrewed the top of the big mahogany oval table, and cleared the middle of the room; then he (father) arranged six chairs opposite each other, so that the coffin could stand on their beds.

``You niver seed such a length as he (Walter) is!'' (the miner)
said the miner, and watching anxiously as he (father) worked.

Paul went to the bay window and looked out. The ash-tree stood monstrous and black in front of the wide darkness. It was a faintly luminous night. Paul went back to his (Paul) mother.

At ten o'clock Morel called:

``He (Walter)'s here!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Everyone started. There was a noise of unbarring and unlocking the front door, which opened straight from the night into the room.

``Bring another candle,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
called Morel.

Annie and Arthur went. Paul followed with his (Paul) mother. He (Paul) stood with his (Paul) arm round her (mother) waist in the inner doorway. Down the middle of the cleared room waited six chairs, face to face. In the window, against the lace curtains, Arthur held up one candle, and by the open door, against the night, Annie stood leaning forward, her (Annie) brass candlestick glittering.

There was the noise of wheels. Outside in the darkness of the street below Paul could see horses and a black vehicle, one lamp, and a few pale faces; then some men, miners, all in their shirt-sleeves, seemed to struggle in the obscurity. Presently two men appeared, bowed beneath a great weight. It was Morel and his (Paul) neighbour.

``Steady!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
called Morel, out of breath.

He (Paul) and his (Paul) fellow mounted the steep garden step, heaved into the candlelight with their gleaming coffin-end. Limbs of other men were seen struggling behind. Morel and Burns, in front, staggered; the great dark weight swayed.

``Steady, steady!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Morel, as if in pain.

All the six bearers were up in the small garden, holding the great coffin aloft. There were three more steps to the door. The yellow lamp of the carriage shone alone down the black road.

``Now then!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.

The coffin swayed, the men began to mount the three steps with their load. Annie's candle flickered, and she (Annie) whimpered as the first men appeared, and the limbs and bowed heads of six men struggled to climb into the room, bearing the coffin that rode like sorrow on their living flesh.

``Oh, my son--my son!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel sang softly, and each time the coffin swung to the unequal climbing of the men:
``Oh, my son--my son--my son!'' (the men)

``Mother!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul whimpered, his (Paul) hand round her (Morel) waist.

She (Morel) did not hear.

``Oh, my son--my son!'' (she)
she (Morel) repeated.

Paul saw drops of sweat fall from his (Paul) father's brow. Six men were in the room--six coatless men, with yielding, struggling limbs, filling the room and knocking against the furniture. The coffin veered, and was gently lowered on to the chairs. The sweat fell from Morel's face on its boards.

``My word, he (son)'s a weight!'' (a man miners)
said a man, and the five miners sighed, bowed, and, trembling with the struggle, descended the steps again, closing the door behind them.

The family was alone in the parlour with the great polished box. William, when laid out, was six feet four inches long. Like a monument lay the bright brown, ponderous coffin. Paul thought it would never be got out of the room again. His (Paul) mother was stroking the polished wood.

They buried him (Paul) on the Monday in the little cemetery on the hillside that looks over the fields at the big church and the houses. It was sunny, and the white chrysanthemums frilled themselves in the warmth.

Mrs. Morel could not be persuaded, after this, to talk and take her (Morel) old bright interest in life. She (Morel) remained shut off. All the way home in the train she (Morel) had said to herself:

``If only it could have been me!'' (she)

When Paul came home at night he (Paul) found his (Paul) mother sitting, her (mother) day's work done, with hands folded in her (mother) lap upon her (mother) coarse apron. She (mother) always used to have changed her (mother) dress and put on a black apron, before. Now Annie set his (Paul) supper, and his (Paul) mother sat looking blankly in front of her (mother), her (mother) mouth shut tight. Then he (Paul) beat his (Paul) brains for news to tell her (mother).

``Mother, Miss Jordan was down to-day, and she (Mother) said my sketch of a colliery at work was beautiful.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

But Mrs. Morel took no notice. Night after night he (Paul) forced himself to tell her (Morel) things, although she (Morel) did not listen. It drove him (Paul) almost insane to have her (Morel) thus. At last:

``What's a-matter, mother?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

She (Morel) did not hear.

``What's a-matter?'' (he)
he (Paul) persisted.
``Mother, what's a-matter?'' (unknown)

``You know what's the matter,'' (she)
she (Morel) said irritably, turning away.

The lad--he (lad) was sixteen years old--went to bed drearily. He (lad) was cut off and wretched through October, November and December. His (lad) mother tried, but she (mother) could not rouse herself. She (mother) could only brood on her (mother) dead son; he (son) had been let to die so cruelly.

At last, on December 23, with his (son) five shillings Christmas-box in his (son) pocket, Paul wandered blindly home. His (Paul) mother looked at him (Paul), and her (mother) heart stood still.

``What's the matter?'' (she)
she (mother) asked.

``I'm badly, mother!'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.
``Mr. Jordan gave me five shillings for a Christmas-box!'' (He)

He (Paul) handed it to her (mother) with trembling hands. She (mother) put it on the table.

``You aren't glad!'' (he)
he (Paul) reproached her (mother); but he (Paul) trembled violently.

``Where hurts you?'' (she)
she (mother) said, unbuttoning his (Paul) overcoat.

It was the old question.

``I feel badly, mother.'' (She)

She (mother) undressed him (Paul) and put him (Paul) to bed. He (Paul) had pneumonia dangerously, the doctor said.

``Might he (Jordan) never have had it if I'd kept him (Jordan) at home, not let him (Jordan) go to Nottingham?'' (she)
was one of the first things she (mother) asked.

``He (Jordan) might not have been so bad,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

Mrs. Morel stood condemned on her (Morel) own ground.

``I should have watched the living, not the dead,'' (she)
she (Morel) told herself.

Paul was very ill. His (Paul) mother lay in bed at nights with him (Paul); they could not afford a nurse. He (Paul) grew worse, and the crisis approached. One night he (Paul) tossed into consciousness in the ghastly, sickly feeling of dissolution, when all the cells in the body seem in intense irritability to be breaking down, and consciousness makes a last flare of struggle, like madness.

``I s'll die, mother!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried, heaving for breath on the pillow.

She (mother) lifted him (Paul) up, crying in a small voice:

``Oh, my son--my son!'' (him)

That brought him (Paul) to. He (Paul) realised her (mother). His (Paul) whole will rose up and arrested him (Paul). He (Paul) put his (Paul) head on her (mother) breast, and took ease of her (mother) for love.

``For some things,'' (aunt thing)
said his (Paul) aunt,
``it was a good thing Paul was ill that Christmas. I believe it saved his (Paul) mother.'' (aunt thing)

Paul was in bed for seven weeks. He (Paul) got up white and fragile. His (Paul) father had bought him (Paul) a pot of scarlet and gold tulips. They used to flame in the window in the March sunshine as he (Paul) sat on the sofa chattering to his (Paul) mother. The two knitted together in perfect intimacy. Mrs. Morel's life now rooted itself in Paul.

William had been a prophet. Mrs. Morel had a little present and a letter from Lily at Christmas. Mrs. Morel's sister had a letter at the New Year.

``I was at a ball last night. Some delightful people were there, and I enjoyed myself thoroughly,'' (unknown)
said the letter.
``I had every dance--did not sit out one.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel never heard any more of her (Morel).

Morel and his (William) wife were gentle with each other for some time after the death of their son. He (son) would go into a kind of daze, staring wide-eyed and blank across the room. Then he (son) got up suddenly and hurried out to the Three Spots, returning in his (son) normal state. But never in his (son) life would he (son) go for a walk up Shepstone, past the office where his (son) son had worked, and he (son) always avoided the cemetery.

PART TWO

CHAPTER VII

LAD-AND-GIRL LOVE

PAUL had been many times up to Willey Farm during the autumn. He (Willey) was friends with the two youngest boys. Edgar the eldest, would not condescend at first. And Miriam also refused to be approached. She (Miriam) was afraid of being set at nought, as by her (Miriam) own brothers. The girl was romantic in her (girl) soul. Everywhere was a Walter Scott heroine being loved by men with helmets or with plumes in their caps. She (heroine) herself was something of a princess turned into a swine-girl in her (heroine) own imagination. And she (heroine) was afraid lest this boy, who, nevertheless, looked something like a Walter Scott hero, who could paint and speak French, and knew what algebra meant, and who went by train to Nottingham every day, might consider her (heroine) simply as the swine-girl, unable to perceive the princess beneath; so she (heroine) held aloof.

Her (heroine) great companion was her (heroine) mother. They were both brown-eyed, and inclined to be mystical, such women as treasure religion inside them, breathe it in their nostrils, and see the whole of life in a mist thereof. So to Miriam, Christ and God made one great figure, which she (Miriam) loved tremblingly and passionately when a tremendous sunset burned out the western sky, and Ediths, and Lucys, and Rowenas, Brian de Bois Guilberts, Rob Roys, and Guy Mannerings, rustled the sunny leaves in the morning, or sat in her (Miriam) bedroom aloft, alone, when it snowed. That was life to her (Miriam). For the rest, she (Miriam) drudged in the house, which work she (Miriam) would not have minded had not her (Miriam) clean red floor been mucked up immediately by the trampling farm-boots of her (Miriam) brothers. She (Miriam) madly wanted her (Miriam) little brother of four to let her (Miriam) swathe him (brother) and stifle him (brother) in her (Miriam) love; she (Miriam) went to church reverently, with bowed head, and quivered in anguish from the vulgarity of the other choir-girls and from the common-sounding voice of the curate; she (Miriam) fought with her (Miriam) brothers, whom she (Miriam) considered brutal louts; and she (Miriam) held not her (Miriam) father in too high esteem because he (father) did not carry any mystical ideals cherished in his (father) heart, but only wanted to have as easy a time as he (father) could, and his (father) meals when he (father) was ready for them.

She (Miriam) hated her (Miriam) position as swine-girl. She (Miriam) wanted to be considered. She (Miriam) wanted to learn, thinking that if she (Miriam) could read, as Paul said he (Paul) could read,

``Colomba'' (he)
, or the
``Voyage autour de ma Chambre'' (he)
, the world would have a different face for her (Miriam) and a deepened respect. She (Miriam) could not be princess by wealth or standing. So she (princess) was mad to have learning whereon to pride herself. For she (princess) was different from other folk, and must not be scooped up among the common fry. Learning was the only distinction to which she (princess) thought to aspire.

Her (princess) beauty--that of a shy, wild, quiveringly sensitive thing--seemed nothing to her (princess). Even her (princess) soul, so strong for rhapsody, was not enough. She (princess) must have something to reinforce her (princess) pride, because she (princess) felt different from other people. Paul she (princess) eyed rather wistfully. On the whole, she (princess) scorned the male sex. But here was a new specimen, quick, light, graceful, who could be gentle and who could be sad, and who was clever, and who knew a lot, and who had a death in the family. The boy's poor morsel of learning exalted him (boy) almost sky-high in her (princess) esteem. Yet she (princess) tried hard to scorn him (boy), because he (boy) would not see in her (princess) the princess but only the swine-girl. And he (boy) scarcely observed her (princess).

Then he (boy) was so ill, and she (princess) felt he (boy) would be weak. Then she (princess) would be stronger than he (boy). Then she (princess) could love him (boy). If she (princess) could be mistress of him (boy) in his (boy) weakness, take care of him (boy), if he (boy) could depend on her (princess), if she (princess) could, as it were, have him (boy) in her (princess) arms, how she (princess) would love him (boy)!

As soon as the skies brightened and plum-blossom was out, Paul drove off in the milkman's heavy float up to Willey Farm. Mr. Leivers shouted in a kindly fashion at the boy, then clicked to the horse as they climbed the hill slowly, in the freshness of the morning. White clouds went on their way, crowding to the back of the hills that were rousing in the springtime. The water of Nethermere lay below, very blue against the seared meadows and the thorn-trees.

It was four and a half miles' drive. Tiny buds on the hedges, vivid as copper-green, were opening into rosettes; and thrushes called, and blackbirds shrieked and scolded. It was a new, glamorous world.

Miriam, peeping through the kitchen window, saw the horse walk through the big white gate into the farmyard that was backed by the oak-wood, still bare. Then a youth in a heavy overcoat climbed down. He (Miriam) put up his (Miriam) hands for the whip and the rug that the good-looking, ruddy farmer handed down to him (Miriam).

Miriam appeared in the doorway. She (Miriam) was nearly sixteen, very beautiful, with her (Miriam) warm colouring, her (Miriam) gravity, her (Miriam) eyes dilating suddenly like an ecstasy.

``I say,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, turning shyly aside,
``your daffodils are nearly out. Isn't it early? But don't they look cold?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``Cold!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam, in her (Miriam) musical, caressing voice.

``The green on their buds--'' (he)
and he (Paul) faltered into silence timidly.

``Let me take the rug,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam over-gently.

``I can carry it,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered, rather injured. But he (Paul) yielded it to her (Miriam).

Then Mrs. Leivers appeared.

``I'm sure you're tired and cold,'' (she)
she (Leivers) said.
``Let me take your coat. It IS heavy. You mustn't walk far in it.'' (She)

She (Leivers) helped him (Paul) off with his (Paul) coat. He (Paul) was quite unused to such attention. She (Leivers) was almost smothered under its weight.

``Why, mother,'' (the farmer)
laughed the farmer as he (farmer) passed through the kitchen, swinging the great milk-churns,
``you've got almost more than you can manage there.'' (he)

She (Leivers) beat up the sofa cushions for the youth.

The kitchen was very small and irregular. The farm had been originally a labourer's cottage. And the furniture was old and battered. But Paul loved it--loved the sack-bag that formed the hearthrug, and the funny little corner under the stairs, and the small window deep in the corner, through which, bending a little, he (Paul) could see the plum trees in the back garden and the lovely round hills beyond.

``Won't you lie down?'' (Mrs. Leivers)
said Mrs. Leivers.

``Oh no; I'm not tired,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``Isn't it lovely coming out, don't you think? I saw a sloe-bush in blossom and a lot of celandines. I'm glad it's sunny.'' (unknown)

``Can I give you anything to eat or to drink?'' (unknown)

``No, thank you.'' (unknown)

``How's your mother?'' (unknown)

``I think she (mother)'s tired now. I think she (mother)'s had too much to do. Perhaps in a little while she (mother)'ll go to Skegness with me. Then she (mother)'ll be able to rest. I s'll be glad if she (mother) can.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Leivers)
replied Mrs. Leivers.
``It's a wonder she (mother) isn't ill herself.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam was moving about preparing dinner. Paul watched everything that happened. His (Paul) face was pale and thin, but his (Paul) eyes were quick and bright with life as ever. He (Paul) watched the strange, almost rhapsodic way in which the girl moved about, carrying a great stew-jar to the oven, or looking in the saucepan. The atmosphere was different from that of his (Paul) own home, where everything seemed so ordinary. When Mr. Leivers called loudly outside to the horse, that was reaching over to feed on the rose-bushes in the garden, the girl started, looked round with dark eyes, as if something had come breaking in on her (girl) world. There was a sense of silence inside the house and out. Miriam seemed as in some dreamy tale, a maiden in bondage, her (Miriam) spirit dreaming in a land far away and magical. And her (Miriam) discoloured, old blue frock and her (Miriam) broken boots seemed only like the romantic rags of King Cophetua's beggar-maid.

She (Miriam) suddenly became aware of his (King) keen blue eyes upon her (Miriam), taking her (Miriam) all in. Instantly her (Miriam) broken boots and her (Miriam) frayed old frock hurt her (Miriam). She (Miriam) resented his (King) seeing everything. Even he (King) knew that her (Miriam) stocking was not pulled up. She (Miriam) went into the scullery, blushing deeply. And afterwards her (Miriam) hands trembled slightly at her (Miriam) work. She (Miriam) nearly dropped all she (Miriam) handled. When her (Miriam) inside dream was shaken, her (Miriam) body quivered with trepidation. She (Miriam) resented that he (King) saw so much.

Mrs. Leivers sat for some time talking to the boy, although she (Leivers) was needed at her (Leivers) work. She (Leivers) was too polite to leave him (boy). Presently she (Leivers) excused herself and rose. After a while she (Leivers) looked into the tin saucepan.

``Oh DEAR, Miriam,'' (she)
she (Leivers) cried,
``these potatoes have boiled dry!'' (she)

Miriam started as if she (Miriam) had been stung.

``HAVE they, mother?'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried.

``I shouldn't care, Miriam,'' (the mother)
said the mother,
``if I hadn't trusted them to you.'' (the mother)
She (mother) peered into the pan.

The girl stiffened as if from a blow. Her (girl) dark eyes dilated; she (girl) remained standing in the same spot.

``Well,'' (she)
she (girl) answered, gripped tight in self-conscious shame,
``I'm sure I looked at them five minutes since.'' (she)

``Yes,'' (the mother)
said the mother,
``I know it's easily done.'' (the mother)

``They're not much burned,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``It doesn't matter, does it?'' (Mrs. Leivers)

Mrs. Leivers looked at the youth with her (Leivers) brown, hurt eyes.

``It wouldn't matter but for the boys,'' (she)
she (Leivers) said to him (Paul).
``Only Miriam knows what a trouble they make if the potatoes are `caught'.'' (unknown)

``Then,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
thought Paul to himself,
``you shouldn't let them make a trouble.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

After a while Edgar came in. He (Edgar) wore leggings, and his (Edgar) boots were covered with earth. He (Edgar) was rather small, rather formal, for a farmer. He (Edgar) glanced at Paul, nodded to him (Paul) distantly, and said:

``Dinner ready?'' (him)

``Nearly, Edgar,'' (the mother)
replied the mother apologetically.

``I'm ready for mine,'' (the man)
said the young man, taking up the newspaper and reading. Presently the rest of the family trooped in. Dinner was served. The meal went rather brutally. The over-gentleness and apologetic tone of the mother brought out all the brutality of manners in the sons. Edgar tasted the potatoes, moved his (Edgar) mouth quickly like a rabbit, looked indignantly at his (Edgar) mother, and said:

``These potatoes are burnt, mother.'' (mother)

``Yes, Edgar. I forgot them for a minute. Perhaps you'll have bread if you can't eat them.'' (Edgar)

Edgar looked in anger across at Miriam.

``What was Miriam doing that she (Miriam) couldn't attend to them?'' (he)
he (Edgar) said.

Miriam looked up. Her (Miriam) mouth opened, her (Miriam) dark eyes blazed and winced, but she (Miriam) said nothing. She (Miriam) swallowed her (Miriam) anger and her (Miriam) shame, bowing her (Miriam) dark head.

``I'm sure she (Miriam) was trying hard,'' (the mother)
said the mother.

``She (Miriam) hasn't got sense even to boil the potatoes,'' (Edgar)
said Edgar.
``What is she (Miriam) kept at home for?'' (unknown)

``On'y for eating everything that's left in th' pantry,'' (Maurice)
said Maurice.

``They don't forget that potato-pie against our Miriam,'' (the father)
laughed the father.

She (mother) was utterly humiliated. The mother sat in silence, suffering, like some saint out of place at the brutal board.

It puzzled Paul. He (Paul) wondered vaguely why all this intense feeling went running because of a few burnt potatoes. The mother exalted everything--even a bit of housework--to the plane of a religious trust. The sons resented this; they felt themselves cut away underneath, and they answered with brutality and also with a sneering superciliousness.

Paul was just opening out from childhood into manhood. This atmosphere, where everything took a religious value, came with a subtle fascination to him (Paul). There was something in the air. His (Paul) own mother was logical. Here there was something different, something he (Paul) loved, something that at times he (Paul) hated.

Miriam quarrelled with her (Miriam) brothers fiercely. Later in the afternoon, when they had gone away again, her (Miriam) mother said:

``You disappointed me at dinner-time, Miriam.'' (mother)

The girl dropped her (mother) head.

``They are such BRUTES!'' (she)
she (mother) suddenly cried, looking up with flashing eyes.

``But hadn't you promised not to answer them?'' (the mother)
said the mother. ``And I believed in you. I CAN
``T stand it when you wrangle.'' (unknown)

``But they're so hateful!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
cried Miriam,
``and--and LOW.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

``Yes, dear. But how often have I asked you not to answer Edgar back? Can't you let him (Edgar) say what he (Edgar) likes?'' (unknown)

``But why should he (Edgar) say what he (Edgar) likes?'' (unknown)

``Aren't you strong enough to bear it, Miriam, if even for my sake? Are you so weak that you must wrangle with them?'' (Mrs. Leivers)

Mrs. Leivers stuck unflinchingly to this doctrine of

``the other cheek'' (Mrs. Leivers)
. She (Leivers) could not instil it at all into the boys. With the girls she (Leivers) succeeded better, and Miriam was the child of her (Miriam) heart. The boys loathed the other cheek when it was presented to them. Miriam was often sufficiently lofty to turn it. Then they spat on her (Miriam) and hated her (Miriam). But she (Miriam) walked in her (Miriam) proud humility, living within herself.

There was always this feeling of jangle and discord in the Leivers family. Although the boys resented so bitterly this eternal appeal to their deeper feelings of resignation and proud humility, yet it had its effect on them. They could not establish between themselves and an outsider just the ordinary human feeling and unexaggerated friendship; they were always restless for the something deeper. Ordinary folk seemed shallow to them, trivial and inconsiderable. And so they were unaccustomed, painfully uncouth in the simplest social intercourse, suffering, and yet insolent in their superiority. Then beneath was the yearning for the soul-intimacy to which they could not attain because they were too dumb, and every approach to close connection was blocked by their clumsy contempt of other people. They wanted genuine intimacy, but they could not get even normally near to anyone, because they scorned to take the first steps, they scorned the triviality which forms common human intercourse.

Paul fell under Mrs. Leivers's spell. Everything had a religious and intensified meaning when he (Paul) was with her (Leivers). His (Paul) soul, hurt, highly developed, sought her (Leivers) as if for nourishment. Together they seemed to sift the vital fact from an experience.

Miriam was her (Miriam) mother's daughter. In the sunshine of the afternoon mother and daughter went down the fields with him (Paul). They looked for nests. There was a jenny wren's in the hedge by the orchard.

``I DO want you to see this,'' (Mrs. Leivers)
said Mrs. Leivers.

He (wren) crouched down and carefully put his (wren) finger through the thorns into the round door of the nest.

``It's almost as if you were feeling inside the live body of the bird,'' (he)
he (wren) said,
``it's so warm. They say a bird makes its nest round like a cup with pressing its breast on it. Then how did it make the ceiling round, I wonder?'' (he)

The nest seemed to start into life for the two women. After that, Miriam came to see it every day. It seemed so close to her (Miriam). Again, going down the hedgeside with the girl, he (wren) noticed the celandines, scalloped splashes of gold, on the side of the ditch.

``I like them,'' (he)
he (wren) said,
``when their petals go flat back with the sunshine. They seemed to be pressing themselves at the sun.'' (he)

And then the celandines ever after drew her (girl) with a little spell. Anthropomorphic as she (girl) was, she (girl) stimulated him (wren) into appreciating things thus, and then they lived for her (girl). She (girl) seemed to need things kindling in her (girl) imagination or in her (girl) soul before she (girl) felt she (girl) had them. And she (girl) was cut off from ordinary life by her (girl) religious intensity which made the world for her (girl) either a nunnery garden or a paradise, where sin and knowledge were not, or else an ugly, cruel thing.

So it was in this atmosphere of subtle intimacy, this meeting in their common feeling for something in Nature, that their love started.

Personally, he (wren) was a long time before he (wren) realized her (girl). For ten months he (wren) had to stay at home after his (wren) illness. For a while he (wren) went to Skegness with his (wren) mother, and was perfectly happy. But even from the seaside he (wren) wrote long letters to Mrs. Leivers about the shore and the sea. And he (wren) brought back his (wren) beloved sketches of the flat Lincoln coast, anxious for them to see. Almost they would interest the Leivers more than they interested his (wren) mother. It was not his (wren) art Mrs. Morel cared about; it was himself and his (wren) achievement. But Mrs. Leivers and her (Leivers) children were almost his (wren) disciples. They kindled him (wren) and made him (wren) glow to his (wren) work, whereas his (wren) mother's influence was to make him (wren) quietly determined, patient, dogged, unwearied.

He (wren) soon was friends with the boys, whose rudeness was only superficial. They had all, when they could trust themselves, a strange gentleness and lovableness.

``Will you come with me on to the fallow?'' (Edgar)
asked Edgar, rather hesitatingly.

Paul went joyfully, and spent the afternoon helping to hoe or to single turnips with his (Paul) friend. He (Paul) used to lie with the three brothers in the hay piled up in the barn and tell them about Nottingham and about Jordan's. In return, they taught him (Paul) to milk, and let him (Paul) do little jobs--chopping hay or pulping turnips--just as much as he (Paul) liked. At midsummer he (Paul) worked all through hay-harvest with them, and then he (Paul) loved them. The family was so cut off from the world actually. They seemed, somehow, like

''_les derniers fils d'une race epuisee_'' (unknown)
. Though the lads were strong and healthy, yet they had all that over-sensitiveness and hanging-back which made them so lonely, yet also such close, delicate friends once their intimacy was won. Paul loved them dearly, and they him (Paul).

Miriam came later. But he (Paul) had come into her (Miriam) life before she (Miriam) made any mark on his (Paul). One dull afternoon, when the men were on the land and the rest at school, only Miriam and her (Miriam) mother at home, the girl said to him (Paul), after having hesitated for some time:

``Have you seen the swing?'' (him)

``No,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.
``Where?'' (unknown)

``In the cowshed,'' (she)
she (Miriam) replied.

She (Miriam) always hesitated to offer or to show him (Paul) anything. Men have such different standards of worth from women, and her (Miriam) dear things--the valuable things to her (Miriam)--her (Miriam) brothers had so often mocked or flouted.

``Come on, then,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied, jumping up.

There were two cowsheds, one on either side of the barn. In the lower, darker shed there was standing for four cows. Hens flew scolding over the manger-wall as the youth and girl went forward for the great thick rope which hung from the beam in the darkness overhead, and was pushed back over a peg in the wall.

``It's something like a rope!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed appreciatively; and he (Paul) sat down on it, anxious to try it. Then immediately he (Paul) rose.

``Come on, then, and have first go,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to the girl.

``See,'' (she)
she (girl) answered, going into the barn,
``we put some bags on the seat'' (she)
; and she (girl) made the swing comfortable for him (Paul). That gave her (girl) pleasure. He (Paul) held the rope.

``Come on, then,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to her (girl).

``No, I won't go first,'' (she)
she (girl) answered.

She (girl) stood aside in her (girl) still, aloof fashion.

``Why?'' (unknown)

``You go,'' (she)
she (girl) pleaded.

Almost for the first time in her (girl) life she (girl) had the pleasure of giving up to a man, of spoiling him (man). Paul looked at her (girl).

``All right,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, sitting down.
``Mind out!'' (He)

He (Paul) set off with a spring, and in a moment was flying through the air, almost out of the door of the shed, the upper half of which was open, showing outside the drizzling rain, the filthy yard, the cattle standing disconsolate against the black cartshed, and at the back of all the grey-green wall of the wood. She (girl) stood below in her (girl) crimson tam-o'-shanter and watched. He (Paul) looked down at her (girl), and she (girl) saw his (Paul) blue eyes sparkling.

``It's a treat of a swing,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Yes.'' (He)

He (Paul) was swinging through the air, every bit of him (Paul) swinging, like a bird that swoops for joy of movement. And he (Paul) looked down at her (girl). Her (girl) crimson cap hung over her (girl) dark curls, her (girl) beautiful warm face, so still in a kind of brooding, was lifted towards him (Paul). It was dark and rather cold in the shed. Suddenly a swallow came down from the high roof and darted out of the door.

``I didn't know a bird was watching,'' (he)
he (Paul) called.

He (Paul) swung negligently. She (girl) could feel him (Paul) falling and lifting through the air, as if he (Paul) were lying on some force.

``Now I'll die,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, in a detached, dreamy voice, as though he (Paul) were the dying motion of the swing. She (girl) watched him (Paul), fascinated. Suddenly he (Paul) put on the brake and jumped out.

``I've had a long turn,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``But it's a treat of a swing--it's a real treat of a swing!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam was amused that he (Paul) took a swing so seriously and felt so warmly over it.

``No; you go on,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``Why, don't you want one?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked, astonished.

``Well, not much. I'll have just a little.'' (She)

She (Miriam) sat down, whilst he (Paul) kept the bags in place for her (Miriam).

``It's so ripping!'' (he)
he (Paul) said, setting her (Miriam) in motion.
``Keep your heels up, or they'll bang the manger wall.'' (She)

She (Miriam) felt the accuracy with which he (Paul) caught her (Miriam), exactly at the right moment, and the exactly proportionate strength of his (Paul) thrust, and she (Miriam) was afraid. Down to her (Miriam) bowels went the hot wave of fear. She (Miriam) was in his (Paul) hands. Again, firm and inevitable came the thrust at the right moment. She (Miriam) gripped the rope, almost swooning.

``Ha!'' (she)
she (Miriam) laughed in fear.
``No higher!'' (unknown)

``But you're not a BIT high,'' (he)
he (Paul) remonstrated.

``But no higher.'' (He)

He (Paul) heard the fear in her (Miriam) voice, and desisted. Her (Miriam) heart melted in hot pain when the moment came for him (Paul) to thrust her (Miriam) forward again. But he (Paul) left her (Miriam) alone. She (Miriam) began to breathe.

``Won't you really go any farther?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.
``Should I keep you there?'' (unknown)

``No; let me go by myself,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered.

He (Paul) moved aside and watched her (Miriam).

``Why, you're scarcely moving,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (Miriam) laughed slightly with shame, and in a moment got down.

``They say if you can swing you won't be sea-sick,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, as he (Paul) mounted again.
``I don't believe I should ever be sea-sick.'' (he)

Away he (Paul) went. There was something fascinating to her (Miriam) in him (Paul). For the moment he (Paul) was nothing but a piece of swinging stuff; not a particle of him (Paul) that did not swing. She (Miriam) could never lose herself so, nor could her (Miriam) brothers. It roused a warmth in her (Miriam). It was almost as if he (Paul) were a flame that had lit a warmth in her (Miriam) whilst he (Paul) swung in the middle air.

And gradually the intimacy with the family concentrated for Paul on three persons--the mother, Edgar, and Miriam. To the mother he (Edgar) went for that sympathy and that appeal which seemed to draw him (Edgar) out. Edgar was his (Edgar) very close friend. And to Miriam he (Edgar) more or less condescended, because she (Miriam) seemed so humble.

But the girl gradually sought him (Edgar) out. If he (Edgar) brought up his (Edgar) sketch-book, it was she (girl) who pondered longest over the last picture. Then she (girl) would look up at him (Edgar). Suddenly, her (girl) dark eyes alight like water that shakes with a stream of gold in the dark, she (girl) would ask:

``Why do I like this so?'' (she)

Always something in his (Edgar) breast shrank from these close, intimate, dazzled looks of hers.

``Why DO you?'' (he)
he (Edgar) asked.

``I don't know. It seems so true.'' (unknown)

``It's because--it's because there is scarcely any shadow in it; it's more shimmery, as if I'd painted the shimmering protoplasm in the leaves and everywhere, and not the stiffness of the shape. That seems dead to me. Only this shimmeriness is the real living. The shape is a dead crust. The shimmer is inside really.'' (she)

And she (girl), with her (girl) little finger in her (girl) mouth, would ponder these sayings. They gave her (girl) a feeling of life again, and vivified things which had meant nothing to her (girl). She (girl) managed to find some meaning in his (Edgar) struggling, abstract speeches. And they were the medium through which she (girl) came distinctly at her (girl) beloved objects.

Another day she (girl) sat at sunset whilst he (Edgar) was painting some pine-trees which caught the red glare from the west. He (Edgar) had been quiet.

``There you are!'' (he)
he (Edgar) said suddenly.
``I wanted that. Now, look at them and tell me, are they pine trunks or are they red coals, standing-up pieces of fire in that darkness? There's God's burning bush for you, that burned not away.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam looked, and was frightened. But the pine trunks were wonderful to her (Miriam), and distinct. He (Edgar) packed his (Edgar) box and rose. Suddenly he (Edgar) looked at her (Miriam).

``Why are you always sad?'' (he)
he (Edgar) asked her (Miriam).

``Sad!'' (she)
she (Miriam) exclaimed, looking up at him (Edgar) with startled, wonderful brown eyes.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Edgar) replied.
``You are always sad.'' (unknown)

``I am not--oh, not a bit!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried.

``But even your joy is like a flame coming off of sadness,'' (he)
he (Edgar) persisted.
``You're never jolly, or even just all right.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) pondered.
``I wonder--why?'' (unknown)

``Because you're not; because you're different inside, like a pine-tree, and then you flare up; but you're not just like an ordinary tree, with fidgety leaves and jolly--'' (He)

He (Edgar) got tangled up in his (Edgar) own speech; but she (Miriam) brooded on it, and he (Edgar) had a strange, roused sensation, as if his (Edgar) feelings were new. She (Miriam) got so near him (Edgar). It was a strange stimulant.

Then sometimes he (Edgar) hated her (Miriam). Her (Miriam) youngest brother was only five. He (Edgar) was a frail lad, with immense brown eyes in his (Edgar) quaint fragile face--one of Reynolds's

``Choir of Angels'' (Reynolds)
, with a touch of elf. Often Miriam kneeled to the child and drew him (Edgar) to her (Miriam).

``Eh, my Hubert!'' (she)
she (Miriam) sang, in a voice heavy and surcharged with love.
``Eh, my Hubert!'' (him)

And, folding him (Edgar) in her (Miriam) arms, she (Miriam) swayed slightly from side to side with love, her (Miriam) face half lifted, her (Miriam) eyes half closed, her (Miriam) voice drenched with love.

``Don't!'' (the child Miriam)
said the child, uneasy--
``don't, Miriam!'' (the child Miriam)

``Yes; you love me, don't you?'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured deep in her (Miriam) throat, almost as if she (Miriam) were in a trance, and swaying also as if she (Miriam) were swooned in an ecstasy of love.

``Don't!'' (the child)
repeated the child, a frown on his (Edgar) clear brow.

``You love me, don't you?'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured.

``What do you make such a FUSS for?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
cried Paul, all in suffering because of her (Miriam) extreme emotion.
``Why can't you be ordinary with him (Hubert)?'' (She)

She (Miriam) let the child go, and rose, and said nothing. Her (Miriam) intensity, which would leave no emotion on a normal plane, irritated the youth into a frenzy. And this fearful, naked contact of her (Miriam) on small occasions shocked him (Paul). He (Paul) was used to his (Paul) mother's reserve. And on such occasions he (Paul) was thankful in his (Paul) heart and soul that he (Paul) had his (Paul) mother, so sane and wholesome.

All the life of Miriam's body was in her (Miriam) eyes, which were usually dark as a dark church, but could flame with light like a conflagration. Her (Miriam) face scarcely ever altered from its look of brooding. She (Miriam) might have been one of the women who went with Mary when Jesus was dead. Her (Mary) body was not flexible and living. She (Mary) walked with a swing, rather heavily, her (Mary) head bowed forward, pondering. She (Mary) was not clumsy, and yet none of her (Mary) movements seemed quite THE movement. Often, when wiping the dishes, she (Mary) would stand in bewilderment and chagrin because she (Mary) had pulled in two halves a cup or a tumbler. It was as if, in her (Mary) fear and self-mistrust, she (Mary) put too much strength into the effort. There was no looseness or abandon about her (Mary). Everything was gripped stiff with intensity, and her (Mary) effort, overcharged, closed in on itself.

She (Mary) rarely varied from her (Mary) swinging, forward, intense walk. Occasionally she (Mary) ran with Paul down the fields. Then her (Mary) eyes blazed naked in a kind of ecstasy that frightened him (Paul). But she (Mary) was physically afraid. If she (Mary) were getting over a stile, she (Mary) gripped his (Paul) hands in a little hard anguish, and began to lose her (Mary) presence of mind. And he (Paul) could not persuade her (Mary) to jump from even a small height. Her (Mary) eyes dilated, became exposed and palpitating.

``No!'' (she)
she (Mary) cried, half laughing in terror--
``no!'' (she)

``You shall!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried once, and, jerking her (Mary) forward, he (Paul) brought her (Mary) falling from the fence. But her (Mary) wild
``Ah!'' (she)
of pain, as if she (Mary) were losing consciousness, cut him (Paul). She (Mary) landed on her (Mary) feet safely, and afterwards had courage in this respect.

She (Mary) was very much dissatisfied with her (Mary) lot.

``Don't you like being at home?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul asked her (Mary), surprised.

``Who would?'' (she)
she (Mary) answered, low and intense.
``What is it? I'm all day cleaning what the boys make just as bad in five minutes. I don't WANT to be at home.'' (unknown)

``What do you want, then?'' (unknown)

``I want to do something. I want a chance like anybody else. Why should I, because I'm a girl, be kept at home and not allowed to be anything? What chance HAVE I?'' (unknown)

``Chance of what?'' (unknown)

``Of knowing anything--of learning, of doing anything. It's not fair, because I'm a woman.'' (She)

She (Mary) seemed very bitter. Paul wondered. In his (Paul) own home Annie was almost glad to be a girl. She (girl) had not so much responsibility; things were lighter for her (girl). She (girl) never wanted to be other than a girl. But Miriam almost fiercely wished she (Miriam) were a man. And yet she (Miriam) hated men at the same time.

``But it's as well to be a woman as a man,'' (he)
he (man) said, frowning.

``Ha! Is it? Men have everything.'' (unknown)

``I should think women ought to be as glad to be women as men are to be men,'' (he)
he (man) answered.

``No!'' (she)
--she (Miriam) shook her (Miriam) head--
``no! Everything the men have.'' (she)

``But what do you want?'' (he)
he (man) asked.

``I want to learn. Why SHOULD it be that I know nothing?'' (unknown)

``What! such as mathematics and French?'' (unknown)

``Why SHOULDN

``T I know mathematics? Yes!'' (unknown)
she (Miriam) cried, her (Miriam) eye expanding in a kind of defiance.

``Well, you can learn as much as I know,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``I'll teach you, if you like.'' (unknown)

Her (Miriam) eyes dilated. She (Miriam) mistrusted him (man) as teacher.

``Would you?'' (he)
he (man) asked.

Her (Miriam) head had dropped, and she (Miriam) was sucking her (Miriam) finger broodingly.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said hesitatingly.

He (man) used to tell his (man) mother all these things.

``I'm going to teach Miriam algebra,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Well,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel,
``I hope she (Miriam)'ll get fat on it.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

When he (man) went up to the farm on the Monday evening, it was drawing twilight. Miriam was just sweeping up the kitchen, and was kneeling at the hearth when he (man) entered. Everyone was out but her (Miriam). She (Miriam) looked round at him (man), flushed, her (Miriam) dark eyes shining, her (Miriam) fine hair falling about her (Miriam) face.

``Hello!'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, soft and musical.
``I knew it was you.'' (unknown)

``How?'' (unknown)

``I knew your step. Nobody treads so quick and firm.'' (He)

He (man) sat down, sighing.

``Ready to do some algebra?'' (he)
he (man) asked, drawing a little book from his (man) pocket.

``But--'' (He)

He (man) could feel her (Miriam) backing away.

``You said you wanted,'' (he)
he (man) insisted.

``To-night, though?'' (she)
she (Miriam) faltered.

``But I came on purpose. And if you want to learn it, you must begin.'' (She)

She (Miriam) took up her (Miriam) ashes in the dustpan and looked at him (man), half tremulously, laughing.

``Yes, but to-night! You see, I haven't thought of it.'' (unknown)

``Well, my goodness! Take the ashes and come.'' (He)

He (man) went and sat on the stone bench in the back-yard, where the big milk-cans were standing, tipped up, to air. The men were in the cowsheds. He (man) could hear the little sing-song of the milk spurting into the pails. Presently she (Miriam) came, bringing some big greenish apples.

``You know you like them,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

He (man) took a bite.
