``Sit down,'' (he)
he (man) said, with his (man) mouth full.

She (Miriam) was short-sighted, and peered over his (man) shoulder. It irritated him (man). He (man) gave her (Miriam) the book quickly.

``Here,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``It's only letters for figures. You put down `a' instead of '2' or '6'.'' (he)

They worked, he (man) talking, she (Miriam) with her (Miriam) head down on the book. He (man) was quick and hasty. She (Miriam) never answered. Occasionally, when he (man) demanded of her (Miriam),

``Do you see?'' (her)
she (Miriam) looked up at him (man), her (Miriam) eyes wide with the half-laugh that comes of fear.
``Don't you?'' (he)
he (man) cried.

He (man) had been too fast. But she (Miriam) said nothing. He (man) questioned her (Miriam) more, then got hot. It made his (man) blood rouse to see her (Miriam) there, as it were, at his (man) mercy, her (Miriam) mouth open, her (Miriam) eyes dilated with laughter that was afraid, apologetic, ashamed. Then Edgar came along with two buckets of milk.

``Hello!'' (he)
he (Edgar) said.
``What are you doing?'' (unknown)

``Algebra,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
replied Paul.

``Algebra!'' (Edgar)
repeated Edgar curiously. Then he (Edgar) passed on with a laugh. Paul took a bite at his (Paul) forgotten apple, looked at the miserable cabbages in the garden, pecked into lace by the fowls, and he (Paul) wanted to pull them up. Then he (Paul) glanced at Miriam. She (Miriam) was poring over the book, seemed absorbed in it, yet trembling lest she (Miriam) could not get at it. It made him (Paul) cross. She (Miriam) was ruddy and beautiful. Yet her (Miriam) soul seemed to be intensely supplicating. The algebra-book she (Miriam) closed, shrinking, knowing he (Paul) was angered; and at the same instant he (Paul) grew gentle, seeing her (Miriam) hurt because she (Miriam) did not understand.

But things came slowly to her (Miriam). And when she (Miriam) held herself in a grip, seemed so utterly humble before the lesson, it made his (Paul) blood rouse. He (Paul) stormed at her (Miriam), got ashamed, continued the lesson, and grew furious again, abusing her (Miriam). She (Miriam) listened in silence. Occasionally, very rarely, she (Miriam) defended herself. Her (Miriam) liquid dark eyes blazed at him (Paul).

``You don't give me time to learn it,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``All right,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered, throwing the book on the table and lighting a cigarette. Then, after a while, he (Paul) went back to her (Miriam) repentant. So the lessons went. He (Paul) was always either in a rage or very gentle.

``What do you tremble your SOUL before it for?'' (he)
he (Paul) cried.
``You don't learn algebra with your blessed soul. Can't you look at it with your clear simple wits?'' (he)

Often, when he (Paul) went again into the kitchen, Mrs. Leivers would look at him (Paul) reproachfully, saying:

``Paul, don't be so hard on Miriam. She (Miriam) may not be quick, but I'm sure she (Miriam) tries.'' (him)

``I can't help it,'' (he)
he (Paul) said rather pitiably.
``I go off like it.'' (unknown)

``You don't mind me, Miriam, do you?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked of the girl later.

``No,'' (she)
she (girl) reassured him (Paul) in her (girl) beautiful deep tones--
``no, I don't mind.'' (him)

``Don't mind me; it's my fault.'' (her)

But, in spite of himself, his (Paul) blood began to boil with her (girl). It was strange that no one else made him (Paul) in such fury. He (Paul) flared against her (girl). Once he (Paul) threw the pencil in her (girl) face. There was a silence. She (girl) turned her (girl) face slightly aside.

``I didn't--'' (he)
he (Paul) began, but got no farther, feeling weak in all his (Paul) bones. She (girl) never reproached him (Paul) or was angry with him (Paul). He (Paul) was often cruelly ashamed. But still again his (Paul) anger burst like a bubble surcharged; and still, when he (Paul) saw her (girl) eager, silent, as it were, blind face, he (Paul) felt he (Paul) wanted to throw the pencil in it; and still, when he (Paul) saw her (girl) hand trembling and her (girl) mouth parted with suffering, his (Paul) heart was scalded with pain for her (girl). And because of the intensity to which she (girl) roused him (Paul), he (Paul) sought her (girl).

Then he (Paul) often avoided her (girl) and went with Edgar. Miriam and her (Miriam) brother were naturally antagonistic. Edgar was a rationalist, who was curious, and had a sort of scientific interest in life. It was a great bitterness to Miriam to see herself deserted by Paul for Edgar, who seemed so much lower. But the youth was very happy with her (Miriam) elder brother. The two men spent afternoons together on the land or in the loft doing carpentry, when it rained. And they talked together, or Paul taught Edgar the songs he (Paul) himself had learned from Annie at the piano. And often all the men, Mr. Leivers as well, had bitter debates on the nationalizing of the land and similar problems. Paul had already heard his (Paul) mother's views, and as these were as yet his (Paul) own, he (Paul) argued for her (mother). Miriam attended and took part, but was all the time waiting until it should be over and a personal communication might begin.

``After all,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said within herself,
``if the land were nationalized, Edgar and Paul and I would be just the same.'' (she)
So she (Miriam) waited for the youth to come back to her (Miriam).

He (Paul) was studying for his (Paul) painting. He (Paul) loved to sit at home, alone with his (Paul) mother, at night, working and working. She (mother) sewed or read. Then, looking up from his (Paul) task, he (Paul) would rest his (Paul) eyes for a moment on her (mother) face, that was bright with living warmth, and he (Paul) returned gladly to his (Paul) work.

``I can do my best things when you sit there in your rocking-chair, mother,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I'm sure!'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed, sniffing with mock scepticism. But she (mother) felt it was so, and her (mother) heart quivered with brightness. For many hours she (mother) sat still, slightly conscious of him (Paul) labouring away, whilst she (mother) worked or read her (mother) book. And he (Paul), with all his (Paul) soul's intensity directing his (Paul) pencil, could feel her (mother) warmth inside him (Paul) like strength. They were both very happy so, and both unconscious of it. These times, that meant so much, and which were real living, they almost ignored.

He (Paul) was conscious only when stimulated. A sketch finished, he (Paul) always wanted to take it to Miriam. Then he (Paul) was stimulated into knowledge of the work he (Paul) had produced unconsciously. In contact with Miriam he (Paul) gained insight; his (Paul) vision went deeper. From his (Paul) mother he (Paul) drew the life-warmth, the strength to produce; Miriam urged this warmth into intensity like a white light.

When he (Paul) returned to the factory the conditions of work were better. He (Paul) had Wednesday afternoon off to go to the Art School--Miss Jordan's provision--returning in the evening. Then the factory closed at six instead of eight on Thursday and Friday evenings.

One evening in the summer Miriam and he (Paul) went over the fields by Herod's Farm on their way from the library home. So it was only three miles to Willey Farm. There was a yellow glow over the mowing-grass, and the sorrel-heads burned crimson. Gradually, as they walked along the high land, the gold in the west sank down to red, the red to crimson, and then the chill blue crept up against the glow.

They came out upon the high road to Alfreton, which ran white between the darkening fields. There Paul hesitated. It was two miles home for him (Paul), one mile forward for Miriam. They both looked up the road that ran in shadow right under the glow of the north-west sky. On the crest of the hill, Selby, with its stark houses and the up-pricked headstocks of the pit, stood in black silhouette small against the sky.

He (Selby) looked at his (Selby) watch.

``Nine o'clock!'' (he)
he (Selby) said.

The pair stood, loth to part, hugging their books.

``The wood is so lovely now,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.
``I wanted you to see it.'' (He)

He (Selby) followed her (Miriam) slowly across the road to the white gate.

``They grumble so if I'm late,'' (he)
he (Selby) said.

``But you're not doing anything wrong,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered impatiently.

He (Selby) followed her (Miriam) across the nibbled pasture in the dusk. There was a coolness in the wood, a scent of leaves, of honeysuckle, and a twilight. The two walked in silence. Night came wonderfully there, among the throng of dark tree-trunks. He (Selby) looked round, expectant.

She (Miriam) wanted to show him (Selby) a certain wild-rose bush she (Miriam) had discovered. She (Miriam) knew it was wonderful. And yet, till he (Selby) had seen it, she (Miriam) felt it had not come into her (Miriam) soul. Only he (Selby) could make it her (Miriam) own, immortal. She (Miriam) was dissatisfied.

Dew was already on the paths. In the old oak-wood a mist was rising, and he (Selby) hesitated, wondering whether one whiteness were a strand of fog or only campion-flowers pallid in a cloud.

By the time they came to the pine-trees Miriam was getting very eager and very tense. Her (Miriam) bush might be gone. She (Miriam) might not be able to find it; and she (Miriam) wanted it so much. Almost passionately she (Miriam) wanted to be with him (Selby) when he (Selby) stood before the flowers. They were going to have a communion together--something that thrilled her (Miriam), something holy. He (Selby) was walking beside her (Miriam) in silence. They were very near to each other. She (Miriam) trembled, and he (Selby) listened, vaguely anxious.

Coming to the edge of the wood, they saw the sky in front, like mother-of-pearl, and the earth growing dark. Somewhere on the outermost branches of the pine-wood the honeysuckle was streaming scent.

``Where?'' (he)
he (Selby) asked.

``Down the middle path,'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured, quivering.

When they turned the corner of the path she (Miriam) stood still. In the wide walk between the pines, gazing rather frightened, she (Miriam) could distinguish nothing for some moments; the greying light robbed things of their colour. Then she (Miriam) saw her (Miriam) bush.

``Ah!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried, hastening forward.

It was very still. The tree was tall and straggling. It had thrown its briers over a hawthorn-bush, and its long streamers trailed thick, right down to the grass, splashing the darkness everywhere with great spilt stars, pure white. In bosses of ivory and in large splashed stars the roses gleamed on the darkness of foliage and stems and grass. Paul and Miriam stood close together, silent, and watched. Point after point the steady roses shone out to them, seeming to kindle something in their souls. The dusk came like smoke around, and still did not put out the roses.

Paul looked into Miriam's eyes. She (Miriam) was pale and expectant with wonder, her (Miriam) lips were parted, and her (Miriam) dark eyes lay open to him (Paul). His (Paul) look seemed to travel down into her (Miriam). Her (Miriam) soul quivered. It was the communion she (Miriam) wanted. He (Paul) turned aside, as if pained. He (Paul) turned to the bush.

``They seem as if they walk like butterflies, and shake themselves,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (Miriam) looked at her (Miriam) roses. They were white, some incurved and holy, others expanded in an ecstasy. The tree was dark as a shadow. She (Miriam) lifted her (Miriam) hand impulsively to the flowers; she (Miriam) went forward and touched them in worship.

``Let us go,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

There was a cool scent of ivory roses--a white, virgin scent. Something made him (Paul) feel anxious and imprisoned. The two walked in silence.

``Till Sunday,'' (he)
he (Paul) said quietly, and left her (Miriam); and she (Miriam) walked home slowly, feeling her (Miriam) soul satisfied with the holiness of the night. He (Paul) stumbled down the path. And as soon as he (Paul) was out of the wood, in the free open meadow, where he (Paul) could breathe, he (Paul) started to run as fast as he (Paul) could. It was like a delicious delirium in his (Paul) veins.

Always when he (Paul) went with Miriam, and it grew rather late, he (Paul) knew his (Paul) mother was fretting and getting angry about him (Paul)--why, he (Paul) could not understand. As he (Paul) went into the house, flinging down his (Paul) cap, his (Paul) mother looked up at the clock. She (mother) had been sitting thinking, because a chill to her (mother) eyes prevented her (mother) reading. She (mother) could feel Paul being drawn away by this girl. And she (mother) did not care for Miriam.

``She (mother) is one of those who will want to suck a man's soul out till he (man) has none of his (man) own left,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said to herself;
``and he (man) is just such a gaby as to let himself be absorbed. She (mother) will never let him (man) become a man; she (mother) never will.'' (she)
So, while he (Paul) was away with Miriam, Mrs. Morel grew more and more worked up.

She (Miriam) glanced at the clock and said, coldly and rather tired:

``You have been far enough to-night.'' (She)

His (Paul) soul, warm and exposed from contact with the girl, shrank.

``You must have been right home with her (mother),'' (mother)
his (Paul) mother continued.

He (Paul) would not answer. Mrs. Morel, looking at him (Paul) quickly, saw his (Paul) hair was damp on his (Paul) forehead with haste, saw him (Paul) frowning in his (Paul) heavy fashion, resentfully.

``She (mother) must be wonderfully fascinating, that you can't get away from her (mother), but must go trailing eight miles at this time of night.'' (He)

He (Paul) was hurt between the past glamour with Miriam and the knowledge that his (Paul) mother fretted. He (Paul) had meant not to say anything, to refuse to answer. But he (Paul) could not harden his (Paul) heart to ignore his (Paul) mother.

``I DO like to talk to her (mother),'' (he)
he (Paul) answered irritably.

``Is there nobody else to talk to?'' (unknown)

``You wouldn't say anything if I went with Edgar.'' (unknown)

``You know I should. You know, whoever you went with, I should say it was too far for you to go trailing, late at night, when you've been to Nottingham. Besides'' (unknown)
--her (mother) voice suddenly flashed into anger and contempt--
``it is disgusting--bits of lads and girls courting.'' (unknown)

``It is NOT courting,'' (he)
he (Paul) cried.

``I don't know what else you call it.'' (unknown)

``It's not! Do you think we SPOON and do? We only talk.'' (unknown)

``Till goodness knows what time and distance,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
was the sarcastic rejoinder.

Paul snapped at the laces of his (Paul) boots angrily.

``What are you so mad about?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.
``Because you don't like her (lads).'' (unknown)

``I don't say I don't like her (lads). But I don't hold with children keeping company, and never did.'' (unknown)

``But you don't mind our Annie going out with Jim Inger.'' (unknown)

``They've more sense than you two.'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``Our Annie's not one of the deep sort.'' (He)

He (Paul) failed to see the meaning of this remark. But his (Paul) mother looked tired. She (mother) was never so strong after William's death; and her (mother) eyes hurt her (mother).

``Well,'' (he)
he (William) said,
``it's so pretty in the country. Mr. Sleath asked about you. He (Mr.) said he (Mr.)'d missed you. Are you a bit better?'' (he)

``I ought to have been in bed a long time ago,'' (she)
she (mother) replied.

``Why, mother, you know you wouldn't have gone before quarter-past ten.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes, I should!'' (unknown)

``Oh, little woman, you'd say anything now you're disagreeable with me, wouldn't you?'' (He)

He (William) kissed her (mother) forehead that he (William) knew so well: the deep marks between the brows, the rising of the fine hair, greying now, and the proud setting of the temples. His (William) hand lingered on her (mother) shoulder after his (William) kiss. Then he (William) went slowly to bed. He (William) had forgotten Miriam; he (William) only saw how his (William) mother's hair was lifted back from her (mother) warm, broad brow. And somehow, she (mother) was hurt.

Then the next time he (William) saw Miriam he (William) said to her (Miriam):

``Don't let me be late to-night--not later than ten o'clock. My mother gets so upset.'' (he)

Miriam dropped her (Miriam) bead, brooding.

``Why does she (mother) get upset?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Because she (mother) says I oughtn't to be out late when I have to get up early.'' (unknown)

``Very well!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam, rather quietly, with just a touch of a sneer.

He (William) resented that. And he (William) was usually late again.

That there was any love growing between him (William) and Miriam neither of them would have acknowledged. He (William) thought he (William) was too sane for such sentimentality, and she (Miriam) thought herself too lofty. They both were late in coming to maturity, and psychical ripeness was much behind even the physical. Miriam was exceedingly sensitive, as her (Miriam) mother had always been. The slightest grossness made her (Miriam) recoil almost in anguish. Her (Miriam) brothers were brutal, but never coarse in speech. The men did all the discussing of farm matters outside. But, perhaps, because of the continual business of birth and of begetting which goes on upon every farm, Miriam was the more hypersensitive to the matter, and her (Miriam) blood was chastened almost to disgust of the faintest suggestion of such intercourse. Paul took his (Paul) pitch from her (Miriam), and their intimacy went on in an utterly blanched and chaste fashion. It could never be mentioned that the mare was in foal.

When he (Paul) was nineteen, he (Paul) was earning only twenty shillings a week, but he (Paul) was happy. His (Paul) painting went well, and life went well enough. On the Good Friday he (Paul) organised a walk to the Hemlock Stone. There were three lads of his (Paul) own age, then Annie and Arthur, Miriam and Geoffrey. Arthur, apprenticed as an electrician in Nottingham, was home for the holiday. Morel, as usual, was up early, whistling and sawing in the yard. At seven o'clock the family heard him (Arthur) buy threepennyworth of hot-cross buns; he (Arthur) talked with gusto to the little girl who brought them, calling her (girl)

``my darling'' (the girl)
. He (Arthur) turned away several boys who came with more buns, telling them they had been
``kested'' (boys)
by a little lass. Then Mrs. Morel got up, and the family straggled down. It was an immense luxury to everybody, this lying in bed just beyond the ordinary time on a weekday. And Paul and Arthur read before breakfast, and had the meal unwashed, sitting in their shirt-sleeves. This was another holiday luxury. The room was warm. Everything felt free of care and anxiety. There was a sense of plenty in the house.

While the boys were reading, Mrs. Morel went into the garden. They were now in another house, an old one, near the Scargill Street home, which had been left soon after William had died. Directly came an excited cry from the garden:

``Paul! Paul! come and look!'' (mother)

It was his (William) mother's voice. He (William) threw down his (William) book and went out. There was a long garden that ran to a field. It was a grey, cold day, with a sharp wind blowing out of Derbyshire. Two fields away Bestwood began, with a jumble of roofs and red house-ends, out of which rose the church tower and the spire of the Congregational Chapel. And beyond went woods and hills, right away to the pale grey heights of the Pennine Chain.

Paul looked down the garden for his (Paul) mother. Her (mother) head appeared among the young currant-bushes.

``Come here!'' (she)
she (mother) cried.

``What for?'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.

``Come and see.'' (She)

She (mother) had been looking at the buds on the currant trees. Paul went up.

``To think,'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``that here I might never have seen them!'' (she)

Her (mother) son went to her (mother) side. Under the fence, in a little bed, was a ravel of poor grassy leaves, such as come from very immature bulbs, and three scyllas in bloom. Mrs. Morel pointed to the deep blue flowers.

``Now, just see those!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed. ``I was looking at the currant bushes, when, thinks I to myself, ``There's something very blue; is it a bit of sugar-bag?
'' and there, behold you! Sugar-bag! Three glories of the snow, and such beauties! But where on earth did they come from?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Well, that's a marvel, now! I THOUGHT I knew every weed and blade in this garden. But HAVEN

``T they done well? You see, that gooseberry-bush just shelters them. Not nipped, not touched!'' (He)

He (Paul) crouched down and turned up the bells of the little blue flowers.

``They're a glorious colour!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Aren't they!'' (she)
she (Morel) cried.
``I guess they come from Switzerland, where they say they have such lovely things. Fancy them against the snow! But where have they come from? They can't have BLOWN here, can they?'' (he)

Then he (Paul) remembered having set here a lot of little trash of bulbs to mature.

``And you never told me,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

``No! I thought I'd leave it till they might flower.'' (unknown)

``And now, you see! I might have missed them. And I've never had a glory of the snow in my garden in my life.'' (She)

She (Morel) was full of excitement and elation. The garden was an endless joy to her (Morel). Paul was thankful for her (Morel) sake at last to be in a house with a long garden that went down to a field. Every morning after breakfast she (Morel) went out and was happy pottering about in it. And it was true, she (Morel) knew every weed and blade.

Everybody turned up for the walk. Food was packed, and they set off, a merry, delighted party. They hung over the wall of the mill-race, dropped paper in the water on one side of the tunnel and watched it shoot out on the other. They stood on the foot-bridge over Boathouse Station and looked at the metals gleaming coldly.

``You should see the Flying Scotsman come through at half-past six!'' (Leonard)
said Leonard, whose father was a signalman.
``Lad, but she (it) doesn't half buzz!'' (the party)
and the little party looked up the lines one way, to London, and the other way, to Scotland, and they felt the touch of these two magical places.

In Ilkeston the colliers were waiting in gangs for the public-houses to open. It was a town of idleness and lounging. At Stanton Gate the iron foundry blazed. Over everything there were great discussions. At Trowell they crossed again from Derbyshire into Nottinghamshire. They came to the Hemlock Stone at dinner-time. Its field was crowded with folk from Nottingham and Ilkeston.

They had expected a venerable and dignified monument. They found a little, gnarled, twisted stump of rock, something like a decayed mushroom, standing out pathetically on the side of a field. Leonard and Dick immediately proceeded to carve their initials,

``L. W.'' (Dick)
and
``R. P.'' (Dick)
, in the old red sandstone; but Paul desisted, because he (Paul) had read in the newspaper satirical remarks about initial-carvers, who could find no other road to immortality. Then all the lads climbed to the top of the rock to look round.

Everywhere in the field below, factory girls and lads were eating lunch or sporting about. Beyond was the garden of an old manor. It had yew-hedges and thick clumps and borders of yellow crocuses round the lawn.

``See,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul to Miriam,
``what a quiet garden!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

She (Miriam) saw the dark yews and the golden crocuses, then she (Miriam) looked gratefully. He (Paul) had not seemed to belong to her (Miriam) among all these others; he (Paul) was different then--not her (Miriam) Paul, who understood the slightest quiver of her (Miriam) innermost soul, but something else, speaking another language than hers. How it hurt her (Miriam), and deadened her (Miriam) very perceptions. Only when he (Paul) came right back to her (Miriam), leaving his (Paul) other, his (Paul) lesser self, as she (Miriam) thought, would she (Miriam) feel alive again. And now he (Paul) asked her (Miriam) to look at this garden, wanting the contact with her (Miriam) again. Impatient of the set in the field, she (Miriam) turned to the quiet lawn, surrounded by sheaves of shut-up crocuses. A feeling of stillness, almost of ecstasy, came over her (Miriam). It felt almost as if she (Miriam) were alone with him (Paul) in this garden.

Then he (Paul) left her (Miriam) again and joined the others. Soon they started home. Miriam loitered behind, alone. She (Miriam) did not fit in with the others; she (Miriam) could very rarely get into human relations with anyone: so her (Miriam) friend, her (Miriam) companion, her (Miriam) lover, was Nature. She (Miriam) saw the sun declining wanly. In the dusky, cold hedgerows were some red leaves. She (Miriam) lingered to gather them, tenderly, passionately. The love in her (Miriam) finger-tips caressed the leaves; the passion in her (Miriam) heart came to a glow upon the leaves.

Suddenly she (Miriam) realised she (Miriam) was alone in a strange road, and she (Miriam) hurried forward. Turning a corner in the lane, she (Miriam) came upon Paul, who stood bent over something, his (Paul) mind fixed on it, working away steadily, patiently, a little hopelessly. She (Miriam) hesitated in her (Miriam) approach, to watch.

He (Paul) remained concentrated in the middle of the road. Beyond, one rift of rich gold in that colourless grey evening seemed to make him (Paul) stand out in dark relief. She (Miriam) saw him (Paul), slender and firm, as if the setting sun had given him (Paul) to her (Miriam). A deep pain took hold of her (Miriam), and she (Miriam) knew she (Miriam) must love him (Paul). And she (Miriam) had discovered him (Paul), discovered in him (Paul) a rare potentiality, discovered his (Paul) loneliness. Quivering as at some

``annunciation'' (she)
, she (Miriam) went slowly forward.

At last he (Paul) looked up.

``Why,'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed gratefully,
``have you waited for me!'' (he)

She (Miriam) saw a deep shadow in his (Paul) eyes.

``What is it?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``The spring broken here;'' (he)
and he (Paul) showed her (Miriam) where his (Paul) umbrella was injured.

Instantly, with some shame, she (Miriam) knew he (Paul) had not done the damage himself, but that Geoffrey was responsible.

``It is only an old umbrella, isn't it?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

She (Miriam) wondered why he (Geoffrey), who did not usually trouble over trifles, made such a mountain of this molehill.

``But it was William's an' my mother can't help but know,'' (he)
he (Geoffrey) said quietly, still patiently working at the umbrella.

The words went through Miriam like a blade. This, then, was the confirmation of her (Miriam) vision of him (Geoffrey)! She (Miriam) looked at him (Geoffrey). But there was about him (Geoffrey) a certain reserve, and she (Miriam) dared not comfort him (Geoffrey), not even speak softly to him (Geoffrey).

``Come on,'' (he)
he (Geoffrey) said.
``I can't do it;'' (unknown)
and they went in silence along the road.

That same evening they were walking along under the trees by Nether Green. He (Green) was talking to her (Miriam) fretfully, seemed to be struggling to convince himself.

``You know,'' (he)
he (Green) said, with an effort,
``if one person loves, the other does.'' (he)

``Ah!'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered. ``Like mother said to me when I was little,
``Love begets love.''' (unknown)

``Yes, something like that, I think it MUST be.'' (unknown)

``I hope so, because, if it were not, love might be a very terrible thing,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``Yes, but it IS--at least with most people,'' (he)
he (Green) answered.

And Miriam, thinking he (Green) had assured himself, felt strong in herself. She (Miriam) always regarded that sudden coming upon him (Green) in the lane as a revelation. And this conversation remained graven in her (Miriam) mind as one of the letters of the law.

Now she (Miriam) stood with him (Green) and for him (Green). When, about this time, he (Green) outraged the family feeling at Willey Farm by some overbearing insult, she (Miriam) stuck to him (Farm), and believed he (Farm) was right. And at this time she (Miriam) dreamed dreams of him (Farm), vivid, unforgettable. These dreams came again later on, developed to a more subtle psychological stage.

On the Easter Monday the same party took an excursion to Wingfield Manor. It was great excitement to Miriam to catch a train at Sethley Bridge, amid all the bustle of the Bank Holiday crowd. They left the train at Alfreton. Paul was interested in the street and in the colliers with their dogs. Here was a new race of miners. Miriam did not live till they came to the church. They were all rather timid of entering, with their bags of food, for fear of being turned out. Leonard, a comic, thin fellow, went first; Paul, who would have died rather than be sent back, went last. The place was decorated for Easter. In the font hundreds of white narcissi seemed to be growing. The air was dim and coloured from the windows and thrilled with a subtle scent of lilies and narcissi. In that atmosphere Miriam's soul came into a glow. Paul was afraid of the things he (Paul) mustn't do; and he (Paul) was sensitive to the feel of the place. Miriam turned to him (Paul). He (Paul) answered. They were together. He (Paul) would not go beyond the Communion-rail. She (Miriam) loved him (Paul) for that. Her (Miriam) soul expanded into prayer beside him (Paul). He (Paul) felt the strange fascination of shadowy religious places. All his (Paul) latent mysticism quivered into life. She (Miriam) was drawn to him (Paul). He (Paul) was a prayer along with her (Miriam).

Miriam very rarely talked to the other lads. They at once became awkward in conversation with her (Miriam). So usually she (Miriam) was silent.

It was past midday when they climbed the steep path to the manor. All things shone softly in the sun, which was wonderfully warm and enlivening. Celandines and violets were out. Everybody was tip-top full with happiness. The glitter of the ivy, the soft, atmospheric grey of the castle walls, the gentleness of everything near the ruin, was perfect.

The manor is of hard, pale grey stone, and the other walls are blank and calm. The young folk were in raptures. They went in trepidation, almost afraid that the delight of exploring this ruin might be denied them. In the first courtyard, within the high broken walls, were farm-carts, with their shafts lying idle on the ground, the tyres of the wheels brilliant with gold-red rust. It was very still.

All eagerly paid their sixpences, and went timidly through the fine clean arch of the inner courtyard. They were shy. Here on the pavement, where the hall had been, an old thorn tree was budding. All kinds of strange openings and broken rooms were in the shadow around them.

After lunch they set off once more to explore the ruin. This time the girls went with the boys, who could act as guides and expositors. There was one tall tower in a corner, rather tottering, where they say Mary Queen of Scots was imprisoned.

``Think of the Queen going up here!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam in a low voice, as she (Miriam) climbed the hollow stairs.

``If she (Queen) could get up,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``for she (Queen) had rheumatism like anything. I reckon they treated her (Queen) rottenly.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``You don't think she (Queen) deserved it?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
asked Miriam.

``No, I don't. She (Queen) was only lively.'' (unknown)

They continued to mount the winding staircase. A high wind, blowing through the loopholes, went rushing up the shaft, and filled the girl's skirts like a balloon, so that she (girl) was ashamed, until he (Paul) took the hem of her (girl) dress and held it down for her (girl). He (Paul) did it perfectly simply, as he (Paul) would have picked up her (girl) glove. She (girl) remembered this always.

Round the broken top of the tower the ivy bushed out, old and handsome. Also, there were a few chill gillivers, in pale cold bud. Miriam wanted to lean over for some ivy, but he (Paul) would not let her (Miriam). Instead, she (Miriam) had to wait behind him (Paul), and take from him (Paul) each spray as he (Paul) gathered it and held it to her (Miriam), each one separately, in the purest manner of chivalry. The tower seemed to rock in the wind. They looked over miles and miles of wooded country, and country with gleams of pasture.

The crypt underneath the manor was beautiful, and in perfect preservation. Paul made a drawing: Miriam stayed with him (Paul). She (Miriam) was thinking of Mary Queen of Scots looking with her (Miriam) strained, hopeless eyes, that could not understand misery, over the hills whence no help came, or sitting in this crypt, being told of a God as cold as the place she (Miriam) sat in.

They set off again gaily, looking round on their beloved manor that stood so clean and big on its hill.

``Supposing you could have THAT farm,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul to Miriam.

``Yes!'' (unknown)

``Wouldn't it be lovely to come and see you!'' (he)

They were now in the bare country of stone walls, which he (Paul) loved, and which, though only ten miles from home, seemed so foreign to Miriam. The party was straggling. As they were crossing a large meadow that sloped away from the sun, along a path embedded with innumerable tiny glittering points, Paul, walking alongside, laced his (Paul) fingers in the strings of the bag Miriam was carrying, and instantly she (Miriam) felt Annie behind, watchful and jealous. But the meadow was bathed in a glory of sunshine, and the path was jewelled, and it was seldom that he (Paul) gave her (Miriam) any sign. She (Miriam) held her (Miriam) fingers very still among the strings of the bag, his (Paul) fingers touching; and the place was golden as a vision.

At last they came into the straggling grey village of Crich, that lies high. Beyond the village was the famous Crich Stand that Paul could see from the garden at home. The party pushed on. Great expanse of country spread around and below. The lads were eager to get to the top of the hill. It was capped by a round knoll, half of which was by now cut away, and on the top of which stood an ancient monument, sturdy and squat, for signalling in old days far down into the level lands of Nottinghamshire and Leicestershire.

It was blowing so hard, high up there in the exposed place, that the only way to be safe was to stand nailed by the wind to the wan of the tower. At their feet fell the precipice where the limestone was quarried away. Below was a jumble of hills and tiny villages--Mattock, Ambergate, Stoney Middleton. The lads were eager to spy out the church of Bestwood, far away among the rather crowded country on the left. They were disgusted that it seemed to stand on a plain. They saw the hills of Derbyshire fall into the monotony of the Midlands that swept away South.

Miriam was somewhat scared by the wind, but the lads enjoyed it. They went on, miles and miles, to Whatstandwell. All the food was eaten, everybody was hungry, and there was very little money to get home with. But they managed to procure a loaf and a currant-loaf, which they hacked to pieces with shut-knives, and ate sitting on the wall near the bridge, watching the bright Derwent rushing by, and the brakes from Matlock pulling up at the inn.

Paul was now pale with weariness. He (Paul) had been responsible for the party all day, and now he (Paul) was done. Miriam understood, and kept close to him (Paul), and he (Paul) left himself in her (Miriam) hands.

They had an hour to wait at Ambergate Station. Trains came, crowded with excursionists returning to Manchester, Birmingham, and London.

``We might be going there--folk easily might think we're going that far,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

They got back rather late. Miriam, walking home with Geoffrey, watched the moon rise big and red and misty. She (Miriam) felt something was fulfilled in her (Miriam).

She (Miriam) had an elder sister, Agatha, who was a school-teacher. Between the two girls was a feud. Miriam considered Agatha worldly. And she (Miriam) wanted herself to be a school-teacher.

One Saturday afternoon Agatha and Miriam were upstairs dressing. Their bedroom was over the stable. It was a low room, not very large, and bare. Miriam had nailed on the wall a reproduction of Veronese's

``St. Catherine'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
. She (Miriam) loved the woman who sat in the window, dreaming. Her (Miriam) own windows were too small to sit in. But the front one was dripped over with honeysuckle and virginia creeper, and looked upon the tree-tops of the oak-wood across the yard, while the little back window, no bigger than a handkerchief, was a loophole to the east, to the dawn beating up against the beloved round hills.

The two sisters did not talk much to each other. Agatha, who was fair and small and determined, had rebelled against the home atmosphere, against the doctrine of

``the other cheek'' (Agatha)
. She (Agatha) was out in the world now, in a fair way to be independent. And she (Agatha) insisted on worldly values, on appearance, on manners, on position, which Miriam would fain have ignored.

Both girls liked to be upstairs, out of the way, when Paul came. They preferred to come running down, open the stair-foot door, and see him (Paul) watching, expectant of them. Miriam stood painfully pulling over her (Miriam) head a rosary he (Paul) had given her (Miriam). It caught in the fine mesh of her (Miriam) hair. But at last she (Miriam) had it on, and the red-brown wooden beads looked well against her (Miriam) cool brown neck. She (Miriam) was a well-developed girl, and very handsome. But in the little looking-glass nailed against the whitewashed wall she (Miriam) could only see a fragment of herself at a time. Agatha had bought a little mirror of her (Agatha) own, which she (Agatha) propped up to suit herself. Miriam was near the window. Suddenly she (Miriam) heard the well-known click of the chain, and she (Miriam) saw Paul fling open the gate, push his (Paul) bicycle into the yard. She (Miriam) saw him (Paul) look at the house, and she (Miriam) shrank away. He (Paul) walked in a nonchalant fashion, and his (Paul) bicycle went with him (Paul) as if it were a live thing.

``Paul's come!'' (she)
she (Miriam) exclaimed.

``Aren't you glad?'' (Agatha)
said Agatha cuttingly.

Miriam stood still in amazement and bewilderment.

``Well, aren't you?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Yes, but I'm not going to let him (Paul) see it, and think I wanted him (Paul).'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam was startled. She (Miriam) heard him (Paul) putting his (Paul) bicycle in the stable underneath, and talking to Jimmy, who had been a pit-horse, and who was seedy.

``Well, Jimmy my lad, how are ter? Nobbut sick an' sadly, like? Why, then, it's a shame, my owd lad.'' (She)

She (Miriam) heard the rope run through the hole as the horse lifted its head from the lad's caress. How she (Miriam) loved to listen when he (lad) thought only the horse could hear. But there was a serpent in her (Miriam) Eden. She (Miriam) searched earnestly in herself to see if she (Miriam) wanted Paul Morel. She (Miriam) felt there would be some disgrace in it. Full of twisted feeling, she (Miriam) was afraid she (Miriam) did want him (Morel). She (Miriam) stood self-convicted. Then came an agony of new shame. She (Miriam) shrank within herself in a coil of torture. Did she (Miriam) want Paul Morel, and did he (Morel) know she (Miriam) wanted him (Morel)? What a subtle infamy upon her (Miriam). She (Miriam) felt as if her (Miriam) whole soul coiled into knots of shame.

Agatha was dressed first, and ran downstairs. Miriam heard her (Miriam) greet the lad gaily, knew exactly how brilliant her (Miriam) grey eyes became with that tone. She (Miriam) herself would have felt it bold to have greeted him (lad) in such wise. Yet there she (Miriam) stood under the self-accusation of wanting him (lad), tied to that stake of torture. In bitter perplexity she (Miriam) kneeled down and prayed:

``O Lord, let me not love Paul Morel. Keep me from loving him (Morel), if I ought not to love him (Morel).'' (she)

Something anomalous in the prayer arrested her (Miriam). She (Miriam) lifted her (Miriam) head and pondered. How could it be wrong to love him (lad)? Love was God's gift. And yet it caused her (Miriam) shame. That was because of him (God), Paul Morel. But, then, it was not his (Morel) affair, it was her (Miriam) own, between herself and God. She (Miriam) was to be a sacrifice. But it was God's sacrifice, not Paul Morel's or her (Miriam) own. After a few minutes she (Miriam) hid her (Miriam) face in the pillow again, and said:

``But, Lord, if it is Thy will that I should love him (Lord), make me love him (Lord)--as Christ would, who died for the souls of men. Make me love him (Christ) splendidly, because he (Christ) is Thy son.'' (she)

She (Miriam) remained kneeling for some time, quite still, and deeply moved, her (Miriam) black hair against the red squares and the lavender-sprigged squares of the patchwork quilt. Prayer was almost essential to her (Miriam). Then she (Miriam) fell into that rapture of self-sacrifice, identifying herself with a God who was sacrificed, which gives to so many human souls their deepest bliss.

When she (Miriam) went downstairs Paul was lying back in an armchair, holding forth with much vehemence to Agatha, who was scorning a little painting he (Paul) had brought to show her (Agatha). Miriam glanced at the two, and avoided their levity. She (Miriam) went into the parlour to be alone.

It was tea-time before she (Miriam) was able to speak to Paul, and then her (Miriam) manner was so distant he (Paul) thought he (Paul) had offended her (Miriam).

Miriam discontinued her (Miriam) practice of going each Thursday evening to the library in Bestwood. After calling for Paul regularly during the whole spring, a number of trifling incidents and tiny insults from his (Paul) family awakened her (Miriam) to their attitude towards her (Miriam), and she (Miriam) decided to go no more. So she (Miriam) announced to Paul one evening she (Miriam) would not call at his (Paul) house again for him (Paul) on Thursday nights.

``Why?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked, very short.

``Nothing. Only I'd rather not.'' (unknown)

``Very well.'' (unknown)

``But,'' (she)
she (Miriam) faltered,
``if you'd care to meet me, we could still go together.'' (she)

``Meet you where?'' (unknown)

``Somewhere--where you like.'' (unknown)

``I shan't meet you anywhere. I don't see why you shouldn't keep calling for me. But if you won't, I don't want to meet you.'' (her)

So the Thursday evenings which had been so precious to her (Miriam), and to him (Paul), were dropped. He (Paul) worked instead. Mrs. Morel sniffed with satisfaction at this arrangement.

He (Paul) would not have it that they were lovers. The intimacy between them had been kept so abstract, such a matter of the soul, all thought and weary struggle into consciousness, that he (Paul) saw it only as a platonic friendship. He (Paul) stoutly denied there was anything else between them. Miriam was silent, or else she (Miriam) very quietly agreed. He (Paul) was a fool who did not know what was happening to himself. By tacit agreement they ignored the remarks and insinuations of their acquaintances.

``We aren't lovers, we are friends,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to her (Miriam).
``WE know it. Let them talk. What does it matter what they say.'' (she)

Sometimes, as they were walking together, she (Miriam) slipped her (Miriam) arm timidly into his (Paul). But he (Paul) always resented it, and she (Miriam) knew it. It caused a violent conflict in him (Paul). With Miriam he (Paul) was always on the high plane of abstraction, when his (Paul) natural fire of love was transmitted into the fine stream of thought. She (Miriam) would have it so. If he (Paul) were jolly and, as she (Miriam) put it, flippant, she (Miriam) waited till he (Paul) came back to her (Miriam), till the change had taken place in him (Paul) again, and he (Paul) was wrestling with his (Paul) own soul, frowning, passionate in his (Paul) desire for understanding. And in this passion for understanding her (Miriam) soul lay close to his (Paul); she (Miriam) had him (Paul) all to herself. But he (Paul) must be made abstract first.

Then, if she (Miriam) put her (Miriam) arm in his (Paul), it caused him (Paul) almost torture. His (Paul) consciousness seemed to split. The place where she (Miriam) was touching him (Paul) ran hot with friction. He (Paul) was one internecine battle, and he (Paul) became cruel to her (Miriam) because of it.

One evening in midsummer Miriam called at the house, warm from climbing. Paul was alone in the kitchen; his (Paul) mother could be heard moving about upstairs.

``Come and look at the sweet-peas,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to the girl.

They went into the garden. The sky behind the townlet and the church was orange-red; the flower-garden was flooded with a strange warm light that lifted every leaf into significance. Paul passed along a fine row of sweet-peas, gathering a blossom here and there, all cream and pale blue. Miriam followed, breathing the fragrance. To her (Miriam), flowers appealed with such strength she (Miriam) felt she (Miriam) must make them part of herself. When she (Miriam) bent and breathed a flower, it was as if she (Miriam) and the flower were loving each other. Paul hated her (Miriam) for it. There seemed a sort of exposure about the action, something too intimate.

When he (Paul) had got a fair bunch, they returned to the house. He (Paul) listened for a moment to his (Paul) mother's quiet movement upstairs, then he (Paul) said:

``Come here, and let me pin them in for you.'' (he)
He (Paul) arranged them two or three at a time in the bosom of her (mother) dress, stepping back now and then to see the effect.
``You know,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, taking the pin out of his (Paul) mouth,
``a woman ought always to arrange her (woman) flowers before her (woman) glass.'' (he)

Miriam laughed. She (Miriam) thought flowers ought to be pinned in one's dress without any care. That Paul should take pains to fix her (Miriam) flowers for her (Miriam) was his (Paul) whim.

He (Paul) was rather offended at her (Miriam) laughter.

``Some women do--those who look decent,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Miriam laughed again, but mirthlessly, to hear him (Paul) thus mix her (Miriam) up with women in a general way. From most men she (Miriam) would have ignored it. But from him (Paul) it hurt her (Miriam).

He (Paul) had nearly finished arranging the flowers when he (Paul) heard his (Paul) mother's footstep on the stairs. Hurriedly he (Paul) pushed in the last pin and turned away.

``Don't let mater know,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Miriam picked up her (Miriam) books and stood in the doorway looking with chagrin at the beautiful sunset. She (Miriam) would call for Paul no more, she (Miriam) said.

``Good-evening, Mrs. Morel,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, in a deferential way. She (Miriam) sounded as if she (Miriam) felt she (Miriam) had no right to be there.

``Oh, is it you, Miriam?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel coolly.

But Paul insisted on everybody's accepting his (Paul) friendship with the girl, and Mrs. Morel was too wise to have any open rupture.

It was not till he (Paul) was twenty years old that the family could ever afford to go away for a holiday. Mrs. Morel had never been away for a holiday, except to see her (Morel) sister, since she (Morel) had been married. Now at last Paul had saved enough money, and they were all going. There was to be a party: some of Annie's friends, one friend of Paul's, a young man in the same office where William had previously been, and Miriam.

It was great excitement writing for rooms. Paul and his (Paul) mother debated it endlessly between them. They wanted a furnished cottage for two weeks. She (mother) thought one week would be enough, but he (Paul) insisted on two.

At last they got an answer from Mablethorpe, a cottage such as they wished for thirty shillings a week. There was immense jubilation. Paul was wild with joy for his (Paul) mother's sake. She (mother) would have a real holiday now. He (Paul) and she (mother) sat at evening picturing what it would be like. Annie came in, and Leonard, and Alice, and Kitty. There was wild rejoicing and anticipation. Paul told Miriam. She (Miriam) seemed to brood with joy over it. But the Morel's house rang with excitement.

They were to go on Saturday morning by the seven train. Paul suggested that Miriam should sleep at his (Paul) house, because it was so far for her (Miriam) to walk. She (Miriam) came down for supper. Everybody was so excited that even Miriam was accepted with warmth. But almost as soon as she (Miriam) entered the feeling in the family became close and tight. He (Paul) had discovered a poem by Jean Ingelow which mentioned Mablethorpe, and so he (Paul) must read it to Miriam. He (Paul) would never have got so far in the direction of sentimentality as to read poetry to his (Paul) own family. But now they condescended to listen. Miriam sat on the sofa absorbed in him (Paul). She (Miriam) always seemed absorbed in him (Paul), and by him (Paul), when he (Paul) was present. Mrs. Morel sat jealously in her (Morel) own chair. She (Morel) was going to hear also. And even Annie and the father attended, Morel with his (father) head cocked on one side, like somebody listening to a sermon and feeling conscious of the fact. Paul ducked his (Paul) head over the book. He (Paul) had got now all the audience he (Paul) cared for. And Mrs. Morel and Annie almost contested with Miriam who should listen best and win his (Paul) favour. He (Paul) was in very high feather.

``But,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
interrupted Mrs. Morel, ``what IS the
``Bride of Enderby' that the bells are supposed to ring?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``It's an old tune they used to play on the bells for a warning against water. I suppose the Bride of Enderby was drowned in a flood,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied. He (Paul) had not the faintest knowledge what it really was, but he (Paul) would never have sunk so low as to confess that to his (Paul) womenfolk. They listened and believed him (Paul). He (Paul) believed himself.

``And the people knew what that tune meant?'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother.

``Yes--just like the Scotch when they heard

``The Flowers o' the Forest'--and when they used to ring the bells backward for alarm.'' (unknown)

``How?'' (Annie)
said Annie.
``A bell sounds the same whether it's rung backwards or forwards.'' (unknown)

``But,'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``if you start with the deep bell and ring up to the high one--der--der--der--der--der--der--der--der!'' (he)

He (Paul) ran up the scale. Everybody thought it clever. He (Paul) thought so too. Then, waiting a minute, he (Paul) continued the poem.

``Hm!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel curiously, when he (Paul) finished.
``But I wish everything that's written weren't so sad.'' (unknown)

``I canna see what they want drownin' theirselves for,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.

There was a pause. Annie got up to clear the table.

Miriam rose to help with the pots.

``Let ME help to wash up,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``Certainly not,'' (Annie)
cried Annie.
``You sit down again. There aren't many.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

And Miriam, who could not be familiar and insist, sat down again to look at the book with Paul.

He (Paul) was master of the party; his (Paul) father was no good. And great tortures he (Paul) suffered lest the tin box should be put out at Firsby instead of at Mablethorpe. And he (Paul) wasn't equal to getting a carriage. His (Paul) bold little mother did that.

``Here!'' (she)
she (mother) cried to a man.
``Here!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul and Annie got behind the rest, convulsed with shamed laughter.

``How much will it be to drive to Brook Cottage?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Two shillings.'' (unknown)

``Why, how far is it?'' (unknown)

``A good way.'' (unknown)

``I don't believe it,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

But she (Morel) scrambled in. There were eight crowded in one old seaside carriage.

``You see,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``it's only threepence each, and if it were a tramcar--'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

They drove along. Each cottage they came to, Mrs. Morel cried:

``Is it this? Now, this is it!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Everybody sat breathless. They drove past. There was a universal sigh.

``I'm thankful it wasn't that brute,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``I WAS frightened.'' (unknown)
They drove on and on.

At last they descended at a house that stood alone over the dyke by the highroad. There was wild excitement because they had to cross a little bridge to get into the front garden. But they loved the house that lay so solitary, with a sea-meadow on one side, and immense expanse of land patched in white barley, yellow oats, red wheat, and green root-crops, flat and stretching level to the sky.

Paul kept accounts. He (Paul) and his (Paul) mother ran the show. The total expenses--lodging, food, everything--was sixteen shillings a week per person. He (Paul) and Leonard went bathing in the mornings. Morel was wandering abroad quite early.

``You, Paul,'' (mother)
his (Paul) mother called from the bedroom,
``eat a piece of bread-and-butter.'' (mother)

``All right,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.

And when he (Paul) got back he (Paul) saw his (Paul) mother presiding in state at the breakfast-table. The woman of the house was young. Her (woman) husband was blind, and she (woman) did laundry work. So Mrs. Morel always washed the pots in the kitchen and made the beds.

``But you said you'd have a real holiday,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``and now you work.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``Work!'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed.
``What are you talking about!'' (He)

He (Paul) loved to go with her (Morel) across the fields to the village and the sea. She (Morel) was afraid of the plank bridge, and he (Paul) abused her (Morel) for being a baby. On the whole he (Paul) stuck to her (Morel) as if he (Paul) were HER man.

Miriam did not get much of him (Paul), except, perhaps, when all the others went to the

``Coons'' (the others)
. Coons were insufferably stupid to Miriam, so he (Paul) thought they were to himself also, and he (Paul) preached priggishly to Annie about the fatuity of listening to them. Yet he (Paul), too, knew all their songs, and sang them along the roads roisterously. And if he (Paul) found himself listening, the stupidity pleased him (Paul) very much. Yet to Annie he (Paul) said:

``Such rot! there isn't a grain of intelligence in it. Nobody with more gumption than a grasshopper could go and sit and listen.'' (he)
And to Miriam he (Paul) said, with much scorn of Annie and the others:
``I suppose they're at the `Coons'.'' (the others)

It was queer to see Miriam singing coon songs. She (Miriam) had a straight chin that went in a perpendicular line from the lower lip to the turn. She (Miriam) always reminded Paul of some sad Botticelli angel when she (Miriam) sang, even when it was:

``Come down lover's lane For a walk with me, talk with me.'' (she)

Only when he (Paul) sketched, or at evening when the others were at the

``Coons'' (the others)
, she (Miriam) had him (Paul) to herself. He (Paul) talked to her (Miriam) endlessly about his (Paul) love of horizontals: how they, the great levels of sky and land in Lincolnshire, meant to him (Paul) the eternality of the will, just as the bowed Norman arches of the church, repeating themselves, meant the dogged leaping forward of the persistent human soul, on and on, nobody knows where; in contradiction to the perpendicular lines and to the Gothic arch, which, he (Norman) said, leapt up at heaven and touched the ecstasy and lost itself in the divine. Himself, he (Norman) said, was Norman, Miriam was Gothic. She (Miriam) bowed in consent even to that.

One evening he (Norman) and she (Miriam) went up the great sweeping shore of sand towards Theddlethorpe. The long breakers plunged and ran in a hiss of foam along the coast. It was a warm evening. There was not a figure but themselves on the far reaches of sand, no noise but the sound of the sea. Paul loved to see it clanging at the land. He (Paul) loved to feel himself between the noise of it and the silence of the sandy shore. Miriam was with him (Paul). Everything grew very intense. It was quite dark when they turned again. The way home was through a gap in the sandhills, and then along a raised grass road between two dykes. The country was black and still. From behind the sandhills came the whisper of the sea. Paul and Miriam walked in silence. Suddenly he (Paul) started. The whole of his (Paul) blood seemed to burst into flame, and he (Paul) could scarcely breathe. An enormous orange moon was staring at them from the rim of the sandhills. He (Paul) stood still, looking at it.

``Ah!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
cried Miriam, when she (Miriam) saw it.

He (Paul) remained perfectly still, staring at the immense and ruddy moon, the only thing in the far-reaching darkness of the level. His (Paul) heart beat heavily, the muscles of his (Paul) arms contracted.

``What is it?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
murmured Miriam, waiting for him (Paul).

He (Paul) turned and looked at her (Miriam). She (Miriam) stood beside him (Paul), for ever in shadow. Her (Miriam) face, covered with the darkness of her (Miriam) hat, was watching him (Paul) unseen. But she (Miriam) was brooding. She (Miriam) was slightly afraid--deeply moved and religious. That was her (Miriam) best state. He (Paul) was impotent against it. His (Paul) blood was concentrated like a flame in his (Paul) chest. But he (Paul) could not get across to her (Miriam). There were flashes in his (Paul) blood. But somehow she (Miriam) ignored them. She (Miriam) was expecting some religious state in him (Paul). Still yearning, she (Miriam) was half aware of his (Paul) passion, and gazed at him (Paul), troubled.

``What is it?'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured again.

``It's the moon,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered, frowning.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) assented.
``Isn't it wonderful?'' (She)
She (Miriam) was curious about him (Paul). The crisis was past.

He (Paul) did not know himself what was the matter. He (Paul) was naturally so young, and their intimacy was so abstract, he (Paul) did not know he (Paul) wanted to crush her (Miriam) on to his (Paul) breast to ease the ache there. He (Paul) was afraid of her (Miriam). The fact that he (Paul) might want her (Miriam) as a man wants a woman had in him (Paul) been suppressed into a shame. When she (woman) shrank in her (woman) convulsed, coiled torture from the thought of such a thing, he (Paul) had winced to the depths of his (Paul) soul. And now this

``purity'' (unknown)
prevented even their first love-kiss. It was as if she (woman) could scarcely stand the shock of physical love, even a passionate kiss, and then he (Paul) was too shrinking and sensitive to give it.

As they walked along the dark fen-meadow he (Paul) watched the moon and did not speak. She (woman) plodded beside him (Paul). He (Paul) hated her (woman), for she (woman) seemed in some way to make him (Paul) despise himself. Looking ahead--he (Paul) saw the one light in the darkness, the window of their lamp-lit cottage.

He (Paul) loved to think of his (Paul) mother, and the other jolly people.

``Well, everybody else has been in long ago!'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother as they entered.

``What does that matter!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried irritably.
``I can go a walk if I like, can't I?'' (unknown)

``And I should have thought you could get in to supper with the rest,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``I shall please myself,'' (he)
he (Paul) retorted.
``It's not LATE. I shall do as I like.'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother cuttingly,
``then DO as you like.'' (mother)
And she (mother) took no further notice of him (Paul) that evening. Which he (Paul) pretended neither to notice nor to care about, but sat reading. Miriam read also, obliterating herself. Mrs. Morel hated her (Morel) for making her (Morel) son like this. She (Morel) watched Paul growing irritable, priggish, and melancholic. For this she (Morel) put the blame on Miriam. Annie and all her (Annie) friends joined against the girl. Miriam had no friend of her (Miriam) own, only Paul. But she (Miriam) did not suffer so much, because she (Miriam) despised the triviality of these other people.

And Paul hated her (Miriam) because, somehow, she (Miriam) spoilt his (Paul) ease and naturalness. And he (Paul) writhed himself with a feeling of humiliation.

CHAPTER VIII

STRIFE IN LOVE

ARTHUR finished his (ARTHUR) apprenticeship, and got a job on the electrical plant at Minton Pit. He (Minton) earned very little, but had a good chance of getting on. But he (Minton) was wild and restless. He (Minton) did not drink nor gamble. Yet he (Minton) somehow contrived to get into endless scrapes, always through some hot-headed thoughtlessness. Either he (Minton) went rabbiting in the woods, like a poacher, or he (Minton) stayed in Nottingham all night instead of coming home, or he (Minton) miscalculated his (Minton) dive into the canal at Bestwood, and scored his (Minton) chest into one mass of wounds on the raw stones and tins at the bottom.

He (Minton) had not been at his (Minton) work many months when again he (Minton) did not come home one night.

``Do you know where Arthur is?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul at breakfast.

``I do not,'' (mother)
replied his (Paul) mother.

``He (Arthur) is a fool,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``And if he (Arthur) DID anything I shouldn't mind. But no, he (Arthur) simply can't come away from a game of whist, or else he (Arthur) must see a girl home from the skating-rink--quite proprietously--and so can't get home. He (Arthur)'s a fool.'' (unknown)

``I don't know that it would make it any better if he (Arthur) did something to make us all ashamed,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``Well, I should respect him (Arthur) more,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``I very much doubt it,'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother coldly.

They went on with breakfast.

``Are you fearfully fond of him (Arthur)?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul asked his (Paul) mother.

``What do you ask that for?'' (unknown)

``Because they say a woman always like the youngest best.'' (unknown)

``She (woman) may do--but I don't. No, he (Arthur) wearies me.'' (unknown)

``And you'd actually rather he (Arthur) was good?'' (unknown)

``I'd rather he (Arthur) showed some of a man's common sense.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul was raw and irritable. He (Paul) also wearied his (Paul) mother very often. She (mother) saw the sunshine going out of him (Paul), and she (mother) resented it.

As they were finishing breakfast came the postman with a letter from Derby. Mrs. Morel screwed up her (Morel) eyes to look at the address.

``Give it here, blind eye!'' (son)
exclaimed her (Morel) son, snatching it away from her (Morel).

She (Morel) started, and almost boxed his (son) ears.

``It's from your son, Arthur,'' (he)
he (son) said.

``What now--!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Mrs. Morel.

''`My dearest Mother,''' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Paul read, '''I don't know what made me such a fool. I want you to come and fetch me back from here. I came with Jack Bredon yesterday, instead of going to work, and enlisted. He (Jack) said he (Jack) was sick of wearing the seat of a stool out, and, like the idiot you know I am, I came away with him (idiot).

'''I have taken the King's shilling, but perhaps if you came for me they would let me go back with you. I was a fool when I did it. I don't want to be in the army. My dear mother, I am nothing but a trouble to you. But if you get me out of this, I promise I will have more sense and consideration...''' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel sat down in her (Morel) rocking-chair.

``Well, NOW,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried,
``let him (Arthur) stop!'' (she)

``Yes,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``let him (Arthur) stop.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

There was silence. The mother sat with her (mother) hands folded in her (mother) apron, her (mother) face set, thinking.

``If I'm not SICK!'' (she)
she (mother) cried suddenly.
``Sick!'' (unknown)

``Now,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, beginning to frown,
``you're not going to worry your soul out about this, do you hear.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``I suppose I'm to take it as a blessing,'' (she)
she (mother) flashed, turning on her (mother) son.

``You're not going to mount it up to a tragedy, so there,'' (he)
he (Paul) retorted.

``The FOOL!--the young fool!'' (she)
she (mother) cried.

``He (fool)'ll look well in uniform,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul irritatingly.

His (Paul) mother turned on him (Paul) like a fury.

``Oh, will he (fool)!'' (she)
she (mother) cried.
``Not in my eyes!'' (unknown)

``He (fool) should get in a cavalry regiment; he (fool)'ll have the time of his (fool) life, and will look an awful swell.'' (unknown)

``Swell!--SWELL!--a mighty swell idea indeed!--a common soldier!'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``what am I but a common clerk?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``A good deal, my boy!'' (mother)
cried his (Paul) mother, stung.

``What?'' (unknown)

``At any rate, a MAN, and not a thing in a red coat.'' (unknown)

``I shouldn't mind being in a red coat--or dark blue, that would suit me better--if they didn't boss me about too much.'' (mother)

But his (Paul) mother had ceased to listen.

``Just as he (boss) was getting on, or might have been getting on, at his (boss) job--a young nuisance--here he (boss) goes and ruins himself for life. What good will he (boss) be, do you think, after THIS?'' (unknown)

``It may lick him (boss) into shape beautifully,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Lick him (boss) into shape!--lick what marrow there WAS out of his (boss) bones. A SOLDIER!--a common SOLDIER!--nothing but a body that makes movements when it hears a shout! It's a fine thing!'' (unknown)

``I can't understand why it upsets you,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``No, perhaps you can't. But I understand'' (she)
; and she (mother) sat back in her (mother) chair, her (mother) chin in one hand, holding her (mother) elbow with the other, brimmed up with wrath and chagrin.

``And shall you go to Derby?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``It's no good.'' (unknown)

``I'll see for myself.'' (unknown)

``And why on earth don't you let him (boss) stop. It's just what he (boss) wants.'' (unknown)

``Of course,'' (the mother)
cried the mother,
``YOU know what he (boss) wants!'' (the mother)

She (mother) got ready and went by the first train to Derby, where she (mother) saw her (mother) son and the sergeant. It was, however, no good.

When Morel was having his (sergeant) dinner in the evening, she (Morel) said suddenly:

``I've had to go to Derby to-day.'' (she)

The miner turned up his (sergeant) eyes, showing the whites in his (sergeant) black face.

``Has ter, lass. What took thee there?'' (unknown)

``That Arthur!'' (unknown)

``Oh--an' what's agate now?'' (unknown)

``He (Arthur)'s only enlisted.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Morel put down his (sergeant) knife and leaned back in his (sergeant) chair.

``Nay,'' (he)
he (sergeant) said,
``that he (Arthur) niver `as!'' (he)

``And is going down to Aldershot tomorrow.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (the miner)
exclaimed the miner.
``That's a winder.'' (He)
He (sergeant) considered it a moment, said
``H'm!'' (He)
and proceeded with his (sergeant) dinner. Suddenly his (sergeant) face contracted with wrath.
``I hope he (Arthur) may never set foot i' my house again,'' (he)
he (sergeant) said.

``The idea!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Mrs. Morel.
``Saying such a thing!'' (unknown)

``I do,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
repeated Morel.
``A fool as runs away for a soldier, let `im look after `issen; I s'll do no more for `im.'' (unknown)

``A fat sight you have done as it is,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

And Morel was almost ashamed to go to his (sergeant) public-house that evening.

``Well, did you go?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul to his (Paul) mother when he (Paul) came home.

``I did.'' (unknown)

``And could you see him (soldier)?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``And what did he (soldier) say?'' (unknown)

``He (soldier) blubbered when I came away.'' (unknown)

``H'm!'' (unknown)

``And so did I, so you needn't `h'm'!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel fretted after her (Morel) son. She (Morel) knew he (Paul) would not like the army. He (Paul) did not. The discipline was intolerable to him (Paul).

``But the doctor,'' (she)
she (Morel) said with some pride to Paul,
``said he (doctor) was perfectly proportioned--almost exactly; all his (doctor) measurements were correct. He (doctor) IS good-looking, you know.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``He (doctor)'s awfully nice-looking. But he (doctor) doesn't fetch the girls like William, does he (William)?'' (unknown)

``No; it's a different character. He (character)'s a good deal like his (character) father, irresponsible.'' (mother)

To console his (Paul) mother, Paul did not go much to Willey Farm at this time. And in the autumn exhibition of students' work in the Castle he (Paul) had two studies, a landscape in water-colour and a still life in oil, both of which had first-prize awards. He (Paul) was highly excited.

``What do you think I've got for my pictures, mother?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked, coming home one evening. She (Morel) saw by his (Paul) eyes he (Paul) was glad. Her (Morel) face flushed.

``Now, how should I know, my boy!'' (unknown)

``A first prize for those glass jars--'' (unknown)

``H'm!'' (unknown)

``And a first prize for that sketch up at Willey Farm.'' (unknown)

``Both first?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``H'm!'' (her)

There was a rosy, bright look about her (Morel), though she (Morel) said nothing.

``It's nice,'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``isn't it?'' (he)

``It is.'' (unknown)

``Why don't you praise me up to the skies?'' (She)

She (Morel) laughed.

``I should have the trouble of dragging you down again,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

But she (Morel) was full of joy, nevertheless. William had brought her (Morel) his (William) sporting trophies. She (Morel) kept them still, and she (Morel) did not forgive his (William) death. Arthur was handsome--at least, a good specimen--and warm and generous, and probably would do well in the end. But Paul was going to distinguish himself. She (Morel) had a great belief in him (Paul), the more because he (Paul) was unaware of his (Paul) own powers. There was so much to come out of him (Paul). Life for her (Morel) was rich with promise. She (Morel) was to see herself fulfilled. Not for nothing had been her (Morel) struggle.

Several times during the exhibition Mrs. Morel went to the Castle unknown to Paul. She (Morel) wandered down the long room looking at the other exhibits. Yes, they were good. But they had not in them a certain something which she (Morel) demanded for her (Morel) satisfaction. Some made her (Morel) jealous, they were so good. She (Morel) looked at them a long time trying to find fault with them. Then suddenly she (Morel) had a shock that made her (Morel) heart beat. There hung Paul's picture! She (Morel) knew it as if it were printed on her (Morel) heart.

``Name--Paul Morel--First Prize.'' (public)

It looked so strange, there in public, on the walls of the Castle gallery, where in her (Morel) lifetime she (Morel) had seen so many pictures. And she (Morel) glanced round to see if anyone had noticed her (Morel) again in front of the same sketch.

But she (Morel) felt a proud woman. When she (Morel) met well-dressed ladies going home to the Park, she (Morel) thought to herself:

``Yes, you look very well--but I wonder if YOUR son has two first prizes in the Castle.'' (she)

And she (Morel) walked on, as proud a little woman as any in Nottingham. And Paul felt he (Paul) had done something for her (Morel), if only a trifle. All his (Paul) work was hers.

One day, as he (Paul) was going up Castle Gate, he (Paul) met Miriam. He (Paul) had seen her (Miriam) on the Sunday, and had not expected to meet her (Miriam) in town. She (Miriam) was walking with a rather striking woman, blonde, with a sullen expression, and a defiant carriage. It was strange how Miriam, in her (Miriam) bowed, meditative bearing, looked dwarfed beside this woman with the handsome shoulders. Miriam watched Paul searchingly. His (Paul) gaze was on the stranger, who ignored him (Paul). The girl saw his (Paul) masculine spirit rear its head.

``Hello!'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``you didn't tell me you were coming to town.'' (he)

``No,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
replied Miriam, half apologetically.
``I drove in to Cattle Market with father.'' (He)

He (Paul) looked at her (Miriam) companion.

``I've told you about Mrs. Dawes,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam huskily; she (Miriam) was nervous.
``Clara, do you know Paul?'' (unknown)

``I think I've seen him (Paul) before,'' (Mrs. Dawes/Dawes)
replied Mrs. Dawes indifferently, as she (Dawes) shook hands with him (Paul). She (Dawes) had scornful grey eyes, a skin like white honey, and a full mouth, with a slightly lifted upper lip that did not know whether it was raised in scorn of all men or out of eagerness to be kissed, but which believed the former. She (Dawes) carried her (Dawes) head back, as if she (Dawes) had drawn away in contempt, perhaps from men also. She (Dawes) wore a large, dowdy hat of black beaver, and a sort of slightly affected simple dress that made her (Dawes) look rather sack-like. She (Dawes) was evidently poor, and had not much taste. Miriam usually looked nice.

``Where have you seen me?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul asked of the woman.

She (Miriam) looked at him (Paul) as if she (Miriam) would not trouble to answer. Then:

``Walking with Louie Travers,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

Louie was one of the

``Spiral'' (Louie/Louie Travers)
girls.

``Why, do you know her (Clara)?'' (he)
he (Louie) asked.

She (Miriam) did not answer. He (Louie) turned to Miriam.

``Where are you going?'' (he)
he (Louie) asked.

``To the Castle.'' (unknown)

``What train are you going home by?'' (unknown)

``I am driving with father. I wish you could come too. What time are you free?'' (unknown)

``You know not till eight to-night, damn it!'' (the women)

And directly the two women moved on.

Paul remembered that Clara Dawes was the daughter of an old friend of Mrs. Leivers. Miriam had sought her (Miriam) out because she (Miriam) had once been Spiral overseer at Jordan's, and because her (Miriam) husband, Baxter Dawes, was smith for the factory, making the irons for cripple instruments, and so on. Through her (Miriam) Miriam felt she (Miriam) got into direct contact with Jordan's, and could estimate better Paul's position. But Mrs. Dawes was separated from her (Dawes) husband, and had taken up Women's Rights. She (Dawes) was supposed to be clever. It interested Paul.

Baxter Dawes he (Dawes) knew and disliked. The smith was a man of thirty-one or thirty-two. He (smith) came occasionally through Paul's corner--a big, well-set man, also striking to look at, and handsome. There was a peculiar similarity between himself and his (man) wife. He (man) had the same white skin, with a clear, golden tinge. His (man) hair was of soft brown, his (man) moustache was golden. And he (man) had a similar defiance in his (man) bearing and manner. But then came the difference. His (man) eyes, dark brown and quick-shifting, were dissolute. They protruded very slightly, and his (man) eyelids hung over them in a way that was half hate. His (man) mouth, too, was sensual. His (man) whole manner was of cowed defiance, as if he (man) were ready to knock anybody down who disapproved of him (man)--perhaps because he (man) really disapproved of himself.

From the first day he (man) had hated Paul. Finding the lad's impersonal, deliberate gaze of an artist on his (artist) face, he (artist) got into a fury.

``What are yer lookin' at?'' (he)
he (artist) sneered, bullying.

The boy glanced away. But the smith used to stand behind the counter and talk to Mr. Pappleworth. His (Pappleworth) speech was dirty, with a kind of rottenness. Again he (Pappleworth) found the youth with his (Pappleworth) cool, critical gaze fixed on his (Pappleworth) face. The smith started round as if he (smith) had been stung.

``What'r yer lookin' at, three hap`orth o' pap?'' (he)
he (smith) snarled.

The boy shrugged his (smith) shoulders slightly.

``Why yer--!'' (Mrs. Dawes/Dawes)
shouted Dawes.

``Leave him (father) alone,'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)
said Mr. Pappleworth, in that insinuating voice which means,
``He (father)'s only one of your good little sops who can't help it.'' (Mr. Pappleworth/Pappleworth)

Since that time the boy used to look at the man every time he (man) came through with the same curious criticism, glancing away before he (man) met the smith's eye. It made Dawes furious. They hated each other in silence.

Clara Dawes had no children. When she (Dawes) had left her (Dawes) husband the home had been broken up, and she (Dawes) had gone to live with her (Dawes) mother. Dawes lodged with his (husband) sister. In the same house was a sister-in-law, and somehow Paul knew that this girl, Louie Travers, was now Dawes's woman. She (Dawes) was a handsome, insolent hussy, who mocked at the youth, and yet flushed if he (Paul) walked along to the station with her (Dawes) as she (Dawes) went home.

The next time he (Paul) went to see Miriam it was Saturday evening. She (Miriam) had a fire in the parlour, and was waiting for him (Paul). The others, except her (Miriam) father and mother and the young children, had gone out, so the two had the parlour together. It was a long, low, warm room. There were three of Paul's small sketches on the wall, and his (Paul) photo was on the mantelpiece. On the table and on the high old rosewood piano were bowls of coloured leaves. He (Paul) sat in the armchair, she (Miriam) crouched on the hearthrug near his (Paul) feet. The glow was warm on her (Miriam) handsome, pensive face as she (Miriam) kneeled there like a devotee.

``What did you think of Mrs. Dawes?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked quietly.

``She (Dawes) doesn't look very amiable,'' (he)
he (devotee) replied.

``No, but don't you think she (Dawes)'s a fine woman?'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, in a deep tone,

``Yes--in stature. But without a grain of taste. I like her (Dawes) for some things. IS she (Dawes) disagreeable?'' (she)

``I don't think so. I think she (Dawes)'s dissatisfied.'' (unknown)

``What with?'' (unknown)
