``Well--how would you like to be tied for life to a man like that?'' (unknown)

``Why did she (Dawes) marry him (man), then, if she (Dawes) was to have revulsions so soon?'' (unknown)

``Ay, why did she (Dawes)!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
repeated Miriam bitterly.

``And I should have thought she (Dawes) had enough fight in her (Dawes) to match him (man),'' (he)
he (devotee) said.

Miriam bowed her (Miriam) head.

``Ay?'' (she)
she (Miriam) queried satirically.
``What makes you think so?'' (unknown)

``Look at her (Dawes) mouth--made for passion--and the very setback of her (Dawes) throat--'' (He)
He (devotee) threw his (devotee) head back in Clara's defiant manner.

Miriam bowed a little lower.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

There was a silence for some moments, while he (devotee) thought of Clara.

``And what were the things you liked about her (Dawes)?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``I don't know--her (Dawes) skin and the texture of her (Dawes)--and her (Dawes)--I don't know--there's a sort of fierceness somewhere in her (Dawes). I appreciate her (Dawes) as an artist, that's all.'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (He)

He (devotee) wondered why Miriam crouched there brooding in that strange way. It irritated him (devotee).

``You don't really like her (Dawes), do you?'' (he)
he (devotee) asked the girl.

She (Miriam) looked at him (devotee) with her (Miriam) great, dazzled dark eyes.

``I do,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``You don't--you can't--not really.'' (unknown)

``Then what?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked slowly.

``Eh, I don't know--perhaps you like her (Dawes) because she (Dawes)'s got a grudge against men.'' (Mrs. Dawes/Dawes)

That was more probably one of his (devotee) own reasons for liking Mrs. Dawes, but this did not occur to him (devotee). They were silent. There had come into his (devotee) forehead a knitting of the brows which was becoming habitual with him (devotee), particularly when he (devotee) was with Miriam. She (Miriam) longed to smooth it away, and she (Miriam) was afraid of it. It seemed the stamp of a man who was not her (Miriam) man in Paul Morel.

There were some crimson berries among the leaves in the bowl. He (Morel) reached over and pulled out a bunch.

``If you put red berries in your hair,'' (he)
he (Morel) said,
``why would you look like some witch or priestess, and never like a reveller?'' (he)

She (Miriam) laughed with a naked, painful sound.

``I don't know,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

His (Morel) vigorous warm hands were playing excitedly with the berries.

``Why can't you laugh?'' (he)
he (Morel) said.
``You never laugh laughter. You only laugh when something is odd or incongruous, and then it almost seems to hurt you.'' (She)

She (Miriam) bowed her (Miriam) head as if he (Morel) were scolding her (Miriam).

``I wish you could laugh at me just for one minute--just for one minute. I feel as if it would set something free.'' (unknown)

``But'' (she)
--and she (Miriam) looked up at him (Morel) with eyes frightened and struggling--
``I do laugh at you--I DO.'' (him)

``Never! There's always a kind of intensity. When you laugh I could always cry; it seems as if it shows up your suffering. Oh, you make me knit the brows of my very soul and cogitate.'' (she)

Slowly she (Miriam) shook her (Miriam) head despairingly.

``I'm sure I don't want to,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``I'm so damned spiritual with YOU always!'' (he)
he (Morel) cried.

She (Miriam) remained silent, thinking,

``Then why don't you be otherwise.'' (She)
But he (Morel) saw her (Miriam) crouching, brooding figure, and it seemed to tear him (Morel) in two.

``But, there, it's autumn,'' (he)
he (Morel) said,
``and everybody feels like a disembodied spirit then.'' (he)

There was still another silence. This peculiar sadness between them thrilled her (Miriam) soul. He (Morel) seemed so beautiful with his (Morel) eyes gone dark, and looking as if they were deep as the deepest well.

``You make me so spiritual!'' (he)
he (Morel) lamented.
``And I don't want to be spiritual.'' (She)

She (Miriam) took her (Miriam) finger from her (Miriam) mouth with a little pop, and looked up at him (Morel) almost challenging. But still her (Miriam) soul was naked in her (Miriam) great dark eyes, and there was the same yearning appeal upon her (Miriam). If he (Morel) could have kissed her (Miriam) in abstract purity he (Morel) would have done so. But he (Morel) could not kiss her (Miriam) thus--and she (Miriam) seemed to leave no other way. And she (Miriam) yearned to him (Morel).

He (Morel) gave a brief laugh.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Morel) said,
``get that French and we'll do some--some Verlaine.'' (he)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said in a deep tone, almost of resignation. And she (Miriam) rose and got the books. And her (Miriam) rather red, nervous hands looked so pitiful, he (Morel) was mad to comfort her (Miriam) and kiss her (Miriam). But then be dared not--or could not. There was something prevented him (Morel). His (Morel) kisses were wrong for her (Miriam). They continued the reading till ten o'clock, when they went into the kitchen, and Paul was natural and jolly again with the father and mother. His (Paul) eyes were dark and shining; there was a kind of fascination about him (Paul).

When he (Paul) went into the barn for his (Paul) bicycle he (Paul) found the front wheel punctured.

``Fetch me a drop of water in a bowl,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to her (mother).
``I shall be late, and then I s'll catch it.'' (He)

He (Paul) lighted the hurricane lamp, took off his (Paul) coat, turned up the bicycle, and set speedily to work. Miriam came with the bowl of water and stood close to him (Paul), watching. She (Miriam) loved to see his (Paul) hands doing things. He (Paul) was slim and vigorous, with a kind of easiness even in his (Paul) most hasty movements. And busy at his (Paul) work he (Paul) seemed to forget her (Miriam). She (Miriam) loved him (Paul) absorbedly. She (Miriam) wanted to run her (Miriam) hands down his (Paul) sides. She (Miriam) always wanted to embrace him (Paul), so long as he (Paul) did not want her (Miriam).

``There!'' (he)
he (Paul) said, rising suddenly.
``Now, could you have done it quicker?'' (unknown)

``No!'' (she)
she (Miriam) laughed.

He (Paul) straightened himself. His (Paul) back was towards her (Miriam). She (Miriam) put her (Miriam) two hands on his (Paul) sides, and ran them quickly down.

``You are so FINE!'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

He (Paul) laughed, hating her (Miriam) voice, but his (Paul) blood roused to a wave of flame by her (Miriam) hands. She (Miriam) did not seem to realise HIM in all this. He (Paul) might have been an object. She (Miriam) never realised the male he (Paul) was.

He (Paul) lighted his (Paul) bicycle-lamp, bounced the machine on the barn floor to see that the tyres were sound, and buttoned his (Paul) coat.

``That's all right!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (Miriam) was trying the brakes, that she (Miriam) knew were broken.

``Did you have them mended?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``No!'' (unknown)

``But why didn't you?'' (unknown)

``The back one goes on a bit.'' (unknown)

``But it's not safe.'' (unknown)

``I can use my toe.'' (unknown)

``I wish you'd had them mended,'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured.

``Don't worry--come to tea tomorrow, with Edgar.'' (unknown)

``Shall we?'' (unknown)

``Do--about four. I'll come to meet you.'' (unknown)

``Very well.'' (She)

She (Miriam) was pleased. They went across the dark yard to the gate. Looking across, he (Paul) saw through the uncurtained window of the kitchen the heads of Mr. and Mrs. Leivers in the warm glow. It looked very cosy. The road, with pine trees, was quite black in front.

``Till tomorrow,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, jumping on his (Paul) bicycle.

``You'll take care, won't you?'' (she)
she (Leivers) pleaded.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

His (Paul) voice already came out of the darkness. She (Leivers) stood a moment watching the light from his (Paul) lamp race into obscurity along the ground. She (Leivers) turned very slowly indoors. Orion was wheeling up over the wood, his (Paul) dog twinkling after him (Paul), half smothered. For the rest the world was full of darkness, and silent, save for the breathing of cattle in their stalls. She (Leivers) prayed earnestly for his (Paul) safety that night. When he (Paul) left her (Leivers), she (Leivers) often lay in anxiety, wondering if he (Paul) had got home safely.

He (Paul) dropped down the hills on his (Paul) bicycle. The roads were greasy, so he (Paul) had to let it go. He (Paul) felt a pleasure as the machine plunged over the second, steeper drop in the hill.

``Here goes!'' (he)
he (Paul) said. It was risky, because of the curve in the darkness at the bottom, and because of the brewers' waggons with drunken waggoners asleep. His (Paul) bicycle seemed to fall beneath him (Paul), and he (Paul) loved it. Recklessness is almost a man's revenge on his (Paul) woman. He (Paul) feels he (Paul) is not valued, so he (Paul) will risk destroying himself to deprive her (woman) altogether.

The stars on the lake seemed to leap like grasshoppers, silver upon the blackness, as he (Paul) spun past. Then there was the long climb home.

``See, mother!'' (he)
he (Paul) said, as he (Paul) threw her (woman) the berries and leaves on to the table.

``H'm!'' (she)
she (woman) said, glancing at them, then away again. She (woman) sat reading, alone, as she (woman) always did.

``Aren't they pretty?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (He)

He (Paul) knew she (woman) was cross with him (Paul). After a few minutes he (Paul) said:

``Edgar and Miriam are coming to tea tomorrow.'' (he)

She (woman) did not answer.

``You don't mind?'' (she)

Still she (woman) did not answer.

``Do you?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``You know whether I mind or not.'' (unknown)

``I don't see why you should. I have plenty of meals there.'' (unknown)

``You do.'' (unknown)

``Then why do you begrudge them tea?'' (unknown)

``I begrudge whom tea?'' (unknown)

``What are you so horrid for?'' (unknown)

``Oh, say no more! You've asked her (Miriam) to tea, it's quite sufficient. She (Miriam)'ll come.'' (He)

He (Paul) was very angry with his (Paul) mother. He (Paul) knew it was merely Miriam she (Miriam) objected to. He (Paul) flung off his (Paul) boots and went to bed.

Paul went to meet his (Paul) friends the next afternoon. He (Paul) was glad to see them coming. They arrived home at about four o'clock. Everywhere was clean and still for Sunday afternoon. Mrs. Morel sat in her (Morel) black dress and black apron. She (Morel) rose to meet the visitors. With Edgar she (Morel) was cordial, but with Miriam cold and rather grudging. Yet Paul thought the girl looked so nice in her (girl) brown cashmere frock.

He (Paul) helped his (Paul) mother to get the tea ready. Miriam would have gladly proffered, but was afraid. He (Paul) was rather proud of his (Paul) home. There was about it now, he (Paul) thought, a certain distinction. The chairs were only wooden, and the sofa was old. But the hearthrug and cushions were cosy; the pictures were prints in good taste; there was a simplicity in everything, and plenty of books. He (Paul) was never ashamed in the least of his (Paul) home, nor was Miriam of hers, because both were what they should be, and warm. And then he (Paul) was proud of the table; the china was pretty, the cloth was fine. It did not matter that the spoons were not silver nor the knives ivory-handled; everything looked nice. Mrs. Morel had managed wonderfully while her (Morel) children were growing up, so that nothing was out of place.

Miriam talked books a little. That was her (Miriam) unfailing topic. But Mrs. Morel was not cordial, and turned soon to Edgar.

At first Edgar and Miriam used to go into Mrs. Morel's pew. Morel never went to chapel, preferring the public-house. Mrs. Morel, like a little champion, sat at the head of her (Morel) pew, Paul at the other end; and at first Miriam sat next to him (Paul). Then the chapel was like home. It was a pretty place, with dark pews and slim, elegant pillars, and flowers. And the same people had sat in the same places ever since he (Paul) was a boy. It was wonderfully sweet and soothing to sit there for an hour and a half, next to Miriam, and near to his (Paul) mother, uniting his (Paul) two loves under the spell of the place of worship. Then he (Paul) felt warm and happy and religious at once. And after chapel he (Paul) walked home with Miriam, whilst Mrs. Morel spent the rest of the evening with her (Morel) old friend, Mrs. Burns. He (friend) was keenly alive on his (friend) walks on Sunday nights with Edgar and Miriam. He (Edgar) never went past the pits at night, by the lighted lamp-house, the tall black headstocks and lines of trucks, past the fans spinning slowly like shadows, without the feeling of Miriam returning to him (Edgar), keen and almost unbearable.

She (Miriam) did not very long occupy the Morels' pew. Her (Miriam) father took one for themselves once more. It was under the little gallery, opposite the Morels'. When Paul and his (Paul) mother came in the chapel the Leivers's pew was always empty. He (Paul) was anxious for fear she (mother) would not come: it was so far, and there were so many rainy Sundays. Then, often very late indeed, she (mother) came in, with her (mother) long stride, her (mother) head bowed, her (mother) face hidden under her (mother) hat of dark green velvet. Her (mother) face, as she (mother) sat opposite, was always in shadow. But it gave him (Paul) a very keen feeling, as if all his (Paul) soul stirred within him (Paul), to see her (mother) there. It was not the same glow, happiness, and pride, that he (Paul) felt in having his (Paul) mother in charge: something more wonderful, less human, and tinged to intensity by a pain, as if there were something he (Paul) could not get to.

At this time he (Paul) was beginning to question the orthodox creed. He (Paul) was twenty-one, and she (mother) was twenty. She (mother) was beginning to dread the spring: he (Paul) became so wild, and hurt her (mother) so much. All the way he (Paul) went cruelly smashing her (mother) beliefs. Edgar enjoyed it. He (Edgar) was by nature critical and rather dispassionate. But Miriam suffered exquisite pain, as, with an intellect like a knife, the man she (Miriam) loved examined her (Miriam) religion in which she (Miriam) lived and moved and had her (Miriam) being. But he (man) did not spare her (Miriam). He (man) was cruel. And when they went alone he (man) was even more fierce, as if he (man) would kill her (Miriam) soul. He (man) bled her (Miriam) beliefs till she (Miriam) almost lost consciousness.

``She (Miriam) exults--she (Miriam) exults as she (Miriam) carries him (Miriam) off from me,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel cried in her (Morel) heart when Paul had gone.
``She (Miriam)'s not like an ordinary woman, who can leave me my share in him (Miriam). She (Miriam) wants to absorb him (Miriam). She (Miriam) wants to draw him (Miriam) out and absorb him (Miriam) till there is nothing left of him (Miriam), even for himself. He (Miriam) will never be a man on his (Miriam) own feet--she (Miriam) will suck him (Miriam) up.'' (the mother)
So the mother sat, and battled and brooded bitterly.

And he (Paul), coming home from his (Paul) walks with Miriam, was wild with torture. He (Paul) walked biting his (Paul) lips and with clenched fists, going at a great rate. Then, brought up against a stile, he (Paul) stood for some minutes, and did not move. There was a great hollow of darkness fronting him (Paul), and on the black upslopes patches of tiny lights, and in the lowest trough of the night, a flare of the pit. It was all weird and dreadful. Why was he (Paul) torn so, almost bewildered, and unable to move? Why did his (Paul) mother sit at home and suffer? He (Paul) knew she (mother) suffered badly. But why should she (mother)? And why did he (Paul) hate Miriam, and feel so cruel towards her (Miriam), at the thought of his (Paul) mother. If Miriam caused his (Paul) mother suffering, then he (Paul) hated her (Miriam)--and he (Paul) easily hated her (Miriam). Why did she (Miriam) make him (Paul) feel as if he (Paul) were uncertain of himself, insecure, an indefinite thing, as if he (Paul) had not sufficient sheathing to prevent the night and the space breaking into him (Paul)? How he (Paul) hated her (Miriam)! And then, what a rush of tenderness and humility!

Suddenly he (Paul) plunged on again, running home. His (Paul) mother saw on him (Paul) the marks of some agony, and she (mother) said nothing. But he (Paul) had to make her (mother) talk to him (Paul). Then she (mother) was angry with him (Paul) for going so far with Miriam.

``Why don't you like her (Miriam), mother?'' (he)
he (Paul) cried in despair.

``I don't know, my boy,'' (she)
she (Miriam) replied piteously.
``I'm sure I've tried to like her (mother). I've tried and tried, but I can't--I can't!'' (he)

And he (Paul) felt dreary and hopeless between the two.

Spring was the worst time. He (Paul) was changeable, and intense and cruel. So he (Paul) decided to stay away from her (Miriam). Then came the hours when he (Paul) knew Miriam was expecting him (Paul). His (Paul) mother watched him (Paul) growing restless. He (Paul) could not go on with his (Paul) work. He (Paul) could do nothing. It was as if something were drawing his (Paul) soul out towards Willey Farm. Then he (Paul) put on his (Paul) hat and went, saying nothing. And his (Paul) mother knew he (Paul) was gone. And as soon as he (Paul) was on the way he (Paul) sighed with relief. And when he (Paul) was with her (mother) he (Paul) was cruel again.

One day in March he (Paul) lay on the bank of Nethermere, with Miriam sitting beside him (Paul). It was a glistening, white-and-blue day. Big clouds, so brilliant, went by overhead, while shadows stole along on the water. The clear spaces in the sky were of clean, cold blue. Paul lay on his (Paul) back in the old grass, looking up. He (Paul) could not bear to look at Miriam. She (Miriam) seemed to want him (Paul), and he (Paul) resisted. He (Paul) resisted all the time. He (Paul) wanted now to give her (Miriam) passion and tenderness, and he (Paul) could not. He (Paul) felt that she (Miriam) wanted the soul out of his (Paul) body, and not him (Paul). All his (Paul) strength and energy she (Miriam) drew into herself through some channel which united them. She (Miriam) did not want to meet him (Paul), so that there were two of them, man and woman together. She (woman) wanted to draw all of him (man) into her (woman). It urged him (man) to an intensity like madness, which fascinated him (man), as drug-taking might.

He (man) was discussing Michael Angelo. It felt to her (woman) as if she (woman) were fingering the very quivering tissue, the very protoplasm of life, as she (woman) heard him (man). It gave her (woman) deepest satisfaction. And in the end it frightened her (woman). There he (man) lay in the white intensity of his (man) search, and his (man) voice gradually filled her (woman) with fear, so level it was, almost inhuman, as if in a trance.

``Don't talk any more,'' (she)
she (woman) pleaded softly, laying her (woman) hand on his (man) forehead.

He (man) lay quite still, almost unable to move. His (man) body was somewhere discarded.

``Why not? Are you tired?'' (unknown)

``Yes, and it wears you out.'' (He)

He (man) laughed shortly, realising.

``Yet you always make me like it,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``I don't wish to,'' (she)
she (woman) said, very low.

``Not when you've gone too far, and you feel you can't bear it. But your unconscious self always asks it of me. And I suppose I want it.'' (He)

He (man) went on, in his (man) dead fashion:

``If only you could want ME, and not want what I can reel off for you!'' (He)

``I!'' (she)
she (woman) cried bitterly--
``I! Why, when would you let me take you?'' (she)

``Then it's my fault,'' (he)
he (man) said, and, gathering himself together, he (man) got up and began to talk trivialities. He (man) felt insubstantial. In a vague way he (man) hated her (woman) for it. And he (man) knew he (man) was as much to blame himself. This, however, did not prevent his (man) hating her (woman).

One evening about this time he (man) had walked along the home road with her (woman). They stood by the pasture leading down to the wood, unable to part. As the stars came out the clouds closed. They had glimpses of their own constellation, Orion, towards the west. His (man) jewels glimmered for a moment, his (man) dog ran low, struggling with difficulty through the spume of cloud.

Orion was for them chief in significance among the constellations. They had gazed at him (man) in their strange, surcharged hours of feeling, until they seemed themselves to live in every one of his (man) stars. This evening Paul had been moody and perverse. Orion had seemed just an ordinary constellation to him (Paul). He (Paul) had fought against his (Paul) glamour and fascination. Miriam was watching her (Miriam) lover's mood carefully. But he (Paul) said nothing that gave him (Paul) away, till the moment came to part, when he (Paul) stood frowning gloomily at the gathered clouds, behind which the great constellation must be striding still.

There was to be a little party at his (Paul) house the next day, at which she (Miriam) was to attend.

``I shan't come and meet you,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Oh, very well; it's not very nice out,'' (she)
she (Miriam) replied slowly.

``It's not that--only they don't like me to. They say I care more for you than for them. And you understand, don't you? You know it's only friendship.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam was astonished and hurt for him (Paul). It had cost him (Paul) an effort. She (Miriam) left him (Paul), wanting to spare him (Paul) any further humiliation. A fine rain blew in her (Miriam) face as she (Miriam) walked along the road. She (Miriam) was hurt deep down; and she (Miriam) despised him (Paul) for being blown about by any wind of authority. And in her (Miriam) heart of hearts, unconsciously, she (Miriam) felt that he (Paul) was trying to get away from her (Miriam). This she (Miriam) would never have acknowledged. She (Miriam) pitied him (Paul).

At this time Paul became an important factor in Jordan's warehouse. Mr. Pappleworth left to set up a business of his (Pappleworth) own, and Paul remained with Mr. Jordan as Spiral overseer. His (Paul) wages were to be raised to thirty shillings at the year-end, if things went well.

Still on Friday night Miriam often came down for her (Miriam) French lesson. Paul did not go so frequently to Willey Farm, and she (Miriam) grieved at the thought of her (Miriam) education's coming to end; moreover, they both loved to be together, in spite of discords. So they read Balzac, and did compositions, and felt highly cultured.

Friday night was reckoning night for the miners. Morel

``reckoned'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
--shared up the money of the stall--either in the New Inn at Bretty or in his (Paul) own house, according as his (Paul) fellow-butties wished. Barker had turned a non-drinker, so now the men reckoned at Morel's house.

Annie, who had been teaching away, was at home again. She (Annie) was still a tomboy; and she (Annie) was engaged to be married. Paul was studying design.

Morel was always in good spirits on Friday evening, unless the week's earnings were small. He (Paul) bustled immediately after his (Paul) dinner, prepared to get washed. It was decorum for the women to absent themselves while the men reckoned. Women were not supposed to spy into such a masculine privacy as the butties' reckoning, nor were they to know the exact amount of the week's earnings. So, whilst her (Morel) father was spluttering in the scullery, Annie went out to spend an hour with a neighbour. Mrs. Morel attended to her (Morel) baking.

``Shut that doo-er!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
bawled Morel furiously.

Annie banged it behind her (Annie), and was gone.

``If tha oppens it again while I'm weshin' me, I'll ma'e thy jaw rattle,'' (he)
he (father) threatened from the midst of his (father) soap-suds. Paul and the mother frowned to hear him (Paul).

Presently he (Paul) came running out of the scullery, with the soapy water dripping from him (Paul), dithering with cold.

``Oh, my sirs!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``Wheer's my towel?'' (he)

It was hung on a chair to warm before the fire, otherwise he (Paul) would have bullied and blustered. He (Paul) squatted on his (Paul) heels before the hot baking-fire to dry himself.

``F-ff-f!'' (he)
he (Paul) went, pretending to shudder with cold.

``Goodness, man, don't be such a kid!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``It's NOT cold.'' (unknown)

``Thee strip thysen stark nak'd to wesh thy flesh i' that scullery,'' (the miner)
said the miner, as he (Paul) rubbed his (Paul) hair;
``nowt b'r a ice-`ouse!'' (he)

``And I shouldn't make that fuss,'' (wife)
replied his (Paul) wife.

``No, tha'd drop down stiff, as dead as a door-knob, wi' thy nesh sides.'' (unknown)

``Why is a door-knob deader than anything else?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul, curious.

``Eh, I dunno; that's what they say,'' (father)
replied his (Paul) father.
``But there's that much draught i' yon scullery, as it blows through your ribs like through a five-barred gate.'' (unknown)

``It would have some difficulty in blowing through yours,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

Morel looked down ruefully at his (Paul) sides.

``Me!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed.
``I'm nowt b'r a skinned rabbit. My bones fair juts out on me.'' (unknown)

``I should like to know where,'' (wife)
retorted his (Paul) wife.

``Iv`ry-wheer! I'm nobbut a sack o' faggots.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel laughed. He (Paul) had still a wonderfully young body, muscular, without any fat. His (Paul) skin was smooth and clear. It might have been the body of a man of twenty-eight, except that there were, perhaps, too many blue scars, like tattoo-marks, where the coal-dust remained under the skin, and that his (man) chest was too hairy. But he (man) put his (man) hand on his (man) side ruefully. It was his (man) fixed belief that, because he (man) did not get fat, he (man) was as thin as a starved rat. Paul looked at his (Paul) father's thick, brownish hands all scarred, with broken nails, rubbing the fine smoothness of his (Paul) sides, and the incongruity struck him (Paul). It seemed strange they were the same flesh.

``I suppose,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to his (Paul) father,
``you had a good figure once.'' (father)

``Eh!'' (the miner)
exclaimed the miner, glancing round, startled and timid, like a child.

``He (I) had,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
exclaimed Mrs. Morel,
``if he (I) didn't hurtle himself up as if he (I) was trying to get in the smallest space he (I) could.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Me!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
exclaimed Morel--
``me a good figure! I wor niver much more n'r a skeleton.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Man!'' (wife)
cried his (Paul) wife,
``don't be such a pulamiter!'' (wife)

''`Strewth!'' (wife)
he (Paul) said.
``Tha's niver knowed me but what I looked as if I wor goin' off in a rapid decline.'' (She)

She (Morel) sat and laughed.

``You've had a constitution like iron,'' (she)
she (Morel) said;
``and never a man had a better start, if it was body that counted. You should have seen him (man) as a young man,'' (she)
she (Morel) cried suddenly to Paul, drawing herself up to imitate her (Morel) husband's once handsome bearing.

Morel watched her (Morel) shyly. He (Paul) saw again the passion she (Morel) had had for him (Paul). It blazed upon her (Morel) for a moment. He (Paul) was shy, rather scared, and humble. Yet again he (Paul) felt his (Paul) old glow. And then immediately he (Paul) felt the ruin he (Paul) had made during these years. He (Paul) wanted to bustle about, to run away from it.

``Gi'e my back a bit of a wesh,'' (he)
he (Paul) asked her (Morel).

His (Paul) wife brought a well-soaped flannel and clapped it on his (Paul) shoulders. He (Paul) gave a jump.

``Eh, tha mucky little `ussy!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried.
``Cowd as death!'' (unknown)

``You ought to have been a salamander,'' (she)
she (wife) laughed, washing his (Paul) back. It was very rarely she (wife) would do anything so personal for him (Paul). The children did those things.

``The next world won't be half hot enough for you,'' (she)
she (wife) added.

``No,'' (he)
he (Paul) said;
``tha`lt see as it's draughty for me.'' (he)

But she (wife) had finished. She (wife) wiped him (Paul) in a desultory fashion, and went upstairs, returning immediately with his (Paul) shifting-trousers. When he (Paul) was dried he (Paul) struggled into his (Paul) shirt. Then, ruddy and shiny, with hair on end, and his (Paul) flannelette shirt hanging over his (Paul) pit-trousers, he (Paul) stood warming the garments he (Paul) was going to put on. He (Paul) turned them, he (Paul) pulled them inside out, he (Paul) scorched them.

``Goodness, man!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Mrs. Morel,
``get dressed!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Should thee like to clap thysen into britches as cowd as a tub o' water?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

At last he (Paul) took off his (Paul) pit-trousers and donned decent black. He (Paul) did all this on the hearthrug, as he (Paul) would have done if Annie and her (Annie) familiar friends had been present.

Mrs. Morel turned the bread in the oven. Then from the red earthenware panchion of dough that stood in a corner she (Morel) took another handful of paste, worked it to the proper shape, and dropped it into a tin. As she (Morel) was doing so Barker knocked and entered. He (Barker) was a quiet, compact little man, who looked as if he (Barker) would go through a stone wall. His (Barker) black hair was cropped short, his (Barker) head was bony. Like most miners, he (Barker) was pale, but healthy and taut.

``Evenin', missis,'' (he)
he (Barker) nodded to Mrs. Morel, and he (Barker) seated himself with a sigh.

``Good-evening,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied cordially.

``Tha's made thy heels crack,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Morel.

``I dunno as I have,'' (Barker)
said Barker.

He (Barker) sat, as the men always did in Morel's kitchen, effacing himself rather.

``How's missis?'' (she)
she (Morel) asked of him (Morel).

He (Morel) had told her (Morel) some time back:

``We're expectin' us third just now, you see.'' (He)

``Well,'' (he)
he (Morel) answered, rubbing his (Morel) head,
``she (I) keeps pretty middlin', I think.'' (he)

``Let's see--when?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
asked Mrs. Morel.

``Well, I shouldn't be surprised any time now.'' (unknown)

``Ah! And she (I)'s kept fairly?'' (unknown)

``Yes, tidy.'' (unknown)

``That's a blessing, for she (I)'s none too strong.'' (unknown)

``No. An' I've done another silly trick.'' (unknown)

``What's that?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel knew Barker wouldn't do anything very silly.

``I'm come be-out th' market-bag.'' (unknown)

``You can have mine.'' (unknown)

``Nay, you'll be wantin' that yourself.'' (unknown)

``I shan't. I take a string bag always.'' (She)

She (Morel) saw the determined little collier buying in the week's groceries and meat on the Friday nights, and she (Morel) admired him (Barker).

``Barker's little, but he (Barker)'s ten times the man you are,'' (she)
she (Morel) said to her (Morel) husband.

Just then Wesson entered. He (Wesson) was thin, rather frail-looking, with a boyish ingenuousness and a slightly foolish smile, despite his (Wesson) seven children. But his (Wesson) wife was a passionate woman.

``I see you've kested me,'' (he)
he (Wesson) said, smiling rather vapidly.

``Yes,'' (Barker)
replied Barker.

The newcomer took off his (Barker) cap and his (Barker) big woollen muffler. His (Barker) nose was pointed and red.

``I'm afraid you're cold, Mr. Wesson,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``It's a bit nippy,'' (he)
he (Barker) replied.

``Then come to the fire.'' (unknown)

``Nay, I s'll do where I am.'' (Both colliers)

Both colliers sat away back. They could not be induced to come on to the hearth. The hearth is sacred to the family.

``Go thy ways i' th' armchair,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
cried Morel cheerily.

``Nay, thank yer; I'm very nicely here.'' (unknown)

``Yes, come, of course,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
insisted Mrs. Morel.

He (Barker) rose and went awkwardly. He (Barker) sat in Morel's armchair awkwardly. It was too great a familiarity. But the fire made him (Barker) blissfully happy.

``And how's that chest of yours?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
demanded Mrs. Morel.

He (Barker) smiled again, with his (Barker) blue eyes rather sunny.

``Oh, it's very middlin','' (he)
he (Barker) said.

``Wi' a rattle in it like a kettle-drum,'' (Barker)
said Barker shortly.

``T-t-t-t!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
went Mrs. Morel rapidly with her (Morel) tongue.
``Did you have that flannel singlet made?'' (unknown)

``Not yet,'' (he)
he (Barker) smiled.

``Then, why didn't you?'' (she)
she (Morel) cried.

``It'll come,'' (he)
he (Barker) smiled.

``Ah, an' Doomsday!'' (Barker)
exclaimed Barker.

Barker and Morel were both impatient of Wesson. But, then, they were both as hard as nails, physically.

When Morel was nearly ready he (Barker) pushed the bag of money to Paul.

``Count it, boy,'' (he)
he (Paul) asked humbly.

Paul impatiently turned from his (Paul) books and pencil, tipped the bag upside down on the table. There was a five-pound bag of silver, sovereigns and loose money. He (Paul) counted quickly, referred to the checks--the written papers giving amount of coal--put the money in order. Then Barker glanced at the checks.

Mrs. Morel went upstairs, and the three men came to table. Morel, as master of the house, sat in his (Barker) armchair, with his (Barker) back to the hot fire. The two butties had cooler seats. None of them counted the money.

``What did we say Simpson's was?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
asked Morel; and the butties cavilled for a minute over the dayman's earnings. Then the amount was put aside.

``An' Bill Naylor's?'' (unknown)

This money also was taken from the pack.

Then, because Wesson lived in one of the company's houses, and his (Wesson) rent had been deducted, Morel and Barker took four-and-six each. And because Morel's coals had come, and the leading was stopped, Barker and Wesson took four shillings each. Then it was plain sailing. Morel gave each of them a sovereign till there were no more sovereigns; each half a crown till there were no more half-crowns; each a shilling till there were no more shillings. If there was anything at the end that wouldn't split, Morel took it and stood drinks.

Then the three men rose and went. Morel scuttled out of the house before his (Barker) wife came down. She (Morel) heard the door close, and descended. She (Morel) looked hastily at the bread in the oven. Then, glancing on the table, she (Morel) saw her (Morel) money lying. Paul had been working all the time. But now he (Paul) felt his (Paul) mother counting the week's money, and her (mother) wrath rising,

``T-t-t-t-t!'' (mother)
went her (mother) tongue.

He (Paul) frowned. He (Paul) could not work when she (mother) was cross. She (mother) counted again.

``A measly twenty-five shillings!'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed.
``How much was the cheque?'' (unknown)

``Ten pounds eleven,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul irritably. He (Paul) dreaded what was coming.

``And he (Naylor) gives me a scrattlin' twenty-five, an' his (Naylor) club this week! But I know him (Naylor). He (Naylor) thinks because YOU

``RE earning he (Naylor) needn't keep the house any longer. No, all he (Naylor) has to do with his (Naylor) money is to guttle it. But I'll show him (Naylor)!'' (unknown)

``Oh, mother, don't!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
cried Paul.

``Don't what, I should like to know?'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed.

``Don't carry on again. I can't work.'' (She)

She (mother) went very quiet.

``Yes, it's all very well,'' (she)
she (mother) said;
``but how do you think I'm going to manage?'' (she)

``Well, it won't make it any better to whittle about it.'' (unknown)

``I should like to know what you'd do if you had it to put up with.'' (unknown)

``It won't be long. You can have my money. Let him (it) go to hell.'' (He)

He (Paul) went back to his (Paul) work, and she (mother) tied her (mother) bonnet-strings grimly. When she (mother) was fretted he (Paul) could not bear it. But now he (Paul) began to insist on her (mother) recognizing him (Paul).

``The two loaves at the top,'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``will be done in twenty minutes. Don't forget them.'' (she)

``All right,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered; and she (mother) went to market.

He (Paul) remained alone working. But his (Paul) usual intense concentration became unsettled. He (Paul) listened for the yard-gate. At a quarter-past seven came a low knock, and Miriam entered.

``All alone?'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``Yes.'' (she)

As if at home, she (Miriam) took off her (Miriam) tam-o'-shanter and her (Miriam) long coat, hanging them up. It gave him (Paul) a thrill. This might be their own house, his (Paul) and hers. Then she (Miriam) came back and peered over his (Paul) work.

``What is it?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Still design, for decorating stuffs, and for embroidery.'' (She)

She (Miriam) bent short-sightedly over the drawings.

It irritated him (Paul) that she (Miriam) peered so into everything that was his (Paul), searching him (Paul) out. He (Paul) went into the parlour and returned with a bundle of brownish linen. Carefully unfolding it, he (Paul) spread it on the floor. It proved to be a curtain or portiere, beautifully stencilled with a design on roses.

``Ah, how beautiful!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried.

The spread cloth, with its wonderful reddish roses and dark green stems, all so simple, and somehow so wicked-looking, lay at her (Miriam) feet. She (Miriam) went on her (Miriam) knees before it, her (Miriam) dark curls dropping. He (Paul) saw her (Miriam) crouched voluptuously before his (Paul) work, and his (Paul) heart beat quickly. Suddenly she (Miriam) looked up at him (Paul).

``Why does it seem cruel?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``What?'' (unknown)

``There seems a feeling of cruelty about it,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``It's jolly good, whether or not,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied, folding up his (Paul) work with a lover's hands.

She (Miriam) rose slowly, pondering.

``And what will you do with it?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Send it to Liberty's. I did it for my mother, but I think she (mother)'d rather have the money.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam. He (Paul) had spoken with a touch of bitterness, and Miriam sympathised. Money would have been nothing to HER.

He (Paul) took the cloth back into the parlour. When he (Paul) returned he (Paul) threw to Miriam a smaller piece. It was a cushion-cover with the same design.

``I did that for you,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (Miriam) fingered the work with trembling hands, and did not speak. He (Paul) became embarrassed.

``By Jove, the bread!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried.

He (Paul) took the top loaves out, tapped them vigorously. They were done. He (Paul) put them on the hearth to cool. Then he (Paul) went to the scullery, wetted his (Paul) hands, scooped the last white dough out of the punchion, and dropped it in a baking-tin. Miriam was still bent over her (Miriam) painted cloth. He (Paul) stood rubbing the bits of dough from his (Paul) hands.

``You do like it?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

She (Miriam) looked up at him (Paul), with her (Miriam) dark eyes one flame of love. He (Paul) laughed uncomfortably. Then he (Paul) began to talk about the design. There was for him (Paul) the most intense pleasure in talking about his (Paul) work to Miriam. All his (Paul) passion, all his (Paul) wild blood, went into this intercourse with her (Miriam), when he (Paul) talked and conceived his (Paul) work. She (Miriam) brought forth to him (Paul) his (Paul) imaginations. She (Miriam) did not understand, any more than a woman understands when she (Miriam) conceives a child in her (Miriam) womb. But this was life for her (Miriam) and for him (Paul).

While they were talking, a young woman of about twenty-two, small and pale, hollow-eyed, yet with a relentless look about her (woman), entered the room. She (woman) was a friend at the Morel's.

``Take your things off,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``No, I'm not stopping.'' (She)

She (woman) sat down in the armchair opposite Paul and Miriam, who were on the sofa. Miriam moved a little farther from him (Paul). The room was hot, with a scent of new bread. Brown, crisp loaves stood on the hearth.

``I shouldn't have expected to see you here to-night, Miriam Leivers,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice wickedly.

``Why not?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
murmured Miriam huskily.

``Why, let's look at your shoes.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam remained uncomfortably still.

``If tha doesna tha durs`na,'' (Beatrice)
laughed Beatrice.

Miriam put her (Miriam) feet from under her (Miriam) dress. Her (Miriam) boots had that queer, irresolute, rather pathetic look about them, which showed how self-conscious and self-mistrustful she (Miriam) was. And they were covered with mud.

``Glory! You're a positive muck-heap,'' (Beatrice)
exclaimed Beatrice.
``Who cleans your boots?'' (unknown)

``I clean them myself.'' (unknown)

``Then you wanted a job,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice. ``It would ha' taken a lot of men to ha' brought me down here to-night. But love laughs at sludge, doesn't it,
``Postle my duck?'' (unknown)

``Inter alia,'' (he)
he (Brown) said.

``Oh, Lord! are you going to spout foreign languages? What does it mean, Miriam?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

There was a fine sarcasm in the last question, but Miriam did not see it.

''`Among other things,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
I believe,'' she (Miriam) said humbly.

Beatrice put her (Beatrice) tongue between her (Beatrice) teeth and laughed wickedly.

''`Among other things,'' (Beatrice)
`Postle?'' she (Beatrice) repeated.
``Do you mean love laughs at mothers, and fathers, and sisters, and brothers, and men friends, and lady friends, and even at the b`loved himself?'' (She)

She (Beatrice) affected a great innocence.

``In fact, it's one big smile,'' (he)
he (Brown) replied.

``Up its sleeve,

``Postle Morel--you believe me,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
she (Beatrice) said; and she (Beatrice) went off into another burst of wicked, silent laughter.

Miriam sat silent, withdrawn into herself. Every one of Paul's friends delighted in taking sides against her (Miriam), and he (Paul) left her (Miriam) in the lurch--seemed almost to have a sort of revenge upon her (Miriam) then.

``Are you still at school?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
asked Miriam of Beatrice.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``You've not had your notice, then?'' (unknown)

``I expect it at Easter.'' (unknown)

``Isn't it an awful shame, to turn you off merely because you didn't pass the exam?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice coldly.

``Agatha says you're as good as any teacher anywhere. It seems to me ridiculous. I wonder why you didn't pass.'' (unknown)

``Short of brains, eh, `Postle?'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice briefly.

``Only brains to bite with,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
replied Paul, laughing.

``Nuisance!'' (she)
she (Beatrice) cried; and, springing from her (Beatrice) seat, she (Beatrice) rushed and boxed his (Paul) ears. She (Beatrice) had beautiful small hands. He (Paul) held her (Beatrice) wrists while she (Beatrice) wrestled with him (Paul). At last she (Beatrice) broke free, and seized two handfuls of his (Paul) thick, dark brown hair, which she (Beatrice) shook.

``Beat!'' (he)
he (Paul) said, as he (Paul) pulled his (Paul) hair straight with his (Paul) fingers.
``I hate you!'' (She)

She (Beatrice) laughed with glee.

``Mind!'' (she)
she (Beatrice) said.
``I want to sit next to you.'' (unknown)

``I'd as lief be neighbours with a vixen,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, nevertheless making place for her (Beatrice) between him (Paul) and Miriam.

``Did it ruffle his (Short) pretty hair, then!'' (she)
she (Beatrice) cried; and, with her (Beatrice) hair-comb, she (Beatrice) combed him (Paul) straight.
``And his (Short) nice little moustache!'' (she)
she (Beatrice) exclaimed. She (Beatrice) tilted his (Paul) head back and combed his (Paul) young moustache.
``It's a wicked moustache, `Postle,'' (she)
she (Beatrice) said.
``It's a red for danger. Have you got any of those cigarettes?'' (He)

He (Paul) pulled his (Paul) cigarette-case from his (Paul) pocket. Beatrice looked inside it.

``And fancy me having Connie's last cig.,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice, putting the thing between her (Beatrice) teeth. He (Paul) held a lit match to her (Beatrice), and she (Beatrice) puffed daintily.

``Thanks so much, darling,'' (she)
she (Beatrice) said mockingly.

It gave her (Beatrice) a wicked delight.

``Don't you think he (Short) does it nicely, Miriam?'' (she)
she (Beatrice) asked.

``Oh, very!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

He (Paul) took a cigarette for himself.

``Light, old boy?'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice, tilting her (Beatrice) cigarette at him (Paul).

He (Paul) bent forward to her (Beatrice) to light his (Paul) cigarette at hers. She (Beatrice) was winking at him (Paul) as he (Paul) did so. Miriam saw his (Paul) eyes trembling with mischief, and his (Paul) full, almost sensual, mouth quivering. He (Paul) was not himself, and she (Miriam) could not bear it. As he (Paul) was now, she (Miriam) had no connection with him (Paul); she (Miriam) might as well not have existed. She (Miriam) saw the cigarette dancing on his (Paul) full red lips. She (Miriam) hated his (Paul) thick hair for being tumbled loose on his (Paul) forehead.

``Sweet boy!'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice, tipping up his (Paul) chin and giving him (Paul) a little kiss on the cheek.

``I s'll kiss thee back, Beat,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Tha wunna!'' (she)
she (Beatrice) giggled, jumping up and going away.
``Isn't he (boy) shameless, Miriam?'' (unknown)

``Quite,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.
``By the way, aren't you forgetting the bread?'' (unknown)

``By Jove!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried, flinging open the oven door.

Out puffed the bluish smoke and a smell of burned bread.

``Oh, golly!'' (Beatrice)
cried Beatrice, coming to his (Paul) side. He (Paul) crouched before the oven, she (Beatrice) peered over his (Paul) shoulder.
``This is what comes of the oblivion of love, my boy.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul was ruefully removing the loaves. One was burnt black on the hot side; another was hard as a brick.

``Poor mater!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``You want to grate it,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice.
``Fetch me the nutmeg-grater.'' (She)

She (Beatrice) arranged the bread in the oven. He (Paul) brought the grater, and she (Beatrice) grated the bread on to a newspaper on the table. He (Paul) set the doors open to blow away the smell of burned bread. Beatrice grated away, puffing her (Beatrice) cigarette, knocking the charcoal off the poor loaf.

``My word, Miriam! you're in for it this time,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice.

``I!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
exclaimed Miriam in amazement.

``You'd better be gone when his (boy) mother comes in. I know why King Alfred burned the cakes. Now I see it!

``Postle would fix up a tale about his (Alfred) work making him (Alfred) forget, if he (Alfred) thought it would wash. If that old woman had come in a bit sooner, she (woman)'d have boxed the brazen thing's ears who made the oblivion, instead of poor Alfred's.'' (She)

She (Beatrice) giggled as she (Beatrice) scraped the loaf. Even Miriam laughed in spite of herself. Paul mended the fire ruefully.

The garden gate was heard to bang.

``Quick!'' (Beatrice)
cried Beatrice, giving Paul the scraped loaf.
``Wrap it up in a damp towel.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul disappeared into the scullery. Beatrice hastily blew her (Beatrice) scrapings into the fire, and sat down innocently. Annie came bursting in. She (Annie) was an abrupt, quite smart young woman. She (Annie) blinked in the strong light.

``Smell of burning!'' (she)
she (Annie) exclaimed.

``It's the cigarettes,'' (Beatrice)
replied Beatrice demurely.

``Where's Paul?'' (Leonard)

Leonard had followed Annie. He (Leonard) had a long comic face and blue eyes, very sad.

``I suppose he (Paul)'s left you to settle it between you,'' (he)
he (Leonard) said. He (Leonard) nodded sympathetically to Miriam, and became gently sarcastic to Beatrice.

``No,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice,
``he (Paul)'s gone off with number nine.'' (Beatrice)

``I just met number five inquiring for him (Paul),'' (Leonard)
said Leonard.

``Yes--we're going to share him (Paul) up like Solomon's baby,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice.

Annie laughed.

``Oh, ay,'' (Leonard)
said Leonard.
``And which bit should you have?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (Beatrice)
said Beatrice.
``I'll let all the others pick first.'' (unknown)

``An' you'd have the leavings, like?'' (Leonard)
said Leonard, twisting up a comic face.

Annie was looking in the oven. Miriam sat ignored. Paul entered.

``This bread's a fine sight, our Paul,'' (Annie)
said Annie.

``Then you should stop an' look after it,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``You mean YOU should do what you're reckoning to do,'' (Annie)
replied Annie.

``He (Paul) should, shouldn't he (Paul)!'' (Beatrice)
cried Beatrice.

``I s'd think he (Paul)'d got plenty on hand,'' (Leonard)
said Leonard.

``You had a nasty walk, didn't you, Miriam?'' (Annie)
said Annie.

``Yes--but I'd been in all week--'' (Leonard)

``And you wanted a bit of a change, like,'' (Leonard)
insinuated Leonard kindly.

``Well, you can't be stuck in the house for ever,'' (Annie)
Annie agreed. She (Annie) was quite amiable. Beatrice pulled on her (Beatrice) coat, and went out with Leonard and Annie. She (Annie) would meet her (Annie) own boy.

``Don't forget that bread, our Paul,'' (Annie)
cried Annie.
``Good-night, Miriam. I don't think it will rain.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

When they had all gone, Paul fetched the swathed loaf, unwrapped it, and surveyed it sadly.

``It's a mess!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``But,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
answered Miriam impatiently,
``what is it, after all--twopence, ha`penny.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

``Yes, but--it's the mater's precious baking, and she (Miriam)'ll take it to heart. However, it's no good bothering.'' (He)

He (Paul) took the loaf back into the scullery. There was a little distance between him (Paul) and Miriam. He (Paul) stood balanced opposite her (Miriam) for some moments considering, thinking of his (Paul) behaviour with Beatrice. He (Paul) felt guilty inside himself, and yet glad. For some inscrutable reason it served Miriam right. He (Paul) was not going to repent. She (Miriam) wondered what he (Paul) was thinking of as he (Paul) stood suspended. His (Paul) thick hair was tumbled over his (Paul) forehead. Why might she (Miriam) not push it back for him (Paul), and remove the marks of Beatrice's comb? Why might she (Beatrice) not press his (Paul) body with her (Beatrice) two hands. It looked so firm, and every whit living. And he (Paul) would let other girls, why not her (Beatrice)?

Suddenly he (Paul) started into life. It made her (Beatrice) quiver almost with terror as he (Paul) quickly pushed the hair off his (Paul) forehead and came towards her (Beatrice).

``Half-past eight!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``We'd better buck up. Where's your French?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam shyly and rather bitterly produced her (Miriam) exercise-book. Every week she (Miriam) wrote for him (Paul) a sort of diary of her (Miriam) inner life, in her (Miriam) own French. He (Paul) had found this was the only way to get her (Miriam) to do compositions. And her (Miriam) diary was mostly a love-letter. He (Paul) would read it now; she (Miriam) felt as if her (Miriam) soul's history were going to be desecrated by him (Paul) in his (Paul) present mood. He (Paul) sat beside her (Miriam). She (Miriam) watched his (Paul) hand, firm and warm, rigorously scoring her (Miriam) work. He (Paul) was reading only the French, ignoring her (Miriam) soul that was there. But gradually his (Paul) hand forgot its work. He (Paul) read in silence, motionless. She (Miriam) quivered.

'''_Ce matin les oiseaux m`ont eveille,''' (She)
he (Paul) read.
''`Il faisait encore un crepuscule. Mais la petite fenetre de ma chambre etait bleme, et puis, jaune, et tous les oiseaux du bois eclaterent dans un chanson vif et resonnant. Toute l'aube tressaillit. J'avais reve de vous. Est-ce que vous voyez aussi l'aube? Les oiseaux m`eveillent presque tous les matins, et toujours il y a quelque chose de terreur dans le cri des grives. Il est si clair_--''' (he)

Miriam sat tremulous, half ashamed. He (Les) remained quite still, trying to understand. He (Les) only knew she (Miriam) loved him (Les). He (Les) was afraid of her (Miriam) love for him (Les). It was too good for him (Les), and he (Les) was inadequate. His (Les) own love was at fault, not hers. Ashamed, he (Les) corrected her (Miriam) work, humbly writing above her (Miriam) words.

``Look,'' (he)
he (Les) said quietly,
``the past participle conjugated with _avoir_ agrees with the direct object when it precedes.'' (he)

She (Miriam) bent forward, trying to see and to understand. Her (Miriam) free, fine curls tickled his (Les) face. He (Les) started as if they had been red hot, shuddering. He (Les) saw her (Miriam) peering forward at the page, her (Miriam) red lips parted piteously, the black hair springing in fine strands across her (Miriam) tawny, ruddy cheek. She (Miriam) was coloured like a pomegranate for richness. His (Les) breath came short as he (Les) watched her (Miriam). Suddenly she (Miriam) looked up at him (Les). Her (Miriam) dark eyes were naked with their love, afraid, and yearning. His (Les) eyes, too, were dark, and they hurt her (Miriam). They seemed to master her (Miriam). She (Miriam) lost all her (Miriam) self-control, was exposed in fear. And he (Les) knew, before he (Les) could kiss her (Miriam), he (Les) must drive something out of himself. And a touch of hate for her (Miriam) crept back again into his (Les) heart. He (Les) returned to her (Miriam) exercise.

Suddenly he (Les) flung down the pencil, and was at the oven in a leap, turning the bread. For Miriam he (Les) was too quick. She (Miriam) started violently, and it hurt her (Miriam) with real pain. Even the way he (Les) crouched before the oven hurt her (Miriam). There seemed to be something cruel in it, something cruel in the swift way he (Les) pitched the bread out of the tins, caught it up again. If only he (Les) had been gentle in his (Les) movements she (Miriam) would have felt so rich and warm. As it was, she (Miriam) was hurt.

He (Les) returned and finished the exercise.

``You've done well this week,'' (he)
he (Les) said.

She (Miriam) saw he (Les) was flattered by her (Miriam) diary. It did not repay her (Miriam) entirely.

``You really do blossom out sometimes,'' (he)
he (Les) said.
``You ought to write poetry.'' (She)

She (Miriam) lifted her (Miriam) head with joy, then she (Miriam) shook it mistrustfully.

``I don't trust myself,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``You should try!'' (she)

Again she (Miriam) shook her (Miriam) head.

``Shall we read, or is it too late?'' (he)
he (Les) asked.

``It is late--but we can read just a little,'' (she)
she (Miriam) pleaded.

She (Miriam) was really getting now the food for her (Miriam) life during the next week. He (Les) made her (Miriam) copy Baudelaire's

``Le Balcon'' (Baudelaire)
. Then he (Les) read it for her (Miriam). His (Les) voice was soft and caressing, but growing almost brutal. He (Les) had a way of lifting his (Les) lips and showing his (Les) teeth, passionately and bitterly, when he (Les) was much moved. This he (Les) did now. It made Miriam feel as if he (Les) were trampling on her (Miriam). She (Miriam) dared not look at him (Les), but sat with her (Miriam) head bowed. She (Miriam) could not understand why he (Les) got into such a tumult and fury. It made her (Miriam) wretched. She (Miriam) did not like Baudelaire, on the whole--nor Verlaine.

``Behold her (Le) singing in the field Yon solitary highland lass.'' (unknown)

That nourished her (Miriam) heart. So did

``Fair Ines'' (unknown)
. And--

``It was a beauteous evening, calm and pure, And breathing holy quiet like a nun.'' (unknown)

These were like herself. And there was he (Les), saying in his (Les) throat bitterly:

''_Tu te rappelleras la beaute des caresses_.'' (he)

The poem was finished; he (Les) took the bread out of the oven, arranging the burnt loaves at the bottom of the panchion, the good ones at the top. The desiccated loaf remained swathed up in the scullery.

``Mater needn't know till morning,'' (he)
he (Les) said.
``It won't upset her (nun) so much then as at night.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam looked in the bookcase, saw what postcards and letters he (Les) had received, saw what books were there. She (Miriam) took one that had interested him (Les). Then he (Les) turned down the gas and they set off. He (Les) did not trouble to lock the door.

He (Les) was not home again until a quarter to eleven. His (Les) mother was seated in the rocking-chair. Annie, with a rope of hair hanging down her (Annie) back, remained sitting on a low stool before the fire, her (Annie) elbows on her (Annie) knees, gloomily. On the table stood the offending loaf unswathed. Paul entered rather breathless. No one spoke. His (Paul) mother was reading the little local newspaper. He (Paul) took off his (Paul) coat, and went to sit down on the sofa. His (Paul) mother moved curtly aside to let him (Paul) pass. No one spoke. He (Paul) was very uncomfortable. For some minutes he (Paul) sat pretending to read a piece of paper he (Paul) found on the table. Then--

``I forgot that bread, mother,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

There was no answer from either woman.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``it's only twopence ha`penny. I can pay you for that.'' (he)

Being angry, he (Paul) put three pennies on the table and slid them towards his (Paul) mother. She (mother) turned away her (mother) head. Her (mother) mouth was shut tightly.

``Yes,'' (Annie)
said Annie,
``you don't know how badly my mother is!'' (Annie)

The girl sat staring glumly into the fire.

``Why is she (mother) badly?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul, in his (Paul) overbearing way.

``Well!'' (Annie)
said Annie.
``She (mother) could scarcely get home.'' (He)

He (Paul) looked closely at his (Paul) mother. She (Annie) looked ill.

``WHY could you scarcely get home?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked her (Annie), still sharply. She (Annie) would not answer.

``I found her (mother) as white as a sheet sitting here,'' (Annie)
said Annie, with a suggestion of tears in her (Annie) voice.

``Well, WHY?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
insisted Paul. His (Paul) brows were knitting, his (Paul) eyes dilating passionately.

``It was enough to upset anybody,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel,
``hugging those parcels--meat, and green-groceries, and a pair of curtains--'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Well, why DID you hug them; you needn't have done.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Then who would?'' (unknown)

``Let Annie fetch the meat.'' (unknown)

``Yes, and I WOULD fetch the meat, but how was I to know. You were off with Miriam, instead of being in when my mother came.'' (unknown)

``And what was the matter with you?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul of his (Paul) mother.

``I suppose it's my heart,'' (she)
she (mother) replied. Certainly she (mother) looked bluish round the mouth.

``And have you felt it before?'' (unknown)

``Yes--often enough.'' (unknown)

``Then why haven't you told me?--and why haven't you seen a doctor?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel shifted in her (Morel) chair, angry with him (Paul) for his (Paul) hectoring.

``You'd never notice anything,'' (Annie)
said Annie.
``You're too eager to be off with Miriam.'' (unknown)

``Oh, am I--and any worse than you with Leonard?'' (unknown)

``I was in at a quarter to ten.'' (unknown)

There was silence in the room for a time.

``I should have thought,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel bitterly,
``that she (Miriam) wouldn't have occupied you so entirely as to burn a whole ovenful of bread.'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``Beatrice was here as well as she (Beatrice).'' (unknown)

``Very likely. But we know why the bread is spoilt.'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (he)
he (Paul) flashed.

``Because you were engrossed with Miriam,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel hotly.

``Oh, very well--then it was NOT!'' (he)
he (Paul) replied angrily.

He (Paul) was distressed and wretched. Seizing a paper, he (Paul) began to read. Annie, her (Annie) blouse unfastened, her (Annie) long ropes of hair twisted into a plait, went up to bed, bidding him (Paul) a very curt good-night.

Paul sat pretending to read. He (Paul) knew his (Paul) mother wanted to upbraid him (Paul). He (Paul) also wanted to know what had made her (mother) ill, for he (Paul) was troubled. So, instead of running away to bed, as he (Paul) would have liked to do, he (Paul) sat and waited. There was a tense silence. The clock ticked loudly.

``You'd better go to bed before your father comes in,'' (the mother)
said the mother harshly.
``And if you're going to have anything to eat, you'd better get it.'' (unknown)

``I don't want anything.'' (mother)

It was his (Paul) mother's custom to bring him (Paul) some trifle for supper on Friday night, the night of luxury for the colliers. He (Paul) was too angry to go and find it in the pantry this night. This insulted her (mother).

``If I WANTED you to go to Selby on Friday night, I can imagine the scene,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``But you're never too tired to go if SHE will come for you. Nay, you neither want to eat nor drink then.'' (unknown)

``I can't let her (you) go alone.'' (unknown)

``Can't you? And why does she (you) come?'' (unknown)

``Not because I ask her (you).'' (unknown)

``She (you) doesn't come without you want her (you)--'' (he)

``Well, what if I DO want her (you)--'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.

``Why, nothing, if it was sensible or reasonable. But to go trapseing up there miles and miles in the mud, coming home at midnight, and got to go to Nottingham in the morning--'' (unknown)

``If I hadn't, you'd be just the same.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I should, because there's no sense in it. Is she (you) so fascinating that you must follow her (you) all that way?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel was bitterly sarcastic. She (Morel) sat still, with averted face, stroking with a rhythmic, jerked movement, the black sateen of her (Morel) apron. It was a movement that hurt Paul to see.

``I do like her (you),'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``but--'' (he)

``LIKE her (you)!'' (he)
said Mrs. Morel, in the same biting tones.
``It seems to me you like nothing and nobody else. There's neither Annie, nor me, nor anyone now for you.'' (unknown)

``What nonsense, mother--you know I don't love her (mother)--I--I tell you I DON

``T love her (mother)--she (mother) doesn't even walk with my arm, because I don't want her (mother) to.'' (unknown)

``Then why do you fly to her (mother) so often?'' (unknown)

``I DO like to talk to her (mother)--I never said I didn't. But I DON

``T love her (mother).'' (unknown)

``Is there nobody else to talk to?'' (unknown)

``Not about the things we talk of. There's a lot of things that you're not interested in, that--'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``What things?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel was so intense that Paul began to pant.

``Why--painting--and books. YOU don't care about Herbert Spencer.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (unknown)
was the sad reply.
``And YOU won't at my age.'' (unknown)

``Well, but I do now--and Miriam does--'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``And how do you know,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
Mrs. Morel flashed defiantly,
``that I shouldn't. Do you ever try me!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

``But you don't, mother, you know you don't care whether a picture's decorative or not; you don't care what MANNER it is in.'' (unknown)

``How do you know I don't care? Do you ever try me? Do you ever talk to me about these things, to try?'' (unknown)

``But it's not that that matters to you, mother, you know t's not.'' (unknown)

``What is it, then--what is it, then, that matters to me?'' (she)
she (Morel) flashed. He (Paul) knitted his (Paul) brows with pain.

``You're old, mother, and we're young.'' (He)

He (Paul) only meant that the interests of HER age were not the interests of his (Paul). But he (Paul) realised the moment he (Paul) had spoken that he (Paul) had said the wrong thing.

``Yes, I know it well--I am old. And therefore I may stand aside; I have nothing more to do with you. You only want me to wait on you--the rest is for Miriam.'' (He)

He (Paul) could not bear it. Instinctively he (Paul) realised that he (Paul) was life to her (Morel). And, after all, she (Morel) was the chief thing to him (Paul), the only supreme thing.

``You know it isn't, mother, you know it isn't!'' (She)

She (Morel) was moved to pity by his (Paul) cry.

``It looks a great deal like it,'' (she)
she (Morel) said, half putting aside her (Morel) despair.

``No, mother--I really DON

``T love her (mother). I talk to her (mother), but I want to come home to you.'' (He)

He (Paul) had taken off his (Paul) collar and tie, and rose, bare-throated, to go to bed. As he (Paul) stooped to kiss his (Paul) mother, she (mother) threw her (mother) arms round his (Paul) neck, hid her (mother) face on his (Paul) shoulder, and cried, in a whimpering voice, so unlike her (mother) own that he (Paul) writhed in agony:

``I can't bear it. I could let another woman--but not her (woman). She (woman)'d leave me no room, not a bit of room--'' (he)

And immediately he (Paul) hated Miriam bitterly.

``And I've never--you know, Paul--I've never had a husband--not really--'' (He)

He (Paul) stroked his (Paul) mother's hair, and his (Paul) mouth was on her (mother) throat.

``And she (woman) exults so in taking you from me--she (woman)'s not like ordinary girls.'' (unknown)

``Well, I don't love her (woman), mother,'' (he)
he (Paul) murmured, bowing his (Paul) head and hiding his (Paul) eyes on her (mother) shoulder in misery. His (Paul) mother kissed him (Paul) a long, fervent kiss.

``My boy!'' (she)
she (mother) said, in a voice trembling with passionate love.

Without knowing, he (Paul) gently stroked her (mother) face.

``There,'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother,
``now go to bed. You'll be so tired in the morning.'' (mother)
As she (mother) was speaking she (mother) heard her (mother) husband coming.
``There's your father--now go.'' (she)
Suddenly she (mother) looked at him (husband) almost as if in fear.
``Perhaps I'm selfish. If you want her (mother), take her (mother), my boy.'' (mother)

His (husband) mother looked so strange, Paul kissed her (mother), trembling.

``Ha--mother!'' (he)
he (Paul) said softly.

Morel came in, walking unevenly. His (Paul) hat was over one corner of his (Paul) eye. He (Paul) balanced in the doorway.

``At your mischief again?'' (he)
he (Paul) said venomously.

Mrs. Morel's emotion turned into sudden hate of the drunkard who had come in thus upon her (Morel).

``At any rate, it is sober,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

``H'm--h'm! h'm--h'm!'' (he)
he (drunkard) sneered. He (drunkard) went into the passage, hung up his (drunkard) hat and coat. Then they heard him (drunkard) go down three steps to the pantry. He (drunkard) returned with a piece of pork-pie in his (drunkard) fist. It was what Mrs. Morel had bought for her (Morel) son.

``Nor was that bought for you. If you can give me no more than twenty-five shillings, I'm sure I'm not going to buy you pork-pie to stuff, after you've swilled a bellyful of beer.'' (unknown)

``Wha-at--wha-at!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
snarled Morel, toppling in his (drunkard) balance.
``Wha-at--not for me?'' (He)
He (drunkard) looked at the piece of meat and crust, and suddenly, in a vicious spurt of temper, flung it into the fire.

Paul started to his (Paul) feet.

``Waste your own stuff!'' (he)
he (Paul) cried.

``What--what!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
suddenly shouted Morel, jumping up and clenching his (Paul) fist.
``I'll show yer, yer young jockey!'' (unknown)

``All right!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul viciously, putting his (Paul) head on one side.
``Show me!'' (He)

He (Paul) would at that moment dearly have loved to have a smack at something. Morel was half crouching, fists up, ready to spring. The young man stood, smiling with his (man) lips.

``Ussha!'' (the father)
hissed the father, swiping round with a great stroke just past his (man) son's face. He (man) dared not, even though so close, really touch the young man, but swerved an inch away.

``Right!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, his (Paul) eyes upon the side of his (Paul) father's mouth, where in another instant his (Paul) fist would have hit. He (Paul) ached for that stroke. But he (Paul) heard a faint moan from behind. His (Paul) mother was deadly pale and dark at the mouth. Morel was dancing up to deliver another blow.

``Father!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, so that the word rang.

Morel started, and stood at attention.

``Mother!'' (the boy)
moaned the boy.
``Mother!'' (She)

She (Morel) began to struggle with herself. Her (Morel) open eyes watched him (Paul), although she (Morel) could not move. Gradually she (Morel) was coming to herself. He (Paul) laid her (Morel) down on the sofa, and ran upstairs for a little whisky, which at last she (Morel) could sip. The tears were hopping down his (Paul) face. As he (Paul) kneeled in front of her (Morel) he (Paul) did not cry, but the tears ran down his (Paul) face quickly. Morel, on the opposite side of the room, sat with his (Paul) elbows on his (Paul) knees glaring across.

``What's a-matter with `er?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``Faint!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
replied Paul.

``H'm!'' (The man)

The elderly man began to unlace his (man) boots. He (man) stumbled off to bed. His (man) last fight was fought in that home.

Paul kneeled there, stroking his (Paul) mother's hand.

``Don't be poorly, mother--don't be poorly!'' (he)
he (Paul) said time after time.

``It's nothing, my boy,'' (she)
she (mother) murmured.

At last he (Paul) rose, fetched in a large piece of coal, and raked the fire. Then he (Paul) cleared the room, put everything straight, laid the things for breakfast, and brought his (Paul) mother's candle.

``Can you go to bed, mother?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I'll come.'' (unknown)

``Sleep with Annie, mother, not with him (boy).'' (unknown)

``No. I'll sleep in my own bed.'' (unknown)

``Don't sleep with him (boy), mother.'' (unknown)

``I'll sleep in my own bed.'' (She)

She (mother) rose, and he (Paul) turned out the gas, then followed her (mother) closely upstairs, carrying her (mother) candle. On the landing he (Paul) kissed her (mother) close.

``Good-night, mother.'' (unknown)

``Good-night!'' (she)
she (mother) said.

He (Paul) pressed his (Paul) face upon the pillow in a fury of misery. And yet, somewhere in his (Paul) soul, he (Paul) was at peace because he (Paul) still loved his (Paul) mother best. It was the bitter peace of resignation.

The efforts of his (Paul) father to conciliate him (Paul) next day were a great humiliation to him (Paul).

Everybody tried to forget the scene.

CHAPTER IX

DEFEAT OF MIRIAM

PAUL was dissatisfied with himself and with everything. The deepest of his (Paul) love belonged to his (Paul) mother. When he (Paul) felt he (Paul) had hurt her (mother), or wounded his (Paul) love for her (mother), he (Paul) could not bear it. Now it was spring, and there was battle between him (Paul) and Miriam. This year he (Paul) had a good deal against her (Miriam). She (Miriam) was vaguely aware of it. The old feeling that she (Miriam) was to be a sacrifice to this love, which she (Miriam) had had when she (Miriam) prayed, was mingled in all her (Miriam) emotions. She (Miriam) did not at the bottom believe she (Miriam) ever would have him (Paul). She (Miriam) did not believe in herself primarily: doubted whether she (Miriam) could ever be what he (Paul) would demand of her (Miriam). Certainly she (Miriam) never saw herself living happily through a lifetime with him (Paul). She (Miriam) saw tragedy, sorrow, and sacrifice ahead. And in sacrifice she (Miriam) was proud, in renunciation she (Miriam) was strong, for she (Miriam) did not trust herself to support everyday life. She (Miriam) was prepared for the big things and the deep things, like tragedy. It was the sufficiency of the small day-life she (Miriam) could not trust.

The Easter holidays began happily. Paul was his (Paul) own frank self. Yet she (Miriam) felt it would go wrong. On the Sunday afternoon she (Miriam) stood at her (Miriam) bedroom window, looking across at the oak-trees of the wood, in whose branches a twilight was tangled, below the bright sky of the afternoon. Grey-green rosettes of honeysuckle leaves hung before the window, some already, she (Miriam) fancied, showing bud. It was spring, which she (Miriam) loved and dreaded.

Hearing the clack of the gate she (Miriam) stood in suspense. It was a bright grey day. Paul came into the yard with his (Paul) bicycle, which glittered as he (Paul) walked. Usually he (Paul) rang his (Paul) bell and laughed towards the house. To-day he (Paul) walked with shut lips and cold, cruel bearing, that had something of a slouch and a sneer in it. She (Miriam) knew him (Paul) well by now, and could tell from that keen-looking, aloof young body of his (Paul) what was happening inside him (Paul). There was a cold correctness in the way he (Paul) put his (Paul) bicycle in its place, that made her (Miriam) heart sink.

She (Miriam) came downstairs nervously. She (Miriam) was wearing a new net blouse that she (Miriam) thought became her (Miriam). It had a high collar with a tiny ruff, reminding her (Miriam) of Mary, Queen of Scots, and making her (Miriam), she (Miriam) thought, look wonderfully a woman, and dignified. At twenty she (Miriam) was full-breasted and luxuriously formed. Her (Miriam) face was still like a soft rich mask, unchangeable. But her (Miriam) eyes, once lifted, were wonderful. She (Miriam) was afraid of him (Paul). He (Paul) would notice her (Miriam) new blouse.

He (Paul), being in a hard, ironical mood, was entertaining the family to a description of a service given in the Primitive Methodist Chapel, conducted by one of the well-known preachers of the sect. He (Paul) sat at the head of the table, his (Paul) mobile face, with the eyes that could be so beautiful, shining with tenderness or dancing with laughter, now taking on one expression and then another, in imitation of various people he (Paul) was mocking. His (Paul) mockery always hurt her (Miriam); it was too near the reality. He (Paul) was too clever and cruel. She (Miriam) felt that when his (Paul) eyes were like this, hard with mocking hate, he (Paul) would spare neither himself nor anybody else. But Mrs. Leivers was wiping her (Leivers) eyes with laughter, and Mr. Leivers, just awake from his (Leivers) Sunday nap, was rubbing his (Leivers) head in amusement. The three brothers sat with ruffled, sleepy appearance in their shirt-sleeves, giving a guffaw from time to time. The whole family loved a

``take-off'' (The family)
more than anything.

He (Leivers) took no notice of Miriam. Later, she (Miriam) saw him (Leivers) remark her (Miriam) new blouse, saw that the artist approved, but it won from him (artist) not a spark of warmth. She (Miriam) was nervous, could hardly reach the teacups from the shelves.

When the men went out to milk, she (Miriam) ventured to address him (artist) personally.

``You were late,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

``Was I?'' (he)
he (artist) answered.

There was silence for a while.

``Was it rough riding?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``I didn't notice it.'' (She)
She (Miriam) continued quickly to lay the table. When she (Miriam) had finished--

``Tea won't be for a few minutes. Will you come and look at the daffodils?'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

He (artist) rose without answering. They went out into the back garden under the budding damson-trees. The hills and the sky were clean and cold. Everything looked washed, rather hard. Miriam glanced at Paul. He (Paul) was pale and impassive. It seemed cruel to her (Miriam) that his (Paul) eyes and brows, which she (Miriam) loved, could look so hurting.

``Has the wind made you tired?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked. She (Miriam) detected an underneath feeling of weariness about him (Paul).

``No, I think not,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.

``It must be rough on the road--the wood moans so.'' (unknown)

``You can see by the clouds it's a south-west wind; that helps me here.'' (unknown)

``You see, I don't cycle, so I don't understand,'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured.

``Is there need to cycle to know that!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

She (Miriam) thought his (Paul) sarcasms were unnecessary. They went forward in silence. Round the wild, tussocky lawn at the back of the house was a thorn hedge, under which daffodils were craning forward from among their sheaves of grey-green blades. The cheeks of the flowers were greenish with cold. But still some had burst, and their gold ruffled and glowed. Miriam went on her (Miriam) knees before one cluster, took a wild-looking daffodil between her (Miriam) hands, turned up its face of gold to her (Miriam), and bowed down, caressing it with her (Miriam) mouth and cheeks and brow. He (it) stood aside, with his (it) hands in his (it) pockets, watching her (Miriam). One after another she (Miriam) turned up to him (it) the faces of the yellow, bursten flowers appealingly, fondling them lavishly all the while.

``Aren't they magnificent?'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured.

``Magnificent! It's a bit thick--they're pretty!'' (She)

She (Miriam) bowed again to her (Miriam) flowers at his (it) censure of her (Miriam) praise. He (it) watched her (Miriam) crouching, sipping the flowers with fervid kisses.

``Why must you always be fondling things?'' (he)
he (it) said irritably.

``But I love to touch them,'' (she)
she (Miriam) replied, hurt.

``Can you never like things without clutching them as if you wanted to pull the heart out of them? Why don't you have a bit more restraint, or reserve, or something?'' (She)

She (Miriam) looked up at him (it) full of pain, then continued slowly to stroke her (Miriam) lips against a ruffled flower. Their scent, as she (Miriam) smelled it, was so much kinder than he (it); it almost made her (Miriam) cry.

``You wheedle the soul out of things,'' (he)
he (it) said.
``I would never wheedle--at any rate, I'd go straight.'' (He)

He (it) scarcely knew what he (it) was saying. These things came from him (it) mechanically. She (Miriam) looked at him (it). His (it) body seemed one weapon, firm and hard against her (Miriam).

``You're always begging things to love you,'' (he)
he (it) said,
``as if you were a beggar for love. Even the flowers, you have to fawn on them--'' (he)
