His (Paul) mother knew how he (Paul) was suffering for want of a woman, and she (woman) saw him (Paul) going to Miriam. If he (Paul) had made up his (Paul) mind, nothing on earth would alter him (Paul). Mrs. Morel was tired. She (Morel) began to give up at last; she (Morel) had finished. She (Morel) was in the way.

He (Paul) went on determinedly. He (Paul) realised more or less what his (Paul) mother felt. It only hardened his (Paul) soul. He (Paul) made himself callous towards her (mother); but it was like being callous to his (Paul) own health. It undermined him (Paul) quickly; yet he (Paul) persisted.

He (Paul) lay back in the rocking-chair at Willey Farm one evening. He (Willey) had been talking to Miriam for some weeks, but had not come to the point. Now he (Willey) said suddenly:

``I am twenty-four, almost.'' (he)

She (Miriam) had been brooding. She (Miriam) looked up at him (Willey) suddenly in surprise.

``Yes. What makes you say it?'' (she)

There was something in the charged atmosphere that she (Miriam) dreaded.

``Sir Thomas More says one can marry at twenty-four.'' (She)

She (Miriam) laughed quaintly, saying:

``Does it need Sir Thomas More's sanction?'' (She)

``No; but one ought to marry about then.'' (unknown)

``Ay,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered broodingly; and she (Miriam) waited.

``I can't marry you,'' (he)
he (Willey) continued slowly,
``not now, because we've no money, and they depend on me at home.'' (he)

She (Miriam) sat half-guessing what was coming.

``But I want to marry now--'' (she)

``You want to marry?'' (she)
she (Miriam) repeated.

``A woman--you know what I mean.'' (She)

She (Miriam) was silent.

``Now, at last, I must,'' (he)
he (Willey) said.

``Ay,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered.

``And you love me?'' (She)

She (Miriam) laughed bitterly.

``Why are you ashamed of it,'' (he)
he (Willey) answered.
``You wouldn't be ashamed before your God, why are you before people?'' (unknown)

``Nay,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered deeply,
``I am not ashamed.'' (she)

``You are,'' (he)
he (Willey) replied bitterly;
``and it's my fault. But you know I can't help being--as I am--don't you?'' (he)

``I know you can't help it,'' (she)
she (Miriam) replied.

``I love you an awful lot--then there is something short.'' (unknown)

``Where?'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered, looking at him (Willey).

``Oh, in me! It is I who ought to be ashamed--like a spiritual cripple. And I am ashamed. It is misery. Why is it?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
replied Miriam.

``And I don't know,'' (he)
he (Willey) repeated.
``Don't you think we have been too fierce in our what they call purity? Don't you think that to be so much afraid and averse is a sort of dirtiness?'' (She)

She (Miriam) looked at him (Willey) with startled dark eyes.

``You recoiled away from anything of the sort, and I took the motion from you, and recoiled also, perhaps worse.'' (unknown)

There was silence in the room for some time.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said,
``it is so.'' (she)

``There is between us,'' (he)
he (Willey) said,
``all these years of intimacy. I feel naked enough before you. Do you understand?'' (he)

``I think so,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered.

``And you love me?'' (She)

She (Miriam) laughed.

``Don't be bitter,'' (he)
he (Willey) pleaded.

She (Miriam) looked at him (Willey) and was sorry for him (Willey); his (Willey) eyes were dark with torture. She (Miriam) was sorry for him (Willey); it was worse for him (Willey) to have this deflated love than for herself, who could never be properly mated. He (Willey) was restless, for ever urging forward and trying to find a way out. He (Willey) might do as he (Willey) liked, and have what he (Willey) liked of her (Miriam).

``Nay,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said softly,
``I am not bitter.'' (she)

She (Miriam) felt she (Miriam) could bear anything for him (Willey); she (Miriam) would suffer for him (Willey). She (Miriam) put her (Miriam) hand on his (Willey) knee as he (Willey) leaned forward in his (Willey) chair. He (Willey) took it and kissed it; but it hurt to do so. He (Willey) felt he (Willey) was putting himself aside. He (Willey) sat there sacrificed to her (Miriam) purity, which felt more like nullity. How could he (Willey) kiss her (Miriam) hand passionately, when it would drive her (Miriam) away, and leave nothing but pain? Yet slowly he (Willey) drew her (Miriam) to him (Willey) and kissed her (Miriam).

They knew each other too well to pretend anything. As she (Miriam) kissed him (Willey), she (Miriam) watched his (Willey) eyes; they were staring across the room, with a peculiar dark blaze in them that fascinated her (Miriam). He (Willey) was perfectly still. She (Miriam) could feel his (Willey) heart throbbing heavily in his (Willey) breast.

``What are you thinking about?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

The blaze in his (Willey) eyes shuddered, became uncertain.

``I was thinking, all the while, I love you. I have been obstinate.'' (She)

She (Miriam) sank her (Miriam) head on his (Willey) breast.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered.

``That's all,'' (he)
he (Willey) said, and his (Willey) voice seemed sure, and his (Willey) mouth was kissing her (Miriam) throat.

Then she (Miriam) raised her (Miriam) head and looked into his (Willey) eyes with her (Miriam) full gaze of love. The blaze struggled, seemed to try to get away from her (Miriam), and then was quenched. He (Willey) turned his (Willey) head quickly aside. It was a moment of anguish.

``Kiss me,'' (she)
she (Miriam) whispered.

He (Willey) shut his (Willey) eyes, and kissed her (Miriam), and his (Willey) arms folded her (Miriam) closer and closer.

When she (Miriam) walked home with him (Willey) over the fields, he (Willey) said:

``I am glad I came back to you. I feel so simple with you--as if there was nothing to hide. We will be happy?'' (he)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) murmured, and the tears came to her (Miriam) eyes.

``Some sort of perversity in our souls,'' (he)
he (Willey) said,
``makes us not want, get away from, the very thing we want. We have to fight against that.'' (he)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, and she (Miriam) felt stunned.

As she (Miriam) stood under the drooping-thorn tree, in the darkness by the roadside, he (Willey) kissed her (Miriam), and his (Willey) fingers wandered over her (Miriam) face. In the darkness, where he (Willey) could not see her (Miriam) but only feel her (Miriam), his (Willey) passion flooded him (Willey). He (Willey) clasped her (Miriam) very close.

``Sometime you will have me?'' (he)
he (Willey) murmured, hiding his (Willey) face on her (Miriam) shoulder. It was so difficult.

``Not now,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

His (Willey) hopes and his (Willey) heart sunk. A dreariness came over him (Willey).

``No,'' (he)
he (Willey) said.

His (Willey) clasp of her (Miriam) slackened.

``I love to feel your arm THERE!'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, pressing his (Willey) arm against her (Miriam) back, where it went round her (Miriam) waist.
``It rests me so.'' (He)

He (Willey) tightened the pressure of his (Willey) arm upon the small of her (Miriam) back to rest her (Miriam).

``We belong to each other,'' (he)
he (Willey) said.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Then why shouldn't we belong to each other altogether?'' (unknown)

``But--'' (she)
she (Miriam) faltered.

``I know it's a lot to ask,'' (he)
he (Willey) said;
``but there's not much risk for you really--not in the Gretchen way. You can trust me there?'' (he)

``Oh, I can trust you.'' (unknown)
The answer came quick and strong.
``It's not that--it's not that at all--but--'' (She)

``What?'' (She)

She (Miriam) hid her (Miriam) face in his (Willey) neck with a little cry of misery.

``I don't know!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried.

She (Miriam) seemed slightly hysterical, but with a sort of horror. His (Willey) heart died in him (Willey).

``You don't think it ugly?'' (he)
he (Willey) asked.

``No, not now. You have TAUGHT me it isn't.'' (unknown)

``You are afraid?'' (She)

She (Miriam) calmed herself hastily.

``Yes, I am only afraid,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

He (Willey) kissed her (Miriam) tenderly.

``Never mind,'' (he)
he (Willey) said.
``You should please yourself.'' (she)

Suddenly she (Miriam) gripped his (Willey) arms round her (Miriam), and clenched her (Miriam) body stiff.

``You SHALL have me,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, through her (Miriam) shut teeth.

His (Willey) heart beat up again like fire. He (Willey) folded her (Miriam) close, and his (Willey) mouth was on her (Miriam) throat. She (Miriam) could not bear it. She (Miriam) drew away. He (Willey) disengaged her (Miriam).

``Won't you be late?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked gently.

He (Willey) sighed, scarcely hearing what she (Miriam) said. She (Miriam) waited, wishing he (Willey) would go. At last he (Willey) kissed her (Miriam) quickly and climbed the fence. Looking round he (Willey) saw the pale blotch of her (Miriam) face down in the darkness under the hanging tree. There was no more of her (Miriam) but this pale blotch.

``Good-bye!'' (she)
she (Miriam) called softly. She (Miriam) had no body, only a voice and a dim face. He (Willey) turned away and ran down the road, his (Willey) fists clenched; and when he (Willey) came to the wall over the lake he (Willey) leaned there, almost stunned, looking up the black water.

Miriam plunged home over the meadows. She (Miriam) was not afraid of people, what they might say; but she (Miriam) dreaded the issue with him (Willey). Yes, she (Miriam) would let him (Willey) have her (Miriam) if he (Willey) insisted; and then, when she (Miriam) thought of it afterwards, her (Miriam) heart went down. He (Willey) would be disappointed, he (Willey) would find no satisfaction, and then he (Willey) would go away. Yet he (Willey) was so insistent; and over this, which did not seem so all-important to her (Miriam), was their love to break down. After all, he (Willey) was only like other men, seeking his (Willey) satisfaction. Oh, but there was something more in him (Willey), something deeper! She (Miriam) could trust to it, in spite of all desires. He (Willey) said that possession was a great moment in life. All strong emotions concentrated there. Perhaps it was so. There was something divine in it; then she (Miriam) would submit, religiously, to the sacrifice. He (Willey) should have her (Miriam). And at the thought her (Miriam) whole body clenched itself involuntarily, hard, as if against something; but Life forced her (Miriam) through this gate of suffering, too, and she (Miriam) would submit. At any rate, it would give him (Willey) what he (Willey) wanted, which was her (Miriam) deepest wish. She (Miriam) brooded and brooded and brooded herself towards accepting him (Willey).

He (He) courted her (Miriam) now like a lover. Often, when he (he) grew hot, she (Miriam) put his (him) face from her (Miriam), held it between her (Miriam) hands, and looked in his (he) eyes. He (he) could not meet her (Miriam) gaze. Her (Miriam) dark eyes, full of love, earnest and searching, made him (he) turn away. Not for an instant would she (Miriam) let him (he) forget. Back again he (him) had to torture himself into a sense of his (he) responsibility and hers. Never any relaxing, never any leaving himself to the great hunger and impersonality of passion; he (him) must be brought back to a deliberate, reflective creature. As if from a swoon of passion she (Miriam) caged him (he) back to the littleness, the personal relationship. He (he) could not bear it.

``Leave me alone--leave me alone!'' (he)
he (him) wanted to cry; but she (Miriam) wanted him (him) to look at her (Miriam) with eyes full of love. His (his) eyes, full of the dark, impersonal fire of desire, did not belong to her (Miriam).

There was a great crop of cherries at the farm. The trees at the back of the house, very large and tall, hung thick with scarlet and crimson drops, under the dark leaves. Paul and Edgar were gathering the fruit one evening. It had been a hot day, and now the clouds were rolling in the sky, dark and warm. Paul combed high in the tree, above the scarlet roofs of the buildings. The wind, moaning steadily, made the whole tree rock with a subtle, thrilling motion that stirred the blood. The young man, perched insecurely in the slender branches, rocked till he (man) felt slightly drunk, reached down the boughs, where the scarlet beady cherries hung thick underneath, and tore off handful after handful of the sleek, cool-fleshed fruit. Cherries touched his (man) ears and his (man) neck as he (man) stretched forward, their chill finger-tips sending a flash down his (man) blood. All shades of red, from a golden vermilion to a rich crimson, glowed and met his (man) eyes under a darkness of leaves.

The sun, going down, suddenly caught the broken clouds. Immense piles of gold flared out in the south-east, heaped in soft, glowing yellow right up the sky. The world, till now dusk and grey, reflected the gold glow, astonished. Everywhere the trees, and the grass, and the far-off water, seemed roused from the twilight and shining.

Miriam came out wondering.

``Oh!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul heard her (Miriam) mellow voice call,
``isn't it wonderful?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

He (Paul) looked down. There was a faint gold glimmer on her (Miriam) face, that looked very soft, turned up to him (Paul).

``How high you are!'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

Beside her (Miriam), on the rhubarb leaves, were four dead birds, thieves that had been shot. Paul saw some cherry stones hanging quite bleached, like skeletons, picked clear of flesh. He (Paul) looked down again to Miriam.

``Clouds are on fire,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Beautiful!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried.

She (Miriam) seemed so small, so soft, so tender, down there. He (Paul) threw a handful of cherries at her (Miriam). She (Miriam) was startled and frightened. He (Paul) laughed with a low, chuckling sound, and pelted her (Miriam). She (Miriam) ran for shelter, picking up some cherries. Two fine red pairs she (Miriam) hung over her (Miriam) ears; then she (Miriam) looked up again.

``Haven't you got enough?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Nearly. It is like being on a ship up here.'' (unknown)

``And how long will you stay?'' (unknown)

``While the sunset lasts.'' (She)

She (Miriam) went to the fence and sat there, watching the gold clouds fall to pieces, and go in immense, rose-coloured ruin towards the darkness. Gold flamed to scarlet, like pain in its intense brightness. Then the scarlet sank to rose, and rose to crimson, and quickly the passion went out of the sky. All the world was dark grey. Paul scrambled quickly down with his (Paul) basket, tearing his (Paul) shirt-sleeve as he (Paul) did so.

``They are lovely,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam, fingering the cherries.

``I've torn my sleeve,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.

She (Miriam) took the three-cornered rip, saying:

``I shall have to mend it.'' (She)
It was near the shoulder. She (Miriam) put her (Miriam) fingers through the tear.
``How warm!'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

He (Paul) laughed. There was a new, strange note in his (Paul) voice, one that made her (Miriam) pant.

``Shall we stay out?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Won't it rain?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``No, let us walk a little way.'' (unknown)

They went down the fields and into the thick plantation of trees and pines.

``Shall we go in among the trees?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``Do you want to?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

It was very dark among the firs, and the sharp spines pricked her (Miriam) face. She (Miriam) was afraid. Paul was silent and strange.

``I like the darkness,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``I wish it were thicker--good, thick darkness.'' (He)

He (Paul) seemed to be almost unaware of her (Miriam) as a person: she (Miriam) was only to him (Paul) then a woman. She (Miriam) was afraid.

He (Paul) stood against a pine-tree trunk and took her (Miriam) in his (Paul) arms. She (Miriam) relinquished herself to him (Paul), but it was a sacrifice in which she (Miriam) felt something of horror. This thick-voiced, oblivious man was a stranger to her (Miriam).

Later it began to rain. The pine-trees smelled very strong. Paul lay with his (Paul) head on the ground, on the dead pine needles, listening to the sharp hiss of the rain--a steady, keen noise. His (Paul) heart was down, very heavy. Now he (Paul) realised that she (Miriam) had not been with him (Paul) all the time, that her (Miriam) soul had stood apart, in a sort of horror. He (Paul) was physically at rest, but no more. Very dreary at heart, very sad, and very tender, his (Paul) fingers wandered over her (Miriam) face pitifully. Now again she (Miriam) loved him (Paul) deeply. He (Paul) was tender and beautiful.

``The rain!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Yes--is it coming on you?'' (She)

She (Miriam) put her (Miriam) hands over him (Paul), on his (Paul) hair, on his (Paul) shoulders, to feel if the raindrops fell on him (Paul). She (Miriam) loved him (Paul) dearly. He (Paul), as he (Paul) lay with his (Paul) face on the dead pine-leaves, felt extraordinarily quiet. He (Paul) did not mind if the raindrops came on him (Paul): he (Paul) would have lain and got wet through: he (Paul) felt as if nothing mattered, as if his (Paul) living were smeared away into the beyond, near and quite lovable. This strange, gentle reaching-out to death was new to him (Paul).

``We must go,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered, but did not move.

To him (Paul) now, life seemed a shadow, day a white shadow; night, and death, and stillness, and inaction, this seemed like BEING. To be alive, to be urgent and insistent--that was NOT-TO-BE. The highest of all was to melt out into the darkness and sway there, identified with the great Being.

``The rain is coming in on us,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

He (Paul) rose, and assisted her (Miriam).

``It is a pity,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``What?'' (unknown)

``To have to go. I feel so still.'' (unknown)

``Still!'' (she)
she (Miriam) repeated.

``Stiller than I have ever been in my life.'' (He)

He (Paul) was walking with his (Paul) hand in hers. She (Miriam) pressed his (Paul) fingers, feeling a slight fear. Now he (Paul) seemed beyond her (Miriam); she (Miriam) had a fear lest she (Miriam) should lose him (Paul).

``The fir-trees are like presences on the darkness: each one only a presence.'' (She)

She (Miriam) was afraid, and said nothing.

``A sort of hush: the whole night wondering and asleep: I suppose that's what we do in death--sleep in wonder.'' (She)

She (Miriam) had been afraid before of the brute in him (Paul): now of the mystic. She (Miriam) trod beside him (Paul) in silence. The rain fell with a heavy

``Hush!'' (unknown)
on the trees. At last they gained the cartshed.

``Let us stay here awhile,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

There was a sound of rain everywhere, smothering everything.

``I feel so strange and still,'' (he)
he (Paul) said;
``along with everything.'' (he)

``Ay,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered patiently.

He (Paul) seemed again unaware of her (Miriam), though he (Paul) held her (Miriam) hand close.

``To be rid of our individuality, which is our will, which is our effort--to live effortless, a kind of curious sleep--that is very beautiful, I think; that is our after-life--our immortality.'' (unknown)

``Yes?'' (unknown)

``Yes--and very beautiful to have.'' (unknown)

``You don't usually say that.'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

In a while they went indoors. Everybody looked at them curiously. He (Paul) still kept the quiet, heavy look in his (Paul) eyes, the stillness in his (Paul) voice. Instinctively, they all left him (Paul) alone.

About this time Miriam's grandmother, who lived in a tiny cottage in Woodlinton, fell ill, and the girl was sent to keep house. It was a beautiful little place. The cottage had a big garden in front, with red brick walls, against which the plum trees were nailed. At the back another garden was separated from the fields by a tall old hedge. It was very pretty. Miriam had not much to do, so she (Miriam) found time for her (Miriam) beloved reading, and for writing little introspective pieces which interested her (Miriam).

At the holiday-time her (Miriam) grandmother, being better, was driven to Derby to stay with her (Miriam) daughter for a day or two. She (Miriam) was a crotchety old lady, and might return the second day or the third; so Miriam stayed alone in the cottage, which also pleased her (Miriam).

Paul used often to cycle over, and they had as a rule peaceful and happy times. He (Paul) did not embarrass her (Miriam) much; but then on the Monday of the holiday he (Paul) was to spend a whole day with her (Miriam).

It was perfect weather. He (Paul) left his (Paul) mother, telling her (mother) where he (Paul) was going. She (mother) would be alone all the day. It cast a shadow over him (Paul); but he (Paul) had three days that were all his (Paul) own, when he (Paul) was going to do as he (Paul) liked. It was sweet to rush through the morning lanes on his (Paul) bicycle.

He (Paul) got to the cottage at about eleven o'clock. Miriam was busy preparing dinner. She (Miriam) looked so perfectly in keeping with the little kitchen, ruddy and busy. He (Paul) kissed her (Miriam) and sat down to watch. The room was small and cosy. The sofa was covered all over with a sort of linen in squares of red and pale blue, old, much washed, but pretty. There was a stuffed owl in a case over a corner cupboard. The sunlight came through the leaves of the scented geraniums in the window. She (Miriam) was cooking a chicken in his (Paul) honour. It was their cottage for the day, and they were man and wife. He (man) beat the eggs for her (wife) and peeled the potatoes. He (man) thought she (wife) gave a feeling of home almost like his (man) mother; and no one could look more beautiful, with her (wife) tumbled curls, when she (wife) was flushed from the fire.

The dinner was a great success. Like a young husband, he (husband) carved. They talked all the time with unflagging zest. Then he (husband) wiped the dishes she (wife) had washed, and they went out down the fields. There was a bright little brook that ran into a bog at the foot of a very steep bank. Here they wandered, picking still a few marsh-marigolds and many big blue forget-me-nots. Then she (wife) sat on the bank with her (wife) hands full of flowers, mostly golden water-blobs. As she (wife) put her (wife) face down into the marigolds, it was all overcast with a yellow shine.

``Your face is bright,'' (he)
he (husband) said,
``like a transfiguration.'' (he)

She (wife) looked at him (husband), questioning. He (husband) laughed pleadingly to her (wife), laying his (husband) hands on hers. Then he (husband) kissed her (wife) fingers, then her (wife) face.

The world was all steeped in sunshine, and quite still, yet not asleep, but quivering with a kind of expectancy.

``I have never seen anything more beautiful than this,'' (he)
he (husband) said. He (husband) held her (wife) hand fast all the time.

``And the water singing to itself as it runs--do you love it?'' (She)
She (wife) looked at him (husband) full of love. His (husband) eyes were very dark, very bright.

``Don't you think it's a great day?'' (he)
he (husband) asked.

She (wife) murmured her (wife) assent. She (wife) WAS happy, and he (husband) saw it.

``And our day--just between us,'' (he)
he (husband) said.

They lingered a little while. Then they stood up upon the sweet thyme, and he (husband) looked down at her (wife) simply.

``Will you come?'' (he)
he (husband) asked.

They went back to the house, hand in hand, in silence. The chickens came scampering down the path to her (wife). He (husband) locked the door, and they had the little house to themselves.

He (husband) never forgot seeing her (wife) as she (wife) lay on the bed, when he (husband) was unfastening his (husband) collar. First he (husband) saw only her (wife) beauty, and was blind with it. She (wife) had the most beautiful body he (husband) had ever imagined. He (husband) stood unable to move or speak, looking at her (wife), his (husband) face half-smiling with wonder. And then he (husband) wanted her (wife), but as he (husband) went forward to her (wife), her (wife) hands lifted in a little pleading movement, and he (husband) looked at her (wife) face, and stopped. Her (wife) big brown eyes were watching him (husband), still and resigned and loving; she (wife) lay as if she (wife) had given herself up to sacrifice: there was her (wife) body for him (husband); but the look at the back of her (wife) eyes, like a creature awaiting immolation, arrested him (husband), and all his (husband) blood fell back.

``You are sure you want me?'' (he)
he (husband) asked, as if a cold shadow had come over him (husband).

``Yes, quite sure.'' (She)

She (wife) was very quiet, very calm. She (wife) only realised that she (wife) was doing something for him (husband). He (husband) could hardly bear it. She (wife) lay to be sacrificed for him (husband) because she (wife) loved him (husband) so much. And he (husband) had to sacrifice her (wife). For a second, he (husband) wished he (husband) were sexless or dead. Then he (husband) shut his (husband) eyes again to her (wife), and his (husband) blood beat back again.

And afterwards he (husband) loved her (wife)--loved her (wife) to the last fibre of his (husband) being. He (husband) loved her (wife). But he (husband) wanted, somehow, to cry. There was something he (husband) could not bear for her (wife) sake. He (husband) stayed with her (wife) till quite late at night. As he (husband) rode home he (husband) felt that he (husband) was finally initiated. He (husband) was a youth no longer. But why had he (husband) the dull pain in his (husband) soul? Why did the thought of death, the after-life, seem so sweet and consoling?

He (husband) spent the week with Miriam, and wore her (Miriam) out with his (husband) passion before it was gone. He (husband) had always, almost wilfully, to put her (Miriam) out of count, and act from the brute strength of his (husband) own feelings. And he (husband) could not do it often, and there remained afterwards always the sense of failure and of death. If he (husband) were really with her (Miriam), he (husband) had to put aside himself and his (husband) desire. If he (husband) would have her (Miriam), he (husband) had to put her (Miriam) aside.

``When I come to you,'' (he)
he (husband) asked her (Miriam), his (husband) eyes dark with pain and shame,
``you don't really want me, do you?'' (her)

``Ah, yes!'' (she)
she (Miriam) replied quickly.

He (husband) looked at her (Miriam).

``Nay,'' (he)
he (husband) said.

She (Miriam) began to tremble.

``You see,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, taking his (husband) face and shutting it out against her (Miriam) shoulder--
``you see--as we are--how can I get used to you? It would come all right if we were married.'' (she)

He (husband) lifted her (Miriam) head, and looked at her (Miriam).

``You mean, now, it is always too much shock?'' (unknown)

``Yes--and--'' (She)

``You are always clenched against me.'' (She)

She (Miriam) was trembling with agitation.

``You see,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said,
``I'm not used to the thought--'' (she)

``You are lately,'' (she)
he (husband) said.

``But all my life. Mother said to me: ``There is one thing in marriage that is always dreadful, but you have to bear it.

'' And I believed it.'' (unknown)

``And still believe it,'' (he)
he (husband) said.

``No!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried hastily.
``I believe, as you do, that loving, even in THAT way, is the high-water mark of living.'' (unknown)

``That doesn't alter the fact that you never want it.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, taking his (husband) head in her (Miriam) arms and rocking in despair.
``Don't say so! You don't understand.'' (She)
She (Miriam) rocked with pain.
``Don't I want your children?'' (unknown)

``But not me.'' (unknown)

``How can you say so? But we must be married to have children--'' (unknown)

``Shall we be married, then? I want you to have my children.'' (He)

He (husband) kissed her (Miriam) hand reverently. She (Miriam) pondered sadly, watching him (husband).

``We are too young,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said at length.

``Twenty-four and twenty-three--'' (she)

``Not yet,'' (she)
she (Miriam) pleaded, as she (Miriam) rocked herself in distress.

``When you will,'' (he)
he (husband) said.

She (Miriam) bowed her (Miriam) head gravely. The tone of hopelessness in which he (husband) said these things grieved her (Miriam) deeply. It had always been a failure between them. Tacitly, she (Miriam) acquiesced in what he (husband) felt.

And after a week of love he (husband) said to his (husband) mother suddenly one Sunday night, just as they were going to bed:

``I shan't go so much to Miriam's, mother.'' (mother)

She (mother) was surprised, but she (mother) would not ask him (husband) anything.

``You please yourself,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

So he (husband) went to bed. But there was a new quietness about him (husband) which she (mother) had wondered at. She (mother) almost guessed. She (mother) would leave him (husband) alone, however. Precipitation might spoil things. She (mother) watched him (husband) in his (husband) loneliness, wondering where he (husband) would end. He (husband) was sick, and much too quiet for him (husband). There was a perpetual little knitting of his (husband) brows, such as she (mother) had seen when he (husband) was a small baby, and which had been gone for many years. Now it was the same again. And she (mother) could do nothing for him (husband). He (husband) had to go on alone, make his (husband) own way.

He (husband) continued faithful to Miriam. For one day he (husband) had loved her (Miriam) utterly. But it never came again. The sense of failure grew stronger. At first it was only a sadness. Then he (husband) began to feel he (husband) could not go on. He (husband) wanted to run, to go abroad, anything. Gradually he (husband) ceased to ask her (Miriam) to have him (he). Instead of drawing them together, it put them apart. And then he (he) realised, consciously, that it was no good. It was useless trying: it would never be a success between them.

For some months he (he) had seen very little of Clara. They had occasionally walked out for half an hour at dinner-time. But he (he) always reserved himself for Miriam. With Clara, however, his (him) brow cleared, and he (He) was gay again. She (Clara) treated him (his) indulgently, as if he (his) were a child. He (he) thought he (he) did not mind. But deep below the surface it piqued him (He).

Sometimes Miriam said:

``What about Clara? I hear nothing of her (Clara) lately.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

``I walked with her (Clara) about twenty minutes yesterday,'' (he)
he (him) replied.

``And what did she (Clara) talk about?'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I suppose I did all the jawing--I usually do. I think I was telling her (Clara) about the strike, and how the women took it.'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (he)

So he (His) gave the account of himself.

But insidiously, without his (he) knowing it, the warmth he (he) felt for Clara drew him (he) away from Miriam, for whom he (he) felt responsible, and to whom he (he) felt he (he) belonged. He (he) thought he (He) was being quite faithful to her (Miriam). It was not easy to estimate exactly the strength and warmth of one's feelings for a woman till they have run away with one.

He (He) began to give more time to his (he) men friends. There was Jessop, at the art school; Swain, who was chemistry demonstrator at the university; Newton, who was a teacher; besides Edgar and Miriam's younger brothers. Pleading work, he (Edgar) sketched and studied with Jessop. He (Edgar) called in the university for Swain, and the two went

``down town'' (Swain)
together. Having come home in the train with Newton, he (Newton) called and had a game of billiards with him (Newton) in the Moon and Stars. If he (Newton) gave to Miriam the excuse of his (Newton) men friends, he (Newton) felt quite justified. His (Newton) mother began to be relieved. He (Newton) always told her (mother) where he (Newton) had been.

During the summer Clara wore sometimes a dress of soft cotton stuff with loose sleeves. When she (Clara) lifted her (Clara) hands, her (Clara) sleeves fell back, and her (Clara) beautiful strong arms shone out.

``Half a minute,'' (he)
he (Newton) cried.
``Hold your arm still.'' (He)

He (Newton) made sketches of her (Clara) hand and arm, and the drawings contained some of the fascination the real thing had for him (Newton). Miriam, who always went scrupulously through his (Newton) books and papers, saw the drawings.

``I think Clara has such beautiful arms,'' (he)
he (Newton) said.

``Yes! When did you draw them?'' (unknown)

``On Tuesday, in the work-room. You know, I've got a corner where I can work. Often I can do every single thing they need in the department, before dinner. Then I work for myself in the afternoon, and just see to things at night.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, turning the leaves of his (Newton) sketch-book.

Frequently he (Newton) hated Miriam. He (Newton) hated her (Miriam) as she (Miriam) bent forward and pored over his (Newton) things. He (Newton) hated her (Miriam) way of patiently casting him (Newton) up, as if he (Newton) were an endless psychological account. When he (Newton) was with her (Miriam), he (Newton) hated her (Miriam) for having got him (Newton), and yet not got him (Newton), and he (Newton) tortured her (Miriam). She (Miriam) took all and gave nothing, he (Newton) said. At least, she (Miriam) gave no living warmth. She (Miriam) was never alive, and giving off life. Looking for her (Miriam) was like looking for something which did not exist. She (Miriam) was only his (Newton) conscience, not his (Newton) mate. He (Newton) hated her (Miriam) violently, and was more cruel to her (Miriam). They dragged on till the next summer. He (Newton) saw more and more of Clara.

At last he (Newton) spoke. He (Newton) had been sitting working at home one evening. There was between him (Newton) and his (Newton) mother a peculiar condition of people frankly finding fault with each other. Mrs. Morel was strong on her (Morel) feet again. He (Newton) was not going to stick to Miriam. Very well; then she (Miriam) would stand aloof till he (Newton) said something. It had been coming a long time, this bursting of the storm in him (Newton), when he (Newton) would come back to her (Miriam). This evening there was between them a peculiar condition of suspense. He (Newton) worked feverishly and mechanically, so that he (Newton) could escape from himself. It grew late. Through the open door, stealthily, came the scent of madonna lilies, almost as if it were prowling abroad. Suddenly he (Newton) got up and went out of doors.

The beauty of the night made him (Newton) want to shout. A half-moon, dusky gold, was sinking behind the black sycamore at the end of the garden, making the sky dull purple with its glow. Nearer, a dim white fence of lilies went across the garden, and the air all round seemed to stir with scent, as if it were alive. He (Newton) went across the bed of pinks, whose keen perfume came sharply across the rocking, heavy scent of the lilies, and stood alongside the white barrier of flowers. They flagged all loose, as if they were panting. The scent made him (Newton) drunk. He (Newton) went down to the field to watch the moon sink under.

A corncrake in the hay-close called insistently. The moon slid quite quickly downwards, growing more flushed. Behind him (Newton) the great flowers leaned as if they were calling. And then, like a shock, he (Newton) caught another perfume, something raw and coarse. Hunting round, he (Newton) found the purple iris, touched their fleshy throats and their dark, grasping hands. At any rate, he (Newton) had found something. They stood stiff in the darkness. Their scent was brutal. The moon was melting down upon the crest of the hill. It was gone; all was dark. The corncrake called still.

Breaking off a pink, he (Newton) suddenly went indoors.

``Come, my boy,'' (mother)
said his (Newton) mother.
``I'm sure it's time you went to bed.'' (He)

He (Newton) stood with the pink against his (Newton) lips.

``I shall break off with Miriam, mother,'' (he)
he (Newton) answered calmly.

She (mother) looked up at him (Newton) over her (mother) spectacles. He (Newton) was staring back at her (mother), unswerving. She (mother) met his (Newton) eyes for a moment, then took off her (mother) glasses. He (Newton) was white. The male was up in him (Newton), dominant. She (mother) did not want to see him (Newton) too clearly.

``But I thought--'' (she)
she (mother) began.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Newton) answered,
``I don't love her (Miriam). I don't want to marry her (Miriam)--so I shall have done.'' (he)

``But,'' (mother)
exclaimed his (Newton) mother, amazed,
``I thought lately you had made up your mind to have her (Miriam), and so I said nothing.'' (mother)

``I had--I wanted to--but now I don't want. It's no good. I shall break off on Sunday. I ought to, oughtn't I?'' (unknown)

``You know best. You know I said so long ago.'' (unknown)

``I can't help that now. I shall break off on Sunday.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (mother)
said his (Newton) mother, ``I think it will be best. But lately I decided you had made up your mind to have her (Miriam), so I said nothing, and should have said nothing. But I say as I have always said, I DON
``T think she (Miriam) is suited to you.'' (unknown)

``On Sunday I break off,'' (he)
he (Newton) said, smelling the pink. He (Newton) put the flower in his (Newton) mouth. Unthinking, he (Newton) bared his (Newton) teeth, closed them on the blossom slowly, and had a mouthful of petals. These he (Newton) spat into the fire, kissed his (Newton) mother, and went to bed.

On Sunday he (Newton) went up to the farm in the early afternoon. He (Newton) had written Miriam that they would walk over the fields to Hucknall. His (Newton) mother was very tender with him (Newton). He (Newton) said nothing. But she (mother) saw the effort it was costing. The peculiar set look on his (Newton) face stilled her (mother).

``Never mind, my son,'' (she)
she (mother) said.
``You will be so much better when it is all over.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul glanced swiftly at his (Paul) mother in surprise and resentment. He (Paul) did not want sympathy.

Miriam met him (Paul) at the lane-end. She (Miriam) was wearing a new dress of figured muslin that had short sleeves. Those short sleeves, and Miriam's brown-skinned arms beneath them--such pitiful, resigned arms--gave him (Paul) so much pain that they helped to make him (Paul) cruel. She (Miriam) had made herself look so beautiful and fresh for him (Paul). She (Miriam) seemed to blossom for him (Paul) alone. Every time he (Paul) looked at her (Miriam)--a mature young woman now, and beautiful in her (Miriam) new dress--it hurt so much that his (Paul) heart seemed almost to be bursting with the restraint he (Paul) put on it. But he (Paul) had decided, and it was irrevocable.

On the hills they sat down, and he (Paul) lay with his (Paul) head in her (Miriam) lap, whilst she (Miriam) fingered his (Paul) hair. She (Miriam) knew that

``he (son) was not there,'' (She)
as she (Miriam) put it. Often, when she (Miriam) had him (Paul) with her (Miriam), she (Miriam) looked for him (Paul), and could not find him (Paul). But this afternoon she (Miriam) was not prepared.

It was nearly five o'clock when he (Paul) told her (Miriam). They were sitting on the bank of a stream, where the lip of turf hung over a hollow bank of yellow earth, and he (lip) was hacking away with a stick, as he (lip) did when he (lip) was perturbed and cruel.

``I have been thinking,'' (he)
he (lip) said,
``we ought to break off.'' (he)

``Why?'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried in surprise.

``Because it's no good going on.'' (unknown)

``Why is it no good?'' (unknown)

``It isn't. I don't want to marry. I don't want ever to marry. And if we're not going to marry, it's no good going on.'' (unknown)

``But why do you say this now?'' (unknown)

``Because I've made up my mind.'' (unknown)

``And what about these last months, and the things you told me then?'' (unknown)

``I can't help it! I don't want to go on.'' (unknown)

``You don't want any more of me?'' (unknown)

``I want us to break off--you be free of me, I free of you.'' (unknown)

``And what about these last months?'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I've not told you anything but what I thought was true.'' (unknown)

``Then why are you different now?'' (unknown)

``I'm not--I'm the same--only I know it's no good going on.'' (unknown)

``You haven't told me why it's no good.'' (unknown)

``Because I don't want to go on--and I don't want to marry.'' (unknown)

``How many times have you offered to marry me, and I wouldn't?'' (unknown)

``I know; but I want us to break off.'' (he)

There was silence for a moment or two, while he (lip) dug viciously at the earth. She (Miriam) bent her (Miriam) head, pondering. He (lip) was an unreasonable child. He (lip) was like an infant which, when it has drunk its fill, throws away and smashes the cup. She (Miriam) looked at him (lip), feeling she (Miriam) could get hold of him (lip) and WRING some consistency out of him (lip). But she (Miriam) was helpless. Then she (Miriam) cried:

``I have said you were only fourteen--you are only FOUR!'' (she)

He (lip) still dug at the earth viciously. He (lip) heard.

``You are a child of four,'' (she)
she (Miriam) repeated in her (Miriam) anger.

He (lip) did not answer, but said in his (lip) heart:

``All right; if I'm a child of four, what do you want me for? I don't want another mother.'' (He)
But he (lip) said nothing to her (Miriam), and there was silence.

``And have you told your people?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``I have told my mother.'' (unknown)

There was another long interval of silence.

``Then what do you WANT?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Why, I want us to separate. We have lived on each other all these years; now let us stop. I will go my own way without you, and you will go your way without me. You will have an independent life of your own then.'' (she)

There was in it some truth that, in spite of her (Miriam) bitterness, she (Miriam) could not help registering. She (Miriam) knew she (Miriam) felt in a sort of bondage to him (lip), which she (Miriam) hated because she (Miriam) could not control it. She (Miriam) hated her (Miriam) love for him (lip) from the moment it grew too strong for her (Miriam). And, deep down, she (Miriam) had hated him (lip) because she (Miriam) loved him (lip) and he (lip) dominated her (Miriam). She (Miriam) had resisted his (lip) domination. She (Miriam) had fought to keep herself free of him (lip) in the last issue. And she (Miriam) was free of him (lip), even more than he (lip) of her (Miriam).

``And,'' (he)
he (lip) continued,
``we shall always be more or less each other's work. You have done a lot for me, I for you. Now let us start and live by ourselves.'' (he)

``What do you want to do?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Nothing--only to be free,'' (he)
he (lip) answered.

She (Miriam), however, knew in her (Miriam) heart that Clara's influence was over him (lip) to liberate him (lip). But she (Miriam) said nothing.

``And what have I to tell my mother?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``I told my mother,'' (he)
he (lip) answered,
``that I was breaking off--clean and altogether.'' (he)

``I shall not tell them at home,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

Frowning,

``You please yourself,'' (he)
he (lip) said.

He (lip) knew he (lip) had landed her (Miriam) in a nasty hole, and was leaving her (Miriam) in the lurch. It angered him (lip).

``Tell them you wouldn't and won't marry me, and have broken off,'' (he)
he (lip) said.
``It's true enough.'' (She)

She (Miriam) bit her (Miriam) finger moodily. She (Miriam) thought over their whole affair. She (Miriam) had known it would come to this; she (Miriam) had seen it all along. It chimed with her (Miriam) bitter expectation.

``Always--it has always been so!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried.
``It has been one long battle between us--you fighting away from me.'' (unknown)

It came from her (Miriam) unawares, like a flash of lightning. The man's heart stood still. Was this how she (Miriam) saw it?

``But we've had SOME perfect hours, SOME perfect times, when we were together!'' (he)
he (man) pleaded.

``Never!'' (she)
she (Miriam) cried;
``never! It has always been you fighting me off.'' (she)

``Not always--not at first!'' (he)
he (man) pleaded.

``Always, from the very beginning--always the same!'' (She)

She (Miriam) had finished, but she (Miriam) had done enough. He (man) sat aghast. He (man) had wanted to say:

``It has been good, but it is at an end.'' (He)
And she (Miriam)--she (Miriam) whose love he (man) had believed in when he (man) had despised himself--denied that their love had ever been love.
``He (we) had always fought away from her (us)?'' (unknown)
Then it had been monstrous. There had never been anything really between them; all the time he (man) had been imagining something where there was nothing. And she (Miriam) had known. She (Miriam) had known so much, and had told him (man) so little. She (Miriam) had known all the time. All the time this was at the bottom of her (Miriam)!

He (man) sat silent in bitterness. At last the whole affair appeared in a cynical aspect to him (man). She (Miriam) had really played with him (man), not he (man) with her (Miriam). She (Miriam) had hidden all her (Miriam) condemnation from him (man), had flattered him (man), and despised him (man). She (Miriam) despised him (man) now. He (man) grew intellectual and cruel.

``You ought to marry a man who worships you,'' (he)
he (man) said;
``then you could do as you liked with him (man). Plenty of men will worship you, if you get on the private side of their natures. You ought to marry one such. They would never fight you off.'' (he)

``Thank you!'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.
``But don't advise me to marry someone else any more. You've done it before.'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (he)
he (man) said;
``I will say no more.'' (he)

He (man) sat still, feeling as if he (man) had had a blow, instead of giving one. Their eight years of friendship and love, THE eight years of his (man) life, were nullified.

``When did you think of this?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``I thought definitely on Thursday night.'' (unknown)

``I knew it was coming,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.

That pleased him (man) bitterly.

``Oh, very well! If she (You) knew then it doesn't come as a surprise to her (You),'' (he)
he (man) thought.

``And have you said anything to Clara?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``No; but I shall tell her (Clara) now.'' (unknown)

There was a silence.

``Do you remember the things you said this time last year, in my grandmother's house--nay last month even?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (man) said;
``I do! And I meant them! I can't help that it's failed.'' (he)

``It has failed because you want something else.'' (unknown)

``It would have failed whether or not. YOU never believed in me.'' (She)

She (Miriam) laughed strangely.

He (man) sat in silence. He (man) was full of a feeling that she (Miriam) had deceived him (man). She (Miriam) had despised him (man) when he (man) thought she (Miriam) worshipped him (man). She (Miriam) had let him (man) say wrong things, and had not contradicted him (man). She (Miriam) had let him (man) fight alone. But it stuck in his (man) throat that she (Miriam) had despised him (man) whilst he (man) thought she (Miriam) worshipped him (man). She (Miriam) should have told him (man) when she (Miriam) found fault with him (man). She (Miriam) had not played fair. He (man) hated her (Miriam). All these years she (Miriam) had treated him (man) as if he (man) were a hero, and thought of him (man) secretly as an infant, a foolish child. Then why had she (Miriam) left the foolish child to his (man) folly? His (man) heart was hard against her (Miriam).

She (Miriam) sat full of bitterness. She (Miriam) had known--oh, well she (Miriam) had known! All the time he (man) was away from her (Miriam) she (Miriam) had summed him (man) up, seen his (man) littleness, his (man) meanness, and his (man) folly. Even she (Miriam) had guarded her (Miriam) soul against him (man). She (Miriam) was not overthrown, not prostrated, not even much hurt. She (Miriam) had known. Only why, as he (man) sat there, had he (man) still this strange dominance over her (Miriam)? His (man) very movements fascinated her (Miriam) as if she (Miriam) were hypnotised by him (man). Yet he (man) was despicable, false, inconsistent, and mean. Why this bondage for her (Miriam)? Why was it the movement of his (man) arm stirred her (Miriam) as nothing else in the world could? Why was she (Miriam) fastened to him (man)? Why, even now, if he (man) looked at her (She) and commanded her (She), would she (her) have to obey? She (her) would obey him (man) in his (man) trifling commands. But once he (man) was obeyed, then she (her) had him (man) in her (she) power, she (She) knew, to lead him (man) where she (she) would. She (she) was sure of herself. Only, this new influence! Ah, he (man) was not a man! He (man) was a baby that cries for the newest toy. And all the attachment of his (man) soul would not keep him (man). Very well, he (man) would have to go. But he (man) would come back when he (man) had tired of his (man) new sensation.

He (man) hacked at the earth till she (she) was fretted to death. She (she) rose. He (man) sat flinging lumps of earth in the stream.

``We will go and have tea here?'' (he)
he (man) asked.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (her) answered.

They chattered over irrelevant subjects during tea. He (man) held forth on the love of ornament--the cottage parlour moved him (man) thereto--and its connection with aesthetics. She (she) was cold and quiet. As they walked home, she (She) asked:

``And we shall not see each other?'' (she)

``No--or rarely,'' (he)
he (man) answered.

``Nor write?'' (she)
she (her) asked, almost sarcastically.

``As you will,'' (he)
he (man) answered.
``We're not strangers--never should be, whatever happened. I will write to you now and again. You please yourself.'' (unknown)

``I see!'' (she)
she (She) answered cuttingly.

But he (man) was at that stage at which nothing else hurts. He (man) had made a great cleavage in his (man) life. He (man) had had a great shock when she (she) had told him (man) their love had been always a conflict. Nothing more mattered. If it never had been much, there was no need to make a fuss that it was ended.

He (man) left her (she) at the lane-end. As she (she) went home, solitary, in her (she) new frock, having her (her) people to face at the other end, he (man) stood still with shame and pain in the highroad, thinking of the suffering he (man) caused her (her).

In the reaction towards restoring his (man) self-esteem, he (man) went into the Willow Tree for a drink. There were four girls who had been out for the day, drinking a modest glass of port. They had some chocolates on the table. Paul sat near with his (Paul) whisky. He (Paul) noticed the girls whispering and nudging. Presently one, a bonny dark hussy, leaned to him (Paul) and said:

``Have a chocolate?'' (him)

The others laughed loudly at her (she) impudence.

``All right,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``Give me a hard one--nut. I don't like creams.'' (unknown)

``Here you are, then,'' (the girl)
said the girl;
``here's an almond for you.'' (the girl)

She (girl) held the sweet between her (girl) fingers. He (Paul) opened his (Paul) mouth. She (girl) popped it in, and blushed.

``You ARE nice!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Well,'' (she)
she (girl) answered,
``we thought you looked overcast, and they dared me offer you a chocolate.'' (she)

``I don't mind if I have another--another sort,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

And presently they were all laughing together.

It was nine o'clock when he (Paul) got home, falling dark. He (Paul) entered the house in silence. His (Paul) mother, who had been waiting, rose anxiously.

``I told her (I),'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I'm glad,'' (the mother)
replied the mother, with great relief.

He (Paul) hung up his (Paul) cap wearily.

``I said we'd have done altogether,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``That's right, my son,'' (the mother)
said the mother.
``It's hard for her (I) now, but best in the long run. I know. You weren't suited for her (I).'' (He)

He (Paul) laughed shakily as he (Paul) sat down.

``I've had such a lark with some girls in a pub,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

His (Paul) mother looked at him (Paul). He (Paul) had forgotten Miriam now. He (Paul) told her (Miriam) about the girls in the Willow Tree. Mrs. Morel looked at him (Paul). It seemed unreal, his (Paul) gaiety. At the back of it was too much horror and misery.

``Now have some supper,'' (she)
she (Morel) said very gently.

Afterwards he (Paul) said wistfully:

``She (I) never thought she (I)'d have me, mother, not from the first, and so she (I)'s not disappointed.'' (he)

``I'm afraid,'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother,
``she (I) doesn't give up hopes of you yet.'' (mother)

``No,'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``perhaps not.'' (he)

``You'll find it's better to have done,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

``I don't know,'' (he)
he (Paul) said desperately.

``Well, leave her (I) alone,'' (mother)
replied his (Paul) mother. So he (Paul) left her (mother), and she (mother) was alone. Very few people cared for her (mother), and she (mother) for very few people. She (mother) remained alone with herself, waiting.

CHAPTER XII

PASSION

HE (Paul) was gradually making it possible to earn a livelihood by his (Paul) art. Liberty's had taken several of his (Paul) painted designs on various stuffs, and he (Paul) could sell designs for embroideries, for altar-cloths, and similar things, in one or two places. It was not very much he (Paul) made at present, but he (Paul) might extend it. He (Paul) had also made friends with the designer for a pottery firm, and was gaining some knowledge of his (Paul) new acquaintance's art. The applied arts interested him (Paul) very much. At the same time he (Paul) laboured slowly at his (Paul) pictures. He (Paul) loved to paint large figures, full of light, but not merely made up of lights and cast shadows, like the impressionists; rather definite figures that had a certain luminous quality, like some of Michael Angelo's people. And these he (Angelo) fitted into a landscape, in what he (Angelo) thought true proportion. He (Angelo) worked a great deal from memory, using everybody he (Angelo) knew. He (Angelo) believed firmly in his (Angelo) work, that it was good and valuable. In spite of fits of depression, shrinking, everything, he (Angelo) believed in his (Angelo) work.

He (Angelo) was twenty-four when he (Angelo) said his (Angelo) first confident thing to his (Angelo) mother.

``Mother,'' (he)
he (Angelo) said,
``I s'll make a painter that they'll attend to.'' (he)

She (mother) sniffed in her (mother) quaint fashion. It was like a half-pleased shrug of the shoulders.

``Very well, my boy, we'll see,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

``You shall see, my pigeon! You see if you're not swanky one of these days!'' (unknown)

``I'm quite content, my boy,'' (she)
she (mother) smiled.

``But you'll have to alter. Look at you with Minnie!'' (Minnie)

Minnie was the small servant, a girl of fourteen.

``And what about Minnie?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
asked Mrs. Morel, with dignity.

``I heard her (Minnie) this morning: ``Eh, Mrs. Morel! I was going to do that,

'' when you went out in the rain for some coal,'' (I)
he (servant) said.
``That looks a lot like your being able to manage servants!'' (unknown)

``Well, it was only the child's niceness,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.

``And you apologising to her (Morel):

``You can't do two things at once, can you?''' (unknown)

``She (Morel) WAS busy washing up,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel.

``And what did she (Morel) say?

``It could easy have waited a bit. Now look how your feet paddle!''' (unknown)

``Yes--brazen young baggage!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, smiling.

He (servant) looked at his (servant) mother, laughing. She (Morel) was quite warm and rosy again with love of him (servant). It seemed as if all the sunshine were on her (Morel) for a moment. He (servant) continued his (servant) work gladly. She (Morel) seemed so well when she (Morel) was happy that he (servant) forgot her (Morel) grey hair.

And that year she (Morel) went with him (servant) to the Isle of Wight for a holiday. It was too exciting for them both, and too beautiful. Mrs. Morel was full of joy and wonder. But he (servant) would have her (Morel) walk with him (servant) more than she (Morel) was able. She (Morel) had a bad fainting bout. So grey her (Morel) face was, so blue her (Morel) mouth! It was agony to him (servant). He (servant) felt as if someone were pushing a knife in his (servant) chest. Then she (Morel) was better again, and he (servant) forgot. But the anxiety remained inside him (servant), like a wound that did not close.

After leaving Miriam he (servant) went almost straight to Clara. On the Monday following the day of the rupture he (servant) went down to the work-room. She (Clara) looked up at him (servant) and smiled. They had grown very intimate unawares. She (Clara) saw a new brightness about him (servant).

``Well, Queen of Sheba!'' (he)
he (servant) said, laughing.

``But why?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``I think it suits you. You've got a new frock on.'' (She)

She (Clara) flushed, asking:

``And what of it?'' (She)

``Suits you--awfully! I could design you a dress.'' (unknown)

``How would it be?'' (He)

He (servant) stood in front of her (Clara), his (servant) eyes glittering as he (servant) expounded. He (servant) kept her (Clara) eyes fixed with his (servant). Then suddenly he (servant) took hold of her (Clara). She (Clara) half-started back. He (servant) drew the stuff of her (Clara) blouse tighter, smoothed it over her (Clara) breast.

``More SO!'' (he)
he (servant) explained.

But they were both of them flaming with blushes, and immediately he (servant) ran away. He (servant) had touched her (Clara). His (servant) whole body was quivering with the sensation.

There was already a sort of secret understanding between them. The next evening he (servant) went to the cinematograph with her (Clara) for a few minutes before train-time. As they sat, he (servant) saw her (Clara) hand lying near him (servant). For some moments he (servant) dared not touch it. The pictures danced and dithered. Then he (servant) took her (Clara) hand in his (servant). It was large and firm; it filled his (servant) grasp. He (servant) held it fast. She (Clara) neither moved nor made any sign. When they came out his (servant) train was due. He (servant) hesitated.

``Good-night,'' (she)
she (Clara) said. He (servant) darted away across the road.

The next day he (servant) came again, talking to her (Clara). She (Clara) was rather superior with him (servant).

``Shall we go a walk on Monday?'' (he)
he (servant) asked.

She (Clara) turned her (Clara) face aside.

``Shall you tell Miriam?'' (she)
she (Clara) replied sarcastically.

``I have broken off with her (Miriam),'' (he)
he (servant) said.

``When?'' (unknown)

``Last Sunday.'' (unknown)

``You quarrelled?'' (unknown)

``No! I had made up my mind. I told her (Miriam) quite definitely I should consider myself free.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara did not answer, and he (servant) returned to his (servant) work. She (Clara) was so quiet and so superb!

On the Saturday evening he (servant) asked her (Clara) to come and drink coffee with him (servant) in a restaurant, meeting him (servant) after work was over. She (Clara) came, looking very reserved and very distant. He (servant) had three-quarters of an hour to train-time.

``We will walk a little while,'' (he)
he (servant) said.

She (Clara) agreed, and they went past the Castle into the Park. He (servant) was afraid of her (Clara). She (Clara) walked moodily at his (servant) side, with a kind of resentful, reluctant, angry walk. He (servant) was afraid to take her (Clara) hand.

``Which way shall we go?'' (he)
he (servant) asked as they walked in darkness.

``I don't mind.'' (unknown)

``Then we'll go up the steps.'' (He)

He (servant) suddenly turned round. They had passed the Park steps. She (Clara) stood still in resentment at his (servant) suddenly abandoning her (Clara). He (servant) looked for her (Clara). She (Clara) stood aloof. He (servant) caught her (Clara) suddenly in his (servant) arms, held her (Clara) strained for a moment, kissed her (Clara). Then he (servant) let her (Clara) go.

``Come along,'' (he)
he (servant) said, penitent.

She (Clara) followed him (servant). He (servant) took her (Clara) hand and kissed her (Clara) finger-tips. They went in silence. When they came to the light, he (servant) let go her (Clara) hand. Neither spoke till they reached the station. Then they looked each other in the eyes.

``Good-night,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

And he (servant) went for his (servant) train. His (servant) body acted mechanically. People talked to him (servant). He (servant) heard faint echoes answering them. He (servant) was in a delirium. He (servant) felt that he (servant) would go mad if Monday did not come at once. On Monday he (servant) would see her (Clara) again. All himself was pitched there, ahead. Sunday intervened. He (servant) could not bear it. He (servant) could not see her (Clara) till Monday. And Sunday intervened--hour after hour of tension. He (servant) wanted to beat his (servant) head against the door of the carriage. But he (servant) sat still. He (servant) drank some whisky on the way home, but it only made it worse. His (servant) mother must not be upset, that was all. He (servant) dissembled, and got quickly to bed. There he (servant) sat, dressed, with his (servant) chin on his (servant) knees, staring out of the window at the far hill, with its few lights. He (servant) neither thought nor slept, but sat perfectly still, staring. And when at last he (servant) was so cold that he (servant) came to himself, he (servant) found his (servant) watch had stopped at half-past two. It was after three o'clock. He (servant) was exhausted, but still there was the torment of knowing it was only Sunday morning. He (servant) went to bed and slept. Then he (servant) cycled all day long, till he (servant) was fagged out. And he (servant) scarcely knew where he (servant) had been. But the day after was Monday. He (servant) slept till four o'clock. Then he (servant) lay and thought. He (servant) was coming nearer to himself--he (servant) could see himself, real, somewhere in front. She (servant) would go a walk with him (servant) in the afternoon. Afternoon! It seemed years ahead.

Slowly the hours crawled. His (servant) father got up; he (he) heard him (He) pottering about. Then the miner set off to the pit, his (his) heavy boots scraping the yard. Cocks were still crowing. A cart went down the road. His (him) mother got up. She (mother) knocked the fire. Presently she (mother) called him (He) softly. He (his) answered as if he (he) were asleep. This shell of himself did well.

He (him) was walking to the station--another mile! The train was near Nottingham. Would it stop before the tunnels? But it did not matter; it would get there before dinner-time. He (he) was at Jordan's. She (mother) would come in half an hour. At any rate, she (mother) would be near. He (him) had done the letters. She (mother) would be there. Perhaps she (mother) had not come. He (him) ran downstairs. Ah! he (He) saw her (mother) through the glass door. Her (mother) shoulders stooping a little to her (mother) work made him (his) feel he (he) could not go forward; he (him) could not stand. He (he) went in. He (he) was pale, nervous, awkward, and quite cold. Would she (mother) misunderstand him (him)? He (him) could not write his (he) real self with this shell.

``And this afternoon,'' (he)
he (He) struggled to say.
``You will come?'' (unknown)

``I think so,'' (she)
she (mother) replied, murmuring.

He (his) stood before her (mother), unable to say a word. She (mother) hid her (mother) face from him (he). Again came over him (He) the feeling that he (his) would lose consciousness. He (he) set his (He) teeth and went upstairs. He (he) had done everything correctly yet, and he (he) would do so. All the morning things seemed a long way off, as they do to a man under chloroform. He (man) himself seemed under a tight band of constraint. Then there was his (man) other self, in the distance, doing things, entering stuff in a ledger, and he (man) watched that far-off him (man) carefully to see he (man) made no mistake.

But the ache and strain of it could not go on much longer. He (man) worked incessantly. Still it was only twelve o'clock. As if he (man) had nailed his (man) clothing against the desk, he (man) stood there and worked, forcing every stroke out of himself. It was a quarter to one; he (man) could clear away. Then he (man) ran downstairs.

``You will meet me at the Fountain at two o'clock,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``I can't be there till half-past.'' (unknown)

``Yes!'' (he)
he (man) said.

She (man) saw his (man) dark, mad eyes.

``I will try at a quarter past.'' (he)

And he (man) had to be content. He (man) went and got some dinner. All the time he (man) was still under chloroform, and every minute was stretched out indefinitely. He (man) walked miles of streets. Then he (man) thought he (man) would be late at the meeting-place. He (man) was at the Fountain at five past two. The torture of the next quarter of an hour was refined beyond expression. It was the anguish of combining the living self with the shell. Then he (man) saw her (man). She (man) came! And he (man) was there.

``You are late,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Only five minutes,'' (she)
she (man) answered.

``I'd never have done it to you,'' (he)
he (man) laughed.

She (man) was in a dark blue costume. He (man) looked at her (man) beautiful figure.

``You want some flowers,'' (he)
he (man) said, going to the nearest florist's.

She (man) followed him (man) in silence. He (man) bought her (man) a bunch of scarlet, brick-red carnations. She (man) put them in her (man) coat, flushing.

``That's a fine colour!'' (he)
he (man) said.

``I'd rather have had something softer,'' (she)
she (man) said.

He (man) laughed.

``Do you feel like a blot of vermilion walking down the street?'' (he)
he (man) said.

She (man) hung her (man) head, afraid of the people they met. He (man) looked sideways at her (man) as they walked. There was a wonderful close down on her (man) face near the ear that he (man) wanted to touch. And a certain heaviness, the heaviness of a very full ear of corn that dips slightly in the wind, that there was about her (man), made his (man) brain spin. He (man) seemed to be spinning down the street, everything going round.

As they sat in the tramcar, she (man) leaned her (man) heavy shoulder against him (man), and he (man) took her (man) hand. He (man) felt himself coming round from the anaesthetic, beginning to breathe. Her (man) ear, half-hidden among her (man) blonde hair, was near to him (man). The temptation to kiss it was almost too great. But there were other people on top of the car. It still remained to him (man) to kiss it. After all, he (man) was not himself, he (man) was some attribute of hers, like the sunshine that fell on her (man).

He (man) looked quickly away. It had been raining. The big bluff of the Castle rock was streaked with rain, as it reared above the flat of the town. They crossed the wide, black space of the Midland Railway, and passed the cattle enclosure that stood out white. Then they ran down sordid Wilford Road.

She (man) rocked slightly to the tram's motion, and as she (man) leaned against him (Wilford), rocked upon him (Wilford). He (Wilford) was a vigorous, slender man, with exhaustless energy. His (Wilford) face was rough, with rough-hewn features, like the common people's; but his (Wilford) eyes under the deep brows were so full of life that they fascinated her (man). They seemed to dance, and yet they were still trembling on the finest balance of laughter. His (Wilford) mouth the same was just going to spring into a laugh of triumph, yet did not. There was a sharp suspense about him (Wilford). She (man) bit her (man) lip moodily. His (Wilford) hand was hard clenched over hers.

They paid their two halfpennies at the turnstile and crossed the bridge. The Trent was very full. It swept silent and insidious under the bridge, travelling in a soft body. There had been a great deal of rain. On the river levels were flat gleams of flood water. The sky was grey, with glisten of silver here and there. In Wilford churchyard the dahlias were sodden with rain--wet black-crimson balls. No one was on the path that went along the green river meadow, along the elm-tree colonnade.

There was the faintest haze over the silvery-dark water and the green meadow-bank, and the elm-trees that were spangled with gold. The river slid by in a body, utterly silent and swift, intertwining among itself like some subtle, complex creature. Clara walked moodily beside him (Wilford).

``Why,'' (she)
she (Clara) asked at length, in rather a jarring tone,
``did you leave Miriam?'' (she)

He (Wilford) frowned.

``Because I WANTED to leave her (Miriam),'' (he)
he (Wilford) said.

``Why?'' (unknown)

``Because I didn't want to go on with her (Miriam). And I didn't want to marry.'' (She)

She (Clara) was silent for a moment. They picked their way down the muddy path. Drops of water fell from the elm-trees.

``You didn't want to marry Miriam, or you didn't want to marry at all?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``Both,'' (he)
he (Wilford) answered--
``both!'' (he)

They had to manoeuvre to get to the stile, because of the pools of water.

``And what did she (Miriam) say?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
Clara asked.

``Miriam? She (Miriam) said I was a baby of four, and that I always HAD battled her (Miriam) off.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara pondered over this for a time.

``But you have really been going with her (Miriam) for some time?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``And now you don't want any more of her (Miriam)?'' (unknown)

``No. I know it's no good.'' (She)

She (Clara) pondered again.

``Don't you think you've treated her (Miriam) rather badly?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``Yes; I ought to have dropped it years back. But it would have been no good going on. Two wrongs don't make a right.'' (unknown)

``How old ARE you?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
Clara asked.

``Twenty-five.'' (unknown)

``And I am thirty,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

``I know you are.'' (unknown)

``I shall be thirty-one--or AM I thirty-one?'' (unknown)

``I neither know nor care. What does it matter!'' (unknown)

They were at the entrance to the Grove. The wet, red track, already sticky with fallen leaves, went up the steep bank between the grass. On either side stood the elm-trees like pillars along a great aisle, arching over and making high up a roof from which the dead leaves fell. All was empty and silent and wet. She (Clara) stood on top of the stile, and he (Clara) held both her (Clara) hands. Laughing, she (Clara) looked down into his (Clara) eyes. Then she (Clara) leaped. Her (Clara) breast came against his (Clara); he (Clara) held her (Clara), and covered her (Clara) face with kisses.

They went on up the slippery, steep red path. Presently she (Clara) released his (Clara) hand and put it round her (Clara) waist.

``You press the vein in my arm, holding it so tightly,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

They walked along. His (Clara) finger-tips felt the rocking of her (Clara) breast. All was silent and deserted. On the left the red wet plough-land showed through the doorways between the elm-boles and their branches. On the right, looking down, they could see the tree-tops of elms growing far beneath them, hear occasionally the gurgle of the river. Sometimes there below they caught glimpses of the full, soft-sliding Trent, and of water-meadows dotted with small cattle.

``It has scarcely altered since little Kirke White used to come,'' (he)
he (Trent) said.

But he (Trent) was watching her (Clara) throat below the ear, where the flush was fusing into the honey-white, and her (Clara) mouth that pouted disconsolate. She (Clara) stirred against him (Trent) as she (Clara) walked, and his (Trent) body was like a taut string.

Halfway up the big colonnade of elms, where the Grove rose highest above the river, their forward movement faltered to an end. He (Trent) led her (Clara) across to the grass, under the trees at the edge of the path. The cliff of red earth sloped swiftly down, through trees and bushes, to the river that glimmered and was dark between the foliage. The far-below water-meadows were very green. He (Trent) and she (Clara) stood leaning against one another, silent, afraid, their bodies touching all along. There came a quick gurgle from the river below.

``Why,'' (he)
he (Trent) asked at length,
``did you hate Baxter Dawes?'' (he)

She (Clara) turned to him (Trent) with a splendid movement. Her (Clara) mouth was offered him (Trent), and her (Clara) throat; her (Clara) eyes were half-shut; her (Clara) breast was tilted as if it asked for him (Trent). He (Trent) flashed with a small laugh, shut his (Trent) eyes, and met her (Clara) in a long, whole kiss. Her (Clara) mouth fused with his (Trent); their bodies were sealed and annealed. It was some minutes before they withdrew. They were standing beside the public path.

``Will you go down to the river?'' (he)
he (Trent) asked.

She (Clara) looked at him (Trent), leaving herself in his (Trent) hands. He (Trent) went over the brim of the declivity and began to climb down.

``It is slippery,'' (he)
he (Trent) said.

``Never mind,'' (she)
she (Clara) replied.

The red clay went down almost sheer. He (Trent) slid, went from one tuft of grass to the next, hanging on to the bushes, making for a little platform at the foot of a tree. There he (Trent) waited for her (Clara), laughing with excitement. Her (Clara) shoes were clogged with red earth. It was hard for her (Clara). He (Trent) frowned. At last he (Trent) caught her (Clara) hand, and she (Clara) stood beside him (Trent). The cliff rose above them and fell away below. Her (Clara) colour was up, her (Clara) eyes flashed. He (Trent) looked at the big drop below them.

``It's risky,'' (he)
he (Trent) said;
``or messy, at any rate. Shall we go back?'' (he)

``Not for my sake,'' (she)
she (Clara) said quickly.

``All right. You see, I can't help you; I should only hinder. Give me that little parcel and your gloves. Your poor shoes!'' (unknown)

They stood perched on the face of the declivity, under the trees.

``Well, I'll go again,'' (he)
he (Trent) said.

Away he (Trent) went, slipping, staggering, sliding to the next tree, into which he (Trent) fell with a slam that nearly shook the breath out of him (Trent). She (Clara) came after cautiously, hanging on to the twigs and grasses. So they descended, stage by stage, to the river's brink. There, to his (Trent) disgust, the flood had eaten away the path, and the red decline ran straight into the water. He (Trent) dug in his (Trent) heels and brought himself up violently. The string of the parcel broke with a snap; the brown parcel bounded down, leaped into the water, and sailed smoothly away. He (Trent) hung on to his (Trent) tree.

``Well, I'll be damned!'' (he)
he (Trent) cried crossly. Then he (Trent) laughed. She (Trent) was coming perilously down.

``Mind!'' (he)
he (Trent) warned her (Trent). He (Trent) stood with his (Trent) back to the tree, waiting.
``Come now,'' (he)
he (Trent) called, opening his (Trent) arms.

She (Trent) let herself run. He (Trent) caught her (Trent), and together they stood watching the dark water scoop at the raw edge of the bank. The parcel had sailed out of sight.

``It doesn't matter,'' (she)
she (Trent) said.

He (Trent) held her (Trent) close and kissed her (Trent). There was only room for their four feet.

``It's a swindle!'' (he)
he (Trent) said.
``But there's a rut where a man has been, so if we go on I guess we shall find the path again.'' (unknown)

The river slid and twined its great volume. On the other bank cattle were feeding on the desolate flats. The cliff rose high above Paul and Clara on their right hand. They stood against the tree in the watery silence.

``Let us try going forward,'' (he)
he (Paul) said; and they struggled in the red clay along the groove a man's nailed boots had made. They were hot and flushed. Their barkled shoes hung heavy on their steps. At last they found the broken path. It was littered with rubble from the water, but at any rate it was easier. They cleaned their boots with twigs. His (man) heart was beating thick and fast.

Suddenly, coming on to the little level, he (man) saw two figures of men standing silent at the water's edge. His (man) heart leaped. They were fishing. He (man) turned and put his (man) hand up warningly to Clara. She (Clara) hesitated, buttoned her (Clara) coat. The two went on together.

The fishermen turned curiously to watch the two intruders on their privacy and solitude. They had had a fire, but it was nearly out. All kept perfectly still. The men turned again to their fishing, stood over the grey glinting river like statues. Clara went with bowed head, flushing; he (man) was laughing to himself. Directly they passed out of sight behind the willows.

``Now they ought to be drowned,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul softly.

Clara did not answer. They toiled forward along a tiny path on the river's lip. Suddenly it vanished. The bank was sheer red solid clay in front of them, sloping straight into the river. He (lip) stood and cursed beneath his (lip) breath, setting his (lip) teeth.

``It's impossible!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.

He (lip) stood erect, looking round. Just ahead were two islets in the stream, covered with osiers. But they were unattainable. The cliff came down like a sloping wall from far above their heads. Behind, not far back, were the fishermen. Across the river the distant cattle fed silently in the desolate afternoon. He (lip) cursed again deeply under his (lip) breath. He (lip) gazed up the great steep bank. Was there no hope but to scale back to the public path?

``Stop a minute,'' (he)
he (lip) said, and, digging his (lip) heels sideways into the steep bank of red clay, he (lip) began nimbly to mount. He (lip) looked across at every tree-foot. At last he (lip) found what he (lip) wanted. Two beech-trees side by side on the hill held a little level on the upper face between their roots. It was littered with damp leaves, but it would do. The fishermen were perhaps sufficiently out of sight. He (lip) threw down his (lip) rainproof and waved to her (lip) to come.

She (lip) toiled to his (lip) side. Arriving there, she (lip) looked at him (lip) heavily, dumbly, and laid her (lip) head on his (lip) shoulder. He (lip) held her (lip) fast as he (lip) looked round. They were safe enough from all but the small, lonely cows over the river.
