He (lip) sunk his (lip) mouth on her (lip) throat, where he (lip) felt her (lip) heavy pulse beat under his (lip) lips. Everything was perfectly still. There was nothing in the afternoon but themselves.

When she (lip) arose, he (lip), looking on the ground all the time, saw suddenly sprinkled on the black wet beech-roots many scarlet carnation petals, like splashed drops of blood; and red, small splashes fell from her (lip) bosom, streaming down her (lip) dress to her (lip) feet.

``Your flowers are smashed,'' (he)
he (lip) said.

She (lip) looked at him (lip) heavily as she (lip) put back her (lip) hair. Suddenly he (lip) put his (lip) finger-tips on her (lip) cheek.

``Why dost look so heavy?'' (he)
he (lip) reproached her (lip).

She (lip) smiled sadly, as if she (lip) felt alone in herself. He (lip) caressed her (lip) cheek with his (lip) fingers, and kissed her (lip).

``Nay!'' (he)
he (lip) said.
``Never thee bother!'' (She)

She (lip) gripped his (lip) fingers tight, and laughed shakily. Then she (lip) dropped her (lip) hand. He (lip) put the hair back from her (lip) brows, stroking her (lip) temples, kissing them lightly.

``But tha shouldna worrit!'' (he)
he (lip) said softly, pleading.

``No, I don't worry!'' (she)
she (lip) laughed tenderly and resigned.

``Yea, tha does! Dunna thee worrit,'' (he)
he (lip) implored, caressing.

``No!'' (she)
she (lip) consoled him (lip), kissing him (lip).

They had a stiff climb to get to the top again. It took them a quarter of an hour. When he (lip) got on to the level grass, he (lip) threw off his (lip) cap, wiped the sweat from his (lip) forehead, and sighed.

``Now we're back at the ordinary level,'' (he)
he (lip) said.

She (lip) sat down, panting, on the tussocky grass. Her (lip) cheeks were flushed pink. He (lip) kissed her (lip), and she (lip) gave way to joy.

``And now I'll clean thy boots and make thee fit for respectable folk,'' (he)
he (lip) said.

He (lip) kneeled at her (lip) feet, worked away with a stick and tufts of grass. She (lip) put her (lip) fingers in his (lip) hair, drew his (lip) head to her (lip), and kissed it.

``What am I supposed to be doing,'' (he)
he (lip) said, looking at her (lip) laughing;
``cleaning shoes or dibbling with love? Answer me that!'' (he)

``Just whichever I please,'' (she)
she (lip) replied.

``I'm your boot-boy for the time being, and nothing else!'' (unknown)
But they remained looking into each other's eyes and laughing. Then they kissed with little nibbling kisses.

``T-t-t-t!'' (he)
he (lip) went with his (lip) tongue, like his (lip) mother.
``I tell you, nothing gets done when there's a woman about.'' (he)

And he (lip) returned to his (lip) boot-cleaning, singing softly. She (mother) touched his (lip) thick hair, and he (lip) kissed her (mother) fingers. He (lip) worked away at her (mother) shoes. At last they were quite presentable.

``There you are, you see!'' (he)
he (lip) said.
``Aren't I a great hand at restoring you to respectability? Stand up! There, you look as irreproachable as Britannia herself!'' (He)

He (lip) cleaned his (lip) own boots a little, washed his (lip) hands in a puddle, and sang. They went on into Clifton village. He (Clifton) was madly in love with her (mother); every movement she (mother) made, every crease in her (mother) garments, sent a hot flash through him (Clifton) and seemed adorable.

The old lady at whose house they had tea was roused into gaiety by them.

``I could wish you'd had something of a better day,'' (she)
she (lady) said, hovering round.

``Nay!'' (he)
he (Clifton) laughed.
``We've been saying how nice it is.'' (The lady)

The old lady looked at him (Clifton) curiously. There was a peculiar glow and charm about him (Clifton). His (Clifton) eyes were dark and laughing. He (Clifton) rubbed his (Clifton) moustache with a glad movement.

``Have you been saying SO!'' (she)
she (lady) exclaimed, a light rousing in her (lady) old eyes.

``Truly!'' (he)
he (Clifton) laughed.

``Then I'm sure the day's good enough,'' (the lady)
said the old lady.

She (lady) fussed about, and did not want to leave them.

``I don't know whether you'd like some radishes as well,'' (she)
she (lady) said to Clara;
``but I've got some in the garden--AND a cucumber.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara flushed. She (Clara) looked very handsome.

``I should like some radishes,'' (she)
she (Clara) answered.

And the old lady pottered off gleefully.

``If she (herself) knew!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara quietly to him (Clifton).

``Well, she (herself) doesn't know; and it shows we're nice in ourselves, at any rate. You look quite enough to satisfy an archangel, and I'm sure I feel harmless--so--if it makes you look nice, and makes folk happy when they have us, and makes us happy--why, we're not cheating them out of much!'' (unknown)

They went on with the meal. When they were going away, the old lady came timidly with three tiny dahlias in full blow, neat as bees, and speckled scarlet and white. She (lady) stood before Clara, pleased with herself, saying:

``I don't know whether--'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
and holding the flowers forward in her (Clara) old hand.

``Oh, how pretty!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
cried Clara, accepting the flowers.

``Shall she (herself) have them all?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul reproachfully of the old woman.

``Yes, she (herself) shall have them all,'' (she)
she (woman) replied, beaming with joy.
``You have got enough for your share.'' (unknown)

``Ah, but I shall ask her (herself) to give me one!'' (he)
he (Paul) teased.

``Then she (herself) does as she (herself) pleases,'' (the lady)
said the old lady, smiling. And she (lady) bobbed a little curtsey of delight.

Clara was rather quiet and uncomfortable. As they walked along, he (Paul) said:

``You don't feel criminal, do you?'' (he)

She (Clara) looked at him (Paul) with startled grey eyes.

``Criminal!'' (she)
she (Clara) said.
``No.'' (unknown)

``But you seem to feel you have done a wrong?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Clara) said. ``I only think,
``If they knew!''' (unknown)

``If they knew, they'd cease to understand. As it is, they do understand, and they like it. What do they matter? Here, with only the trees and me, you don't feel not the least bit wrong, do you?'' (He)

He (Paul) took her (Clara) by the arm, held her (Clara) facing him (Paul), holding her (Clara) eyes with his (Paul). Something fretted him (Paul).

``Not sinners, are we?'' (he)
he (Paul) said, with an uneasy little frown.

``No,'' (she)
she (Clara) replied.

He (Paul) kissed her (Clara), laughing.

``You like your little bit of guiltiness, I believe,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``I believe Eve enjoyed it, when she (they) went cowering out of Paradise.'' (him)

But there was a certain glow and quietness about her (Clara) that made him (Paul) glad. When he (Paul) was alone in the railway-carriage, he (Paul) found himself tumultuously happy, and the people exceedingly nice, and the night lovely, and everything good.

Mrs. Morel was sitting reading when he (Paul) got home. Her (Morel) health was not good now, and there had come that ivory pallor into her (Morel) face which he (Paul) never noticed, and which afterwards he (Paul) never forgot. She (Morel) did not mention her (Morel) own ill-health to him (Paul). After all, she (Morel) thought, it was not much.

``You are late!'' (she)
she (Morel) said, looking at him (Paul).

His (Paul) eyes were shining; his (Paul) face seemed to glow. He (Paul) smiled to her (Morel).

``Yes; I've been down Clifton Grove with Clara.'' (mother)

His (Paul) mother looked at him (Paul) again.

``But won't people talk?'' (she)
she (mother) said.

``Why? They know she (Clara)'s a suffragette, and so on. And what if they do talk!'' (unknown)

``Of course, there may be nothing wrong in it,'' (mother)
said his (Paul) mother.
``But you know what folks are, and if once she (Clara) gets talked about--'' (unknown)

``Well, I can't help it. Their jaw isn't so almighty important, after all.'' (unknown)

``I think you ought to consider HER.'' (unknown)

``So I DO! What can people say?--that we take a walk together. I believe you're jealous.'' (unknown)

``You know I should be GLAD if she (Clara) weren't a married woman.'' (unknown)

``Well, my dear, she (Clara) lives separate from her (Clara) husband, and talks on platforms; so she (Clara)'s already singled out from the sheep, and, as far as I can see, hasn't much to lose. No; her (Clara) life's nothing to her (Clara), so what's the worth of nothing? She (Clara) goes with me--it becomes something. Then she (Clara) must pay--we both must pay! Folk are so frightened of paying; they'd rather starve and die.'' (unknown)

``Very well, my son. We'll see how it will end.'' (unknown)

``Very well, my mother. I'll abide by the end.'' (unknown)

``We'll see!'' (unknown)

``And she (mother)'s--she (mother)'s AWFULLY nice, mother; she (mother) is really! You don't know!'' (unknown)

``That's not the same as marrying her (mother).'' (unknown)

``It's perhaps better.'' (unknown)

There was silence for a while. He (Paul) wanted to ask his (Paul) mother something, but was afraid.

``Should you like to know her (mother)?'' (He)
He (Paul) hesitated.

``Yes,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel coolly.
``I should like to know what she (mother)'s like.'' (unknown)

``But she (mother)'s nice, mother, she (mother) is! And not a bit common!'' (unknown)

``I never suggested she (mother) was.'' (unknown)

``But you seem to think she (mother)'s--not as good as--She (mother)'s better than ninety-nine folk out of a hundred, I tell you! She (mother)'s BETTER, she (mother) is! She (mother)'s fair, she (mother)'s honest, she (mother)'s straight! There isn't anything underhand or superior about her (mother). Don't be mean about her (mother)!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)

Mrs. Morel flushed.

``I am sure I am not mean about her (mother). She (mother) may be quite as you say, but--'' (he)

``You don't approve,'' (he)
he (Paul) finished.

``And do you expect me to?'' (she)
she (Morel) answered coldly.

``Yes!--yes!--if you'd anything about you, you'd be glad! Do you WANT to see her (mother)?'' (unknown)

``I said I did.'' (unknown)

``Then I'll bring her (mother)--shall I bring her (mother) here?'' (unknown)

``You please yourself.'' (unknown)

``Then I WILL bring her (mother) here--one Sunday--to tea. If you think a horrid thing about her (mother), I shan't forgive you.'' (mother)

His (Paul) mother laughed.

``As if it would make any difference!'' (she)
she (mother) said. He (Paul) knew he (Paul) had won.

``Oh, but it feels so fine, when she (mother)'s there! She (mother)'s such a queen in her (mother) way.'' (he)

Occasionally he (Paul) still walked a little way from chapel with Miriam and Edgar. He (Edgar) did not go up to the farm. She (Miriam), however, was very much the same with him (Edgar), and he (Edgar) did not feel embarrassed in her (Miriam) presence. One evening she (Miriam) was alone when he (Edgar) accompanied her (Miriam). They began by talking books: it was their unfailing topic. Mrs. Morel had said that his (Edgar) and Miriam's affair was like a fire fed on books--if there were no more volumes it would die out. Miriam, for her (Miriam) part, boasted that she (Miriam) could read him (Edgar) like a book, could place her (Miriam) finger any minute on the chapter and the line. He (Edgar), easily taken in, believed that Miriam knew more about him (Edgar) than anyone else. So it pleased him (Edgar) to talk to her (Miriam) about himself, like the simplest egoist. Very soon the conversation drifted to his (Edgar) own doings. It flattered him (Edgar) immensely that he (Edgar) was of such supreme interest.

``And what have you been doing lately?'' (unknown)

``I--oh, not much! I made a sketch of Bestwood from the garden, that is nearly right at last. It's the hundredth try.'' (unknown)

So they went on. Then she (Miriam) said:

``You've not been out, then, lately?'' (she)

``Yes; I went up Clifton Grove on Monday afternoon with Clara.'' (unknown)

``It was not very nice weather,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam,
``was it?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

``But I wanted to go out, and it was all right. The Trent IS full.'' (unknown)

``And did you go to Barton?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``No; we had tea in Clifton.'' (unknown)

``DID you! That would be nice.'' (unknown)

``It was! The jolliest old woman! She (woman) gave us several pompom dahlias, as pretty as you like.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam bowed her (Miriam) head and brooded. He (Edgar) was quite unconscious of concealing anything from her (Miriam).

``What made her (woman) give them you?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

He (Edgar) laughed.

``Because she (woman) liked us--because we were jolly, I should think.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam put her (Miriam) finger in her (Miriam) mouth.

``Were you late home?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

At last he (Edgar) resented her (Miriam) tone.

``I caught the seven-thirty.'' (unknown)

``Ha!'' (he)

They walked on in silence, and he (Edgar) was angry.

``And how IS Clara?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
asked Miriam.

``Quite all right, I think.'' (unknown)

``That's good!'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, with a tinge of irony.
``By the way, what of her (Clara) husband? One never hears anything of him (husband).'' (unknown)

``He (husband)'s got some other woman, and is also quite all right,'' (he)
he (Edgar) replied.
``At least, so I think.'' (unknown)

``I see--you don't know for certain. Don't you think a position like that is hard on a woman?'' (unknown)

``Rottenly hard!'' (unknown)

``It's so unjust!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.
``The man does as he (man) likes--'' (he)

``Then let the woman also,'' (he)
he (Edgar) said.

``How can she (woman)? And if she (woman) does, look at her (woman) position!'' (unknown)

``What of it?'' (unknown)

``Why, it's impossible! You don't understand what a woman forfeits--'' (unknown)

``No, I don't. But if a woman's got nothing but her (woman) fair fame to feed on, why, it's thin tack, and a donkey would die of it!'' (she)

So she (Miriam) understood his (Edgar) moral attitude, at least, and she (Miriam) knew he (Edgar) would act accordingly.

She (Miriam) never asked him (Edgar) anything direct, but she (Miriam) got to know enough.

Another day, when he (Edgar) saw Miriam, the conversation turned to marriage, then to Clara's marriage with Dawes.

``You see,'' (he)
he (Edgar) said,
``she (woman) never knew the fearful importance of marriage. She (woman) thought it was all in the day's march--it would have to come--and Dawes--well, a good many women would have given their souls to get him (You); so why not him (You)? Then she (Dawes) developed into the femme incomprise, and treated him (You) badly, I'll bet my boots.'' (he)

``And she (Dawes) left him (You) because he (You) didn't understand her (Dawes)?'' (unknown)

``I suppose so. I suppose she (Dawes) had to. It isn't altogether a question of understanding; it's a question of living. With him (You), she (Dawes) was only half-alive; the rest was dormant, deadened. And the dormant woman was the femme incomprise, and she (woman) HAD to be awakened.'' (unknown)

``And what about him (You).'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I rather think he (You) loves her (woman) as much as he (You) can, but he (You)'s a fool.'' (unknown)

``It was something like your mother and father,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

``Yes; but my mother, I believe, got real joy and satisfaction out of my father at first. I believe she (mother) had a passion for him (father); that's why she (mother) stayed with him (father). After all, they were bound to each other.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

``That's what one MUST HAVE, I think,'' (he)
he (Edgar) continued--
``the real, real flame of feeling through another person--once, only once, if it only lasts three months. See, my mother looks as if she (mother)'d HAD everything that was necessary for her (mother) living and developing. There's not a tiny bit of feeling of sterility about her (mother).'' (he)

``No,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

``And with my father, at first, I'm sure she (mother) had the real thing. She (mother) knows; she (mother) has been there. You can feel it about her (mother), and about him (father), and about hundreds of people you meet every day; and, once it has happened to you, you can go on with anything and ripen.'' (unknown)

``What happened, exactly?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
asked Miriam.

``It's so hard to say, but the something big and intense that changes you when you really come together with somebody else. It almost seems to fertilise your soul and make it that you can go on and mature.'' (unknown)

``And you think your mother had it with your father?'' (unknown)

``Yes; and at the bottom she (mother) feels grateful to him (father) for giving it her (mother), even now, though they are miles apart.'' (unknown)

``And you think Clara never had it?'' (unknown)

``I'm sure.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam pondered this. She (Miriam) saw what he (Edgar) was seeking--a sort of baptism of fire in passion, it seemed to her (Miriam). She (Miriam) realised that he (Edgar) would never be satisfied till he (Edgar) had it. Perhaps it was essential to him (Edgar), as to some men, to sow wild oats; and afterwards, when he (Edgar) was satisfied, he (Edgar) would not rage with restlessness any more, but could settle down and give her (Miriam) his (Edgar) life into her (Miriam) hands. Well, then, if he (Edgar) must go, let him (Edgar) go and have his (Edgar) fill--something big and intense, he (Edgar) called it. At any rate, when he (Edgar) had got it, he (Edgar) would not want it--that he (Edgar) said himself; he (Edgar) would want the other thing that she (Miriam) could give him (Edgar). He (Edgar) would want to be owned, so that he (Edgar) could work. It seemed to her (Miriam) a bitter thing that he (Edgar) must go, but she (Miriam) could let him (Edgar) go into an inn for a glass of whisky, so she (Miriam) could let him (Edgar) go to Clara, so long as it was something that would satisfy a need in him (Edgar), and leave him (Edgar) free for herself to possess.

``Have you told your mother about Clara?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

She (Clara) knew this would be a test of the seriousness of his (Edgar) feeling for the other woman: she (woman) knew he (Edgar) was going to Clara for something vital, not as a man goes for pleasure to a prostitute, if he (man) told his (man) mother.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``and she (Clara) is coming to tea on Sunday.'' (he)

``To your house?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I want mater to see her (Clara).'' (unknown)

``Ah!'' (unknown)

There was a silence. Things had gone quicker than she (mother) thought. She (mother) felt a sudden bitterness that he (man) could leave her (mother) so soon and so entirely. And was Clara to be accepted by his (man) people, who had been so hostile to herself?

``I may call in as I go to chapel,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.
``It is a long time since I saw Clara.'' (unknown)

``Very well,'' (he)
he (man) said, astonished, and unconsciously angry.

On the Sunday afternoon he (man) went to Keston to meet Clara at the station. As he (man) stood on the platform he (man) was trying to examine in himself if he (man) had a premonition.

``Do I FEEL as if she (Clara)'d come?'' (he)
he (man) said to himself, and he (man) tried to find out. His (man) heart felt queer and contracted. That seemed like foreboding. Then he (man) HAD a foreboding she (Clara) would not come! Then she (Clara) would not come, and instead of taking her (Clara) over the fields home, as he (man) had imagined, he (man) would have to go alone. The train was late; the afternoon would be wasted, and the evening. He (man) hated her (Clara) for not coming. Why had she (Clara) promised, then, if she (Clara) could not keep her (Clara) promise? Perhaps she (Clara) had missed her (Clara) train--he (man) himself was always missing trains--but that was no reason why she (Clara) should miss this particular one. He (man) was angry with her (Clara); he (man) was furious.

Suddenly he (man) saw the train crawling, sneaking round the corner. Here, then, was the train, but of course she (Clara) had not come. The green engine hissed along the platform, the row of brown carriages drew up, several doors opened. No; she (Clara) had not come! No! Yes; ah, there she (Clara) was! She (Clara) had a big black hat on! He (man) was at her (Clara) side in a moment.

``I thought you weren't coming,'' (he)
he (man) said.

She (Clara) was laughing rather breathlessly as she (Clara) put out her (Clara) hand to him (man); their eyes met. He (man) took her (Clara) quickly along the platform, talking at a great rate to hide his (man) feeling. She (Clara) looked beautiful. In her (Clara) hat were large silk roses, coloured like tarnished gold. Her (Clara) costume of dark cloth fitted so beautifully over her (Clara) breast and shoulders. His (man) pride went up as he (man) walked with her (Clara). He (man) felt the station people, who knew him (man), eyed her (Clara) with awe and admiration.

``I was sure you weren't coming,'' (he)
he (man) laughed shakily.

She (Clara) laughed in answer, almost with a little cry.

``And I wondered, when I was in the train, WHATEVER I should do if you weren't there!'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

He (man) caught her (Clara) hand impulsively, and they went along the narrow twitchel. They took the road into Nuttall and over the Reckoning House Farm. It was a blue, mild day. Everywhere the brown leaves lay scattered; many scarlet hips stood upon the hedge beside the wood. He (Nuttall) gathered a few for her (Clara) to wear.

``Though, really,'' (he)
he (Nuttall) said, as he (Nuttall) fitted them into the breast of her (Clara) coat,
``you ought to object to my getting them, because of the birds. But they don't care much for rose-hips in this part, where they can get plenty of stuff. You often find the berries going rotten in the springtime.'' (he)

So he (Nuttall) chattered, scarcely aware of what he (Nuttall) said, only knowing he (Nuttall) was putting berries in the bosom of her (Clara) coat, while she (Clara) stood patiently for him (Nuttall). And she (Clara) watched his (Nuttall) quick hands, so full of life, and it seemed to her (Clara) she (Clara) had never SEEN anything before. Till now, everything had been indistinct.

They came near to the colliery. It stood quite still and black among the corn-fields, its immense heap of slag seen rising almost from the oats.

``What a pity there is a coal-pit here where it is so pretty!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.

``Do you think so?'' (he)
he (Nuttall) answered.
``You see, I am so used to it I should miss it. No; and I like the pits here and there. I like the rows of trucks, and the headstocks, and the steam in the daytime, and the lights at night. When I was a boy, I always thought a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night was a pit, with its steam, and its lights, and the burning bank,--and I thought the Lord was always at the pit-top.'' (she)

As they drew near home she (Clara) walked in silence, and seemed to hang back. He (Nuttall) pressed her (Clara) fingers in his (Nuttall) own. She (Clara) flushed, but gave no response.

``Don't you want to come home?'' (he)
he (Nuttall) asked.

``Yes, I want to come,'' (she)
she (Clara) replied.

It did not occur to him (Nuttall) that her (Clara) position in his (Nuttall) home would be rather a peculiar and difficult one. To him (Nuttall) it seemed just as if one of his (Nuttall) men friends were going to be introduced to his (Nuttall) mother, only nicer.

The Morels lived in a house in an ugly street that ran down a steep hill. The street itself was hideous. The house was rather superior to most. It was old, grimy, with a big bay window, and it was semi-detached; but it looked gloomy. Then Paul opened the door to the garden, and all was different. The sunny afternoon was there, like another land. By the path grew tansy and little trees. In front of the window was a plot of sunny grass, with old lilacs round it. And away went the garden, with heaps of dishevelled chrysanthemums in the sunshine, down to the sycamore-tree, and the field, and beyond one looked over a few red-roofed cottages to the hills with all the glow of the autumn afternoon.

Mrs. Morel sat in her (Morel) rocking-chair, wearing her (Morel) black silk blouse. Her (Morel) grey-brown hair was taken smooth back from her (Morel) brow and her (Morel) high temples; her (Morel) face was rather pale. Clara, suffering, followed Paul into the kitchen. Mrs. Morel rose. Clara thought her (Clara) a lady, even rather stiff. The young woman was very nervous. She (woman) had almost a wistful look, almost resigned.

``Mother--Clara,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

Mrs. Morel held out her (Morel) hand and smiled.

``He (Lord) has told me a good deal about you,'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

The blood flamed in Clara's cheek.

``I hope you don't mind my coming,'' (she)
she (Clara) faltered.

``I was pleased when he (Lord) said he (Lord) would bring you,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
replied Mrs. Morel.

Paul, watching, felt his (Paul) heart contract with pain. His (Paul) mother looked so small, and sallow, and done-for beside the luxuriant Clara.

``It's such a pretty day, mother!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``And we saw a jay.'' (mother)

His (Paul) mother looked at him (Paul); he (Paul) had turned to her (mother). She (mother) thought what a man he (Paul) seemed, in his (Paul) dark, well-made clothes. He (Paul) was pale and detached-looking; it would be hard for any woman to keep him (Paul). Her (woman) heart glowed; then she (woman) was sorry for Clara.

``Perhaps you'll leave your things in the parlour,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel nicely to the young woman.

``Oh, thank you,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.

``Come on,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, and he (Paul) led the way into the little front room, with its old piano, its mahogany furniture, its yellowing marble mantelpiece. A fire was burning; the place was littered with books and drawing-boards.
``I leave my things lying about,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``It's so much easier.'' (She)

She (Morel) loved his (Paul) artist's paraphernalia, and the books, and the photos of people. Soon he (Paul) was telling her (Morel): this was William, this was William's young lady in the evening dress, this was Annie and her (Annie) husband, this was Arthur and his (Arthur) wife and the baby. She (Annie) felt as if she (Annie) were being taken into the family. He (Arthur) showed her (Annie) photos, books, sketches, and they talked a little while. Then they returned to the kitchen. Mrs. Morel put aside her (Morel) book. Clara wore a blouse of fine silk chiffon, with narrow black-and-white stripes; her (Clara) hair was done simply, coiled on top of her (Clara) head. She (Clara) looked rather stately and reserved.

``You have gone to live down Sneinton Boulevard?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel.
``When I was a girl--girl, I say!--when I was a young woman WE lived in Minerva Terrace.'' (unknown)

``Oh, did you!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.
``I have a friend in number 6.'' (unknown)

And the conversation had started. They talked Nottingham and Nottingham people; it interested them both. Clara was still rather nervous; Mrs. Morel was still somewhat on her (Morel) dignity. She (Morel) clipped her (Morel) language very clear and precise. But they were going to get on well together, Paul saw.

Mrs. Morel measured herself against the younger woman, and found herself easily stronger. Clara was deferential. She (Clara) knew Paul's surprising regard for his (Paul) mother, and she (Clara) had dreaded the meeting, expecting someone rather hard and cold. She (Clara) was surprised to find this little interested woman chatting with such readiness; and then she (Clara) felt, as she (Clara) felt with Paul, that she (Clara) would not care to stand in Mrs. Morel's way. There was something so hard and certain in his (Paul) mother, as if she (mother) never had a misgiving in her (mother) life.

Presently Morel came down, ruffled and yawning, from his (Paul) afternoon sleep. He (Paul) scratched his (Paul) grizzled head, he (Paul) plodded in his (Paul) stocking feet, his (Paul) waistcoat hung open over his (Paul) shirt. He (Paul) seemed incongruous.

``This is Mrs. Dawes, father,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

Then Morel pulled himself together. Clara saw Paul's manner of bowing and shaking hands.

``Oh, indeed!'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
exclaimed Morel.
``I am very glad to see you--I am, I assure you. But don't disturb yourself. No, no make yourself quite comfortable, and be very welcome.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara was astonished at this flood of hospitality from the old collier. He (collier) was so courteous, so gallant! She (Clara) thought him (collier) most delightful.

``And may you have come far?'' (he)
he (collier) asked.

``Only from Nottingham,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

``From Nottingham! Then you have had a beautiful day for your journey.'' (he)

Then he (collier) strayed into the scullery to wash his (collier) hands and face, and from force of habit came on to the hearth with the towel to dry himself.

At tea Clara felt the refinement and sang-froid of the household. Mrs. Morel was perfectly at her (Morel) ease. The pouring out the tea and attending to the people went on unconsciously, without interrupting her (Morel) in her (Morel) talk. There was a lot of room at the oval table; the china of dark blue willow-pattern looked pretty on the glossy cloth. There was a little bowl of small, yellow chrysanthemums. Clara felt she (Clara) completed the circle, and it was a pleasure to her (Clara). But she (Clara) was rather afraid of the self-possession of the Morels, father and all. She (Clara) took their tone; there was a feeling of balance. It was a cool, clear atmosphere, where everyone was himself, and in harmony. Clara enjoyed it, but there was a fear deep at the bottom of her (Clara).

Paul cleared the table whilst his (Paul) mother and Clara talked. Clara was conscious of his (Paul) quick, vigorous body as it came and went, seeming blown quickly by a wind at its work. It was almost like the hither and thither of a leaf that comes unexpected. Most of herself went with him (Paul). By the way she (Clara) leaned forward, as if listening, Mrs. Morel could see she (Morel) was possessed elsewhere as she (Morel) talked, and again the elder woman was sorry for her (woman).

Having finished, he (Paul) strolled down the garden, leaving the two women to talk. It was a hazy, sunny afternoon, mild and soft. Clara glanced through the window after him (Paul) as he (Paul) loitered among the chrysanthemums. She (Clara) felt as if something almost tangible fastened her (Clara) to him (Paul); yet he (Paul) seemed so easy in his (Paul) graceful, indolent movement, so detached as he (Paul) tied up the too-heavy flower branches to their stakes, that she (Clara) wanted to shriek in her (Clara) helplessness.

Mrs. Morel rose.

``You will let me help you wash up,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.

``Eh, there are so few, it will only take a minute,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said the other.

Clara, however, dried the tea-things, and was glad to be on such good terms with his (Paul) mother; but it was torture not to be able to follow him (Paul) down the garden. At last she (Clara) allowed herself to go; she (Clara) felt as if a rope were taken off her (Clara) ankle.

The afternoon was golden over the hills of Derbyshire. He (Paul) stood across in the other garden, beside a bush of pale Michaelmas daisies, watching the last bees crawl into the hive. Hearing her (Clara) coming, he (Paul) turned to her (Clara) with an easy motion, saying:

``It's the end of the run with these chaps.'' (he)

Clara stood near him (Paul). Over the low red wall in front was the country and the far-off hills, all golden dim.

At that moment Miriam was entering through the garden-door. She (Miriam) saw Clara go up to him (Paul), saw him (Paul) turn, and saw them come to rest together. Something in their perfect isolation together made her (Clara) know that it was accomplished between them, that they were, as she (Clara) put it, married. She (Clara) walked very slowly down the cinder-track of the long garden.

Clara had pulled a button from a hollyhock spire, and was breaking it to get the seeds. Above her (Clara) bowed head the pink flowers stared, as if defending her (Clara). The last bees were falling down to the hive.

``Count your money,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
laughed Paul, as she (Clara) broke the flat seeds one by one from the roll of coin. She (Clara) looked at him (Paul).

``I'm well off,'' (she)
she (Clara) said, smiling.

``How much? Pf!'' (He)
He (Paul) snapped his (Paul) fingers.
``Can I turn them into gold?'' (unknown)

``I'm afraid not,'' (she)
she (Clara) laughed.

They looked into each other's eyes, laughing. At that moment they became aware of Miriam. There was a click, and everything had altered.

``Hello, Miriam!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed.
``You said you'd come!'' (unknown)

``Yes. Had you forgotten?'' (She)

She (Miriam) shook hands with Clara, saying:

``It seems strange to see you here.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

``Yes,'' (unknown)
replied the other;
``it seems strange to be here.'' (unknown)

There was a hesitation.

``This is pretty, isn't it?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

``I like it very much,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
replied Clara.

Then Miriam realised that Clara was accepted as she (Clara) had never been.

``Have you come down alone?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul.

``Yes; I went to Agatha's to tea. We are going to chapel. I only called in for a moment to see Clara.'' (unknown)

``You should have come in here to tea,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Miriam laughed shortly, and Clara turned impatiently aside.

``Do you like the chrysanthemums?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``Yes; they are very fine,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
replied Miriam.

``Which sort do you like best?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``I don't know. The bronze, I think.'' (unknown)

``I don't think you've seen all the sorts. Come and look. Come and see which are YOUR favourites, Clara.'' (He)

He (Paul) led the two women back to his (Paul) own garden, where the towsled bushes of flowers of all colours stood raggedly along the path down to the field. The situation did not embarrass him (Paul), to his (Paul) knowledge.

``Look, Miriam; these are the white ones that came from your garden. They aren't so fine here, are they?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam.

``But they're hardier. You're so sheltered; things grow big and tender, and then die. These little yellow ones I like. Will you have some?'' (unknown)

While they were out there the bells began to ring in the church, sounding loud across the town and the field. Miriam looked at the tower, proud among the clustering roofs, and remembered the sketches he (Paul) had brought her (Miriam). It had been different then, but he (Paul) had not left her (Miriam) even yet. She (Miriam) asked him (Paul) for a book to read. He (Paul) ran indoors.

``What! is that Miriam?'' (mother)
asked his (Paul) mother coldly.

``Yes; she (Miriam) said she (Miriam)'d call and see Clara.'' (unknown)

``You told her (Clara), then?'' (unknown)
came the sarcastic answer.

``Yes; why shouldn't I?'' (unknown)

``There's certainly no reason why you shouldn't,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
said Mrs. Morel, and she (Morel) returned to her (Morel) book. He (Paul) winced from his (Paul) mother's irony, frowned irritably, thinking:
``Why can't I do as I like?'' (mother)

``You've not seen Mrs. Morel before?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
Miriam was saying to Clara.

``No; but she (Morel)'s so nice!'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
said Miriam, dropping her (Miriam) head;
``in some ways she (Morel)'s very fine.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

``I should think so.'' (unknown)

``Had Paul told you much about her (Morel)?'' (unknown)

``He (Paul) had talked a good deal.'' (unknown)

``Ha!'' (he)

There was silence until he (Paul) returned with the book.

``When will you want it back?'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
Miriam asked.

``When you like,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.

Clara turned to go indoors, whilst he (Paul) accompanied Miriam to the gate.

``When will you come up to Willey Farm?'' (unknown)
the latter asked.

``I couldn't say,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
replied Clara.

``Mother asked me to say she (Mother)'d be pleased to see you any time, if you cared to come.'' (unknown)

``Thank you; I should like to, but I can't say when.'' (unknown)

``Oh, very well!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
exclaimed Miriam rather bitterly, turning away.

She (Miriam) went down the path with her (Miriam) mouth to the flowers he (Paul) had given her (Miriam).

``You're sure you won't come in?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``No, thanks.'' (unknown)

``We are going to chapel.'' (unknown)

``Ah, I shall see you, then!'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)
Miriam was very bitter.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

They parted. He (Paul) felt guilty towards her (Miriam). She (Miriam) was bitter, and she (Miriam) scorned him (Paul). He (Paul) still belonged to herself, she (Miriam) believed; yet he (Paul) could have Clara, take her (Clara) home, sit with her (Clara) next his (Paul) mother in chapel, give her (Clara) the same hymn-book he (Paul) had given herself years before. She (Clara) heard him (Paul) running quickly indoors.

But he (Paul) did not go straight in. Halting on the plot of grass, he (Paul) heard his (Paul) mother's voice, then Clara's answer:

``What I hate is the bloodhound quality in Miriam.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

``Yes,'' (mother T)
said his (Paul) mother quickly, ``yes; DOESN
``T it make you hate her (Miriam), now!'' (mother T)

His (Paul) heart went hot, and he (Paul) was angry with them for talking about the girl. What right had they to say that? Something in the speech itself stung him (Paul) into a flame of hate against Miriam. Then his (Paul) own heart rebelled furiously at Clara's taking the liberty of speaking so about Miriam. After all, the girl was the better woman of the two, he (Paul) thought, if it came to goodness. He (Paul) went indoors. His (Paul) mother looked excited. She (mother) was beating with her (mother) hand rhythmically on the sofa-arm, as women do who are wearing out. He (Paul) could never bear to see the movement. There was a silence; then he (Paul) began to talk.

In chapel Miriam saw him (Paul) find the place in the hymn-book for Clara, in exactly the same way as he (Paul) used for herself. And during the sermon he (Paul) could see the girl across the chapel, her (girl) hat throwing a dark shadow over her (girl) face. What did she (girl) think, seeing Clara with him (Paul)? He (Paul) did not stop to consider. He (Paul) felt himself cruel towards Miriam.

After chapel he (Paul) went over Pentrich with Clara. It was a dark autumn night. They had said good-bye to Miriam, and his (Paul) heart had smitten him (Paul) as he (Paul) left the girl alone.

``But it serves her (Miriam) right,'' (he)
he (Paul) said inside himself, and it almost gave him (Paul) pleasure to go off under her (Miriam) eyes with this other handsome woman.

There was a scent of damp leaves in the darkness. Clara's hand lay warm and inert in his (Paul) own as they walked. He (Paul) was full of conflict. The battle that raged inside him (Paul) made him (Paul) feel desperate.

Up Pentrich Hill Clara leaned against him (Paul) as he (Paul) went. He (Paul) slid his (Paul) arm round her (Clara) waist. Feeling the strong motion of her (Clara) body under his (Paul) arm as she (Clara) walked, the tightness in his (Paul) chest because of Miriam relaxed, and the hot blood bathed him (Paul). He (Paul) held her (Miriam) closer and closer.

Then:

``You still keep on with Miriam,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said quietly.

``Only talk. There never WAS a great deal more than talk between us,'' (he)
he (Paul) said bitterly.

``Your mother doesn't care for her (mother),'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.

``No, or I might have married her (mother). But it's all up really!'' (unknown)

Suddenly his (Paul) voice went passionate with hate.

``If I was with her (mother) now, we should be jawing about the

``Christian Mystery', or some such tack. Thank God, I'm not!'' (unknown)

They walked on in silence for some time.

``But you can't really give her (mother) up,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.

``I don't give her (mother) up, because there's nothing to give,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``There is for her (mother).'' (unknown)

``I don't know why she (mother) and I shouldn't be friends as long as we live,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``But it'll only be friends.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara drew away from him (Paul), leaning away from contact with him (Paul).

``What are you drawing away for?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

She (Clara) did not answer, but drew farther from him (Paul).

``Why do you want to walk alone?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

Still there was no answer. She (Clara) walked resentfully, hanging her (Clara) head.

``Because I said I would be friends with Miriam!'' (he)
he (Paul) exclaimed.

She (Clara) would not answer him (Paul) anything.

``I tell you it's only words that go between us,'' (he)
he (Paul) persisted, trying to take her (Clara) again.

She (Clara) resisted. Suddenly he (Paul) strode across in front of her (Clara), barring her (Clara) way.

``Damn it!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``What do you want now?'' (unknown)

``You'd better run after Miriam,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
mocked Clara.

The blood flamed up in him (Paul). He (Paul) stood showing his (Paul) teeth. She (Clara) drooped sulkily. The lane was dark, quite lonely. He (Paul) suddenly caught her (Clara) in his (Paul) arms, stretched forward, and put his (Paul) mouth on her (Clara) face in a kiss of rage. She (Clara) turned frantically to avoid him (Paul). He (Paul) held her (Clara) fast. Hard and relentless his (Paul) mouth came for her (Clara). Her (Clara) breasts hurt against the wall of his (Paul) chest. Helpless, she (Clara) went loose in his (Paul) arms, and he (Paul) kissed her (Clara), and kissed her (Clara).

He (Paul) heard people coming down the hill.

``Stand up! stand up!'' (he)
he (Paul) said thickly, gripping her (Clara) arm till it hurt. If he (Paul) had let go, she (Clara) would have sunk to the ground.

She (Clara) sighed and walked dizzily beside him (Paul). They went on in silence.

``We will go over the fields,'' (he)
he (Paul) said; and then she (Clara) woke up.

But she (Clara) let herself be helped over the stile, and she (Clara) walked in silence with him (Paul) over the first dark field. It was the way to Nottingham and to the station, she (Clara) knew. He (Paul) seemed to be looking about. They came out on a bare hilltop where stood the dark figure of the ruined windmill. There he (Paul) halted. They stood together high up in the darkness, looking at the lights scattered on the night before them, handfuls of glittering points, villages lying high and low on the dark, here and there.

``Like treading among the stars,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, with a quaky laugh.

Then he (Paul) took her (Clara) in his (Paul) arms, and held her (Clara) fast. She (Clara) moved aside her (Clara) mouth to ask, dogged and low:

``What time is it?'' (She)

``It doesn't matter,'' (he)
he (Paul) pleaded thickly.

``Yes it does--yes! I must go!'' (unknown)

``It's early yet,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``What time is it?'' (she)
she (Clara) insisted.

All round lay the black night, speckled and spangled with lights.

``I don't know.'' (She)

She (Clara) put her (Clara) hand on his (Paul) chest, feeling for his (he) watch. He (he) felt the joints fuse into fire. She (Clara) groped in his (he) waistcoat pocket, while he (He) stood panting. In the darkness she (Clara) could see the round, pale face of the watch, but not the figures. She (Clara) stooped over it. He (his) was panting till he (him) could take her (Clara) in his (his) arms again.

``I can't see,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

``Then don't bother.'' (unknown)

``Yes; I'm going!'' (she)
she (Clara) said, turning away.

``Wait! I'll look!'' (he)
But he (he) could not see.
``I'll strike a match.'' (He)

He (he) secretly hoped it was too late to catch the train. She (Clara) saw the glowing lantern of his (him) hands as he (He) cradled the light: then his (his) face lit up, his (He) eyes fixed on the watch. Instantly all was dark again. All was black before her (Clara) eyes; only a glowing match was red near her (Clara) feet. Where was he (his)?

``What is it?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked, afraid.

``You can't do it,'' (unknown)
his (he) voice answered out of the darkness.

There was a pause. She (Clara) felt in his (he) power. She (Clara) had heard the ring in his (he) voice. It frightened her (Clara).

``What time is it?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked, quiet, definite, hopeless.

``Two minutes to nine,'' (he)
he (he) replied, telling the truth with a struggle.

``And can I get from here to the station in fourteen minutes?'' (unknown)

``No. At any rate--'' (She)

She (Clara) could distinguish his (he) dark form again a yard or so away. She (Clara) wanted to escape.

``But can't I do it?'' (she)
she (Clara) pleaded.

``If you hurry,'' (he)
he (He) said brusquely.
``But you could easily walk it, Clara; it's only seven miles to the tram. I'll come with you.'' (unknown)

``No; I want to catch the train.'' (unknown)

``But why?'' (unknown)

``I do--I want to catch the train.'' (unknown)

Suddenly his (him) voice altered.

``Very well,'' (he)
he (He) said, dry and hard.
``Come along, then.'' (he)

And he (he) plunged ahead into the darkness. She (Clara) ran after him (his), wanting to cry. Now he (he) was hard and cruel to her (Clara). She (Clara) ran over the rough, dark fields behind him (him), out of breath, ready to drop. But the double row of lights at the station drew nearer. Suddenly:

``There she (Clara) is!'' (he)
he (he) cried, breaking into a run.

There was a faint rattling noise. Away to the right the train, like a luminous caterpillar, was threading across the night. The rattling ceased.

``She (Clara)'s over the viaduct. You'll just do it.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara ran, quite out of breath, and fell at last into the train. The whistle blew. He (he) was gone. Gone!--and she (Clara) was in a carriage full of people. She (Clara) felt the cruelty of it.

He (his) turned round and plunged home. Before he (his) knew where he (His) was he (he) was in the kitchen at home. He (him) was very pale. His (his) eyes were dark and dangerous-looking, as if he (he) were drunk. His (He) mother looked at him (His).

``Well, I must say your boots are in a nice state!'' (she)
she (mother) said.

He (His) looked at his (He) feet. Then he (he) took off his (him) overcoat. His (he) mother wondered if he (he) were drunk.

``She (Clara) caught the train then?'' (she)
she (mother) said.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``I hope HER feet weren't so filthy. Where on earth you dragged her (Clara) I don't know!'' (He)

He (him) was silent and motionless for some time.

``Did you like her (Clara)?'' (he)
he (He) asked grudgingly at last.

``Yes, I liked her (Clara). But you'll tire of her (Clara), my son; you know you will.'' (He)

He (He) did not answer. She (mother) noticed how he (he) laboured in his (his) breathing.

``Have you been running?'' (she)
she (mother) asked.

``We had to run for the train.'' (unknown)

``You'll go and knock yourself up. You'd better drink hot milk.'' (he)

It was as good a stimulant as he (he) could have, but he (he) refused and went to bed. There he (him) lay face down on the counterpane, and shed tears of rage and pain. There was a physical pain that made him (his) bite his (He) lips till they bled, and the chaos inside him (him) left him (him) unable to think, almost to feel.

``This is how she (Clara) serves me, is it?'' (he)
he (him) said in his (he) heart, over and over, pressing his (He) face in the quilt. And he (his) hated her (mother). Again he (his) went over the scene, and again he (him) hated her (mother).

The next day there was a new aloofness about him (He). Clara was very gentle, almost loving. But he (he) treated her (Clara) distantly, with a touch of contempt. She (Clara) sighed, continuing to be gentle. He (his) came round.

One evening of that week Sarah Bernhardt was at the Theatre Royal in Nottingham, giving

``La Dame aux Camelias'' (Sarah Bernhardt)
. Paul wanted to see this old and famous actress, and he (Paul) asked Clara to accompany him (Paul). He (Paul) told his (Paul) mother to leave the key in the window for him (Paul).

``Shall I book seats?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked of Clara.

``Yes. And put on an evening suit, will you? I've never seen you in it.'' (unknown)

``But, good Lord, Clara! Think of ME in evening suit at the theatre!'' (he)
he (Paul) remonstrated.

``Would you rather not?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``I will if you WANT me to; but I s'll feel a fool.'' (She)

She (Clara) laughed at him (Paul).

``Then feel a fool for my sake, once, won't you?'' (unknown)

The request made his (Paul) blood flush up.

``I suppose I s'll have to.'' (unknown)

``What are you taking a suitcase for?'' (mother)
his (Paul) mother asked.

He (Paul) blushed furiously.

``Clara asked me,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``And what seats are you going in?'' (unknown)

``Circle--three-and-six each!'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm sure!'' (mother)
exclaimed his (Paul) mother sarcastically.

``It's only once in the bluest of blue moons,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

He (Paul) dressed at Jordan's, put on an overcoat and a cap, and met Clara in a cafe. She (Clara) was with one of her (Clara) suffragette friends. She (Clara) wore an old long coat, which did not suit her (Clara), and had a little wrap over her (Clara) head, which he (Paul) hated. The three went to the theatre together.

Clara took off her (Clara) coat on the stairs, and he (Paul) discovered she (Clara) was in a sort of semi-evening dress, that left her (Clara) arms and neck and part of her (Clara) breast bare. Her (Clara) hair was done fashionably. The dress, a simple thing of green crape, suited her (Clara). She (Clara) looked quite grand, he (Paul) thought. He (Paul) could see her (Clara) figure inside the frock, as if that were wrapped closely round her (Clara). The firmness and the softness of her (Clara) upright body could almost be felt as he (Paul) looked at her (Clara). He (Paul) clenched his (Paul) fists.

And he (Paul) was to sit all the evening beside her (Clara) beautiful naked arm, watching the strong throat rise from the strong chest, watching the breasts under the green stuff, the curve of her (Clara) limbs in the tight dress. Something in him (Paul) hated her (Clara) again for submitting him (Paul) to this torture of nearness. And he (Paul) loved her (Clara) as she (Clara) balanced her (Clara) head and stared straight in front of her (Clara), pouting, wistful, immobile, as if she (Clara) yielded herself to her (Clara) fate because it was too strong for her (Clara). She (Clara) could not help herself; she (Clara) was in the grip of something bigger than herself. A kind of eternal look about her (Clara), as if she (Clara) were a wistful sphinx, made it necessary for him (Paul) to kiss her (Clara). He (Paul) dropped his (Paul) programme, and crouched down on the floor to get it, so that he (Paul) could kiss her (Clara) hand and wrist. Her (Clara) beauty was a torture to him (Paul). She (Clara) sat immobile. Only, when the lights went down, she (Clara) sank a little against him (Paul), and he (Paul) caressed her (Clara) hand and arm with his (Paul) fingers. He (Paul) could smell her (Clara) faint perfume. All the time his (Paul) blood kept sweeping up in great white-hot waves that killed his (Paul) consciousness momentarily.

The drama continued. He (Paul) saw it all in the distance, going on somewhere; he (Paul) did not know where, but it seemed far away inside him (Paul). He (Paul) was Clara's white heavy arms, her (Clara) throat, her (Clara) moving bosom. That seemed to be himself. Then away somewhere the play went on, and he (Paul) was identified with that also. There was no himself. The grey and black eyes of Clara, her (Clara) bosom coming down on him (Paul), her (Clara) arm that he (Paul) held gripped between his (Paul) hands, were all that existed. Then he (Paul) felt himself small and helpless, her (Clara) towering in her (Clara) force above him (Paul).

Only the intervals, when the lights came up, hurt him (Paul) expressibly. He (Paul) wanted to run anywhere, so long as it would be dark again. In a maze, he (Paul) wandered out for a drink. Then the lights were out, and the strange, insane reality of Clara and the drama took hold of him (Paul) again.

The play went on. But he (Paul) was obsessed by the desire to kiss the tiny blue vein that nestled in the bend of her (Clara) arm. He (Paul) could feel it. His (Paul) whole face seemed suspended till he (Paul) had put his (Paul) lips there. It must be done. And the other people! At last he (Paul) bent quickly forward and touched it with his (Paul) lips. His (Paul) moustache brushed the sensitive flesh. Clara shivered, drew away her (Clara) arm.

When all was over, the lights up, the people clapping, he (Paul) came to himself and looked at his (Paul) watch. His (Paul) train was gone.

``I s'll have to walk home!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Clara looked at him (Paul).

``It is too late?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

He (Paul) nodded. Then he (Paul) helped her (Clara) on with her (Clara) coat.

``I love you! You look beautiful in that dress,'' (he)
he (Paul) murmured over her (Clara) shoulder, among the throng of bustling people.

She (Clara) remained quiet. Together they went out of the theatre. He (Paul) saw the cabs waiting, the people passing. It seemed he (Paul) met a pair of brown eyes which hated him (Paul). But he (Paul) did not know. He (Paul) and Clara turned away, mechanically taking the direction to the station.

The train had gone. He (Paul) would have to walk the ten miles home.

``It doesn't matter,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``I shall enjoy it.'' (unknown)

``Won't you,'' (she)
she (Clara) said, flushing,
``come home for the night? I can sleep with mother.'' (she)

He (Paul) looked at her (Clara). Their eyes met.

``What will your mother say?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``She (mother) won't mind.'' (unknown)

``You're sure?'' (unknown)

``Quite!'' (unknown)

``SHALL I come?'' (unknown)

``If you will.'' (unknown)

``Very well.'' (unknown)

And they turned away. At the first stopping-place they took the car. The wind blew fresh in their faces. The town was dark; the tram tipped in its haste. He (Paul) sat with her (Clara) hand fast in his (Paul).

``Will your mother be gone to bed?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``She (mother) may be. I hope not.'' (the people)

They hurried along the silent, dark little street, the only people out of doors. Clara quickly entered the house. He (Paul) hesitated.

He (Paul) leaped up the step and was in the room. Her (Clara) mother appeared in the inner doorway, large and hostile.

``Who have you got there?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``It's Mr. Morel; he (Morel) has missed his (Morel) train. I thought we might put him (Morel) up for the night, and save him (Morel) a ten-mile walk.'' (unknown)

``H'm,'' (Mrs. Radford)
exclaimed Mrs. Radford.
``That's your lookout! If you've invited him (Morel), he (Morel)'s very welcome as far as I'm concerned. YOU keep the house!'' (unknown)

``If you don't like me, I'll go away again,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Nay, nay, you needn't! Come along in! I dunno what you'll think of the supper I'd got her (Morel).'' (unknown)

It was a little dish of chip potatoes and a piece of bacon. The table was roughly laid for one.

``You can have some more bacon,'' (Mrs. Radford)
continued Mrs. Radford.
``More chips you can't have.'' (unknown)

``It's a shame to bother you,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Oh, don't you be apologetic! It doesn't DO wi' me! You treated her (Morel) to the theatre, didn't you?'' (unknown)
There was a sarcasm in the last question.

``Well?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
laughed Paul uncomfortably.

``Well, and what's an inch of bacon! Take your coat off.'' (The woman)

The big, straight-standing woman was trying to estimate the situation. She (woman) moved about the cupboard. Clara took his (Paul) coat. The room was very warm and cosy in the lamplight.

``My sirs!'' (Mrs. Radford)
exclaimed Mrs. Radford;
``but you two's a pair of bright beauties, I must say! What's all that get-up for?'' (Mrs. Radford)

``I believe we don't know,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, feeling a victim.

``There isn't room in THIS house for two such bobby-dazzlers, if you fly your kites THAT high!'' (she)
she (Radford) rallied them. It was a nasty thrust.

He (Paul) in his (Paul) dinner jacket, and Clara in her (Clara) green dress and bare arms, were confused. They felt they must shelter each other in that little kitchen.

``And look at THAT blossom!'' (Mrs. Radford)
continued Mrs. Radford, pointing to Clara.
``What does she (Morel) reckon she (Morel) did it for?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul looked at Clara. She (Clara) was rosy; her (Clara) neck was warm with blushes. There was a moment of silence.

``You like to see it, don't you?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

The mother had them in her (mother) power. All the time his (Paul) heart was beating hard, and he (Paul) was tight with anxiety. But he (Paul) would fight her (mother).

``Me like to see it!'' (the woman)
exclaimed the old woman.
``What should I like to see her (Morel) make a fool of herself for?'' (unknown)

``I've seen people look bigger fools,'' (he)
he (Paul) said. Clara was under his (Paul) protection now.

``Oh, ay! and when was that?'' (unknown)
came the sarcastic rejoinder.

``When they made frights of themselves,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered.

Mrs. Radford, large and threatening, stood suspended on the hearthrug, holding her (Radford) fork.

``They're fools either road,'' (she)
she (Radford) answered at length, turning to the Dutch oven.

``No,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, fighting stoutly.
``Folk ought to look as well as they can.'' (unknown)

``And do you call THAT looking nice!'' (the mother)
cried the mother, pointing a scornful fork at Clara.
``That--that looks as if it wasn't properly dressed!'' (unknown)

``I believe you're jealous that you can't swank as well,'' (he)
he (Paul) said laughing.

``Me! I could have worn evening dress with anybody, if I'd wanted to!'' (unknown)
came the scornful answer.

``And why didn't you want to?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked pertinently.
``Or DID you wear it?'' (unknown)

There was a long pause. Mrs. Radford readjusted the bacon in the Dutch oven. His (Paul) heart beat fast, for fear he (Paul) had offended her (Radford).

``Me!'' (she)
she (Radford) exclaimed at last.
``No, I didn't! And when I was in service, I knew as soon as one of the maids came out in bare shoulders what sort SHE was, going to her (it) sixpenny hop!'' (unknown)

``Were you too good to go to a sixpenny hop?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Clara sat with bowed head. His (Paul) eyes were dark and glittering. Mrs. Radford took the Dutch oven from the fire, and stood near him (Paul), putting bits of bacon on his (Paul) plate.

``THERE'S a nice crozzly bit!'' (she)
she (Radford) said.

``Don't give me the best!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``SHE'S got what SHE wants,'' (unknown)
was the answer.

There was a sort of scornful forbearance in the woman's tone that made Paul know she (woman) was mollified.

``But DO have some!'' (he)
he (Paul) said to Clara.

She (Clara) looked up at him (Paul) with her (Clara) grey eyes, humiliated and lonely.

``No thanks!'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

``Why won't you?'' (he)
he (Paul) answered carelessly.

The blood was beating up like fire in his (Paul) veins. Mrs. Radford sat down again, large and impressive and aloof. He (Paul) left Clara altogether to attend to the mother.

``They say Sarah Bernhardt's fifty,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Fifty! She (it)'s turned sixty!'' (unknown)
came the scornful answer.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``you'd never think it! She (it) made me want to howl even now.'' (he)

``I should like to see myself howling at THAT bad old baggage!'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford.
``It's time she (it) began to think herself a grandmother, not a shrieking catamaran--'' (He)

He (Paul) laughed.

``A catamaran is a boat the Malays use,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``And it's a word as I use,'' (she)
she (Radford) retorted.

``My mother does sometimes, and it's no good my telling her (mother),'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I s'd think she (mother) boxes your ears,'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford, good-humouredly.

``She (mother)'d like to, and she (mother) says she (mother) will, so I give her (mother) a little stool to stand on.'' (unknown)

``That's the worst of my mother,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.
``She (mother) never wants a stool for anything.'' (unknown)

``But she (mother) often can't touch THAT lady with a long prop,'' (Mrs. Radford)
retorted Mrs. Radford to Paul.

``I s'd think she (mother) doesn't want touching with a prop,'' (he)
he (Paul) laughed.
``I shouldn't.'' (unknown)

``It might do the pair of you good to give you a crack on the head with one,'' (the mother)
said the mother, laughing suddenly.

``Why are you so vindictive towards me?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``I've not stolen anything from you.'' (unknown)

``No; I'll watch that,'' (the woman)
laughed the older woman.

Soon the supper was finished. Mrs. Radford sat guard in her (Radford) chair. Paul lit a cigarette. Clara went upstairs, returning with a sleeping-suit, which she (Clara) spread on the fender to air.

``Why, I'd forgot all about THEM!'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford.
``Where have they sprung from?'' (unknown)

``Out of my drawer.'' (unknown)

``H'm! You bought 'em for Baxter, an' he (Baxter) wouldn't wear 'em, would he (Baxter)?'' (unknown)
--laughing.
``Said he (Said) reckoned to do wi'out trousers i' bed.'' (She)
She (Radford) turned confidentially to Paul, saying:
``He (Said) couldn't BEAR 'em, them pyjama things.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

The young man sat making rings of smoke.

``Well, it's everyone to his (Said) taste,'' (he)
he (man) laughed.

Then followed a little discussion of the merits of pyjamas.

``My mother loves me in them,'' (he)
he (man) said.
``She (mother) says I'm a pierrot.'' (unknown)

``I can imagine they'd suit you,'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford.

After a while he (man) glanced at the little clock that was ticking on the mantelpiece. It was half-past twelve.

``It is funny,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``but it takes hours to settle down to sleep after the theatre.'' (he)

``It's about time you did,'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford, clearing the table.

``Are YOU tired?'' (he)
he (man) asked of Clara.

``Not the least bit,'' (she)
she (Radford) answered, avoiding his (man) eyes.

``Shall we have a game at cribbage?'' (he)
he (man) said.

``I've forgotten it.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'll teach you again. May we play crib, Mrs. Radford?'' (he)
he (man) asked.

``You'll please yourselves,'' (she)
she (Radford) said;
``but it's pretty late.'' (she)

``A game or so will make us sleepy,'' (he)
he (man) answered.

Clara brought the cards, and sat spinning her (Clara) wedding-ring whilst he (man) shuffled them. Mrs. Radford was washing up in the scullery. As it grew later Paul felt the situation getting more and more tense.

``Fifteen two, fifteen four, fifteen six, and two's eight--!'' (unknown)

The clock struck one. Still the game continued. Mrs. Radford had done all the little jobs preparatory to going to bed, had locked the door and filled the kettle. Still Paul went on dealing and counting. He (Paul) was obsessed by Clara's arms and throat. He (Paul) believed he (Paul) could see where the division was just beginning for her (Clara) breasts. He (Paul) could not leave her (Clara). She (Clara) watched his (Paul) hands, and felt her (Clara) joints melt as they moved quickly. She (Clara) was so near; it was almost as if he (Paul) touched her (Clara), and yet not quite. His (Paul) mettle was roused. He (Paul) hated Mrs. Radford. She (Radford) sat on, nearly dropping asleep, but determined and obstinate in her (Radford) chair. Paul glanced at her (Radford), then at Clara. She (Clara) met his (Paul) eyes, that were angry, mocking, and hard as steel. Her (Clara) own answered him (Paul) in shame. He (Paul) knew SHE, at any rate, was of his (Paul) mind. He (Paul) played on.

At last Mrs. Radford roused herself stiffly, and said:

``Isn't it nigh on time you two was thinking o' bed?'' (Mrs. Radford)

Paul played on without answering. He (Paul) hated her (Radford) sufficiently to murder her (Radford).

``Half a minute,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

The elder woman rose and sailed stubbornly into the scullery, returning with his (Paul) candle, which she (Radford) put on the mantelpiece. Then she (Radford) sat down again. The hatred of her (Radford) went so hot down his (Paul) veins, he (Paul) dropped his (Paul) cards.

``We'll stop, then,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, but his (Paul) voice was still a challenge.

Clara saw his (Paul) mouth shut hard. Again he (Paul) glanced at her (Clara). It seemed like an agreement. She (Clara) bent over the cards, coughing, to clear her (Clara) throat.

``Well, I'm glad you've finished,'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford.
``Here, take your things'' (she)
--she (Radford) thrust the warm suit in his (Paul) hand--
``and this is your candle. Your room's over this; there's only two, so you can't go far wrong. Well, good-night. I hope you'll rest well.'' (she)

``I'm sure I shall; I always do,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Yes; and so you ought at your age,'' (she)
she (Radford) replied.

He (Paul) bade good-night to Clara, and went. The twisting stairs of white, scrubbed wood creaked and clanged at every step. He (Paul) went doggedly. The two doors faced each other. He (Paul) went in his (Paul) room, pushed the door to, without fastening the latch.

It was a small room with a large bed. Some of Clara's hair-pins were on the dressing-table--her (Clara) hair-brush. Her (Clara) clothes and some skirts hung under a cloth in a corner. There was actually a pair of stockings over a chair. He (Paul) explored the room. Two books of his (Paul) own were there on the shelf. He (Paul) undressed, folded his (Paul) suit, and sat on the bed, listening. Then he (Paul) blew out the candle, lay down, and in two minutes was almost asleep. Then click!--he (Paul) was wide awake and writhing in torment. It was as if, when he (Paul) had nearly got to sleep, something had bitten him (Paul) suddenly and sent him (Paul) mad. He (Paul) sat up and looked at the room in the darkness, his (Paul) feet doubled under him (Paul), perfectly motionless, listening. He (Paul) heard a cat somewhere away outside; then the heavy, poised tread of the mother; then Clara's distinct voice:

``Will you unfasten my dress?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

There was silence for some time. At last the mother said:

``Now then! aren't you coming up?'' (the mother)

``No, not yet,'' (the daughter)
replied the daughter calmly.

``Oh, very well then! If it's not late enough, stop a bit longer. Only you needn't come waking me up when I've got to sleep.'' (unknown)

``I shan't be long,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.

Immediately afterwards Paul heard the mother slowly mounting the stairs. The candlelight flashed through the cracks in his (Paul) door. Her (Clara) dress brushed the door, and his (Paul) heart jumped. Then it was dark, and he (Paul) heard the clatter of her (Clara) latch. She (Clara) was very leisurely indeed in her (Clara) preparations for sleep. After a long time it was quite still. He (Paul) sat strung up on the bed, shivering slightly. His (Paul) door was an inch open. As Clara came upstairs, he (Paul) would intercept her (Clara). He (Paul) waited. All was dead silence. The clock struck two. Then he (Paul) heard a slight scrape of the fender downstairs. Now he (Paul) could not help himself. His (Paul) shivering was uncontrollable. He (Paul) felt he (Paul) must go or die.

He (Paul) stepped off the bed, and stood a moment, shuddering. Then he (Paul) went straight to the door. He (Paul) tried to step lightly. The first stair cracked like a shot. He (Paul) listened. The old woman stirred in her (woman) bed. The staircase was dark. There was a slit of light under the stair-foot door, which opened into the kitchen. He (Paul) stood a moment. Then he (Paul) went on, mechanically. Every step creaked, and his (Paul) back was creeping, lest the old woman's door should open behind him (Paul) up above. He (Paul) fumbled with the door at the bottom. The latch opened with a loud clack. He (Paul) went through into the kitchen, and shut the door noisily behind him (Paul). The old woman daren't come now.

Then he (Paul) stood, arrested. Clara was kneeling on a pile of white underclothing on the hearthrug, her (Clara) back towards him (Paul), warming herself. She (Clara) did not look round, but sat crouching on her (Clara) heels, and her (Clara) rounded beautiful back was towards him (Paul), and her (Clara) face was hidden. She (Clara) was warming her (Clara) body at the fire for consolation. The glow was rosy on one side, the shadow was dark and warm on the other. Her (Clara) arms hung slack.

He (Paul) shuddered violently, clenching his (Paul) teeth and fists hard to keep control. Then he (Paul) went forward to her (Clara). He (Paul) put one hand on her (Clara) shoulder, the fingers of the other hand under her (Clara) chin to raise her (Clara) face. A convulsed shiver ran through her (Clara), once, twice, at his (Paul) touch. She (Clara) kept her (Clara) head bent.

``Sorry!'' (he)
he (Paul) murmured, realising that his (Paul) hands were very cold.

Then she (Clara) looked up at him (Paul), frightened, like a thing that is afraid of death.

``My hands are so cold,'' (he)
he (Paul) murmured.

``I like it,'' (she)
she (Clara) whispered, closing her (Clara) eyes.

The breath of her (Clara) words were on his (Paul) mouth. Her (Clara) arms clasped his (Paul) knees. The cord of his (Paul) sleeping-suit dangled against her (Clara) and made her (Clara) shiver. As the warmth went into him (Paul), his (Paul) shuddering became less.

At length, unable to stand so any more, he (Paul) raised her (Clara), and she (Clara) buried her (Clara) head on his (Paul) shoulder. His (Paul) hands went over her (Clara) slowly with an infinite tenderness of caress. She (Clara) clung close to him (Paul), trying to hide herself against him (Paul). He (Paul) clasped her (Clara) very fast. Then at last she (Clara) looked at him (Paul), mute, imploring, looking to see if she (Clara) must be ashamed.

His (Paul) eyes were dark, very deep, and very quiet. It was as if her (Clara) beauty and his (Paul) taking it hurt him (Paul), made him (Paul) sorrowful. He (Paul) looked at her (Clara) with a little pain, and was afraid. He (Paul) was so humble before her (Clara). She (Clara) kissed him (Paul) fervently on the eyes, first one, then the other, and she (Clara) folded herself to him (Paul). She (Clara) gave herself. He (Paul) held her (Clara) fast. It was a moment intense almost to agony.

She (Clara) stood letting him (Paul) adore her (Clara) and tremble with joy of her (Clara). It healed her (Clara) hurt pride. It healed her (Clara); it made her (Clara) glad. It made her (Clara) feel erect and proud again. Her (Clara) pride had been wounded inside her (Clara). She (Clara) had been cheapened. Now she (Clara) radiated with joy and pride again. It was her (Clara) restoration and her (Clara) recognition.

Then he (Paul) looked at her (Clara), his (Paul) face radiant. They laughed to each other, and he (Paul) strained her (Clara) to his (Paul) chest. The seconds ticked off, the minutes passed, and still the two stood clasped rigid together, mouth to mouth, like a statue in one block.

But again his (Paul) fingers went seeking over her (Clara), restless, wandering, dissatisfied. The hot blood came up wave upon wave. She (Clara) laid her (Clara) head on his (Paul) shoulder.

``Come you to my room,'' (he)
he (Paul) murmured.

She (Clara) looked at him (Paul) and shook her (Clara) head, her (Clara) mouth pouting disconsolately, her (Clara) eyes heavy with passion. He (Paul) watched her (Clara) fixedly.

``Yes!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Again she (Clara) shook her (Clara) head.

``Why not?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

She (Clara) looked at him (Paul) still heavily, sorrowfully, and again she (Clara) shook her (Clara) head. His (Paul) eyes hardened, and he (Paul) gave way.

When, later on, he (Paul) was back in bed, he (Paul) wondered why she (Clara) had refused to come to him (Paul) openly, so that her (Clara) mother would know. At any rate, then things would have been definite. And she (Clara) could have stayed with him (Paul) the night, without having to go, as she (Clara) was, to her (Clara) mother's bed. It was strange, and he (Paul) could not understand it. And then almost immediately he (Paul) fell asleep.

He (Paul) awoke in the morning with someone speaking to him (Paul). Opening his (Paul) eyes, he (Paul) saw Mrs. Radford, big and stately, looking down on him (Paul). She (Radford) held a cup of tea in her (Radford) hand.

``Do you think you're going to sleep till Doomsday?'' (she)
she (Radford) said.

He (Paul) laughed at once.

``It ought only to be about five o'clock,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Well,'' (she)
she (Radford) answered,
``it's half-past seven, whether or not. Here, I've brought you a cup of tea.'' (she)

He (Paul) rubbed his (Paul) face, pushed the tumbled hair off his (Paul) forehead, and roused himself.

``What's it so late for!'' (he)
he (Paul) grumbled.

He (Paul) resented being wakened. It amused her (Radford). She (Radford) saw his (Paul) neck in the flannel sleeping-jacket, as white and round as a girl's. He (Paul) rubbed his (Paul) hair crossly.

``It's no good your scratching your head,'' (she)
she (girl) said.
``It won't make it no earlier. Here, an' how long d'you think I'm going to stand waiting wi' this here cup?'' (unknown)

``Oh, dash the cup!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``You should go to bed earlier,'' (the woman)
said the woman.

He (Paul) looked up at her (woman), laughing with impudence.

``I went to bed before YOU did,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Yes, my Guyney, you did!'' (she)
she (woman) exclaimed.

``Fancy,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, stirring his (Paul) tea,
``having tea brought to bed to me! My mother'll think I'm ruined for life.'' (he)

``Don't she (mother) never do it?'' (Mrs. Radford)
asked Mrs. Radford.

``She (mother)'d as leave think of flying.'' (unknown)

``Ah, I always spoilt my lot! That's why they've turned out such bad uns,'' (the woman)
said the elderly woman.

``You'd only Clara,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``And Mr. Radford's in heaven. So I suppose there's only you left to be the bad un.'' (unknown)

``I'm not bad; I'm only soft,'' (she)
she (woman) said, as she (woman) went out of the bedroom.
``I'm only a fool, I am!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara was very quiet at breakfast, but she (Clara) had a sort of air of proprietorship over him (Paul) that pleased him (Paul) infinitely. Mrs. Radford was evidently fond of him (Paul). He (Paul) began to talk of his (Paul) painting.

``What's the good,'' (the mother)
exclaimed the mother,
``of your whittling and worrying and twistin' and too-in' at that painting of yours? What GOOD does it do you, I should like to know? You'd better be enjoyin' yourself.'' (the mother)

``Oh, but,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
exclaimed Paul,
``I made over thirty guineas last year.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``Did you! Well, that's a consideration, but it's nothing to the time you put in.'' (unknown)

``And I've got four pounds owing. A man said he (man)'d give me five pounds if I'd paint him (man) and his (man) missis and the dog and the cottage. And I went and put the fowls in instead of the dog, and he (man) was waxy, so I had to knock a quid off. I was sick of it, and I didn't like the dog. I made a picture of it. What shall I do when he (man) pays me the four pounds?'' (unknown)

``Nay! you know your own uses for your money,'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford.

``But I'm going to bust this four pounds. Should we go to the seaside for a day or two?'' (unknown)

``Who?'' (unknown)

``You and Clara and me.'' (unknown)

``What, on your money!'' (she)
she (Radford) exclaimed, half-wrathful.

``Why not?'' (unknown)

``YOU wouldn't be long in breaking your neck at a hurdle race!'' (she)
she (Radford) said.

``So long as I get a good run for my money! Will you?'' (unknown)

``Nay; you may settle that atween you.'' (unknown)

``And you're willing?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked, amazed and rejoicing.

``You'll do as you like,'' (Mrs. Radford)
said Mrs. Radford,
``whether I'm willing or not.'' (Mrs. Radford)

CHAPTER XIII

BAXTER DAWES

SOON after Paul had been to the theatre with Clara, he (Paul) was drinking in the Punch Bowl with some friends of his (Paul) when Dawes came in. Clara's husband was growing stout; his (Paul) eyelids were getting slack over his (Paul) brown eyes; he (Paul) was losing his (Paul) healthy firmness of flesh. He (Paul) was very evidently on the downward track. Having quarrelled with his (Paul) sister, he (Paul) had gone into cheap lodgings. His (Paul) mistress had left him (Paul) for a man who would marry her (mistress). He (Paul) had been in prison one night for fighting when he (Paul) was drunk, and there was a shady betting episode in which he (Paul) was concerned.

Paul and he (Paul) were confirmed enemies, and yet there was between them that peculiar feeling of intimacy, as if they were secretly near to each other, which sometimes exists between two people, although they never speak to one another. Paul often thought of Baxter Dawes, often wanted to get at him (Paul) and be friends with him (Paul). He (Paul) knew that Dawes often thought about him (Paul), and that the man was drawn to him (man) by some bond or other. And yet the two never looked at each other save in hostility.

Since he (man) was a superior employee at Jordan's, it was the thing for Paul to offer Dawes a drink.

``What'll you have?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked of him (Paul).

``Nowt wi' a bleeder like you!'' (the man)
replied the man.

Paul turned away with a slight disdainful movement of the shoulders, very irritating.

``The aristocracy,'' (he)
he (Paul) continued,
``is really a military institution. Take Germany, now. She (I)'s got thousands of aristocrats whose only means of existence is the army. They're deadly poor, and life's deadly slow. So they hope for a war. They look for war as a chance of getting on. Till there's a war they are idle good-for-nothings. When there's a war, they are leaders and commanders. There you are, then--they WANT war!'' (he)

He (Paul) was not a favourite debater in the public-house, being too quick and overbearing. He (Paul) irritated the older men by his (Paul) assertive manner, and his (Paul) cocksureness. They listened in silence, and were not sorry when he (Paul) finished.

Dawes interrupted the young man's flow of eloquence by asking, in a loud sneer:
