``But Dr. Ansell was going to write you a letter.'' (unknown)

``Ah, yes!'' (the doctor)
replied the doctor, drawing the letter from his (Paul) pocket. He (Paul) was very friendly, affable, busy, kind. He (Paul) would come to Sheffield the next day.

``What is your father?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``He (father) is a coal-miner,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
replied Paul.

``Not very well off, I suppose?'' (unknown)

``This--I see after this,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``And you?'' (the doctor)
smiled the doctor.

``I am a clerk in Jordan's Appliance Factory.'' (The doctor)

The doctor smiled at him (doctor).

``Er--to go to Sheffield!'' (he)
he (doctor) said, putting the tips of his (doctor) fingers together, and smiling with his (doctor) eyes.
``Eight guineas?'' (unknown)

``Thank you!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, flushing and rising.
``And you'll come to-morrow?'' (unknown)

``To-morrow--Sunday? Yes! Can you tell me about what time there is a train in the afternoon?'' (unknown)

``There is a Central gets in at four-fifteen.'' (unknown)

``And will there be any way of getting up to the house? Shall I have to walk?'' (The doctor)
The doctor smiled.

``There is the tram,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul;
``the Western Park tram.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

The doctor made a note of it.

``Thank you!'' (he)
he (Paul) said, and shook hands.

Then Paul went on home to see his (Paul) father, who was left in the charge of Minnie. Walter Morel was getting very grey now. Paul found him (Paul) digging in the garden. He (Paul) had written him (Paul) a letter. He (Paul) shook hands with his (Paul) father.

``Hello, son! Tha has landed, then?'' (the father)
said the father.

``Yes,'' (the son)
replied the son.
``But I'm going back to-night.'' (unknown)

``Are ter, beguy!'' (the collier)
exclaimed the collier.
``An' has ter eaten owt?'' (unknown)

``No.'' (unknown)

``That's just like thee,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.
``Come thy ways in.'' (The father)

The father was afraid of the mention of his (father) wife. The two went indoors. Paul ate in silence; his (Paul) father, with earthy hands, and sleeves rolled up, sat in the arm-chair opposite and looked at him (Paul).

``Well, an' how is she (I)?'' (the miner)
asked the miner at length, in a little voice.

``She (I) can sit up; she (I) can be carried down for tea,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``That's a blessin'!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
exclaimed Morel.
``I hope we s'll soon be havin' her (I) whoam, then. An' what's that Nottingham doctor say?'' (unknown)

``He (doctor)'s going to-morrow to have an examination of her (I).'' (unknown)

``Is he (doctor) beguy! That's a tidy penny, I'm thinkin'!'' (unknown)

``Eight guineas.'' (unknown)

``Eight guineas!'' (the miner)
the miner spoke breathlessly.
``Well, we mun find it from somewhere.'' (unknown)

``I can pay that,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

There was silence between them for some time.

``She (I) says she (I) hopes you're getting on all right with Minnie,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul said.

``Yes, I'm all right, an' I wish as she (Minnie) was,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
answered Morel.
``But Minnie's a good little wench, bless `er heart!'' (He)
He (Paul) sat looking dismal.

``I s'll have to be going at half-past three,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``It's a trapse for thee, lad! Eight guineas! An' when dost think she (Minnie)'ll be able to get as far as this?'' (unknown)

``We must see what the doctors say to-morrow,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul said.

Morel sighed deeply. The house seemed strangely empty, and Paul thought his (Paul) father looked lost, forlorn, and old.

``You'll have to go and see her (Minnie) next week, father,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I hope she (Minnie)'ll be a-whoam by that time,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``If she (Minnie)'s not,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``then you must come.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``I dunno wheer I s'll find th' money,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``And I'll write to you what the doctor says,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``But tha writes i' such a fashion, I canna ma'e it out,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``Well, I'll write plain.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

It was no good asking Morel to answer, for he (Morel) could scarcely do more than write his (Morel) own name.

The doctor came. Leonard felt it his (Leonard) duty to meet him (Leonard) with a cab. The examination did not take long. Annie, Arthur, Paul, and Leonard were waiting in the parlour anxiously. The doctors came down. Paul glanced at them. He (Paul) had never had any hope, except when he (Paul) had deceived himself.

``It MAY be a tumour; we must wait and see,'' (Dr. Jameson)
said Dr. Jameson.

``And if it is,'' (Annie)
said Annie,
``can you sweal it away?'' (Annie)

``Probably,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

Paul put eight sovereigns and half a sovereign on the table. The doctor counted them, took a florin out of his (Paul) purse, and put that down.

``Thank you!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``I'm sorry Mrs. Morel is so ill. But we must see what we can do.'' (unknown)

``There can't be an operation?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

The doctor shook his (Paul) head.

``No,'' (he)
he (Paul) said;
``and even if there could, her (Morel) heart wouldn't stand it.'' (he)

``Is her (Morel) heart risky?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul.

``Yes; you must be careful with her (Morel).'' (unknown)

``Very risky?'' (unknown)

``No--er--no, no! Just take care.'' (the doctor)

And the doctor was gone.

Then Paul carried his (Paul) mother downstairs. She (mother) lay simply, like a child. But when he (Paul) was on the stairs, she (mother) put her (mother) arms round his (Paul) neck, clinging.

``I'm so frightened of these beastly stairs,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

And he (Paul) was frightened, too. He (Paul) would let Leonard do it another time. He (Leonard) felt he (Leonard) could not carry her (mother).

``He (you) thinks it's only a tumour!'' (Annie)
cried Annie to her (Annie) mother.
``And he (you) can sweal it away.'' (unknown)

``I KNEW he (you) could,'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
protested Mrs. Morel scornfully.

She (Morel) pretended not to notice that Paul had gone out of the room. He (Paul) sat in the kitchen, smoking. Then he (Paul) tried to brush some grey ash off his (Paul) coat. He (Paul) looked again. It was one of his (Paul) mother's grey hairs. It was so long! He (Paul) held it up, and it drifted into the chimney. He (Paul) let go. The long grey hair floated and was gone in the blackness of the chimney.

The next day he (Paul) kissed her (mother) before going back to work. It was very early in the morning, and they were alone.

``You won't fret, my boy!'' (she)
she (mother) said.

``No, mother.'' (unknown)

``No; it would be silly. And take care of yourself.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Paul) answered. Then, after a while:
``And I shall come next Saturday, and shall bring my father?'' (unknown)

``I suppose he (father) wants to come,'' (she)
she (mother) replied.
``At any rate, if he (father) does you'll have to let him (father).'' (He)

He (Paul) kissed her (mother) again, and stroked the hair from her (mother) temples, gently, tenderly, as if she (mother) were a lover.

``Shan't you be late?'' (she)
she (mother) murmured.

``I'm going,'' (he)
he (lover) said, very low.

Still he (lover) sat a few minutes, stroking the brown and grey hair from her (mother) temples.

``And you won't be any worse, mother?'' (unknown)

``No, my son.'' (unknown)

``You promise me?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I won't be any worse.'' (He)

He (lover) kissed her (mother), held her (mother) in his (lover) arms for a moment, and was gone. In the early sunny morning he (lover) ran to the station, crying all the way; he (lover) did not know what for. And her (mother) blue eyes were wide and staring as she (mother) thought of him (lover).

In the afternoon he (lover) went a walk with Clara. They sat in the little wood where bluebells were standing. He (lover) took her (Clara) hand.

``You'll see,'' (he)
he (lover) said to Clara,
``she (mother)'ll never be better.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

``Oh, you don't know!'' (unknown)
replied the other.

``I do,'' (he)
he (lover) said.

She (Clara) caught him (lover) impulsively to her (Clara) breast.

``Try and forget it, dear,'' (she)
she (Clara) said;
``try and forget it.'' (she)

``I will,'' (he)
he (lover) answered.

Her (Clara) breast was there, warm for him (lover); her (Clara) hands were in his (lover) hair. It was comforting, and he (lover) held his (lover) arms round her (Clara). But he (lover) did not forget. He (lover) only talked to Clara of something else. And it was always so. When she (Clara) felt it coming, the agony, she (Clara) cried to him (lover):

``Don't think of it, Paul! Don't think of it, my darling!'' (him)

And she (Clara) pressed him (lover) to her (Clara) breast, rocked him (lover), soothed him (lover) like a child. So he (lover) put the trouble aside for her (Clara) sake, to take it up again immediately he (lover) was alone. All the time, as he (lover) went about, he (lover) cried mechanically. His (lover) mind and hands were busy. He (lover) cried, he (lover) did not know why. It was his (lover) blood weeping. He (lover) was just as much alone whether he (lover) was with Clara or with the men in the White Horse. Just himself and this pressure inside him (White), that was all that existed. He (White) read sometimes. He (White) had to keep his (White) mind occupied. And Clara was a way of occupying his (White) mind.

On the Saturday Walter Morel went to Sheffield. He (Morel) was a forlorn figure, looking rather as if nobody owned him (Morel). Paul ran upstairs.

``My father's come,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, kissing his (Paul) mother.

``Has he (father)?'' (she)
she (mother) answered wearily.

The old collier came rather frightened into the bedroom.

``How dun I find thee, lass?'' (he)
he (collier) said, going forward and kissing her (mother) in a hasty, timid fashion.

``Well, I'm middlin','' (she)
she (mother) replied.

``I see tha art,'' (he)
he (collier) said. He (collier) stood looking down on her (mother). Then he (collier) wiped his (collier) eyes with his (collier) handkerchief. Helpless, and as if nobody owned him (collier), he (collier) looked.

``Have you gone on all right?'' (the wife)
asked the wife, rather wearily, as if it were an effort to talk to him (collier).

``Yis,'' (he)
he (collier) answered.
''`Er's a bit behint-hand now and again, as yer might expect.'' (he)

``Does she (lass) have your dinner ready?'' (Mrs. Morel/Morel/MOREL)
asked Mrs. Morel.

``Well, I've `ad to shout at `er once or twice,'' (he)
he (collier) said.

``And you MUST shout at her (lass) if she (lass)'s not ready. She (lass) WILL leave things to the last minute.'' (She)

She (Morel) gave him (collier) a few instructions. He (collier) sat looking at her (Morel) as if she (Morel) were almost a stranger to him (collier), before whom he (collier) was awkward and humble, and also as if he (collier) had lost his (collier) presence of mind, and wanted to run. This feeling that he (collier) wanted to run away, that he (collier) was on thorns to be gone from so trying a situation, and yet must linger because it looked better, made his (collier) presence so trying. He (collier) put up his (collier) eyebrows for misery, and clenched his (collier) fists on his (collier) knees, feeling so awkward in presence of big trouble.

Mrs. Morel did not change much. She (Morel) stayed in Sheffield for two months. If anything, at the end she (Morel) was rather worse. But she (Morel) wanted to go home. Annie had her (Annie) children. Mrs. Morel wanted to go home. So they got a motor-car from Nottingham--for she (Morel) was too ill to go by train--and she (Morel) was driven through the sunshine. It was just August; everything was bright and warm. Under the blue sky they could all see she (Morel) was dying. Yet she (Morel) was jollier than she (Morel) had been for weeks. They all laughed and talked.

``Annie,'' (she)
she (Morel) exclaimed,
``I saw a lizard dart on that rock!'' (she)

Her (Morel) eyes were so quick; she (Morel) was still so full of life.

Morel knew she (Morel) was coming. He (Morel) had the front door open. Everybody was on tiptoe. Half the street turned out. They heard the sound of the great motor-car. Mrs. Morel, smiling, drove home down the street.

``And just look at them all come out to see me!'' (she)
she (Morel) said.
``But there, I suppose I should have done the same. How do you do, Mrs. Mathews? How are you, Mrs. Harrison?'' (unknown)

They none of them could hear, but they saw her (Morel) smile and nod. And they all saw death on her (Morel) face, they said. It was a great event in the street.

Morel wanted to carry her (Morel) indoors, but he (Morel) was too old. Arthur took her (Morel) as if she (Morel) were a child. They had set her (Morel) a big, deep chair by the hearth where her (Morel) rocking-chair used to stand. When she (Morel) was unwrapped and seated, and had drunk a little brandy, she (Morel) looked round the room.

``Don't think I don't like your house, Annie,'' (she)
she (Morel) said;
``but it's nice to be in my own home again.'' (she)

And Morel answered huskily:

``It is, lass, it is.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

And Minnie, the little quaint maid, said:

``An' we glad t' `ave yer.'' (the maid)

There was a lovely yellow ravel of sunflowers in the garden. She (Minnie) looked out of the window.

``There are my sunflowers!'' (she)
she (Minnie) said.

CHAPTER XIV

THE RELEASE

``By the way,'' (Dr. Ansell)
said Dr. Ansell one evening when Morel was in Sheffield,
``we've got a man in the fever hospital here who comes from Nottingham--Dawes. He (man) doesn't seem to have many belongings in this world.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``Baxter Dawes!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul exclaimed.

``That's the man--has been a fine fellow, physically, I should think. Been in a bit of a mess lately. You know him (man)?'' (unknown)

``He (man) used to work at the place where I am.'' (unknown)

``Did he (man)? Do you know anything about him (man)? He (man)'s just sulking, or he (man)'d be a lot better than he (man) is by now.'' (unknown)

``I don't know anything of his (man) home circumstances, except that he (man)'s separated from his (man) wife and has been a bit down, I believe. But tell him (man) about me, will you? Tell him (man) I'll come and see him (man).'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

The next time Morel saw the doctor he (Morel) said:

``And what about Dawes?'' (he)

``I said to him (man),'' (unknown)
answered the other,
''`Do you know a man from Nottingham named Morel?'' (he)
and he (Morel) looked at me as if he (Morel)'d jump at my throat. So I said:
``I see you know the name; it's Paul Morel.'' (I)
Then I told him (Morel) about your saying you would go and see him (Morel).
``What does he (Morel) want?'' (he)
he (Morel) said, as if you were a policeman.''

``And did he (Morel) say he (Morel) would see me?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul.

``He (Morel) wouldn't say anything--good, bad or indifferent,'' (the doctor)
replied the doctor.

``Why not?'' (unknown)

``That's what I want to know. There he (Morel) lies and sulks, day in, day out. Can't get a word of information out of him (Morel).'' (unknown)

``Do you think I might go?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul.

``You might.'' (the men)

There was a feeling of connection between the rival men, more than ever since they had fought. In a way Morel felt guilty towards the other, and more or less responsible. And being in such a state of soul himself, he (Morel) felt an almost painful nearness to Dawes, who was suffering and despairing, too. Besides, they had met in a naked extremity of hate, and it was a bond. At any rate, the elemental man in each had met.

He (man) went down to the isolation hospital, with Dr. Ansell's card. This sister, a healthy young Irishwoman, led him (man) down the ward.

``A visitor to see you, Jim Crow,'' (she)
she (sister) said.

Dawes turned over suddenly with a startled grunt.

``Eh?'' (unknown)

``Caw!'' (she)
she (sister) mocked. ``He (Crow) can only say ``Caw!'' I have brought you a gentleman to see you. Now say ``Thank you,
'' and show some manners.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Dawes looked swiftly with his (gentleman) dark, startled eyes beyond the sister at Paul. His (Paul) look was full of fear, mistrust, hate, and misery. Morel met the swift, dark eyes, and hesitated. The two men were afraid of the naked selves they had been.

``Dr. Ansell told me you were here,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel, holding out his (Morel) hand.

Dawes mechanically shook hands.

``So I thought I'd come in,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
continued Paul.

There was no answer. Dawes lay staring at the opposite wall.

``Say `Caw!'' (the nurse)
' mocked the nurse. ``Say ``Caw!
'' Jim Crow.'' (unknown)

``He (Crow) is getting on all right?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul to her (Dawes).

``Oh yes! He (Crow) lies and imagines he (Crow)'s going to die,'' (the nurse)
said the nurse,
``and it frightens every word out of his (Crow) mouth.'' (the nurse)

``And you MUST have somebody to talk to,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
laughed Morel.

``That's it!'' (the nurse)
laughed the nurse. ``Only two old men and a boy who always cries. It is hard lines! Here am I dying to hear Jim Crow's voice, and nothing but an odd ``Caw!
'' will he (Morel) give!'' (unknown)

``So rough on you!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``Isn't it?'' (the nurse)
said the nurse.

``I suppose I am a godsend,'' (he)
he (Morel) laughed.

``Oh, dropped straight from heaven!'' (the nurse)
laughed the nurse.

Presently she (nurse) left the two men alone. Dawes was thinner, and handsome again, but life seemed low in him (Morel). As the doctor said, he (doctor) was lying sulking, and would not move forward towards convalescence. He (doctor) seemed to grudge every beat of his (doctor) heart.

``Have you had a bad time?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul.

Suddenly again Dawes looked at him (Paul).

``What are you doing in Sheffield?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``My mother was taken ill at my sister's in Thurston Street. What are you doing here?'' (unknown)

There was no answer.

``How long have you been in?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Morel asked.

``I couldn't say for sure,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
Dawes answered grudgingly.

He (Morel) lay staring across at the wall opposite, as if trying to believe Morel was not there. Paul felt his (Paul) heart go hard and angry.

``Dr. Ansell told me you were here,'' (he)
he (Paul) said coldly.

The other man did not answer.

``Typhoid's pretty bad, I know,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Morel persisted.

Suddenly Dawes said:

``What did you come for?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

``Because Dr. Ansell said you didn't know anybody here. Do you?'' (unknown)

``I know nobody nowhere,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

``Well,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``it's because you don't choose to, then.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

There was another silence.

``We s'll be taking my mother home as soon as we can,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``What's a-matter with her (mother)?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
asked Dawes, with a sick man's interest in illness.

``She (mother)'s got a cancer.'' (unknown)

There was another silence.

``But we want to get her (mother) home,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``We s'll have to get a motor-car.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Dawes lay thinking.

``Why don't you ask Thomas Jordan to lend you his (Jordan)?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

``It's not big enough,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Morel answered.

Dawes blinked his (Morel) dark eyes as he (Morel) lay thinking.

``Then ask Jack Pilkington; he (Jack)'d lend it you. You know him (Jack).'' (unknown)

``I think I s'll hire one,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``You're a fool if you do,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

The sick man was gaunt and handsome again. Paul was sorry for him (Paul) because his (Paul) eyes looked so tired.

``Did you get a job here?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``I was only here a day or two before I was taken bad,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
Dawes replied.

``You want to get in a convalescent home,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

The other's face clouded again.

``I'm goin' in no convalescent home,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``My father's been in the one at Seathorpe, an' he (father) liked it. Dr. Ansell would get you a recommend.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Dawes lay thinking. It was evident he (Paul) dared not face the world again.

``The seaside would be all right just now,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Morel said.
``Sun on those sandhills, and the waves not far out.'' (unknown)

The other did not answer.

``By Gad!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul concluded, too miserable to bother much;
``it's all right when you know you're going to walk again, and swim!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Dawes glanced at him (Paul) quickly. The man's dark eyes were afraid to meet any other eyes in the world. But the real misery and helplessness in Paul's tone gave him (Paul) a feeling of relief.

``Is she (You) far gone?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``She (You)'s going like wax,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul answered;
``but cheerful--lively!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

He (Paul) bit his (Paul) lip. After a minute he (Paul) rose.

``Well, I'll be going,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``I'll leave you this half-crown.'' (unknown)

``I don't want it,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
Dawes muttered.

Morel did not answer, but left the coin on the table.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Morel) said,
``I'll try and run in when I'm back in Sheffield. Happen you might like to see my brother-in-law? He (brother-in-law) works in Pyecrofts.'' (he)

``I don't know him (brother-in-law),'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

``He (brother-in-law)'s all right. Should I tell him (brother-in-law) to come? He (brother-in-law) might bring you some papers to look at.'' (The man)

The other man did not answer. Paul went. The strong emotion that Dawes aroused in him (Paul), repressed, made him (Paul) shiver.

He (Paul) did not tell his (Paul) mother, but next day he (Paul) spoke to Clara about this interview. It was in the dinner-hour. The two did not often go out together now, but this day he (Paul) asked her (Clara) to go with him (Paul) to the Castle grounds. There they sat while the scarlet geraniums and the yellow calceolarias blazed in the sunlight. She (Clara) was now always rather protective, and rather resentful towards him (Paul).

``Did you know Baxter was in Sheffield Hospital with typhoid?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

She (Clara) looked at him (Paul) with startled grey eyes, and her (Clara) face went pale.

``No,'' (she)
she (Clara) said, frightened.

``He (Baxter)'s getting better. I went to see him (Baxter) yesterday--the doctor told me.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Clara seemed stricken by the news.

``Is he (doctor) very bad?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked guiltily.

``He (doctor) has been. He (doctor)'s mending now.'' (unknown)

``What did he (doctor) say to you?'' (unknown)

``Oh, nothing! He (doctor) seems to be sulking.'' (unknown)

There was a distance between the two of them. He (Paul) gave her (Clara) more information.

She (Clara) went about shut up and silent. The next time they took a walk together, she (Clara) disengaged herself from his (Paul) arm, and walked at a distance from him (Paul). He (Paul) was wanting her (Clara) comfort badly.

``Won't you be nice with me?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

She (Clara) did not answer.

``What's the matter?'' (he)
he (Paul) said, putting his (Paul) arm across her (Clara) shoulder.

``Don't!'' (she)
she (Clara) said, disengaging herself.

He (Paul) left her (Clara) alone, and returned to his (Paul) own brooding.

``Is it Baxter that upsets you?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked at length.

``I HAVE been VILE to him (Baxter)!'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

``I've said many a time you haven't treated him (Baxter) well,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.

And there was a hostility between them. Each pursued his (Paul) own train of thought.

``I've treated him (Baxter)--no, I've treated him (Baxter) badly,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.
``And now you treat ME badly. It serves me right.'' (unknown)

``How do I treat you badly?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``It serves me right,'' (she)
she (Clara) repeated.
``I never considered him (Baxter) worth having, and now you don't consider ME. But it serves me right. He (Baxter) loved me a thousand times better than you ever did.'' (unknown)

``He (Baxter) didn't!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
protested Paul.

``He (Baxter) did! At any rate, he (Baxter) did respect me, and that's what you don't do.'' (unknown)

``It looked as if he (Baxter) respected you!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``He (Baxter) did! And I MADE him (Baxter) horrid--I know I did! You've taught me that. And he (Baxter) loved me a thousand times better than ever you do.'' (unknown)

``All right,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

He (Paul) only wanted to be left alone now. He (Paul) had his (Paul) own trouble, which was almost too much to bear. Clara only tormented him (Paul) and made him (Paul) tired. He (Paul) was not sorry when he (Paul) left her (Clara).

She (Clara) went on the first opportunity to Sheffield to see her (Clara) husband. The meeting was not a success. But she (Clara) left him (husband) roses and fruit and money. She (Clara) wanted to make restitution. It was not that she (Clara) loved him (husband). As she (Clara) looked at him (husband) lying there her (Clara) heart did not warm with love. Only she (Clara) wanted to humble herself to him (husband), to kneel before him (husband). She (Clara) wanted now to be self-sacrificial. After all, she (Clara) had failed to make Morel really love her (Clara). She (Clara) was morally frightened. She (Clara) wanted to do penance. So she (Clara) kneeled to Dawes, and it gave him (Morel) a subtle pleasure. But the distance between them was still very great--too great. It frightened the man. It almost pleased the woman. She (woman) liked to feel she (woman) was serving him (man) across an insuperable distance. She (woman) was proud now.

Morel went to see Dawes once or twice. There was a sort of friendship between the two men, who were all the while deadly rivals. But they never mentioned the woman who was between them.

Mrs. Morel got gradually worse. At first they used to carry her (Morel) downstairs, sometimes even into the garden. She (Morel) sat propped in her (Morel) chair, smiling, and so pretty. The gold wedding-ring shone on her (Morel) white hand; her (Morel) hair was carefully brushed. And she (Morel) watched the tangled sunflowers dying, the chrysanthemums coming out, and the dahlias.

Paul and she (Morel) were afraid of each other. He (Paul) knew, and she (Morel) knew, that she (Morel) was dying. But they kept up a pretence of cheerfulness. Every morning, when he (Paul) got up, he (Paul) went into her (Morel) room in his (Paul) pyjamas.

``Did you sleep, my dear?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Morel) answered.

``Not very well?'' (unknown)

``Well, yes!'' (he)

Then he (Paul) knew she (Morel) had lain awake. He (Paul) saw her (Morel) hand under the bedclothes, pressing the place on her (Morel) side where the pain was.

``Has it been bad?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``No. It hurt a bit, but nothing to mention.'' (she)

And she (Morel) sniffed in her (Morel) old scornful way. As she (Morel) lay she (Morel) looked like a girl. And all the while her (Morel) blue eyes watched him (Paul). But there were the dark pain-circles beneath that made him (Paul) ache again.

``It's a sunny day,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``It's a beautiful day.'' (unknown)

``Do you think you'll be carried down?'' (unknown)

``I shall see.'' (he)

Then he (Paul) went away to get her (Morel) breakfast. All day long he (Paul) was conscious of nothing but her (Morel). It was a long ache that made him (Paul) feverish. Then, when he (Paul) got home in the early evening, he (Paul) glanced through the kitchen window. She (Morel) was not there; she (Morel) had not got up.

He (Paul) ran straight upstairs and kissed her (Morel). He (Paul) was almost afraid to ask:

``Didn't you get up, pigeon?'' (He)

``No,'' (she)
she (Morel) said,
``it was that morphia; it made me tired.'' (she)

``I think he (It) gives you too much,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I think he (It) does,'' (she)
she (Morel) answered.

He (Paul) sat down by the bed, miserably. She (Morel) had a way of curling and lying on her (Morel) side, like a child. The grey and brown hair was loose over her (Morel) ear.

``Doesn't it tickle you?'' (he)
he (Paul) said, gently putting it back.

``It does,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied.

His (Paul) face was near hers. Her (Morel) blue eyes smiled straight into his (Paul), like a girl's--warm, laughing with tender love. It made him (Paul) pant with terror, agony, and love.

``You want your hair doing in a plait,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``Lie still.'' (her)

And going behind her (Morel), he (Paul) carefully loosened her (Morel) hair, brushed it out. It was like fine long silk of brown and grey. Her (Morel) head was snuggled between her (Morel) shoulders. As he (Paul) lightly brushed and plaited her (Morel) hair, he (Paul) bit his (Paul) lip and felt dazed. It all seemed unreal, he (Paul) could not understand it.

At night he (Paul) often worked in her (Morel) room, looking up from time to time. And so often he (Paul) found her (Morel) blue eyes fixed on him (Paul). And when their eyes met, she (Morel) smiled. He (Paul) worked away again mechanically, producing good stuff without knowing what he (Paul) was doing.

Sometimes he (Paul) came in, very pale and still, with watchful, sudden eyes, like a man who is drunk almost to death. They were both afraid of the veils that were ripping between them.

Then she (Morel) pretended to be better, chattered to him (man) gaily, made a great fuss over some scraps of news. For they had both come to the condition when they had to make much of the trifles, lest they should give in to the big thing, and their human independence would go smash. They were afraid, so they made light of things and were gay.

Sometimes as she (Morel) lay he (man) knew she (Morel) was thinking of the past. Her (Morel) mouth gradually shut hard in a line. She (Morel) was holding herself rigid, so that she (Morel) might die without ever uttering the great cry that was tearing from her (Morel). He (man) never forgot that hard, utterly lonely and stubborn clenching of her (Morel) mouth, which persisted for weeks. Sometimes, when it was lighter, she (Morel) talked about her (Morel) husband. Now she (Morel) hated him (husband). She (Morel) did not forgive him (husband). She (Morel) could not bear him (husband) to be in the room. And a few things, the things that had been most bitter to her (Morel), came up again so strongly that they broke from her (Morel), and she (Morel) told her (Morel) son.

He (son) felt as if his (son) life were being destroyed, piece by piece, within him (son). Often the tears came suddenly. He (son) ran to the station, the tear-drops falling on the pavement. Often he (son) could not go on with his (son) work. The pen stopped writing. He (son) sat staring, quite unconscious. And when he (son) came round again he (son) felt sick, and trembled in his (son) limbs. He (son) never questioned what it was. His (son) mind did not try to analyse or understand. He (son) merely submitted, and kept his (son) eyes shut; let the thing go over him (son).

His (son) mother did the same. She (mother) thought of the pain, of the morphia, of the next day; hardly ever of the death. That was coming, she (mother) knew. She (mother) had to submit to it. But she (mother) would never entreat it or make friends with it. Blind, with her (mother) face shut hard and blind, she (mother) was pushed towards the door. The days passed, the weeks, the months.

Sometimes, in the sunny afternoons, she (mother) seemed almost happy.

``I try to think of the nice times--when we went to Mablethorpe, and Robin Hood's Bay, and Shanklin,'' (she)
she (mother) said.
``After all, not everybody has seen those beautiful places. And wasn't it beautiful! I try to think of that, not of the other things.'' (she)

Then, again, for a whole evening she (mother) spoke not a word; neither did he (it). They were together, rigid, stubborn, silent. He (it) went into his (it) room at last to go to bed, and leaned against the doorway as if paralysed, unable to go any farther. His (it) consciousness went. A furious storm, he (it) knew not what, seemed to ravage inside him (it). He (it) stood leaning there, submitting, never questioning.

In the morning they were both normal again, though her (mother) face was grey with the morphia, and her (mother) body felt like ash. But they were bright again, nevertheless. Often, especially if Annie or Arthur were at home, he (Arthur) neglected her (Annie). He (Arthur) did not see much of Clara. Usually he (Arthur) was with men. He (Arthur) was quick and active and lively; but when his (Arthur) friends saw him (Arthur) go white to the gills, his (Arthur) eyes dark and glittering, they had a certain mistrust of him (Arthur). Sometimes he (Arthur) went to Clara, but she (Clara) was almost cold to him (Arthur).

``Take me!'' (he)
he (Arthur) said simply.

Occasionally she (Clara) would. But she (Clara) was afraid. When he (Arthur) had her (Clara) then, there was something in it that made her (Clara) shrink away from him (Arthur)--something unnatural. She (Clara) grew to dread him (Arthur). He (Arthur) was so quiet, yet so strange. She (Clara) was afraid of the man who was not there with her (Clara), whom she (Clara) could feel behind this make-belief lover; somebody sinister, that filled her (Clara) with horror. She (Clara) began to have a kind of horror of him (lover). It was almost as if he (lover) were a criminal. He (lover) wanted her (Clara)--he (lover) had her (Clara)--and it made her (Clara) feel as if death itself had her (Clara) in its grip. She (Clara) lay in horror. There was no man there loving her (Clara). She (Clara) almost hated him (man). Then came little bouts of tenderness. But she (Clara) dared not pity him (man).

Dawes had come to Colonel Seely's Home near Nottingham. There Paul visited him (Paul) sometimes, Clara very occasionally. Between the two men the friendship developed peculiarly. Dawes, who mended very slowly and seemed very feeble, seemed to leave himself in the hands of Morel.

In the beginning of November Clara reminded Paul that it was her (Clara) birthday.

``I'd nearly forgotten,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``I'd thought quite,'' (she)
she (Clara) replied.

``No. Shall we go to the seaside for the week-end?'' (unknown)

They went. It was cold and rather dismal. She (Clara) waited for him (Paul) to be warm and tender with her (Clara), instead of which he (Paul) seemed hardly aware of her (Clara). He (Paul) sat in the railway-carriage, looking out, and was startled when she (Clara) spoke to him (Paul). He (Paul) was not definitely thinking. Things seemed as if they did not exist. She (Clara) went across to him (Paul).

``What is it dear?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``Nothing!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``Don't those windmill sails look monotonous?'' (He)

He (Paul) sat holding her (Clara) hand. He (Paul) could not talk nor think. It was a comfort, however, to sit holding her (Clara) hand. She (Clara) was dissatisfied and miserable. He (Paul) was not with her (Clara); she (Clara) was nothing.

And in the evening they sat among the sandhills, looking at the black, heavy sea.

``She (Mablethorpe) will never give in,'' (he)
he (Paul) said quietly.

Clara's heart sank.

``No,'' (she)
she (Clara) replied.

``There are different ways of dying. My father's people are frightened, and have to be hauled out of life into death like cattle into a slaughter-house, pulled by the neck; but my mother's people are pushed from behind, inch by inch. They are stubborn people, and won't die.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara.

``And she (mother) won't die. She (mother) can't. Mr. Renshaw, the parson, was in the other day. ``Think!

'' he (Paul) said to her (Clara); `you will have your mother and father, and your sisters, and your son, in the Other Land.'' (she)
And she (Clara) said:
``I have done without them for a long time, and CAN do without them now. It is the living I want, not the dead.'' (she)
She (Clara) wants to live even now.''

``Oh, how horrible!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara, too frightened to speak.

``And she (mother) looks at me, and she (mother) wants to stay with me,'' (he)
he (son) went on monotonously.
``She (mother)'s got such a will, it seems as if she (mother) would never go--never!'' (unknown)

``Don't think of it!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
cried Clara.

``And she (mother) was religious--she (mother) is religious now--but it is no good. She (mother) simply won't give in. And do you know, I said to her (mother) on Thursday: ``Mother, if I had to die, I'd die. I'd WILL to die.'' And she (Clara) said to me, sharp:

``Do you think I haven't? Do you think you can die when you like?''' (unknown)

His (son) voice ceased. He (son) did not cry, only went on speaking monotonously. Clara wanted to run. She (Clara) looked round. There was the black, re-echoing shore, the dark sky down on her (Clara). She (Clara) got up terrified. She (Clara) wanted to be where there was light, where there were other people. She (Clara) wanted to be away from him (son). He (son) sat with his (son) head dropped, not moving a muscle.

``And I don't want her (Mother) to eat,'' (he)
he (son) said, ``and she (Mother) knows it. When I ask her (Mother): ``Shall you have anything' she (Mother)'s almost afraid to say
``Yes.'' (she)
``I'll have a cup of Benger``s,'' she (Clara) says. ``It'll only keep your strength up,'' I said to her (Clara). ``Yes'--and she (Mother) almost cried--`but there's such a gnawing when I eat nothing, I can't bear it.
'' So I went and made her (Clara) the food. It's the cancer that gnaws like that at her (Clara). I wish she (Clara)'d die!'' (I)

``Come!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Clara roughly.
``I'm going.'' (He)

He (son) followed her (Clara) down the darkness of the sands. He (son) did not come to her (Clara). He (son) seemed scarcely aware of her (Clara) existence. And she (Clara) was afraid of him (son), and disliked him (son).

In the same acute daze they went back to Nottingham. He (son) was always busy, always doing something, always going from one to the other of his (son) friends.

On the Monday he (son) went to see Baxter Dawes. Listless and pale, the man rose to greet the other, clinging to his (man) chair as he (man) held out his (man) hand.

``You shouldn't get up,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

Dawes sat down heavily, eyeing Morel with a sort of suspicion.

``Don't you waste your time on me,'' (he)
he (Morel) said,
``if you've owt better to do.'' (he)

``I wanted to come,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``Here! I brought you some sweets.'' (unknown)

The invalid put them aside.

``It's not been much of a week-end,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``How's your mother?'' (unknown)
asked the other.

``Hardly any different.'' (unknown)

``I thought she (mother) was perhaps worse, being as you didn't come on Sunday.'' (unknown)

``I was at Skegness,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``I wanted a change.'' (him)

The other looked at him (Paul) with dark eyes. He (Paul) seemed to be waiting, not quite daring to ask, trusting to be told.

``I went with Clara,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``I knew as much,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes quietly.

``It was an old promise,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``You have it your own way,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

This was the first time Clara had been definitely mentioned between them.

``Nay,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel slowly;
``she (Clara)'s tired of me.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Again Dawes looked at him (Morel).

``Since August she (Clara)'s been getting tired of me,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Morel repeated.

The two men were very quiet together. Paul suggested a game of draughts. They played in silence.

``I s'll go abroad when my mother's dead,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Abroad!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
repeated Dawes.

``Yes; I don't care what I do.'' (unknown)

They continued the game. Dawes was winning.

``I s'll have to begin a new start of some sort,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul;
``and you as well, I suppose.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

He (Paul) took one of Dawes's pieces.

``I dunno where,'' (unknown)
said the other.

``Things have to happen,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Morel said.
``It's no good doing anything--at least--no, I don't know. Give me some toffee.'' (The men)

The two men ate sweets, and began another game of draughts.

``What made that scar on your mouth?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
asked Dawes.

Paul put his (Paul) hand hastily to his (Paul) lips, and looked over the garden.

``I had a bicycle accident,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Dawes's hand trembled as he (Paul) moved the piece.

``You shouldn't ha' laughed at me,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, very low.

``When?'' (unknown)

``That night on Woodborough Road, when you and her (me) passed me--you with your hand on her (me) shoulder.'' (unknown)

``I never laughed at you,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

Dawes kept his (Paul) fingers on the draught-piece.

``I never knew you were there till the very second when you passed,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``It was that as did me,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
Dawes said, very low.

Paul took another sweet.

``I never laughed,'' (he)
he (Paul) said,
``except as I'm always laughing.'' (he)

They finished the game.

That night Morel walked home from Nottingham, in order to have something to do. The furnaces flared in a red blotch over Bulwell; the black clouds were like a low ceiling. As he (Morel) went along the ten miles of highroad, he (Morel) felt as if he (Morel) were walking out of life, between the black levels of the sky and the earth. But at the end was only the sick-room. If he (Morel) walked and walked for ever, there was only that place to come to.

He (Morel) was not tired when he (Morel) got near home, or He (Morel) did not know it. Across the field he (Morel) could see the red firelight leaping in her (Morel) bedroom window.

``When she (me)'s dead,'' (he)
he (Morel) said to himself,
``that fire will go out.'' (he)

He (Morel) took off his (Morel) boots quietly and crept upstairs. His (Morel) mothers door was wide open, because she (Morel) slept alone still. The red firelight dashed its glow on the landing. Soft as a shadow, he (Morel) peeped in her (Morel) doorway.

``Paul!'' (she)
she (Morel) murmured.

His (Morel) heart seemed to break again. He (Morel) went in and sat by the bed.

``How late you are!'' (she)
she (Morel) murmured.

``Not very,'' (he)
he (Morel) said.

``Why, what time is it?'' (unknown)
The murmur came plaintive and helpless.

``It's only just gone eleven.'' (unknown)

That was not true; it was nearly one o'clock.

``Oh!'' (she)
she (Morel) said;
``I thought it was later.'' (she)

And he (Morel) knew the unutterable misery of her (Morel) nights that would not go.

``Can't you sleep, my pigeon?'' (he)
he (Morel) said.

``No, I can't,'' (she)
she (Morel) wailed.

``Never mind, Little!'' (He)
He (Morel) said crooning.
``Never mind, my love. I'll stop with you half an hour, my pigeon; then perhaps it will be better.'' (he)

And he (Morel) sat by the bedside, slowly, rhythmically stroking her (Morel) brows with his (Morel) finger-tips, stroking her (Morel) eyes shut, soothing her (Morel), holding her (Morel) fingers in his (Morel) free hand. They could hear the sleepers' breathing in the other rooms.

``Now go to bed,'' (she)
she (Morel) murmured, lying quite still under his (Morel) fingers and his (Morel) love.

``Will you sleep?'' (he)
he (Morel) asked.

``Yes, I think so.'' (unknown)

``You feel better, my Little, don't you?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Morel) said, like a fretful, half-soothed child.

Still the days and the weeks went by. He (Morel) hardly ever went to see Clara now. But he (Morel) wandered restlessly from one person to another for some help, and there was none anywhere. Miriam had written to him (Morel) tenderly. He (Morel) went to see her (Miriam). Her (Miriam) heart was very sore when she (Miriam) saw him (Morel), white, gaunt, with his (Morel) eyes dark and bewildered. Her (Miriam) pity came up, hurting her (Miriam) till she (Miriam) could not bear it.

``How is she (I)?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``The same--the same!'' (he)
he (Morel) said.
``The doctor says she (I) can't last, but I know she (I) will. She (I)'ll be here at Christmas.'' (Miriam/Miriam Leivers/MIRIAM)

Miriam shuddered. She (Miriam) drew him (Morel) to her (Miriam); she (Miriam) pressed him (Morel) to her (Miriam) bosom; she (Miriam) kissed him (Morel) and kissed him (Morel). He (Morel) submitted, but it was torture. She (Miriam) could not kiss his (Morel) agony. That remained alone and apart. She (Miriam) kissed his (Morel) face, and roused his (Morel) blood, while his (Morel) soul was apart writhing with the agony of death. And she (Miriam) kissed him (Morel) and fingered his (Morel) body, till at last, feeling he (Morel) would go mad, he (Morel) got away from her (Miriam). It was not what he (Morel) wanted just then--not that. And she (Miriam) thought she (Miriam) had soothed him (Morel) and done him (Morel) good.

December came, and some snow. He (Morel) stayed at home all the while now. They could not afford a nurse. Annie came to look after her (Annie) mother; the parish nurse, whom they loved, came in morning and evening. Paul shared the nursing with Annie. Often, in the evenings, when friends were in the kitchen with them, they all laughed together and shook with laughter. It was reaction. Paul was so comical, Annie was so quaint. The whole party laughed till they cried, trying to subdue the sound. And Mrs. Morel, lying alone in the darkness heard them, and among her (Morel) bitterness was a feeling of relief.

Then Paul would go upstairs gingerly, guiltily, to see if she (Morel) had heard.

``Shall I give you some milk?'' (he)
he (Paul) asked.

``A little,'' (she)
she (Morel) replied plaintively.

And he (Paul) would put some water with it, so that it should not nourish her (Morel). Yet he (Paul) loved her (Morel) more than his (Paul) own life.

She (Morel) had morphia every night, and her (Morel) heart got fitful. Annie slept beside her (Annie). Paul would go in in the early morning, when his (Paul) sister got up. His (Paul) mother was wasted and almost ashen in the morning with the morphia. Darker and darker grew her (mother) eyes, all pupil, with the torture. In the mornings the weariness and ache were too much to bear. Yet she (mother) could not--would not--weep, or even complain much.

``You slept a bit later this morning, little one,'' (he)
he (pupil) would say to her (mother).

``Did I?'' (she)
she (mother) answered, with fretful weariness.

``Yes; it's nearly eight o'clock.'' (He)

He (pupil) stood looking out of the window. The whole country was bleak and pallid under the snow. Then he (pupil) felt her (mother) pulse. There was a strong stroke and a weak one, like a sound and its echo. That was supposed to betoken the end. She (mother) let him (pupil) feel her (mother) wrist, knowing what he (pupil) wanted.

Sometimes they looked in each other's eyes. Then they almost seemed to make an agreement. It was almost as if he (pupil) were agreeing to die also. But she (mother) did not consent to die; she (mother) would not. Her (mother) body was wasted to a fragment of ash. Her (mother) eyes were dark and full of torture.

``Can't you give her (I) something to put an end to it?'' (he)
he (pupil) asked the doctor at last.

But the doctor shook his (doctor) head.

``She (I) can't last many days now, Mr. Morel,'' (he)
he (doctor) said.

Paul went indoors.

``I can't bear it much longer; we shall all go mad,'' (Annie)
said Annie.

The two sat down to breakfast.

``Go and sit with her (I) while we have breakfast, Minnie,'' (Annie)
said Annie. But the girl was frightened.

Paul went through the country, through the woods, over the snow. He (Paul) saw the marks of rabbits and birds in the white snow. He (Paul) wandered miles and miles. A smoky red sunset came on slowly, painfully, lingering. He (Paul) thought she (Annie) would die that day. There was a donkey that came up to him (Paul) over the snow by the wood's edge, and put its head against him (Paul), and walked with him (Paul) alongside. He (Paul) put his (Paul) arms round the donkey's neck, and stroked his (Paul) cheeks against his (Paul) ears.

His (Paul) mother, silent, was still alive, with her (mother) hard mouth gripped grimly, her (mother) eyes of dark torture only living.

It was nearing Christmas; there was more snow. Annie and he (Paul) felt as if they could go on no more. Still her (Annie) dark eyes were alive. Morel, silent and frightened, obliterated himself. Sometimes he (Morel) would go into the sick-room and look at her (Annie). Then he (Morel) backed out, bewildered.

She (Annie) kept her (Annie) hold on life still. The miners had been out on strike, and returned a fortnight or so before Christmas. Minnie went upstairs with the feeding-cup. It was two days after the men had been in.

``Have the men been saying their hands are sore, Minnie?'' (she)
she (Minnie) asked, in the faint, querulous voice that would not give in. Minnie stood surprised.

``Not as I know of, Mrs. Morel,'' (she)
she (Minnie) answered.

``But I'll bet they are sore,'' (the woman)
said the dying woman, as she (Minnie) moved her (Minnie) head with a sigh of weariness.
``But, at any rate, there'll be something to buy in with this week.'' (she)

Not a thing did she (Minnie) let slip.

``Your father's pit things will want well airing, Annie,'' (she)
she (Minnie) said, when the men were going back to work.

``Don't you bother about that, my dear,'' (Annie)
said Annie.

One night Annie and Paul were alone. Nurse was upstairs.

``She (Annie)'ll live over Christmas,'' (Annie)
said Annie. They were both full of horror.
``She (Annie) won't,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied grimly.
``I s'll give her (Annie) morphia.'' (unknown)

``Which?'' (Annie)
said Annie.

``All that came from Sheffield,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Ay--do!'' (Annie)
said Annie.

The next day he (Paul) was painting in the bedroom. She (Annie) seemed to be asleep. He (Paul) stepped softly backwards and forwards at his (Paul) painting. Suddenly her (Annie) small voice wailed:

``Don't walk about, Paul.'' (He)

He (Paul) looked round. Her (Annie) eyes, like dark bubbles in her (Annie) face, were looking at him (Paul).

``No, my dear,'' (he)
he (Paul) said gently. Another fibre seemed to snap in his (Paul) heart.

That evening he (Paul) got all the morphia pills there were, and took them downstairs. Carefully he (Paul) crushed them to powder.

``What are you doing?'' (Annie)
said Annie.

``I s'll put 'em in her (Annie) night milk.'' (children)

Then they both laughed together like two conspiring children. On top of all their horror flicked this little sanity.

Nurse did not come that night to settle Mrs. Morel down. Paul went up with the hot milk in a feeding-cup. It was nine o'clock.

She (Morel) was reared up in bed, and he (Paul) put the feeding-cup between her (Morel) lips that he (Paul) would have died to save from any hurt. She (Morel) took a sip, then put the spout of the cup away and looked at him (Paul) with her (Morel) dark, wondering eyes. He (Paul) looked at her (Morel).

``Oh, it IS bitter, Paul!'' (she)
she (Morel) said, making a little grimace.

``It's a new sleeping draught the doctor gave me for you,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``He (doctor) thought it would leave you in such a state in the morning.'' (unknown)

``And I hope it won't,'' (she)
she (Morel) said, like a child.

She (Morel) drank some more of the milk.

``But it IS horrid!'' (she)
she (Morel) said.

He (Paul) saw her (Morel) frail fingers over the cup, her (Morel) lips making a little move.

``I know--I tasted it,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.
``But I'll give you some clean milk afterwards.'' (unknown)

``I think so,'' (she)
she (Morel) said, and she (Morel) went on with the draught. She (Morel) was obedient to him (Paul) like a child. He (Paul) wondered if she (Morel) knew. He (Paul) saw her (Morel) poor wasted throat moving as she (Morel) drank with difficulty. Then he (Paul) ran downstairs for more milk. There were no grains in the bottom of the cup.

``Has she (Annie) had it?'' (Annie)
whispered Annie.

``Yes--and she (Annie) said it was bitter.'' (unknown)

``Oh!'' (Annie)
laughed Annie, putting her (Annie) under lip between her (Annie) teeth.

``And I told her (Annie) it was a new draught. Where's that milk?'' (unknown)

They both went upstairs.

``I wonder why nurse didn't come to settle me down?'' (the mother)
complained the mother, like a child, wistfully.

``She (nurse) said she (nurse) was going to a concert, my love,'' (Annie)
replied Annie.

``Did she (nurse)?'' (unknown)

They were silent a minute. Mrs. Morel gulped the little clean milk.

``Annie, that draught WAS horrid!'' (she)
she (Morel) said plaintively.

``Was it, my love? Well, never mind.'' (The mother)

The mother sighed again with weariness. Her (Morel) pulse was very irregular.

``Let US settle you down,'' (Annie)
said Annie.
``Perhaps nurse will be so late.'' (unknown)

``Ay,'' (the mother)
said the mother--
``try.'' (the mother)

They turned the clothes back. Paul saw his (Paul) mother like a girl curled up in her (girl) flannel nightdress. Quickly they made one half of the bed, moved her (girl), made the other, straightened her (girl) nightgown over her (girl) small feet, and covered her (girl) up.

``There,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul, stroking her (girl) softly.
``There!--now you'll sleep.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (girl) said.
``I didn't think you could do the bed so nicely,'' (she)
she (girl) added, almost gaily. Then she (girl) curled up, with her (girl) cheek on her (girl) hand, her (girl) head snugged between her (girl) shoulders. Paul put the long thin plait of grey hair over her (girl) shoulder and kissed her (girl).

``You'll sleep, my love,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (girl) answered trustfully.
``Good-night.'' (unknown)

They put out the light, and it was still.

Morel was in bed. Nurse did not come. Annie and Paul came to look at her (Annie) at about eleven. She (Annie) seemed to be sleeping as usual after her (Annie) draught. Her (Annie) mouth had come a bit open.

``Shall we sit up?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``I s'll lie with her (nurse) as I always do,'' (Annie)
said Annie.
``She (nurse) might wake up.'' (unknown)

``All right. And call me if you see any difference.'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

They lingered before the bedroom fire, feeling the night big and black and snowy outside, their two selves alone in the world. At last he (Paul) went into the next room and went to bed.

He (Paul) slept almost immediately, but kept waking every now and again. Then he (Paul) went sound asleep. He (Paul) started awake at Annie's whispered,

``Paul, Paul!'' (Annie)
He (Paul) saw his (Paul) sister in her (Annie) white nightdress, with her (Annie) long plait of hair down her (Annie) back, standing in the darkness.

``Yes?'' (he)
he (Paul) whispered, sitting up.

``Come and look at her (nurse).'' (He)

He (Paul) slipped out of bed. A bud of gas was burning in the sick chamber. His (Paul) mother lay with her (mother) cheek on her (mother) hand, curled up as she (mother) had gone to sleep. But her (mother) mouth had fallen open, and she (mother) breathed with great, hoarse breaths, like snoring, and there were long intervals between.

``She (nurse)'s going!'' (he)
he (Paul) whispered.

``Yes,'' (Annie)
said Annie.

``How long has she (nurse) been like it?'' (unknown)

``I only just woke up.'' (Annie)

Annie huddled into the dressing-gown, Paul wrapped himself in a brown blanket. It was three o'clock. He (Paul) mended the fire. Then the two sat waiting. The great, snoring breath was taken--held awhile--then given back. There was a space--a long space. Then they started. The great, snoring breath was taken again. He (Paul) bent close down and looked at her (Annie).

``Isn't it awful!'' (Annie)
whispered Annie.

He (Paul) nodded. They sat down again helplessly. Again came the great, snoring breath. Again they hung suspended. Again it was given back, long and harsh. The sound, so irregular, at such wide intervals, sounded through the house. Morel, in his (Morel) room, slept on. Paul and Annie sat crouched, huddled, motionless. The great snoring sound began again--there was a painful pause while the breath was held--back came the rasping breath. Minute after minute passed. Paul looked at her (Annie) again, bending low over her (Annie).

``She (nurse) may last like this,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

They were both silent. He (Paul) looked out of the window, and could faintly discern the snow on the garden.

``You go to my bed,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to Annie.
``I'll sit up.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Annie) said,
``I'll stop with you.'' (she)

``I'd rather you didn't,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

At last Annie crept out of the room, and he (Paul) was alone. He (Paul) hugged himself in his (Paul) brown blanket, crouched in front of his (Paul) mother, watching. She (mother) looked dreadful, with the bottom jaw fallen back. He (Paul) watched. Sometimes he (Paul) thought the great breath would never begin again. He (Paul) could not bear it--the waiting. Then suddenly, startling him (Paul), came the great harsh sound. He (Paul) mended the fire again, noiselessly. She (mother) must not be disturbed. The minutes went by. The night was going, breath by breath. Each time the sound came he (Paul) felt it wring him (Paul), till at last he (Paul) could not feel so much.

His (Paul) father got up. Paul heard the miner drawing his (Paul) stockings on, yawning. Then Morel, in shirt and stockings, entered.

``Hush!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

Morel stood watching. Then he (Morel) looked at his (Morel) son, helplessly, and in horror.

``Had I better stop a-whoam?'' (he)
he (Morel) whispered.

``No. Go to work. She (nurse)'ll last through to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``I don't think so.'' (unknown)

``Yes. Go to work.'' (The miner)

The miner looked at her (mother) again, in fear, and went obediently out of the room. Paul saw the tape of his (Paul) garters swinging against his (Paul) legs.

After another half-hour Paul went downstairs and drank a cup of tea, then returned. Morel, dressed for the pit, came upstairs again.

``Am I to go?'' (he)
he (Morel) said.

``Yes.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

And in a few minutes Paul heard his (Paul) father's heavy steps go thudding over the deadening snow. Miners called in the streets as they tramped in gangs to work. The terrible, long-drawn breaths continued--heave--heave--heave; then a long pause--then--ah-h-h-h-h! as it came back. Far away over the snow sounded the hooters of the ironworks. One after another they crowed and boomed, some small and far away, some near, the blowers of the collieries and the other works. Then there was silence. He (Paul) mended the fire. The great breaths broke the silence--she (gangs) looked just the same. He (Paul) put back the blind and peered out. Still it was dark. Perhaps there was a lighter tinge. Perhaps the snow was bluer. He (Paul) drew up the blind and got dressed. Then, shuddering, he (Paul) drank brandy from the bottle on the wash-stand. The snow WAS growing blue. He (Paul) heard a cart clanking down the street. Yes, it was seven o'clock, and it was coming a little bit light. He (Paul) heard some people calling. The world was waking. A grey, deathly dawn crept over the snow. Yes, he (Paul) could see the houses. He (Paul) put out the gas. It seemed very dark. The breathing came still, but he (Paul) was almost used to it. He (Paul) could see her (Paul). She (Paul) was just the same. He (Paul) wondered if he (Paul) piled heavy clothes on top of her (Paul) it would stop. He (Paul) looked at her (Paul). That was not her (Paul)--not her (Paul) a bit. If he (Paul) piled the blanket and heavy coats on her (Paul)--

Suddenly the door opened, and Annie entered. She (Annie) looked at him (Paul) questioningly.

``Just the same,'' (he)
he (Paul) said calmly.

They whispered together a minute, then he (Paul) went downstairs to get breakfast. It was twenty to eight. Soon Annie came down.

``Isn't it awful! Doesn't she (nurse) look awful!'' (she)
she (Annie) whispered, dazed with horror.

He (Paul) nodded.

``If she (nurse) looks like that!'' (Annie)
said Annie.

``Drink some tea,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

They went upstairs again. Soon the neighbours came with their frightened question:

``How is she (nurse)?'' (the neighbours)

It went on just the same. She (Annie) lay with her (Annie) cheek in her (Annie) hand, her (Annie) mouth fallen open, and the great, ghastly snores came and went.

At ten o'clock nurse came. She (nurse) looked strange and woebegone.

``Nurse,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
cried Paul,
``she (Nurse)'ll last like this for days?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``She (Nurse) can't, Mr. Morel,'' (nurse)
said nurse.
``She (Nurse) can't.'' (unknown)

There was a silence.

``Isn't it dreadful!'' (the nurse)
wailed the nurse.
``Who would have thought she (Nurse) could stand it? Go down now, Mr. Morel, go down.'' (he)

At last, at about eleven o'clock, he (Paul) went downstairs and sat in the neighbour's house. Annie was downstairs also. Nurse and Arthur were upstairs. Paul sat with his (Paul) head in his (Paul) hand. Suddenly Annie came flying across the yard crying, half mad:

``Paul--Paul--she (Nurse)'s gone!'' (Annie)

In a second he (Paul) was back in his (Paul) own house and upstairs. She (Annie) lay curled up and still, with her (Annie) face on her (Annie) hand, and nurse was wiping her (nurse) mouth. They all stood back. He (Paul) kneeled down, and put his (Paul) face to hers and his (Paul) arms round her (nurse):

``My love--my love--oh, my love!'' (He)
he (Paul) whispered again and again.
``My love--oh, my love!'' (he)

Then he (Paul) heard the nurse behind him (Paul), crying, saying:

``She (Nurse)'s better, Mr. Morel, she (Nurse)'s better.'' (him)

When he (Paul) took his (Paul) face up from his (Paul) warm, dead mother he (Paul) went straight downstairs and began blacking his (Paul) boots.

There was a good deal to do, letters to write, and so on. The doctor came and glanced at her (mother), and sighed.

``Ay--poor thing!'' (he)
he (doctor) said, then turned away.
``Well, call at the surgery about six for the certificate.'' (The father)

The father came home from work at about four o'clock. He (father) dragged silently into the house and sat down. Minnie bustled to give him (father) his (father) dinner. Tired, he (father) laid his (father) black arms on the table. There were swede turnips for his (father) dinner, which he (father) liked. Paul wondered if he (Paul) knew. It was some time, and nobody had spoken. At last the son said:

``You noticed the blinds were down?'' (the son)

Morel looked up.

``No,'' (he)
he (Morel) said.
``Why--has she (Nurse) gone?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``When wor that?'' (unknown)

``About twelve this morning.'' (unknown)

``H'm!'' (The miner)

The miner sat still for a moment, then began his (Morel) dinner. It was as if nothing had happened. He (Morel) ate his (Morel) turnips in silence. Afterwards he (Morel) washed and went upstairs to dress. The door of her (Minnie) room was shut.

``Have you seen her (Nurse)?'' (Annie)
Annie asked of him (Morel) when he (Morel) came down.

``No,'' (he)
he (Morel) said.

In a little while he (Morel) went out. Annie went away, and Paul called on the undertaker, the clergyman, the doctor, the registrar. It was a long business. He (Paul) got back at nearly eight o'clock. The undertaker was coming soon to measure for the coffin. The house was empty except for her (Annie). He (undertaker) took a candle and went upstairs.

The room was cold, that had been warm for so long. Flowers, bottles, plates, all sick-room litter was taken away; everything was harsh and austere. She (Annie) lay raised on the bed, the sweep of the sheet from the raised feet was like a clean curve of snow, so silent. She (Annie) lay like a maiden asleep. With his (undertaker) candle in his (undertaker) hand, he (undertaker) bent over her (Annie). She (Annie) lay like a girl asleep and dreaming of her (Annie) love. The mouth was a little open as if wondering from the suffering, but her (Annie) face was young, her (Annie) brow clear and white as if life had never touched it. He (undertaker) looked again at the eyebrows, at the small, winsome nose a bit on one side. She (Annie) was young again. Only the hair as it arched so beautifully from her (Annie) temples was mixed with silver, and the two simple plaits that lay on her (Annie) shoulders were filigree of silver and brown. She (Annie) would wake up. She (Annie) would lift her (Annie) eyelids. She (Annie) was with him (undertaker) still. He (undertaker) bent and kissed her (Annie) passionately. But there was coldness against his (undertaker) mouth. He (undertaker) bit his (undertaker) lips with horror. Looking at her (Annie), he (undertaker) felt he (undertaker) could never, never let her (Annie) go. No! He (undertaker) stroked the hair from her (Annie) temples. That, too, was cold. He (undertaker) saw the mouth so dumb and wondering at the hurt. Then he (undertaker) crouched on the floor, whispering to her (Annie):

``Mother, mother!'' (he)

He (undertaker) was still with her (Annie) when the undertakers came, young men who had been to school with him (undertaker). They touched her (Annie) reverently, and in a quiet, businesslike fashion. They did not look at her (Annie). He (undertaker) watched jealously. He (undertaker) and Annie guarded her (Annie) fiercely. They would not let anybody come to see her (Annie), and the neighbours were offended.

After a while Paul went out of the house, and played cards at a friend's. It was midnight when he (Paul) got back. His (Paul) father rose from the couch as he (Paul) entered, saying in a plaintive way:

``I thought tha wor niver comin', lad.'' (he)

``I didn't think you'd sit up,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

His (Paul) father looked so forlorn. Morel had been a man without fear--simply nothing frightened him (Morel). Paul realised with a start that he (Paul) had been afraid to go to bed, alone in the house with his (Paul) dead. He (Paul) was sorry.

``I forgot you'd be alone, father,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Dost want owt to eat?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Morel.

``No.'' (unknown)

``Sithee--I made thee a drop o' hot milk. Get it down thee; it's cold enough for owt.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul drank it.

After a while Morel went to bed. He (Morel) hurried past the closed door, and left his (Morel) own door open. Soon the son came upstairs also. He (Morel) went in to kiss her (Paul) good-night, as usual. It was cold and dark. He (Morel) wished they had kept her (Paul) fire burning. Still she (Paul) dreamed her (Paul) young dream. But she (Paul) would be cold.

``My dear!'' (he)
he (Morel) whispered.
``My dear!'' (he)

And he (Morel) did not kiss her (Paul), for fear she (Paul) should be cold and strange to him (Morel). It eased him (Morel) she (Paul) slept so beautifully. He (Morel) shut her (Paul) door softly, not to wake her (Paul), and went to bed.

In the morning Morel summoned his (Morel) courage, hearing Annie downstairs and Paul coughing in the room across the landing. He (Paul) opened her (Annie) door, and went into the darkened room. He (Paul) saw the white uplifted form in the twilight, but her (Annie) he (Paul) dared not see. Bewildered, too frightened to possess any of his (Paul) faculties, he (Paul) got out of the room again and left her (Annie). He (Paul) never looked at her (Annie) again. He (Paul) had not seen her (Annie) for months, because he (Paul) had not dared to look. And she (Annie) looked like his (Paul) young wife again.

``Have you seen her (Nurse)?'' (Annie)
Annie asked of him (Paul) sharply after breakfast.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``And don't you think she (Nurse) looks nice?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (He)

He (Paul) went out of the house soon after. And all the time he (Paul) seemed to be creeping aside to avoid it.

Paul went about from place to place, doing the business of the death. He (Paul) met Clara in Nottingham, and they had tea together in a cafe, when they were quite jolly again. She (Clara) was infinitely relieved to find he (Paul) did not take it tragically.

Later, when the relatives began to come for the funeral, the affair became public, and the children became social beings. They put themselves aside. They buried her (Clara) in a furious storm of rain and wind. The wet clay glistened, all the white flowers were soaked. Annie gripped his (Paul) arm and leaned forward. Down below she (Annie) saw a dark corner of William's coffin. The oak box sank steadily. She (Annie) was gone. The rain poured in the grave. The procession of black, with its umbrellas glistening, turned away. The cemetery was deserted under the drenching cold rain.

Paul went home and busied himself supplying the guests with drinks. His (Paul) father sat in the kitchen with Mrs. Morel's relatives,

``superior'' (Morel relatives)
people, and wept, and said what a good lass she (lass)'d been, and how he (Paul)'d tried to do everything he (Paul) could for her (lass)--everything. He (Paul) had striven all his (Paul) life to do what he (Paul) could for her (lass), and he (Paul)'d nothing to reproach himself with. She (lass) was gone, but he (Paul)'d done his (Paul) best for her (lass). He (Paul) wiped his (Paul) eyes with his (Paul) white handkerchief. He (Paul)'d nothing to reproach himself for, he (Paul) repeated. All his (Paul) life he (Paul)'d done his (Paul) best for her (lass).

And that was how he (Paul) tried to dismiss her (lass). He (Paul) never thought of her (lass) personally. Everything deep in him (Paul) he (Paul) denied. Paul hated his (Paul) father for sitting sentimentalising over her (lass). He (Paul) knew he (Paul) would do it in the public-houses. For the real tragedy went on in Morel in spite of himself. Sometimes, later, he (Morel) came down from his (Morel) afternoon sleep, white and cowering.

``I HAVE been dreaming of thy mother,'' (he)
he (Morel) said in a small voice.

``Have you, father? When I dream of her (mother) it's always just as she (mother) was when she (mother) was well. I dream of her (mother) often, but it seems quite nice and natural, as if nothing had altered.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

But Morel crouched in front of the fire in terror.

The weeks passed half-real, not much pain, not much of anything, perhaps a little relief, mostly a _nuit blanche_. Paul went restless from place to place. For some months, since his (Paul) mother had been worse, he (Paul) had not made love to Clara. She (Clara) was, as it were, dumb to him (Paul), rather distant. Dawes saw her (Dawes) very occasionally, but the two could not get an inch across the great distance between them. The three of them were drifting forward.

Dawes mended very slowly. He (Paul) was in the convalescent home at Skegness at Christmas, nearly well again. Paul went to the seaside for a few days. His (Paul) father was with Annie in Sheffield. Dawes came to Paul's lodgings. His (Paul) time in the home was up. The two men, between whom was such a big reserve, seemed faithful to each other. Dawes depended on Morel now. He (Morel) knew Paul and Clara had practically separated.

Two days after Christmas Paul was to go back to Nottingham. The evening before he (Paul) sat with Dawes smoking before the fire.

``You know Clara's coming down for the day to-morrow?'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

The other man glanced at him (Paul).

``Yes, you told me,'' (he)
he (Paul) replied.

Paul drank the remainder of his (Paul) glass of whisky.

``I told the landlady your wife was coming,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Did you?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes, shrinking, but almost leaving himself in the other's hands. He (Paul) got up rather stiffly, and reached for Morel's glass.

``Let me fill you up,'' (he)
he (Morel) said.

Paul jumped up.

``You sit still,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

But Dawes, with rather shaky hand, continued to mix the drink.

``Say when,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Thanks!'' (unknown)
replied the other.
``But you've no business to get up.'' (unknown)

``It does me good, lad,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
replied Dawes.
``I begin to think I'm right again, then.'' (unknown)

``You are about right, you know.'' (unknown)

``I am, certainly I am,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes, nodding to him (Paul).

``And Len says he (Len) can get you on in Sheffield.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Dawes glanced at him (Paul) again, with dark eyes that agreed with everything the other would say, perhaps a trifle dominated by him (Paul).

``It's funny,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``starting again. I feel in a lot bigger mess than you.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``In what way, lad?'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I don't know. It's as if I was in a tangled sort of hole, rather dark and dreary, and no road anywhere.'' (unknown)

``I know--I understand it,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
Dawes said, nodding.
``But you'll find it'll come all right.'' (He)

He (Paul) spoke caressingly.

``I suppose so,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

Dawes knocked his (Paul) pipe in a hopeless fashion.

``You've not done for yourself like I have,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

Morel saw the wrist and the white hand of the other man gripping the stem of the pipe and knocking out the ash, as if he (Morel) had given up.

``How old are you?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Paul asked.

``Thirty-nine,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
replied Dawes, glancing at him (Paul).

Those brown eyes, full of the consciousness of failure, almost pleading for reassurance, for someone to re-establish the man in himself, to warm him (man), to set him (man) up firm again, troubled Paul.

``You'll just be in your prime,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.
``You don't look as if much life had gone out of you.'' (unknown)

The brown eyes of the other flashed suddenly.

``It hasn't,'' (he)
he (Morel) said.
``The go is there.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul looked up and laughed.

``We've both got plenty of life in us yet to make things fly,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

The eyes of the two men met. They exchanged one look. Having recognised the stress of passion each in the other, they both drank their whisky.

``Yes, begod!'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes, breathless.

There was a pause.

``And I don't see,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``why you shouldn't go on where you left off.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``What--'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes, suggestively.

``Yes--fit your old home together again.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Dawes hid his (Paul) face and shook his (Paul) head.

``Couldn't be done,'' (he)
he (Paul) said, and looked up with an ironic smile.

``Why? Because you don't want?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps.'' (unknown)

They smoked in silence. Dawes showed his (Paul) teeth as he (Paul) bit his (Paul) pipe stem.

``You mean you don't want her (you)?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Paul.

Dawes stared up at the picture with a caustic expression on his (Paul) face.

``I hardly know,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

The smoke floated softly up.

``I believe she (you) wants you,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``Do you?'' (unknown)
replied the other, soft, satirical, abstract.

``Yes. She (you) never really hitched on to me--you were always there in the background. That's why she (you) wouldn't get a divorce.'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)

Dawes continued to stare in a satirical fashion at the picture over the mantelpiece.

``That's how women are with me,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.
``They want me like mad, but they don't want to belong to me. And she (you) BELONGED to you all the time. I knew.'' (The male)

The triumphant male came up in Dawes. He (Dawes) showed his (Dawes) teeth more distinctly.

``Perhaps I was a fool,'' (he)
he (Dawes) said.

``You were a big fool,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``But perhaps even THEN you were a bigger fool,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

There was a touch of triumph and malice in it.

``Do you think so?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

They were silent for some time.

``At any rate, I'm clearing out to-morrow,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.

``I see,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
answered Dawes.

Then they did not talk any more. The instinct to murder each other had returned. They almost avoided each other.

They shared the same bedroom. When they retired Dawes seemed abstract, thinking of something. He (Morel) sat on the side of the bed in his (Morel) shirt, looking at his (Morel) legs.

``Aren't you getting cold?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
asked Morel.

``I was lookin' at these legs,'' (unknown)
replied the other.

``What's up with 'em? They look all right,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
replied Paul, from his (Paul) bed.

``They look all right. But there's some water in 'em yet.'' (unknown)

``And what about it?'' (unknown)

``Come and look.'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

Paul reluctantly got out of bed and went to look at the rather handsome legs of the other man that were covered with glistening, dark gold hair.

``Look here,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes, pointing to his (Paul) shin.
``Look at the water under here.'' (unknown)

``Where?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

The man pressed in his (Paul) finger-tips. They left little dents that filled up slowly.

``It's nothing,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul.

``You feel,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

Paul tried with his (Paul) fingers. It made little dents.

``H'm!'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Rotten, isn't it?'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

``Why? It's nothing much.'' (unknown)

``You're not much of a man with water in your legs.'' (unknown)

``I can't see as it makes any difference,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.
``I've got a weak chest.'' (He)

He (Morel) returned to his (Morel) own bed.

``I suppose the rest of me's all right,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes, and he (Morel) put out the light.

In the morning it was raining. Morel packed his (Morel) bag. The sea was grey and shaggy and dismal. He (Morel) seemed to be cutting himself off from life more and more. It gave him (Morel) a wicked pleasure to do it.

The two men were at the station. Clara stepped out of the train, and came along the platform, very erect and coldly composed. She (Clara) wore a long coat and a tweed hat. Both men hated her (Clara) for her (Clara) composure. Paul shook hands with her (Clara) at the barrier. Dawes was leaning against the bookstall, watching. His (Paul) black overcoat was buttoned up to the chin because of the rain. He (Paul) was pale, with almost a touch of nobility in his (Paul) quietness. He (Paul) came forward, limping slightly.

``You ought to look better than this,'' (she)
she (Dawes) said.
