``Oh, I'm all right now.'' (unknown)

The three stood at a loss. She (Dawes) kept the two men hesitating near her (Dawes).

``Shall we go to the lodging straight off,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul,
``or somewhere else?'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``We may as well go home,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

Paul walked on the outside of the pavement, then Dawes, then Clara. They made polite conversation. The sitting-room faced the sea, whose tide, grey and shaggy, hissed not far off.

Morel swung up the big arm-chair.

``Sit down, Jack,'' (he)
he (Morel) said.

``I don't want that chair,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

``Sit down!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
Morel repeated.

Clara took off her (Dawes) things and laid them on the couch. She (Dawes) had a slight air of resentment. Lifting her (Dawes) hair with her (Dawes) fingers, she (Dawes) sat down, rather aloof and composed. Paul ran downstairs to speak to the landlady.

``I should think you're cold,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes to his (Paul) wife.
``Come nearer to the fire.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, I'm quite warm,'' (she)
she (Dawes) answered.

She (Dawes) looked out of the window at the rain and at the sea.

``When are you going back?'' (she)
she (Dawes) asked.

``Well, the rooms are taken until to-morrow, so he (Jack) wants me to stop. He (Jack)'s going back to-night.'' (unknown)

``And then you're thinking of going to Sheffield?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Are you fit to start work?'' (unknown)

``I'm going to start.'' (unknown)

``You've really got a place?'' (unknown)

``Yes--begin on Monday.'' (unknown)

``You don't look fit.'' (unknown)

``Why don't I?'' (She)

She (Dawes) looked again out of the window instead of answering.

``And have you got lodgings in Sheffield?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (she)

Again she (Dawes) looked away out of the window. The panes were blurred with streaming rain.

``And can you manage all right?'' (she)
she (Dawes) asked.

``I s'd think so. I s'll have to!'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

They were silent when Morel returned.

``I shall go by the four-twenty,'' (he)
he (Morel) said as he (Morel) entered.

Nobody answered.

``I wish you'd take your boots off,'' (he)
he (Morel) said to Clara.

``There's a pair of slippers of mine.'' (unknown)

``Thank you,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.
``They aren't wet.'' (He)

He (Morel) put the slippers near her (Clara) feet. She (Clara) left them there.

Morel sat down. Both the men seemed helpless, and each of them had a rather hunted look. But Dawes now carried himself quietly, seemed to yield himself, while Paul seemed to screw himself up. Clara thought she (Clara) had never seen him (Paul) look so small and mean. He (Paul) was as if trying to get himself into the smallest possible compass. And as he (Paul) went about arranging, and as he (Paul) sat talking, there seemed something false about him (Paul) and out of tune. Watching him (Paul) unknown, she (Clara) said to herself there was no stability about him (Paul). He (Paul) was fine in his (Paul) way, passionate, and able to give her (Clara) drinks of pure life when he (Paul) was in one mood. And now he (Paul) looked paltry and insignificant. There was nothing stable about him (Paul). Her (Clara) husband had more manly dignity. At any rate HE (husband) did not waft about with any wind. There was something evanescent about Morel, she (Clara) thought, something shifting and false. He (Morel) would never make sure ground for any woman to stand on. She (woman) despised him (Morel) rather for his (Morel) shrinking together, getting smaller. Her (woman) husband at least was manly, and when he (Morel) was beaten gave in. But this other would never own to being beaten. He (Morel) would shift round and round, prowl, get smaller. She (woman) despised him (Morel). And yet she (woman) watched him (Morel) rather than Dawes, and it seemed as if their three fates lay in his (Morel) hands. She (Dawes) hated him (Morel) for it.

She (Dawes) seemed to understand better now about men, and what they could or would do. She (Dawes) was less afraid of them, more sure of herself. That they were not the small egoists she (Dawes) had imagined them made her (Dawes) more comfortable. She (Dawes) had learned a good deal--almost as much as she (Dawes) wanted to learn. Her (Dawes) cup had been full. It was still as full as she (Dawes) could carry. On the whole, she (Dawes) would not be sorry when he (Morel) was gone.

They had dinner, and sat eating nuts and drinking by the fire. Not a serious word had been spoken. Yet Clara realised that Morel was withdrawing from the circle, leaving her (Clara) the option to stay with her (Clara) husband. It angered her (Clara). He (husband) was a mean fellow, after all, to take what he (husband) wanted and then give her (Clara) back. She (Clara) did not remember that she (Clara) herself had had what she (Clara) wanted, and really, at the bottom of her (Clara) heart, wished to be given back.

Paul felt crumpled up and lonely. His (Paul) mother had really supported his (Paul) life. He (Paul) had loved her (mother); they two had, in fact, faced the world together. Now she (mother) was gone, and for ever behind him (Paul) was the gap in life, the tear in the veil, through which his (Paul) life seemed to drift slowly, as if he (Paul) were drawn towards death. He (Paul) wanted someone of their own free initiative to help him (Paul). The lesser things he (Paul) began to let go from him (Paul), for fear of this big thing, the lapse towards death, following in the wake of his (Paul) beloved. Clara could not stand for him (Paul) to hold on to. She (Clara) wanted him (Paul), but not to understand him (Paul). He (Paul) felt she (Clara) wanted the man on top, not the real him (Paul) that was in trouble. That would be too much trouble to her (Clara); he (Paul) dared not give it her (Clara). She (Clara) could not cope with him (Paul). It made him (Paul) ashamed. So, secretly ashamed because he (Paul) was in such a mess, because his (Paul) own hold on life was so unsure, because nobody held him (Paul), feeling unsubstantial, shadowy, as if he (Paul) did not count for much in this concrete world, he (Paul) drew himself together smaller and smaller. He (Paul) did not want to die; he (Paul) would not give in. But he (Paul) was not afraid of death. If nobody would help, he (Paul) would go on alone.

Dawes had been driven to the extremity of life, until he (Paul) was afraid. He (Paul) could go to the brink of death, he (Paul) could lie on the edge and look in. Then, cowed, afraid, he (Paul) had to crawl back, and like a beggar take what offered. There was a certain nobility in it. As Clara saw, he (Paul) owned himself beaten, and he (Paul) wanted to be taken back whether or not. That she (Clara) could do for him (Paul). It was three o'clock.

``I am going by the four-twenty,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Paul again to Clara.
``Are you coming then or later?'' (unknown)

``I don't know,'' (she)
she (Clara) said.

``I'm meeting my father in Nottingham at seven-fifteen,'' (he)
he (Paul) said.

``Then,'' (she)
she (Clara) answered,
``I'll come later.'' (she)

Dawes jerked suddenly, as if he (Paul) had been held on a strain. He (Paul) looked out over the sea, but he (Paul) saw nothing.

``There are one or two books in the corner,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
said Morel.
``I've done with 'em.'' (he)

At about four o'clock he (Morel) went.

``I shall see you both later,'' (he)
he (Morel) said, as he (Morel) shook hands.

``I suppose so,'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.
``An' perhaps--one day--I s'll be able to pay you back the money as--'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)

``I shall come for it, you'll see,'' (Paul/Morel/Paul Morel)
laughed Paul.
``I s'll be on the rocks before I'm very much older.'' (unknown)

``Ay--well--'' (Clara/Dawes/Clara Dawes)
said Dawes.

``Good-bye,'' (he)
he (Paul) said to Clara.

``Good-bye,'' (she)
she (Dawes) said, giving him (Paul) her (Dawes) hand. Then she (Dawes) glanced at him (Paul) for the last time, dumb and humble.

He (Paul) was gone. Dawes and his (Paul) wife sat down again.

``It's a nasty day for travelling,'' (the man)
said the man.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (wife) answered.

They talked in a desultory fashion until it grew dark. The landlady brought in the tea. Dawes drew up his (man) chair to the table without being invited, like a husband. Then he (man) sat humbly waiting for his (man) cup. She (Dawes) served him (man) as she (Dawes) would, like a wife, not consulting his (man) wish.

After tea, as it drew near to six o'clock, he (man) went to the window. All was dark outside. The sea was roaring.

``It's raining yet,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Is it?'' (she)
she (Dawes) answered.

``You won't go to-night, shall you?'' (he)
he (man) said, hesitating.

She (Dawes) did not answer. He (man) waited.

``I shouldn't go in this rain,'' (he)
he (man) said.

``Do you WANT me to stay?'' (she)
she (Dawes) asked.

His (man) hand as he (man) held the dark curtain trembled.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (man) said.

He (man) remained with his (man) back to her (Dawes). She (Dawes) rose and went slowly to him (man). He (man) let go the curtain, turned, hesitating, towards her (Dawes). She (Dawes) stood with her (Dawes) hands behind her (Dawes) back, looking up at him (man) in a heavy, inscrutable fashion.

``Do you want me, Baxter?'' (she)
she (Dawes) asked.

His (man) voice was hoarse as he (man) answered:

``Do you want to come back to me?'' (he)

She (Dawes) made a moaning noise, lifted her (Dawes) arms, and put them round his (man) neck, drawing him (man) to her (Dawes). He (man) hid his (man) face on her (Dawes) shoulder, holding her (Dawes) clasped.

``Take me back!'' (she)
she (Dawes) whispered, ecstatic.
``Take me back, take me back!'' (she)
And she (Dawes) put her (Dawes) fingers through his (man) fine, thin dark hair, as if she (Dawes) were only semi-conscious. He (man) tightened his (man) grasp on her (Dawes).

``Do you want me again?'' (he)
he (man) murmured, broken.

CHAPTER XV

DERELICT

CLARA went with her (Dawes) husband to Sheffield, and Paul scarcely saw her (Dawes) again. Walter Morel seemed to have let all the trouble go over him (Morel), and there he (Morel) was, crawling about on the mud of it, just the same. There was scarcely any bond between father and son, save that each felt he (son) must not let the other go in any actual want. As there was no one to keep on the home, and as they could neither of them bear the emptiness of the house, Paul took lodgings in Nottingham, and Morel went to live with a friendly family in Bestwood.

Everything seemed to have gone smash for the young man. He (man) could not paint. The picture he (man) finished on the day of his (man) mother's death--one that satisfied him (man)--was the last thing he (man) did. At work there was no Clara. When he (man) came home he (man) could not take up his (man) brushes again. There was nothing left.

So he (man) was always in the town at one place or another, drinking, knocking about with the men he (man) knew. It really wearied him (man). He (man) talked to barmaids, to almost any woman, but there was that dark, strained look in his (man) eyes, as if he (man) were hunting something.

Everything seemed so different, so unreal. There seemed no reason why people should go along the street, and houses pile up in the daylight. There seemed no reason why these things should occupy the space, instead of leaving it empty. His (man) friends talked to him (man): he (man) heard the sounds, and he (man) answered. But why there should be the noise of speech he (man) could not understand.

He (man) was most himself when he (man) was alone, or working hard and mechanically at the factory. In the latter case there was pure forgetfulness, when he (man) lapsed from consciousness. But it had to come to an end. It hurt him (man) so, that things had lost their reality. The first snowdrops came. He (man) saw the tiny drop-pearls among the grey. They would have given him (man) the liveliest emotion at one time. Now they were there, but they did not seem to mean anything. In a few moments they would cease to occupy that place, and just the space would be, where they had been. Tall, brilliant tram-cars ran along the street at night. It seemed almost a wonder they should trouble to rustle backwards and forwards.

``Why trouble to go tilting down to Trent Bridges?'' (he)
he (man) asked of the big trams. It seemed they just as well might NOT be as be.

The realest thing was the thick darkness at night. That seemed to him (man) whole and comprehensible and restful. He (man) could leave himself to it. Suddenly a piece of paper started near his (man) feet and blew along down the pavement. He (man) stood still, rigid, with clenched fists, a flame of agony going over him (man). And he (man) saw again the sick-room, his (man) mother, her (mother) eyes. Unconsciously he (man) had been with her (mother), in her (mother) company. The swift hop of the paper reminded him (man) she (mother) was gone. But he (man) had been with her (mother). He (man) wanted everything to stand still, so that he (man) could be with her (mother) again.

The days passed, the weeks. But everything seemed to have fused, gone into a conglomerated mass. He (man) could not tell one day from another, one week from another, hardly one place from another. Nothing was distinct or distinguishable. Often he (man) lost himself for an hour at a time, could not remember what he (man) had done.

One evening he (man) came home late to his (man) lodging. The fire was burning low; everybody was in bed. He (man) threw on some more coal, glanced at the table, and decided he (man) wanted no supper. Then he (man) sat down in the arm-chair. It was perfectly still. He (man) did not know anything, yet he (man) saw the dim smoke wavering up the chimney. Presently two mice came out, cautiously, nibbling the fallen crumbs. He (man) watched them as it were from a long way off. The church clock struck two. Far away he (man) could hear the sharp clinking of the trucks on the railway. No, it was not they that were far away. They were there in their places. But where was he (man) himself?

The time passed. The two mice, careering wildly, scampered cheekily over his (man) slippers. He (man) had not moved a muscle. He (man) did not want to move. He (man) was not thinking of anything. It was easier so. There was no wrench of knowing anything. Then, from time to time, some other consciousness, working mechanically, flashed into sharp phrases.

``What am I doing?'' (unknown)

And out of the semi-intoxicated trance came the answer:

``Destroying myself.'' (him)

Then a dull, live feeling, gone in an instant, told him (man) that it was wrong. After a while, suddenly came the question:

``Why wrong?'' (unknown)

Again there was no answer, but a stroke of hot stubbornness inside his (man) chest resisted his (man) own annihilation.

There was a sound of a heavy cart clanking down the road. Suddenly the electric light went out; there was a bruising thud in the penny-in-the-slot meter. He (man) did not stir, but sat gazing in front of him (man). Only the mice had scuttled, and the fire glowed red in the dark room.

Then, quite mechanically and more distinctly, the conversation began again inside him (man).

``She (me)'s dead. What was it all for--her (me) struggle?'' (her)

That was his (man) despair wanting to go after her (man).

``You're alive.'' (unknown)

``She (me)'s not.'' (unknown)

``She (me) is--in you.'' (he)

Suddenly he (man) felt tired with the burden of it.

``You've got to keep alive for her (me) sake,'' (him)
said his (man) will in him (man).

Something felt sulky, as if it would not rouse.

``You've got to carry forward her (me) living, and what she (me) had done, go on with it.'' (he)

But he (man) did not want to. He (man) wanted to give up.

``But you can go on with your painting,'' (him)
said the will in him (man).
``Or else you can beget children. They both carry on her (me) effort.'' (unknown)

``Painting is not living.'' (unknown)

``Then live.'' (unknown)

``Marry whom?'' (unknown)
came the sulky question.

``As best you can.'' (unknown)

``Miriam?'' (he)

But he (man) did not trust that.

He (man) rose suddenly, went straight to bed. When he (man) got inside his (man) bedroom and closed the door, he (man) stood with clenched fist.

``Mater, my dear--'' (he)
he (man) began, with the whole force of his (man) soul. Then he (man) stopped. He (man) would not say it. He (man) would not admit that he (man) wanted to die, to have done. He (man) would not own that life had beaten him (man), or that death had beaten him (man). Going straight to bed, he (man) slept at once, abandoning himself to the sleep.

So the weeks went on. Always alone, his (man) soul oscillated, first on the side of death, then on the side of life, doggedly. The real agony was that he (man) had nowhere to go, nothing to do, nothing to say, and WAS nothing himself. Sometimes he (man) ran down the streets as if he (man) were mad: sometimes he (man) was mad; things weren't there, things were there. It made him (man) pant. Sometimes he (man) stood before the bar of the public-house where he (man) called for a drink. Everything suddenly stood back away from him (man). He (man) saw the face of the barmaid, the gobbling drinkers, his (man) own glass on the slopped, mahogany board, in the distance. There was something between him (man) and them. He (man) could not get into touch. He (man) did not want them; he (man) did not want his (man) drink. Turning abruptly, he (man) went out. On the threshold he (man) stood and looked at the lighted street. But he (man) was not of it or in it. Something separated him (man). Everything went on there below those lamps, shut away from him (man). He (man) could not get at them. He (He) felt he (he) couldn't touch the lamp-posts, not if he (his) reached. Where could he (he) go? There was nowhere to go, neither back into the inn, or forward anywhere. He (he) felt stifled. There was nowhere for him (he). The stress grew inside him (his); he (he) felt he (he) should smash.

``I mustn't,'' (he)
he (He) said; and, turning blindly, he (his) went in and drank. Sometimes the drink did him (he) good; sometimes it made him (His) worse. He (he) ran down the road. For ever restless, he (he) went here, there, everywhere. He (he) determined to work. But when he (He) had made six strokes, he (he) loathed the pencil violently, got up, and went away, hurried off to a club where he (he) could play cards or billiards, to a place where he (him) could flirt with a barmaid who was no more to him (He) than the brass pump-handle she (barmaid) drew.

He (him) was very thin and lantern-jawed. He (he) dared not meet his (him) own eyes in the mirror; he (He) never looked at himself. He (his) wanted to get away from himself, but there was nothing to get hold of. In despair he (He) thought of Miriam. Perhaps--perhaps--?

Then, happening to go into the Unitarian Church one Sunday evening, when they stood up to sing the second hymn he (him) saw her (Miriam) before him (he). The light glistened on her (Miriam) lower lip as she (Miriam) sang. She (Miriam) looked as if she (Miriam) had got something, at any rate: some hope in heaven, if not in earth. Her (Miriam) comfort and her (Miriam) life seemed in the after-world. A warm, strong feeling for her (Miriam) came up. She (Miriam) seemed to yearn, as she (Miriam) sang, for the mystery and comfort. He (lip) put his (lip) hope in her (Miriam). He (lip) longed for the sermon to be over, to speak to her (Miriam).

The throng carried her (Miriam) out just before him (lip). He (lip) could nearly touch her (Miriam). She (Miriam) did not know he (lip) was there. He (lip) saw the brown, humble nape of her (Miriam) neck under its black curls. He (lip) would leave himself to her (Miriam). She (Miriam) was better and bigger than he (lip). He (lip) would depend on her (Miriam).

She (Miriam) went wandering, in her (Miriam) blind way, through the little throngs of people outside the church. She (Miriam) always looked so lost and out of place among people. He (lip) went forward and put his (lip) hand on her (Miriam) arm. She (Miriam) started violently. Her (Miriam) great brown eyes dilated in fear, then went questioning at the sight of him (lip). He (lip) shrank slightly from her (Miriam).

``I didn't know--'' (she)
she (Miriam) faltered.

``Nor I,'' (he)
he (lip) said.

He (lip) looked away. His (lip) sudden, flaring hope sank again.

``What are you doing in town?'' (he)
he (lip) asked.

``I'm staying at Cousin Anne's.'' (unknown)

``Ha! For long?'' (unknown)

``No; only till to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``Must you go straight home?'' (She)

She (Miriam) looked at him (lip), then hid her (Miriam) face under her (Miriam) hat-brim.

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said--
``no; it's not necessary.'' (she)

He (lip) turned away, and she (Miriam) went with him (lip). They threaded through the throng of church people. The organ was still sounding in St. Mary's. Dark figures came through the lighted doors; people were coming down the steps. The large coloured windows glowed up in the night. The church was like a great lantern suspended. They went down Hollow Stone, and he (lip) took the car for the Bridges.

``You will just have supper with me,'' (he)
he (lip) said:
``then I'll bring you back.'' (he)

``Very well,'' (she)
she (Mary) replied, low and husky.

They scarcely spoke while they were on the car. The Trent ran dark and full under the bridge. Away towards Colwick all was black night. He (Trent) lived down Holme Road, on the naked edge of the town, facing across the river meadows towards Sneinton Hermitage and the steep scrap of Colwick Wood. The floods were out. The silent water and the darkness spread away on their left. Almost afraid, they hurried along by the houses.

Supper was laid. He (Wood) swung the curtain over the window. There was a bowl of freesias and scarlet anemones on the table. She (Wood) bent to them. Still touching them with her (Wood) finger-tips, she (Wood) looked up at him (Wood), saying:

``Aren't they beautiful?'' (him)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Wood) said.
``What will you drink--coffee?'' (unknown)

``I should like it,'' (she)
she (Wood) said.

``Then excuse me a moment.'' (He)

He (Wood) went out to the kitchen.

Miriam took off her (Miriam) things and looked round. It was a bare, severe room. Her (Miriam) photo, Clara's, Annie's, were on the wall. She (Miriam) looked on the drawing-board to see what he (Wood) was doing. There were only a few meaningless lines. She (Miriam) looked to see what books he (Wood) was reading. Evidently just an ordinary novel. The letters in the rack she (Miriam) saw were from Annie, Arthur, and from some man or other she (Miriam) did not know. Everything he (Arthur) had touched, everything that was in the least personal to him (Arthur), she (Miriam) examined with lingering absorption. He (Arthur) had been gone from her (Miriam) for so long, she (Miriam) wanted to rediscover him (Arthur), his (Arthur) position, what he (Arthur) was now. But there was not much in the room to help her (Miriam). It only made her (Miriam) feel rather sad, it was so hard and comfortless.

She (Miriam) was curiously examining a sketch-book when he (Arthur) returned with the coffee.

``There's nothing new in it,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said,
``and nothing very interesting.'' (he)

He (Arthur) put down the tray, and went to look over her (Miriam) shoulder. She (Miriam) turned the pages slowly, intent on examining everything.

``H'm!'' (he)
he (Arthur) said, as she (Miriam) paused at a sketch.
``I'd forgotten that. It's not bad, is it?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said.
``I don't quite understand it.'' (He)

He (Arthur) took the book from her (Miriam) and went through it. Again he (Arthur) made a curious sound of surprise and pleasure.

``There's some not bad stuff in there,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said.

``Not at all bad,'' (she)
she (Miriam) answered gravely.

He (Arthur) felt again her (Miriam) interest in his (Arthur) work. Or was it for himself? Why was she (Miriam) always most interested in him (Arthur) as he (Arthur) appeared in his (Arthur) work?

They sat down to supper.

``By the way,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said,
``didn't I hear something about your earning your own living?'' (he)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Miriam) replied, bowing her (Miriam) dark head over her (Miriam) cup.
``And what of it?'' (unknown)

``I'm merely going to the farming college at Broughton for three months, and I shall probably be kept on as a teacher there.'' (unknown)

``I say--that sounds all right for you! You always wanted to be independent.'' (unknown)

``Yes.

``Why didn't you tell me?'' (unknown)

``I only knew last week.'' (unknown)

``But I heard a month ago,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said.

``Yes; but nothing was settled then.'' (unknown)

``I should have thought,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said,
``you'd have told me you were trying.'' (he)

She (Miriam) ate her (Miriam) food in the deliberate, constrained way, almost as if she (Miriam) recoiled a little from doing anything so publicly, that he (Arthur) knew so well.

``I suppose you're glad,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said.

``Very glad.'' (unknown)

``Yes--it will be something.'' (He)

He (Arthur) was rather disappointed.

``I think it will be a great deal,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, almost haughtily, resentfully.

He (Arthur) laughed shortly.

``Why do you think it won't?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Oh, I don't think it won't be a great deal. Only you'll find earning your own living isn't everything.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said, swallowing with difficulty;
``I don't suppose it is.'' (she)

``I suppose work CAN be nearly everything to a man,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said,
``though it isn't to me. But a woman only works with a part of herself. The real and vital part is covered up.'' (he)

``But a man can give ALL himself to work?'' (she)
she (Miriam) asked.

``Yes, practically.'' (unknown)

``And a woman only the unimportant part of herself?'' (unknown)

``That's it.'' (She)

She (Miriam) looked up at him (Arthur), and her (Miriam) eyes dilated with anger.

``Then,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said,
``if it's true, it's a great shame.'' (she)

``It is. But I don't know everything,'' (he)
he (Arthur) answered.

After supper they drew up to the fire. He (Arthur) swung her (Miriam) a chair facing him (Arthur), and they sat down. She (Miriam) was wearing a dress of dark claret colour, that suited her (Miriam) dark complexion and her (Miriam) large features. Still, the curls were fine and free, but her (Miriam) face was much older, the brown throat much thinner. She (Miriam) seemed old to him (Arthur), older than Clara. Her (Clara) bloom of youth had quickly gone. A sort of stiffness, almost of woodenness, had come upon her (Clara). She (Clara) meditated a little while, then looked at him (Arthur).

``And how are things with you?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``About all right,'' (he)
he (Arthur) answered.

She (Clara) looked at him (Arthur), waiting.

``Nay,'' (she)
she (Clara) said, very low.

Her (Clara) brown, nervous hands were clasped over her (Clara) knee. They had still the lack of confidence or repose, the almost hysterical look. He (Arthur) winced as he (Arthur) saw them. Then he (Arthur) laughed mirthlessly. She (Clara) put her (Clara) fingers between her (Clara) lips. His (Arthur) slim, black, tortured body lay quite still in the chair. She (Clara) suddenly took her (Clara) finger from her (Clara) mouth and looked at him (Arthur).

``And you have broken off with Clara?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

His (Arthur) body lay like an abandoned thing, strewn in the chair.

``You know,'' (she)
she (Clara) said,
``I think we ought to be married.'' (she)

He (Arthur) opened his (Arthur) eyes for the first time since many months, and attended to her (Clara) with respect.

``Why?'' (he)
he (Arthur) said.

``See,'' (she)
she (Clara) said,
``how you waste yourself! You might be ill, you might die, and I never know--be no more then than if I had never known you.'' (she)

``And if we married?'' (he)
he (Arthur) asked.

``At any rate, I could prevent you wasting yourself and being a prey to other women--like--like Clara.'' (unknown)

``A prey?'' (he)
he (Arthur) repeated, smiling.

She (Clara) bowed her (Clara) head in silence. He (Arthur) lay feeling his (Arthur) despair come up again.

``I'm not sure,'' (he)
he (Arthur) said slowly,
``that marriage would be much good.'' (he)

``I only think of you,'' (she)
she (Clara) replied.

``I know you do. But--you love me so much, you want to put me in your pocket. And I should die there smothered.'' (She)

She (Clara) bent her (Clara) head, put her (Clara) fingers between her (Clara) lips, while the bitterness surged up in her (Clara) heart.

``And what will you do otherwise?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked.

``I don't know--go on, I suppose. Perhaps I shall soon go abroad.'' (him)

The despairing doggedness in his (Arthur) tone made her (Clara) go on her (Clara) knees on the rug before the fire, very near to him (Arthur). There she (Clara) crouched as if she (Clara) were crushed by something, and could not raise her (Clara) head. His (Arthur) hands lay quite inert on the arms of his (Arthur) chair. She (Clara) was aware of them. She (Clara) felt that now he (Arthur) lay at her (Clara) mercy. If she (Clara) could rise, take him (Arthur), put her (Clara) arms round him (Arthur), and say,

``You are mine,'' (him)
then he (Arthur) would leave himself to her (Clara). But dare she (Clara)? She (Clara) could easily sacrifice herself. But dare she (Clara) assert herself? She (Clara) was aware of his (Arthur) dark-clothed, slender body, that seemed one stroke of life, sprawled in the chair close to her (Clara). But no; she (Clara) dared not put her (Clara) arms round it, take it up, and say,
``It is mine, this body. Leave it to me.'' (she)
And she (Clara) wanted to. It called to all her (Clara) woman's instinct. But she (Clara) crouched, and dared not. She (Clara) was afraid he (Arthur) would not let her (Clara). She (Clara) was afraid it was too much. It lay there, his (Arthur) body, abandoned. She (Clara) knew she (Clara) ought to take it up and claim it, and claim every right to it. But--could she (Clara) do it? Her (Clara) impotence before him (Arthur), before the strong demand of some unknown thing in him (Arthur), was her (Clara) extremity. Her (Clara) hands fluttered; she (Clara) half-lifted her (Clara) head. Her (Clara) eyes, shuddering, appealing, gone, almost distracted, pleaded to him (Arthur) suddenly. His (Arthur) heart caught with pity. He (Arthur) took her (Clara) hands, drew her (Clara) to him (Arthur), and comforted her (Clara).

``Will you have me, to marry me?'' (he)
he (Arthur) said very low.

Oh, why did not he (Arthur) take her (Clara)? Her (Clara) very soul belonged to him (Arthur). Why would he (Arthur) not take what was his (Arthur)? She (Clara) had borne so long the cruelty of belonging to him (Arthur) and not being claimed by him (Arthur). Now he (Arthur) was straining her (Clara) again. It was too much for her (Clara). She (Clara) drew back her (Clara) head, held his (Arthur) face between her (Clara) hands, and looked him (Arthur) in the eyes. No, he (Arthur) was hard. He (Arthur) wanted something else. She (Clara) pleaded to him (Arthur) with all her (Clara) love not to make it her (Clara) choice. She (Clara) could not cope with it, with him (Arthur), she (Clara) knew not with what. But it strained her (Clara) till she (Clara) felt she (Clara) would break.

``Do you want it?'' (she)
she (Clara) asked, very gravely.

``Not much,'' (he)
he (Arthur) replied, with pain.

She (Clara) turned her (Clara) face aside; then, raising herself with dignity, she (Clara) took his (Arthur) head to her (Clara) bosom, and rocked him (Arthur) softly. She (Clara) was not to have him (Arthur), then! So she (Clara) could comfort him (Arthur). She (Clara) put her (Clara) fingers through his (Arthur) hair. For her (Clara), the anguished sweetness of self-sacrifice. For him (Arthur), the hate and misery of another failure. He (Arthur) could not bear it--that breast which was warm and which cradled him (Arthur) without taking the burden of him (Arthur). So much he (Arthur) wanted to rest on her (Clara) that the feint of rest only tortured him (Arthur). He (Arthur) drew away.

``And without marriage we can do nothing?'' (he)
he (Arthur) asked.

His (Arthur) mouth was lifted from his (Arthur) teeth with pain. She (Clara) put her (Clara) little finger between her (Clara) lips.

``No,'' (she)
she (Clara) said, low and like the toll of a bell.
``No, I think not.'' (unknown)

It was the end then between them. She (Clara) could not take him (Arthur) and relieve him (Arthur) of the responsibility of himself. She (Clara) could only sacrifice herself to him (Arthur)--sacrifice herself every day, gladly. And that he (Arthur) did not want. He (Arthur) wanted her (Clara) to hold him (Arthur) and say, with joy and authority:

``Stop all this restlessness and beating against death. You are mine for a mate.'' (him)
She (Clara) had not the strength. Or was it a mate she (Clara) wanted? or did she (Clara) want a Christ in him (Christ)?

He (Christ) felt, in leaving her (Clara), he (Christ) was defrauding her (Clara) of life. But he (Christ) knew that, in staying, stilling the inner, desperate man, he (Christ) was denying his (Christ) own life. And he (Christ) did not hope to give life to her (Clara) by denying his (Christ) own.

She (Clara) sat very quiet. He (Christ) lit a cigarette. The smoke went up from it, wavering. He (Christ) was thinking of his (Christ) mother, and had forgotten Miriam. She (Miriam) suddenly looked at him (Christ). Her (Miriam) bitterness came surging up. Her (Miriam) sacrifice, then, was useless. He (Christ) lay there aloof, careless about her (Miriam). Suddenly she (Miriam) saw again his (Christ) lack of religion, his (Christ) restless instability. He (Christ) would destroy himself like a perverse child. Well, then, he (Christ) would!

``I think I must go,'' (she)
she (Miriam) said softly.

By her (Miriam) tone he (Christ) knew she (Miriam) was despising him (Christ). He (Christ) rose quietly.

``I'll come along with you,'' (he)
he (Christ) answered.

She (Miriam) stood before the mirror pinning on her (Miriam) hat. How bitter, how unutterably bitter, it made her (Miriam) that he (Christ) rejected her (Miriam) sacrifice! Life ahead looked dead, as if the glow were gone out. She (Miriam) bowed her (Miriam) face over the flowers--the freesias so sweet and spring-like, the scarlet anemones flaunting over the table. It was like him (Christ) to have those flowers.

He (Christ) moved about the room with a certain sureness of touch, swift and relentless and quiet. She (Miriam) knew she (Miriam) could not cope with him (Christ). He (Christ) would escape like a weasel out of her (Miriam) hands. Yet without him (Christ) her (Miriam) life would trail on lifeless. Brooding, she (Miriam) touched the flowers.

``Have them!'' (he)
he (Christ) said; and he (Christ) took them out of the jar, dripping as they were, and went quickly into the kitchen. She (Miriam) waited for him (Christ), took the flowers, and they went out together, he (Christ) talking, she (Miriam) feeling dead.

She (Miriam) was going from him (Christ) now. In her (Miriam) misery she (Miriam) leaned against him (Christ) as they sat on the car. He (Christ) was unresponsive. Where would he (Christ) go? What would be the end of him (Christ)? She (Miriam) could not bear it, the vacant feeling where he (Christ) should be. He (Christ) was so foolish, so wasteful, never at peace with himself. And now where would he (Christ) go? And what did he (Christ) care that he (Christ) wasted her (Miriam)? He (Christ) had no religion; it was all for the moment's attraction that he (Christ) cared, nothing else, nothing deeper. Well, she (Miriam) would wait and see how it turned out with him (Christ). When he (Christ) had had enough he (Christ) would give in and come to her (Miriam).

He (Christ) shook hands and left her (Miriam) at the door of her (Miriam) cousin's house. When he (Christ) turned away he (Christ) felt the last hold for him (Christ) had gone. The town, as he (Christ) sat upon the car, stretched away over the bay of railway, a level fume of lights. Beyond the town the country, little smouldering spots for more towns--the sea--the night--on and on! And he (Christ) had no place in it! Whatever spot he (Christ) stood on, there he (Christ) stood alone. From his (Christ) breast, from his (Christ) mouth, sprang the endless space, and it was there behind him (Christ), everywhere. The people hurrying along the streets offered no obstruction to the void in which he (Christ) found himself. They were small shadows whose footsteps and voices could be heard, but in each of them the same night, the same silence. He (Christ) got off the car. In the country all was dead still. Little stars shone high up; little stars spread far away in the flood-waters, a firmament below. Everywhere the vastness and terror of the immense night which is roused and stirred for a brief while by the day, but which returns, and will remain at last eternal, holding everything in its silence and its living gloom. There was no Time, only Space. Who could say his (Christ) mother had lived and did not live? She (mother) had been in one place, and was in another; that was all. And his (Christ) soul could not leave her (mother), wherever she (mother) was. Now she (mother) was gone abroad into the night, and he (Christ) was with her (mother) still. They were together. But yet there was his (Christ) body, his (Christ) chest, that leaned against the stile, his (Christ) hands on the wooden bar. They seemed something. Where was he (Christ)?--one tiny upright speck of flesh, less than an ear of wheat lost in the field. He (Christ) could not bear it. On every side the immense dark silence seemed pressing him (Christ), so tiny a spark, into extinction, and yet, almost nothing, he (Christ) could not be extinct. Night, in which everything was lost, went reaching out, beyond stars and sun. Stars and sun, a few bright grains, went spinning round for terror, and holding each other in embrace, there in a darkness that outpassed them all, and left them tiny and daunted. So much, and himself, infinitesimal, at the core a nothingness, and yet not nothing.

``Mother!'' (he)
he (Christ) whispered--
``mother!'' (he)

She (them) was the only thing that held him (Christ) up, himself, amid all this. And she (them) was gone, intermingled herself. He (Christ) wanted her (them) to touch him (Christ), have him (Christ) alongside with her (them).

But no, he (Christ) would not give in. Turning sharply, he (Christ) walked towards the city's gold phosphorescence. His (Christ) fists were shut, his (Christ) mouth set fast. He (Christ) would not take that direction, to the darkness, to follow her (them). He (Christ) walked towards the faintly humming, glowing town, quickly.

THE END

End of Project Gutenberg's Sons and Lovers, by David Herbert Lawrence
